And a more than slightly unlikely, but attractive, supporting cast of friendly Theosophical Druids, Victorian-style Ancient Britons ("By Lud of Lunden!"), and proto-Vikings? Or even the rather Hinduized Pythagoreanism that seems to underlie all the talk of Secret Wisdom? By this time, too, Mundy's mostly hostile portrait of Caesar could be seen as a foreshadowing of Fascism."Tros" was revived in complete hardcover editions by the science fiction and fantasy publisher Gnome Press in 1958 (along with "The Purple Pirate"), and, most recently by Buccaneer Books in 1995. The trade paperback edition of "Tros" from Black Mask was issued in 2005, and was more than welcome. (There was another hardcover -- I think -- reprinting of "The Purple Pirate." from Amereon, in 1991.)There was also a mass-market paperback version of the whole saga, in six volumes, published in the later 1960s (see below for details), and for me they came at just the right time -- I was reading Caesar in Latin, and was amused when Tros gave him a concise, accurate, and completely misleading, report on his adventures in Britain, in exactly Caesar's own compressed style. And was praised for it.Oh yes -- don't be confused about Mundy's novel "Caesar Dies." It is an unrelated story about the Emperor Commodus, not the Dictator Julius, and Tros isn't involved. (Unless I failed to notice his reincarnation, of course.)"The Complete Tros of Samothrace" bundles together all of this material (except, of course, "Caesar Dies"). If you have a Kindle, or a Kindle app on your PC or Mac (etc., etc.), and think this sounds interesting, treat yourself.Those are the main points. For those who might go looking for print copies, however, I've included some essential bibliographic information in my review of the Black Mask edition of "Tros.". There are some unpleasant surprises awaiting the unwary. Unfortunately, print copies, especially of "Tros," have to be sorted out from among the fractionalized paperback reprints. For the mass-market paperback editions present a much more complicated picture. (One which also impinges on one of the Kindle editions.) There are a couple of points which may be relevant in this context, however.Perhaps vindicating Bobbs-Merrill's original proposal, "Queen Cleopatra" appeared from Ace in 1962, with a cover Gault describes as "obviously redrawn from a publicity still of Elizabeth Taylor." Beyond the desire to cash in on the publicity, there is no special connection between the book and the motion picture (ultimately released in 1963), let alone the associated scandals; just the use of some of the same historical personages. (Lud, and perhaps fear of lawsuits, be thanked, Burton wasn't added to the cover.)In 1967, Avon Books put "Tros of Samothrace" into paperback in four volumes, as "Tros: The First Book of Tros of Samothrace" (= #1-2); "Helma: The Second Book..." (= #3-4); "Liafail: The Third Book..." (#5-6); and "Helene: The Fourth Book..." (#7-9). All of them had lovely covers by Douglas Rosa. ("Helma" and "Helene" are two of the women in Tros' life. "Liafail," the Irish "Stone of Destiny," is here the name of a ship. Not the most appropriate name, one would think, besides being from the wrong branch of the Celtic languages, but philology wasn't Mundy's strong point.)The four volumes were followed by Avon in 1969 with "Queen Cleopatra" and in 1970 with "The Purple Pirate," identified as "Tros of Samothrace #5" and "...#6," respectively, on the uncredited covers (which look to me and others like the work of Jeff Jones, but seem to be attributed by some to Frank Frazetta.)Avon also issued some of Mundy's occult / espionage / adventure stories set in modern India and Tibet, including "Om," at about the same time -- another tangle of titles we won't get into.There is also a recent complete edition of the "Tros" series, published in 2009 in the UK and United States US: Leonaur Books, paperback & hardback as 6 books, corresponding to the Avon divisions, which were Mundy's own: Wolves of the Tiber; Dragons of the North; Serpent of the Waves; City of the Eagles; Queen Cleopatra; Purple Pirate. (I don't know where the NEW titles came from, but they are excellent.) These titles are listed as alternates to the Avon titles in the Amazon description of the Pulptastic "Complete Tros," but that edition actually uses the Avon titles to mark "Books" of "Tros." This despite the fact that Pulptastic also issued separate Kindle editions of each of these titles!Interestingly It is the Avon editions, with their one-name titles, which are referenced in the four divisions of the Kindle "Tros" in the Table of Contents of both the singleton amd "The Complete ... Series" versions.

First off, "Chapman's Homer" is probably not a book for those who have not read Homer before. In fact, it is probably not a book for those unfamiliar with Shakespeare's plays; or, perhaps better, Spenser's Elizabethan Epic, "The Faerie Queene". These will introduce one to the high poetic language of the era; and Spenser to the finding of moral and political significations in events and characters.It is likely to be fascinating to anyone who is interested in the "reception" of Homer over the centuries, and the different guises translators have given him. They will probably welcome this complete, neatly printed, digital edition.At a rough guess, something like 95% of the people who recognize the term "Chapman's Homer" at all will do so in association with Keats' 1816 sonnet, "On first looking into Chapman's Homer." Some large proportion of them probably would, if asked, further associate the translation with the Romantic Movement. Others, who perhaps have a better memory for such things, will recall that belongs to the seventeenth century, specifically the early Jacobean period, not long after the death of Elizabeth I.It was in fact the work of the sometime-playwright George Chapman (1560-1634), who was a fairly successful dramatist in a time when William Shakespeare and Ben Jonson were busy producing works of lasting interest. Chapman eventually left the theater, which was not as lucrative for him as for Shakespeare (who was also a partner in his own theater company, and one of its actors).He became, among other things, a translator from Greek, publishing what are regarded as the first-ever English versions of "The Iliad" and "The Odyssey" in installments from 1611-1615.It was almost exactly 200 years later that Keats, who certainly would have known the eighteenth-century Alexander Pope version in "heroic couplets," seems to have stumbled across copies of Chapman. As he wrote "Oft of one wide expanse, had I been told / That deep-brow'd Homer ruled as his demesne: / Yet did I never breathe its pure serene / Till I heard Chapman speak out loud and bold".Anyone who expects from such praise that Chapman's translations are a long-lost treasure of English literature are probably going to be disappointed. They are extremely interesting, and lack the veneer of classicism and dignity applied by Pope (1715, 1725), and others. However, some of the vocabulary is simply obsolete (this edition includes a glossary, which helps, although it is not properly linked to the text). The meter, to the surprise of many (I would think) is not iambic pentameter, since Milton an accepted "epic meter" for English. This is perhaps just as well, since Chapman used rhymed couplets, and would have found himself in the same strait-jacket as so many English Augustans (leaving aside, for the moment, Dryden and Pope, who seemed to find it roomy enough).No, Chapman used the well-established "fourteener," in rhyming couplets; an old narrative meter (it had been used in the sixteenth-century Scots English translation of the "Aeneid" by Gavin Douglas) which eventually fell out of favor for serious verse. The "fourteener" never completed faded away; the Victorian poet (and fantasy novelist, and interior designer, and fine printer, and business-man and socialist, etc.) William Morris, used it for, among other things, his epic poem "Sigurd the Volsung," and his own translation of the "Aeneid."Still, being unfamiliar to many potential readers, it is a meter which almost demands initial reading aloud, to find the rhythm, and with it the syntax of many lines. The fourteen (sometimes fifteen) syllables tend to produce a caesura (pause) about half-way through the line (seven-seven, eight-six, six-eight).This isn't a great substitute for the Homeric hexameter, but it does allow a more fluid style than some of the alternatives.What Keats seemed to have missed in his enthusiasm is that Chapman had "bought" the general Renaissance belief that Homer was a subtle allegorist, not just a story-teller. However, Renaissance allegories sometimes seem to be about anything the text suggests; unlike the Augustan reading of the "Odyssey" as a series of moral exempla, with the wily Ulysses (their preferred form) somehow turning into a (more) priggish version of Aeneas.On the whole, the translation can be read without wading into the "deeper meanings." For those looking for Chapman's "key" to the "real" Homer, it has been the subject of modern studies, including "Homeric Renaissance: The Odyssey of George Chapman," by George de Forest Lord (1956). Copies are sometimes available through Amazon, and elsewhere.For those who are curious about where Chapman belongs (other than at the beginning) in the long history of Homer translations in English (and don't mind having just his "Iliad" in the package) can try starting with the Delphi Ancient Classics Kindle omnibus, "Complete Works of Homer" (Illustrated). This includes, with a great deal more, Greek texts, and the Alexander Pope translation mentioned above.

This intriguing little volume, first published in 1921 (and at this writing available from Amazon in three paperback editions as well as the present, Gutenberg Project-based Kindle edition) contains a set of stories in prose, in some cases with included verses, written in later medieval Iceland, and a corresponding set of verse renditions of the same story material, from, variously, Iceland itself, the Faroe and Shetland Islands, and Denmark. Nora Kershaw, the translator, is also known as Nora K. Chadwick, having married another scholar, H.M. Chadwick, somewhat later (1922) in her long (d. 1972) career -- see Wikipedia for a short biographical sketch.Some of the the tales have clear connections to late antiquity, when Goths and Huns chased each other around Europe: hence the title of "Stories and Ballads of the *Far* Past." The versions of the stories are later medieval, at the earliest. Any close knowledge of the Migration Age/Fall of the Roman Empire could be an  unwanted distraction, however. The storytellers don't seem to have known any of that history, and probably wouldn't have cared if they did. (Such knowledge wasn't completely unavailable --- Chaucer knew that, whatever Norse or Germans told about Atli or Etzel, the real Attila died "bleeding at the nose" while drunk.)The prose works partake of the realism of style and incident characteristic of the major Icelandic sagas, such as the great "Njal's Saga," but the narratives are clearly intended to be entertainments, and extravagant ones at that, with a few "moral lessons" sneaking their way in as plot-points. (In one, a character stops to remark that he is making a point of violating some good advice....)Some of the stories had been translated before, and some would be again.There are two short tales (the term in "Thattr"), "The Thattr of Nornagest" and "The Thattr of Srli." The former recounts, with a slightly comic edge, stories of legendary heroes, their narrator being a very long-lived survivor who wants to give testimony to the pagan past before dying as a Christian. It is funnier if you know the stories before-hand, but still funny if you don't."The Thattr of Srli" is a romanticized Icelandic version of parts of a story known from other sources, notably the German "Kudrun" epic. The story of how Odin contrived an "Everlasting Battle" on earth (instead of in Valhalla) is joined to some very old character-names from the pre-Viking Age Baltic -- J.R.R. Tolkien was interested in some of the other variants. William Morris and Eirikur Magnussson had already translated the tale as a supplement to their "Three Northern Love Stories.""The Saga of Hromund Greipsson" is supposed to be about a known continental ancestor of an Icelandic family, but the story is filled with magicians, spells, and curses, and the titular hero is a strong-man whose main virtue seems to be a capacity for violence. Not that he is always unjustified -- far from it -- but he escapes being viewed as a thug largely by the lightheartedness of the sometimes over-the-top telling.The centerpiece is a grand heroic saga, based on traditions from the Germanic Migration Age, "The Saga of Hervr and Heithrek," although these follow, rather than precede, adventures clearly inspired by the Viking Age. "The Waking of Angantyr," in which one of the heroines calls on her dead father and uncles to deliver to her a (cursed) heirloom sword has been known in English since the eighteenth century. This episode, and the cursed sword itself, Tyrfing, later inspired Poul Anderson's superb fantasy novel "The Broken Sword,"Another poem from the saga which has attracted attention from scholars has been "The Battle of the Goths and Huns," which includes names which, phonologically, have to go back to when the Goths were living in the shadow of the Carpathian mountains. The names are about the limit of the stories historicity, though. For example, the sword-name "Tyrfing," whatever its actual etymology, has been hopelessly confused with "Tervingi," a name for a division of the Gothic "nation." "Battle of the Goths and Huns" also appears, facing the Old Norse text, in Nora Kershaw's "Anglo-Saxon and Norse Poems" (also 1922). There are Kindle and print editions, sometimes attributed to Nora Kershaw Chadwick, and at least once listed as "anonymous." A pdf version is available from the Library of Congress's Internet Archive site.English translations of the poems in the saga can also be found, with much else, in Lee M. Hollander's "Old Norse Poems" (1936), currently available as a Kindle book.An edition and translation of the saga, from a somewhat different textual base, was published in 1960 as "The Saga of King Heidrek the Wise," the work of Christopher Tolkien. The complicated manuscript bases of what is often known as "Hervarar saga" caused both translators to include appendices with variant prose passages, and extra verses. Christopher Tolkien's rendering is now available, free, as a pdf through the Web Publications page of the Viking Society for Northern Research, so comparing the two translations is now easy (instead of being dependent on a library with extensive holdings). For the dedicated (or very curious) student, The Viking Society also offers "Hervarar saga ok Heireks," ed. G. Turville-Petre (1956). It uses the same base text as Chadwick's translation, but includes English-language Notes, Glossary, and Index of Names.The verse section of "Stories and Ballads" opens with an Icelandic rhymed verse recounting of some of "Hromund Greipson," followed by "The Faroese Ballad of Nornagest." The remaining ballads mainly derive from the "Hervor and Heidrek" traditions: the Faroese "Ballad of Hjalmer and Angantyr" and the Danish "Ballad of Angelfyr and Helmer," and the Faroese "Ballad of Arngrim's Sons," followed by "The Faroese Riddle Ballad." "The Faroese Ballad of Hildina," the final piece is the book, is related to the "Thattr of Srli." I find these pieces, at least in Chadwick's translations, to be most interesting as examples of popular tradition re-working older material, but some may find them just as entertaining as the prose works, and possibly more entertaining.

I have given this edition a two-star rating based a little on the confusing table of contents -- which suggests a lack of attention throughout -- and the lack of notice that this is NOT a new (2013) translation, but a rather old one: and also on the confusing choice of title-- on this factor, see near the end of the review for competing editions. (I prefer to review only editions I've read, but I've been familiar with the translation used here since the late 1960s, have digital copies, and feel no urgent need to acquire a print edition.)Snorri Sturluson, the author, (1179-1241) was an Icelandic poet and politician, whose entanglement in Norway's internal politics, and the king's desire to acquire Iceland, was the main cause of his murder. He is best known, however, for two books attributed to him on period authority. One is known as "Heimskringla," and is a compilation of biographies of the Kings of Norway, going back to their ancestors in mythological and legendary times, and stopping short safely before his own time.The other is the present book, "Edda," a series of treatises, variously amusing or tedious, on traditional Icelandic high-class poetry. A large part of it is given over to stories of the ancient gods and heroes, whose characteristics and careers were the point of departure for Iceland's high-class poets, the Skalds. (There were once skalds from mainland Scandinavia, but the complex art seems to have died out there following Christianization, while it hung on in deeply conservative Iceland, becoming its main "invisible export".)This latter is the book with which we are now concerned.The work is also known, variously, as "Snorri's Edda," "Snorri Sturluson's Edda," "The Younger Edda," and "The Prose Edda." These names were introduced to distinguish it from a collection of mythological and heroic poetry which early modern scholars, for no solid reason, dubbed "Saemund's Edda," after a mistaken attribution; it is now referred to as the "Poetic" or "Elder Edda."(Some scholars also have attributed to Snorri a third work, "The Saga of Egil Skallagrimson," a brilliant piece of work. I am one of those who remain unconvinced, but would like it to be true.)Rasmus B. Anderson (1846-1936), the translator, was a pioneer in introducing Scandinavian culture to English-speaking Americans -- as distinguished from their British counterparts. He was a moving force behind the Norraena Society, with its Norraena Library (1905-1907), the full fifteen-volume set of which is said to have been the largest collection of medieval Scandinavian literature (and some studies) published outside Scandinavia up to that time. It was made up primarily of nineteenth-centuries translations. Many large libraries contain more or less complete sets; at one time or another I have read at least eight of the volumes, and substantially more in their older editions. (There is a handy summary in Wikipedia's article on the Norraena Society, to which I direct the curious; it includes information on what is sometimes considered the sixteenth volume, which I have never seen.)The Norraena Library did not include Anderson's own 1880 translation of "The Younger Edda" (this choice of title), a reprint of which we are offered in this book (again, despite the present edition's date of 2013). It is not the worst of the nineteenth- and early-twentieth-century out-of-copyright translations which have been re-issued, in print or digital format, over the last several years. Like most of them, it offers only the original Preface, the "Fooling of Gylfe" (the source of many of the best-known stories of Norse mythology), and selections from the "Poetic Diction" (Skaldskaparmal), omitting the many, many lists of synonyms and figures of speech which every young poet should know. An additional section (Hattatal), in which Snorri offers a hundred-verse praise-poem, illustrating the meters and devices of the poetry, with commentary, was, as usual, NOT included.For those who really want to read it, there is a free Kindle version, taken from a Project Gutenberg edition. However, there are other options, which some will probably find more rewarding.The most nearly complete of the older translations, that by Arthur Gilchrist Brodeur, includes the first two parts, with manuscript variations noted, plus the whole Skaldskaparmal. It is currently being offered, in an exact reprint of its 1916 American-Scandinavian Foundation edition, in both digital and print forms, by Dover Books. If you want a print or Kindle copy, of one of the older translations, this would be my suggestion. If you don't mind reading pdfs, the Library of Congress hosts the Internet Archive (archive.org), which includes digital versions of (I think) the translations of Rasmus Anderson, J.A. Blackwell, and George W. Dasent (in an English which some find annoying, but others, like me, enjoy.)More recent translations are: a somewhat aging volume by Jean. I. Young, "The Prose Edda: Tales from Norse Mythology," currently in print from the University of California Press (which has kept it alive for decades), which also excludes most of Skaldskaparmal; a similarly-restricted Penguin Classics translation by Jesse Byock (my personal favorite in terms of style; available in both print and Kindle editions), ALSO titled "The Prose Edda: Norse Mythology"; and the only really complete English version, by Anthony Faulkes, currently in print under the Everyman imprint, as just Edda.Faulkes also edited all four parts of the Old Icelandic text (Preface, "Deluding of Gylfi," Skaldskaparmal, and Hattatal). These are presently available, along with some interesting articles, as pdf files, on the Web Publications page of the Viking Society for Northern Research (a UK organization). These are free, for private study; the editions are, obviously, primarily for those seriously interested in studying Old Icelandic, although I find some of the long lists in Skaldskaparmal to be quite fascinating in their original forms.[Addendum, March 2015: There is a good article by Jonas Wellendorf, which briefly examines the various versions of the Prose Edda in the main manuscripts, including their internal arrangement, and their differing additional materials, as "Zoroaster, Saturn, and Othinn: The Loss of Language and the Rise of Idolatry." A pdf can be obtained by searching Academia.edu for Wellendorf's page there, and downloading the file from the list of his publications. Wellendorf offers an "ideological" approach to passages often omitted as interpolations in modern editions of the Prose Edda. The article was originally published in "The Performance of Christian and Pagan Storyworlds: Non-Canonical Chapters of the History of Nordic Medieval Legend," edited by Lars Boje Mortensen and Tuomas M.S. Lehtonen, with Alexandra Bergholm, Volume 3 of "Medieval Identities: Socio-Cultural Spaces," Brepols Publishers, Turnhout, Belgium, 2013.]

[August 31, 2015: Please note that this review has been included by Amazon's software in a group of reviews attached to a Kindle edition dated April 7, 2014, about a year *later* than the date of my review. In other words, Amazon has lumped together reviews for different editions. If I was still able to separately review the 2014 edition I would give it a full five stars, since it does include the original publication data, and appears to be properly organized, although judging from more recent comments navigation may be a problem.. (I'm posting this information *immediately* after finally noticing the confusion, and I have not taken the time to read the edition throughout.) Although the comments on the Kindle edition originally addressed are no longer necessarily relevant, the bulk of the review, regarding Brodeur's fine old translation, still expresses my views.]I've given the separate paperback and Kindle editions offered here a joint rating of three stars, because both of them seem to lack any indication to alert the prospective buyer that the translation of the "Prose Edda" was first published way back in 1916, by the American-Scandinavian Foundation (and not 2011, as one of the copyright notices suggests). That version is long out of print, but there is a free Google Book edition in a very reliable pdf, with the original special characters and formatting intact. Dover Books offers both a Kindle or print edition, either of which can be relied on (Dover also offers the 1923 two-volume Henry Adams Bellows translation of the "Elder" or "Poetic" Edda, also originally an American-Scandinavian Foundation publication.)If one wishes to read this thirteenth-century handbook of Norse myths and Icelandic poetic diction in the sort of prose favored for such translations a century, or more, ago, Brodeur, a fine scholar with a long career (his "The Art of Beowulf" was published in 1959), is probably your best choice, whether in print or digital format. He is less archaic or awkward than Rasmus Andersen, J.A. Blackwell, and George W. Dasent, his Victorian-era precursors, all of whom produced shorter translations. He also had the advantage of a somewhat more advanced state of knowledge of Old Icelandic.Brodeur included an interesting, somewhat dated, "modern" Introduction. From the Old Icelandic work he was translating he included the Preface (a rationalizing account of the origins of the Norse gods in deified mortals), the "Deluding of Gylfi" (in which most of the best-known myths are told to a disguised king by three mysterious figures, High, Just-As-High, and Third), and the "Poetic Diction," or Skaldskaparmal, which starts off as a conversation between the sea-god and the god of poetry, includes some more myths and heroic legends, but eventually trails away in long lists of poetic synonyms and figures of speech. There was also a pretty reliable index.Like his predecessors, Brodeur omitted a fourth section, Hattatal, which is a long praise-poem by Snorri Sturluson (who is generally credited with most or all of the rest), complete with commentary on the meter and (you guessed it) the poetic diction. Most translators (including Jean Young and Jesse Byock in the twentieth century) either skip the third and fourth parts, or give only samples.I've reviewed the Young and the Byock versions, with more information on the Icelandic poet-scholar-politician credited with the work, and explained something about why it is called "Snorri's Edda," "The Younger Edda" or "The Prose Edda." (Another Icelandic text, a compilation of poems in a different style, with bits of linking prose, came to be known as "Poetic Edda," or the "Elder Edda," or, in an abandoned attribution, "Saemund's Edda.")This was, therefore, the most complete translation available in English until 1987, when Anthony Faulkes' full version appeared (full as in, complete with "Hattatal") available in paperback from Everyman since 1994. Faulkes rendering, as just "Edda" is currently in print, at a quite reasonable price, and serious students will want both it and Faulkes' edition of the Old Icelandic text. The latter is available, along with some articles, as a set of free pdfs, on the Web Publications page of the Viking Society (of the UK; formerly known as the Viking Club); and print copies can be ordered from the UK, through the Society Publications page, and (sometimes depending on other sellers) from or through Amazon.Faulkes' translation includes all of the material in Brodeur's edition, plus an additional chapter of "Skaldskaparmal." Faulkes' prose style does not seem to be universally admired by Amazon reviewers, but if you don't like it, you will probably like Brodeur's even less.[Addendum, February 2015: There is a good article by Jonas Wellendorf, which briefly examines the various versions of the Prose Edda in the main manuscripts, including their internal arrangement, and their differing additional materials, as "Zoroaster, Saturn, and Othinn: The Loss of Language and the Rise of Idolatry." A pdf can be obtained by searching Academia.edu for Wellendorf's page there, and downloading the file from the list of his publications. Wellendorf offers an "ideological" approach to passages often omitted as interpolations in modern editions of the Prose Edda. The article was originally published in "The Performance of Christian and Pagan Storyworlds: Non-Canonical Chapters of the History of Nordic Medieval Legend," edited by Lars Boje Mortensen and Tuomas M.S. Lehtonen, with Alexandra Bergholm, Volume 3 of "Medieval Identities: Socio-Cultural Spaces," Brepols Publishers, Turnhout, Belgium, 2013.}

I've reviewed paperback editions of "The Ship of Ishtar," and a digital edition. In those cases, I made an effort to talk about the author, and his place in early twentieth century (1918 and following) place in American science fiction and fantasy. In this instance, I will be giving more details about the book -- while avoiding "spoilers," which makes it a little more difficult.Many readers of Merritt prefer one or another of his "Lost Race" novels, "The Moon Pool," "The Face in the Abyss," and "Dwellers in the Mirage," and there are those would point to his much-revised "The Metal Monster" / "The Metal Emperor," a sequel of sorts  to "The Moon Pool" with which the author himself never seems to have been satisfied.Some of us, however, prefer his alternate-world fantasy adventure, "The Ship of Ishtar," originally serialized in 1924, and reprinted, somewhat abridged, as a novel in 1926 (Putnam). It was the Putnam text that was reprinted by Avon Books from the 1950s through the early 1980s, and is presumably the best-known incarnation. The full text was not restored until the present "Borden Memorial Edition" was published about six years after the author's sudden death in 1943, an edition which includes beautiful black-and-white illustrations by Virgil Finlay. This is not Merritt at his most exotic -- there is little place for his splendid strange terrains in a story set mostly at sea -- but it is Merritt at his most obviously romantic, in a setting in which Love and Death seem to be the most evident Powers.This edition was reprinted in hardcover in 1990, and in trade paperback in the "Collier Nucleus Library" of fantasy and science fiction in 1991. It later served as the basis of the Renaissance E Books edition, available for Kindle, (without illustrations, alas), and of the Paizo paperback, in two-column magazine format, and with additional Finlay illustrations from a magazine reprinting which he also illustrated.The 1924 text is in thirty-five chapters. The Putnam/Avon text, which is available on various places around the web, was re-ordered into thirty-one chapters, some re-titled to fit, and divided into six parts (possibly suggested by the six-part magazine serialization). Whole pages are missing, including the crucial opening scene, which introduces the protagonist, and his feelings of alienation after returning from service in the First World War. Since this backgrounds his doubts of his own sanity, its absence can only confuse the reader. (A modern parallel would be a recent veteran who is sure that bizarre events are a product of Post-traumatic Stress Disorder, until proven otherwise.)The hero, John Kenton, is a well-off adventurer and archeologist (a prototype of Indiana Jones, only with a lot more money), who has financed excavations in Babylon, and receives from it a strange stone block with nearly-illegible warning inscriptions. Naturally, he can't leave well-enough alone when the stone cracks. Fortunately for Kenton, this is not an H.P. Lovecraft story, nor an episode of "Angel," and he does not come to an immediate, unpleasant, end. (Which would have denied us the pleasure of a longish novel, adding another short story to Merritt's bibliography.)Instead, he discovers that the block contains a toy-like ship on a crystal sea, in precious and semi-precious metals and gem-stones. Merritt seems to have taken the basic idea from the ceremonial "ships" in which images of the gods of ancient Mesopotamia were carried in ritual processions. (How ship-like these actually were is an interesting question.) This ship, however, is the gateway to a world of endless day, and the deck of a "real" ship which has voyaged since the days of Sargon of Akkad. (Which modern research puts about 2300 B,C,, but Merritt, stretching an obsolete chronology, generously estimates at about 6000 B.C.)Sort of the ultimate "Flying Dutchman" story (cue the appropriate bits of Wagner); except that the heroine, Sharane, Priestess of Ishtar, is already on the ship. It looks like any redemption will be Kenton's job. And Kenton is not taking anything at face value; even when his antique sword is confidently identified as the weapon of Nabu, god of Wisdom. What does get through to him are the wounds and scars visible on his body during brief returns to his own time and place....As Kenton, and the reader, learn, the ship is the site of an unending duel between the goddess of love and war, Ishtar, and the death-god Nergal, a struggle waged through the persons of their priests, who temporarily incarnate their respective deities.  (Strictly speaking, the game is rigged; in a world without twilight or dawn, Ishtar, goddess of the Morning and Evening Star, is clearly at a disadvantage!) The crew is, from time to time, replenished by victims of spells, from either our world, or one or more similar, but not identical, worlds. (The latter being the only *good* explanation why Sigurd the Viking could have encountered a full-scale Egyptian temple, in good repair and with a full staff, in what historically was Islamic and Coptic Christian Egypt.....)Naturally, Kenton, being as American as Dorothy, can't leave well enough alone, and acts to resolve the situtation. The world of the Ship, however, is not as naturally benign as Oz. His actions lead to complications which fill the next couple of hundred pages. We find, among other things, that this world contains ships beside The Ship, and at least one island, ruled by the King of Two Deaths, and populated by a polyglot mixture from many times and places.Merritt's idea of ancient Mesopotamia is now quite out of date, but it amounts to an entertaining collision of early twentieth-century Assyriology with Herodotus on the one side, and H. Rider Haggard on the other.The mixture is unreliable, but fun. As long as no one takes it too seriously, no harm is done when, from time to time the obsolete nature of Merritt's sources shows through; notably in the use of the name "Ninib" for an important god, instead of the modern reading "Ninurta." Nin.IB is the representation of a name of uncertain pronunciation, showing that is used a glyph which might be read, or called, "ib," but might be read otherwise.  (Cuneiform script was not an ideal medium, and some scribes seem to have rejoiced in being erudite and enigmatic, but modern scholars have worked out ways to indicate uncertainty.)  By the early 1920s, evidence was emerging that it should be read "urta."Likewise, Bel-Merodach (the Biblical form of Bel-Marduk) appears as the chief god in the days of Sargon of Akkad; but he was an essentially local god of Babylon, until as least the days of Hammurabi (ca. 1750 B.C.), when Marduk began his rise to the rank of "Bel" (Lord) in southern Mesopotamia -- a  position in which he was eventually challenged by the Assyrian's patron god, Assur, from the north. Likewise, Nabu (Kenton's patron/puppetmaster), his son, was a minor god in Sargon's day, and only in Neo-Assyrian and Neo-Babylonian times became a rival to his father Marduk in popularity, and was seen as co-regent of the universe....I mention these points because bits and pieces of "information" from Merritt novels -- most commonly, but not exclusively, "The Moon Pool" -- have been quoted for years as sober, if exciting, facts, and now circulate on the Web.

For some reason -- probably because the publisher is "Edizioni Delirium" and the unknown authors are given as "Autori vari," both according to the copyright page, this small file is listed by Amazon as an "Italian Edition" of the text of Carl Orff's "Carmina Burana" ("A Scenic Cantata," to give it the commonly-used English version of its subtitle, here missing -- strictly speaking it is "Profane" -- that is, Un-Sacred or Secular -- "Songs."). On the other hand, some of the information is given in English: "Anonymous" on the cover, and "Cover design" on the copyright page.Perhaps someone, somewhere, was just confused by the fact that most of the text is what perhaps could be considered a very, very, very old-fashioned form of Italian. In fact, it consists of Orff's slightly erratic selection of medieval verses in Latin --  and some bits of Middle High German -- and has not the slightest trace of an Italian (or any other) translation.For some reason, Edizioni Delirium does not indicate that there is a reprise of the opening "O Fortuna" at the end of the cyle -- all that would have been needed was some indication that the reader should go back to page one......The title is generally pronounced, even by broadcasters who have shown signs of knowing better, as "CarMEEna Burana," even though the "i" should be short, NOT like the "i" in machine. (I won't go into the problems of stress/accent in this multi-lingual situation.)The name indicates that the texts come from a manuscript found at "Benediktbeuern" in Bavaria, although this geographical fact seems to have less to do with the origins of the songs -- lay, clerical, monastic --  than with where the copies of the texts in one manuscript happened to wind up in modern times. Other versions of some them survive elsewhere. Actual metrically plausible relevant medieval music for some them exists (and has been recorded). Orff's compositions are entirely twentieth century, however, no matter how often Hollywood tries to make them out to be "medieval sounding."As such, this Kindle edition is a convenient replacement for the liner notes (in legible type) that used to accompany recordings; at least for those notes which didn't include a translation as well. Or for listening to a broadcast version. (And a translation is probably needed to catch all of what is going on, unless you happen to have been trained in Latin, or as a medievalist, or both; these are very funny poems, frequently made more so by passing themselves off (musically) as something much more innocent than they really are.(My favorite story about this I heard from a fellow graduate-student some decades ago. It seems she attended a performance in Austria, and happened to notice of row of elderly Ladies listening with rapt attention to the innocent little children singing in Latin, clearly without the least idea on their part of what they were singing about. She caught the eye of a priest, who DID understand it, and both of them had to struggle not to laugh out loud.....)There have been several translations of some or all of the poems, in various collections (leaving aside those made to accompany recordings or performances).For those looking for a translation of the text in the Kindle format, Penguin Classics has reissued David Parlett's 1986 translation of these poems, and a good deal more from the same medieval collection, "Selections from The Carmina Burana." His main translations, based on critical texts, are readable; special versions of those used by Orff are separated in an appendix, in Orff's order, and using his cuts and other modifications, and are also intended to be singable to his music. This makes it possible to use a hard copy as a silent guide to performance of a broadcast, or live if there are no program notes. If you are using a Kindle or a Kindle app instead of a paper copy, however, and are going to a live performance, I would suggest that you study ahead, and leave it at home!Parlett provides a useful, if now dated, bibliography of the medieval texts. There is what seems to me a decent Wikipedia article on Orff's life and career,  and the various controversies around him currently (i.e., as of this writing) available.

Most of the books I review I have read twice (at least); the exceptions are reference works, which are not intended to be read through, and very long and rather technical books, especially those for which technical comments (as opposed to details on the contents) on my part would be presumptuous."Absorbing Perfections: Kabbalah and Interpretation" (2002), a very long book (about 660 pages) on medieval and early modern hermeneutics, falls neatly into the second category. I intend to re-read it; but not anytime soon. (For one thing, it suggested a lot of other reading I would like to get out of the way first!)Hermeneutics is defined by Merriam-Webster as "the study of the methodological principles of interpretation and explanation; specifically: the study of the general principles of biblical interpretation." And, as the subtitle indicates, "Absorbing Perfections" deals not with just any system of hermeneutics, but the multitude of systems inherited, adopted, adapted, innovated upon, and invented, by Jewish mystics from the High Middle Ages (the thirteenth century onwards) to the eighteenth and even nineteenth centuries. This includes systems which read sacred texts as vast symbolic structures, and also systems which read the individual letters as packed with hidden meanings. (In some cases, to be perceived in trances entered by permutations of the Hebrew letters.)All of this with frequent references to modern (basically post-1950) critical theories and theorists, and the established, or possible, impact of Kabbalistic ideas on their works: especially Derrida and Deconstruction, although literary Structuralism and Post-Modernism make appearances as well. (As I see it, Deconstruction begins with the insight that language is tricky and inexact, and then goes off the rails; but I don't have the background in modern philosophy needed to follow its arguments and applications.  That they attempted to communicate this by means of language could, of course, be a part of the problem.....)Now, there are some good short introductory books on Kabbalah (and other forms of Jewish Mysticim), like Gershom Scholem's "On the Kabbalah and Its Symbolism" (English translation 1965), and some good short collections of Kabbalistic writings, like Daniel Matt's "The Essential Kabbalah" (1996; 240 pages) There are also good, short, but advanced books, like Arthur Green's "Keter: The Crown of God in Early Jewish Mysticism" (1997; 200 pages).Some of the best (and most important), at both introductory and advanced levels, however, are substantial tomes, like Scholem's "Major Trends in Jewish Mysticism" (First edition 1941; third edition about 490 pages, including front matter, bibliographies, and index) and his "Origins of the Kabbalah" (English translation 1987, about 500 pages). These were major efforts at reconstructing the chronology of mystical writings, identifying authors and doctrines, and laying the foundation for rigorously argued studies based on close readings of texts, instead of informed (and uninformed) guesses and personal biases.On the same generous scale are more recent programmatic works, like Moshe Idel's "Kabbalah: New Perspectives" (1988, about 460 pages), and Elliot Wolfson's "Through a Speculum That Shines: Vision and Imagination in Medieval Jewish Mysticism" (1994, about 470 pages). "The Poetry of Kabbalah: Mystical Verse from the Jewish Tradition" (translated and edited by Peter Cole (2012; co-edited with Aminadav Dykman), runs to 450 pages in English, plus about 70 (separately numbered) in Hebrew. Detailed annotations, in smaller print, cover pages 251-434 (and are essential for understanding many of the poems).So far as I know, the current extreme example, published in English in a single volume, is Moshe Idel's "Ben: Sonship and Jewish Mysticism" (2007, almost 740 pages in rather small print).So "Absorbing Perfections," although not quite as massive as this last, is not remarkably long; indeed, given that its subject involves pretty much all surviving Kabbalistic writings, only Idel's decision to give only samples of actual exegesis kept it as short as it is. Fortunately, Idel is a fairly good stylist, so the main obstacles facing readers are (a) the need for background information and (b) the inherent subtlety, and sometimes counter-intuitive nature, of the subjects treated. However, statements are meticulously annotated; the notes fill pages 493-663.I would encourage anyone with a background in modern studies of Kabbalah and at least a little familiarity with post-modern theories of literature to try it. I found it tough going, but illuminating. (Some of my difficulties may have arisen from the fact that I was reading it on a Kindle App, and suffered eyestrain from glare until I reset the app.)Others, who are intrigued, and willing to work at it, will need backgrounding; of the books mentioned above, Scholem's "Major Trends" is still the most comprehensive basic introduction to the Kabbalah, and Idel frequently quotes it (often to disagree). An alternative is a collection of Scholem's "Encyclopedia Judaica" articles, "Kabbalah" (1974). This is considerably more up-to-date on some topics, but it does not cover, or too briefly covers, material needed for "Absorbing Perfections."On the modern hermeneutics side (excluding specifically Biblical criticism and exegesis), the major introduction with which I am familiar (or was; I read it shortly after it appeared) is Jonathan Culler's "On Deconstruction: Theory and Criticism After Structuralism" (1982; 25th Anniversary Edition, 2008). There is, as of this writing, a Wikipedia article "Deconstruction" which I found to be pretty good, despite a number of criticisms of its style and level of difficulty; with cross-references to the articles on Structuralism and Post-Modernism. There is also an article on Jacques Derrida; it will leave the reader confused, but, I think, not as confused as reading Derrida (e.g., "Of Grammatology") directly.Since "Absorbing Perfections" is offered by Amazon only in Kindle format (with hard-copy editions from other sellers) it is worth noting that the Kindle version is NOT formatted with hyperlinks between the main text and the many endnotes. Fortunately, I was reading it using the Mac app version of Kindle, and could keep two copies open on different pages, using the Cloud Drive Reader on my browser, which made the whole experience a lot more satisfying.

This review of "On the Mystical Shape of the Godhead: Basic Concepts in the Kabbalah" is aimed primarily at assessing the book's level of difficulty, and its place among the author's studies of Jewish Mysticism which are now available in English. I have read each of those mentioned at least twice, and most of them three or more times, so I think that my observations are well-informed, if not typical of all potential readers.I have not attempted to summarize the contents, which have been covered in Amazon's Book Description, and by many of the previous reviewers.Kabbalah is an esoteric form of Judaism, so even a truly basic introduction demands some prior knowledge of post-Biblical Jewish history, and exoteric Judaism; otherwise, references to names, locales, philosophical schools, and periods of time, are likely to blur together, even if briefly defined in the volume itself. For a reliable introduction, I would suggest, among many worthy titles, "Back to the Sources: Reading the Classic Jewish Texts," edited by Barry W. Holtz (1984), which covers most of the relevant literature, albeit sometimes very briefly.Gershom Scholem's "On the Mystical Shape of the Godhead" ("Von der mystischen Gestalt der Gottheit," 1962; English translation, Schocken, with Foreword by Joseph Dan, 1991) is a set of six complex and elaborately documented essays, tracing specific themes in Jewish mystical thought. Despite being well-translated, they together make up one of his more difficult works (in English), perhaps surpassed only by his long "Origins of the Kabbalah" (Princeton, 1991), with its densely-argued readings of some notoriously obscure and corrupt medieval texts. In this case, the difficulties are presented mainly by the long histories of the ideas he investigates, and their many variations and transformations.For this reason, the English-language subtitle of "Basic Concepts in the Kabbalah" is accurate, but, as some reviewers have complained, misleading. "Basic" is often used in English book titles to indicate "simple, or elementary." The German "Studien zu Grundbegriffen" in the original subtitle (1962) might instead have been translated as "Investigations towards Fundamental Principles," or something equally, or even more, polysyllabic and intimidating.Certainly, the six essays which made up the contents of "Mystical Shape" are substantially denser, and more elaborately documented -- and often richer in content -- than the five pieces in an earlier volume, to which it is in effect a sequel, "On the Kabbalah and Its Symbolism" ("Zur Kabbala und ihrer Symbolik," 1960; English translation, Schocken, 1965, with Foreword by Bernard McGinn, 1996). Both books contain lectures originally delivered at the C.G. Jung's "Eranos" conferences in Zurich, in the 1950s (one of the few places where Scholem felt he could use his native German language -- and introduce to Jewish thought to a part of the intellectual elite of a continent from which Jews had been nearly obliterated). Revised versions of both "Symbolism" and "Mystical Shape" were published in one volume in Hebrew, in 1976, as Joseph Dan points out in his useful Foreword to this English translation by Joachim Neugroschel. (The 1991 English text of "Mystical Shape" was revised by Jonathan Chipman to incorporate Scholem's emendations.) When the essays are read in order of publication, they take a reader from truly elementary (which is not to say easy or self-evident) aspects of Jewish mysticism to some of its most complex and wide-ranging developments.I have often recommended "Symbolism" as an introductory book; it has the great advantage of being about half the length of Scholem's "Major Trends in Jewish Mysticism" (1941, 1946, 1954; Schocken Paperback 1961; with Foreword by Robert Alter, 1995), and considerably more inviting, as well as significantly shorter, than the encyclopedia articles collected in "Kabbalah" (1974; Meridian paperback, 1978). (Another collection, longer, but addressed to non-specialists, is Scholem's collection of popular and "occasional" pieces, "The Messianic Idea in Judaism, and Other Essays on Jewish Spirituality," Schocken, 1971; with Foreword by Arthur Hertzberg, 1995). However, it might be wise to try "Major Trends" or "Kabbalah" *before* attempting "Mystical Shape."

Unlike the two earlier reviews which Amazon software has attached to it, this is actually a review of a Kindle edition, by a specific translator. For this reason, my comments on the translation, commentary and index (or lack thereof) will not match up with theirs. [See note at end for the edition to which it is linked.]David Grene's translation of Hesiod's "Works and Days" originally appeared in the volume "God and the Land: The Metaphysics of Farming in Hesiod and Vergil" (Oxford University Press, 1998) by Stephanie A. Nelson. This volume is still in print, including a not-too-expensive (by current standards) paperback edition, and available from Amazon. But separate publication of the translation as an inexpensive Kindle book was doubtless a good idea.After all, Grene is a well-known translator, and the translation (as well as the volume in which it appeared) was well-received. And Hesiod, although he lacks the name-recognition of Homer, was a major early Greek poet, whose works deserve to be better known (despite numerous other translations in recent decades).Unfortunately, as too often happens with Kindle editions, there is a big gap between the good idea and its execution; enough to deprive the result of three stars in my rating.To begin with, there is no information given to the reader about where and when the translation first appeared -- which is not Grene's fault; the included "Translator's Note" takes for granted what the digital copyright page does not supply.Worse, the text seems to have been digitized by OCR, with NO attempt to copy-edit the results (or maybe a half-hearted one that caught some problems, but let the rest remain). Spelling of words tends to suffer at the beginning or the end; punctuation often is missing, and may be wrong where it does appear. Gaps in the text seem to be random, possibly marking the ends of pages in the original, but perhaps indicating lines missed.There are no line numbers, and there is no index; finding one's way around the poem, or locating a reference, is up to the reader. The product page claims that it is 100 pages long; quite a lot to page through, especially given that spelling errors make use of the search engine something like shooting dice.It is perhaps a fair warning that this ancient Greek poem about farming and morality has been given as its cover illustration a rural genre-scene -- of what looks like nineteenth-century Europe (but might, I suppose, be American).Finally, the Amazon list of editions in other formats refers one (as is only too usual) to a variety of totally different translations.Fortunately for those who want to read Grene's rendering, a pdf version is available, FREE, from the Library of Congress' "Internet Archive" (archive.org), complete with Grene's introductory remarks, line numbers, and even his brief textual notes. (This may have been the source for the present edition, simply OCR'd from a digital form, instead of scanned directly from a hard copy.)[The Grene translation appears to have been linked to the paperback edition of the translation of Hesiod's "Works and Days" by Tandy and Neale -- a very good translation with a superb "Social Science" commentary on the "peasant ethos" expressed in the poem. This is rather different from Nelson's approach, as described by Grene in his introductory note to his translation.]

Lucas Strigoi thought he had found the one sixteen years ago, he wont make that mistake again until he realizes that the mistake he made was worse than the thought and the woman he should have been with was his exs little sister in this enthralling paranormal romance.Reagans sister broke Lucas heart and he disappeared right after, taking Reagans heart with him and readers cant help but be enthralled as Reagans family sends her across the country to retrieve Lucas for her sisters marriage. The chemistry is hot and steamy but the romance is a bit on the late side since someone interfered all those years ago causing mistakes to be made and lots of emotional turmoil as these strong captivating characters strive for the happily ever after that they were denied in this fast paced smooth flowing plot that ensnares readers with suspense and romance while the intriguing events draw them in and refuse to let go.Lucas and Reagan captured my heart from the very beginning and there were quite a few surprises in the story as well and I have to say that I am very curious about Zeus becoming involved in Chloe and Eross bet.

Having spent a decade on the shadier side of life, Casey Grossier has returned home and cleaned up his act but despite his best efforts he cant shake his crush on his sweet-faced bartender in this riveting romantic suspense. I couldnt help but become engaged in Abilene and Caseys characters as this story is quite the emotional rollercoaster of a romance but while the romance part of the plot has an ending there is some sad affairs that affect the Desert Dogs and the town of Fortuity that hasnt been resolved, so there is a bit of a cliffhanger which of course means that I really cant wait to find out what happens next.See my full review at: Paranormal Haven .com

Bored with everything, Savage Chaucers craving for change and lust for excitement is answered when the innocent nave-looking Sydney Dyke wanders into his club in this exciting paranormal romance. The Fallen Alpha world has many fascinating differences and intriguing characters that I just cant help but get pulled into each and every story and Savage and Sydneys story takes it a step further with even more interesting elements and unexpected surprises that there was no way that I could put this story down once I began reading it and I cant wait to find out what happens next.Copyright Night Owl Reviews4  STARSSee my full review at: Night Owl Reviews .com

As a birthday present to herself, Emma Montrose decides its time to show Jake Sullivan that shes a woman with needs and she wants him in this delightful paranormal romance.Jacks not interested in a commitment so he intends to stay far away from Emma but then work puts them together on a case and the readers cant help but be delighted as Emma and Jack get all hot and steamy when their undercover work makes denying the hot sexual chemistry between them impossible. The characters are strong, captivating and grab the readers attention while the fast paced, smooth flowing plot thrills readers with suspense, excitement and passion as the well written scenes bring the sizzling passion and spine tingling excitement to life and the intriguing events ensure that there is a never a dull moment and provides quite a few a chuckles as the situation demands.Shelley Munro has done it again and created a fascinating new dragon world with intriguing characters and setting and a refreshingly different dragon shifter element based on different mythology that spices things up. Jack and Emmas story may have been a little on the short side but they sure delighted the heck out of me and I cant wait to read the next Dragon Investigator book.4  STARS

This box set includes over twenty-five paranormal holiday tales that will not only delight you but put you in the holiday spirit.While the stories are short the readers cant help but be delighted by all the variety of paranormal available in this box set  with the added benefit of them all having a holiday setting of one type or other. The romance is sweet, the chemistry is sizzling so you have quite the passionate encounters in these fast paced and smooth flowing plots full of suspense, excitement and romance. Now you have twenty-five different authors which means different writing styles so not every story can be perfect (that depends on personal preference_ but theres not one in this box set that wont delight and entertain readers as they are well written stories that captures the imagination and have anticipation building throughout with wonderful characters some more imaginative than others but every one of them captivate and charm readers right into their stories whether its warlocks, shifters, vampires, elves, Santa Claus, dragons or ghosts and theres at least one or two that will surprise you.I have to say that reading them all at one time is a bit much but I was completely caught up in the magic, so much so that I felt like a kid at Christmas and that I just got the best present ever, so grab some hot chocolate and enjoy!

When Tucker Pankov and his team are targeted by assassins and stripped of their top-secret security clearance, Tucker decides their best option is to kidnap the only woman he thinks can save them in high energy romantic suspense. Once again, Katie Reus took command of the written word and brought fourth an exhilarating romantic suspense that gets the blood pumping and the imagination going and I cant wait to read the next one.4  STARSSee my full review at: Paranormal Haven .com

Get ready to join in the gathering as ten paranormal romances rock readers worlds as they ae bewitched into fantasies where their darkest appetites are sated. Lots of sizzling chemistry and hot and steamy sex spices up the darkness as these strong, edgy and compelling characters leave readers breathless with anticipation and fulfilled fantasies. The stories are well written, fast paced and flow smoothly while daring readers to give in to temptation and take a walk on the dark side. Spine tingling excitement builds throughout the stories as readers await the characters fates and the intriguing events draw readers in and ensure that they dont want to leave anytime soon.As with all collections, I wont try to tell you that will fall instantly fall in love with all the stories but I will tell you that you will be hard pressed not to enjoy these ten delicious tales where the authors capture your imagination and introduce you to worlds with sexy characters, decadent romance and fascinating worlds that are sure to have you coming back for more, I know I will be because I was completely ensnared by these stories and I dont know if Ill ever get enough.4  STARS

His two brothers has caved to his moms ultimatum which has Colin McFarlans back against the wall because the only woman hes ever loved is the one who came between him and his brother Brody in this delightful contemporary romance.Fancy Wilson is determined not to add to her mistakes by falling for Colin all over again and the reader cant help but get caught up in this charming romance as Colin and Fancy join forces to break up someone elses romance while fighting their attraction. The chemistry between Colin and Fancy sizzles with lots of steamy passion but the relationship will take some doing considering the past and the fact that Colin is considered a heartbreaker. These strong charismatic characters grab the readers attention while the well-written, fast paced plot flows smoothly with lots of suspense, turmoil and romance with the pressure of the threat his mother made hanging over Colins head and his mothers personal life adding tension and spice to the story while the intriguing events ensure that there is plenty of excitement happening in this rocky romance.The Ugly Stick Saloon series has struck again as I found myself completely charmed by Colin and Fancys story as they provided quite a few chuckles while re-kindling their love.

Baylons wild and reckless nature makes him the perfect assassin for Death until his newest order brings him face to face with Jordyn Patterson and she claims him body and soul which breaks all the rules in this fascinating paranormal romance.This fast paced smooth flowing plot is a thrilling mix of suspense, excitement and romance as the Reapers set out follow their newest order which sets Baylon on a path that could cost him his very existence. The readers cant help but get caught up in all the vibrant chemistry between Baylon and Jordyn as it  flows from the pages but this is one relationship that has an expiration date as it breaks all of Deaths rules and these strong dynamic characters demand your complete attention as they do just that.Jordyn has always been fascinated by the Fae but when a chance encounter has her being rescued from the Dark, her world is turned upside down with lots of spine tingling tension and excitement building as betrayals and unexpected twists keeps the readers on the edge of their seats with the well written scenes and vivid details bringing it all to life and drawing the reader in while the intriguing events guarantee that there is never a dull moment.Well, as you probably know I am 100% enthralled by the Dark World and this newest series addition is just as fascinating and sexy as the others. The Reapers are certainly going to give the Dragon Kings a run for their money in the bad boy sexy department with Baylon and Jordyns story being a great introduction and I cant wait Dark Alphas Embrace to find out what happens next.

The Southern Territory is up for grabs and Christian Duvall is determined to claim it but the battle has taken a treacherous edge because one of his enemies wants what already belongs to Christian in this spectacular paranormal romance.Natalie loves her complex job and the simplicity of her life until she meets Christian and she has to fight to keep him alive and the reader cant help but get drawn into the story as Texas becomes the battleground for some of the most dangerous vampires alive. Expectation builds lots of tension as allies and enemies alike try to remove Christian from the challenge for Lord of the South and excitement builds throughout the story as the dangers escalate with a horde of zombie vampires being prepped to roll right over Texas and everyone that gets in the way. Vivid imagery brings each and every scene to life as the well written passages and details capture the imagination and the intriguing events sweep the readers along on a challenge that guarantees there is never a dull moment while a few unexpected twists keeps everyone on their toes.The plot is fast paced, smooth flowing and provides readers with lots of thrills, suspense and romance as the strong charismatic characters demand attention while Christian uses every shred of power and Natalies determination to win the war. Sizzling chemistry and scorching sex scenes provide spicy excitement while Natalie and Christian try to adjust to trusting one another with some powerful encounters as Christian makes it known to one and all including our favorite vampires that hes the best man for the job.Okay I have to hand it to Christian, he waltzed right in and made my heart pound and my senses tingle with excitement as his powerful vibe leapt from the pages and Natalie just made the perfect female for himtoo bad though because I would have loved to have kept him for myself. Oh wellIll just have to keep dreaming and impatiently waiting for next exciting story and I do mean exciting because no one has heard from Sophia and Colin.

This great clipboard has plenty of space underneath, for papers, pens or pencils, even space for your most recent puzzle magazine.I love it. I love it. I love it.I bought three so that I could have a different board for different purposes, prescription medication information, mathematical recreations, etc.I highly recommend this clipboard.

What I really love about the two frames that came in this carton is that they can go into a properly-sized box and allow it to easily contain hanging files.Sometimes, an Amazon shipping box looks good, so if you need a filing system that you can easily move from room to room, get these frames, put them in a good box, and file away.Or you could put this in something called a "banker's box".HINT: You can avoid buying the frames if you just use the old-style, non-hanging manila file folders all the time.

This wonderful clipboard has a built-in storage box under it. Before I ordered this, I worried about the size of the storage area, but there is enough space on all sides so that a standard 8.5x11 inch stack of paper fits easily.I love it. I bought three so that I could have a different board for different purposes, prescription medication information, mathematical recreations, etc. A pencil and a pen easily fit in the bottom compartment with room to spare. (I have not tried to put a third implement in there. I put a fairly fat pen in, so three or four thinner pens or pencils could fit.I highly recommend this clipboard.

I love these for a unique purpose ... lazinessSometimes, I don't want to worry about whether my spoons and forks are going to be cleaned soon enough, like before the food dries on them, making them harder to clean.When I use these forks, which cost me less than 2 cents each, I don't have to worry too much. If I forget to rinse it off so that it can be washed later in the week in the dishwasher, then I don't feel too bad just throwing it out.So, while some people would buy these for church picnics or family reunions, I purchased them s that I could use then pitch.I highly recommend these forks for your lazy kitchen or for your church picnic; your family get together or your midnight snack.

These cups are very nice for measuring dry or wet ingredients. (I don't suggest them for measuring gaseous ingredients, but that's a joke, sorry!!!)They appear to be accurate, though I have not applied a micrometer (mainly because I don't have one). They are durable and look like they will last forever, even better than the hard plastic measuring cups that I bought from Amazon, but misplaced in my house before I got around to putting them in the kitchen. (They'll show up when I'm looking for something else, my friend says.)RECOMMENDATIONIf you are looking for an excellent set of measuring cups, you have come to the right place. Definitely get these cups.If you are satisfied with your current measuring cups and spoons, you are certainly in good shape and don't need to upgrade, but if you are going to help set your offspring up with his or her own apartment, give them your old cups and spoons, and order these for yourself.PERSONAL BONUS(with a very boring anecdote)BONUS: I keep the big cup on the table where I take my morning pills. As I punch pills from three different cards, I drop the pills into the cup, then I do the same with the three pills that come out of two pill bottles. Then I open a bottle of juice, pour the pills from the cup into my hand, then take them with juice (I cheat and drink right out of the bottle).

This is a nice addition to my freezer space. I really like having a choice between regular ice cubes and these mini ice cubes. I highly recommend having at least two of these trays (two trays in one package) in your freezer along with your regular trays.But, as in life, for every advantage, there is a disadvantage.ADVANTAGEThere's a reason why many fast food places use crushed ice. The smaller each piece of ice, the faster it cools your drink. The only way to cool something faster is to use spherical ice cubes.DISADVANTAGEIce cubes transfer their coldness to the drink by a very simple method, they melt. As the temperature of the drink gets colder, the temperature of the surface of the ice gets warmer, which means the surface is melting.THERE IS A SECRET TO MAKING THE CUBES KEEP YOUR DRINK COLDER LONGERThe colder the drink is BEFORE you pour it over the ice, the longer the ice will last, the less it will dilute the drink, and the longer the drink will stay cold. Some people would say that putting the cubes into the drink is better than pouring the drink over the ice, which I kind of agree with, but do not have any mathematics to support that idea. I don't think the difference is big enough to make any change in your ice methods beneficial in this "over or under" method.NOTE: Most people will want to ignore the rest of my review. I get into High School Geometry, and make up my own "Coolness Quotient" formula as part of that explanation.RECOMMENDATION: DO YOU NEED THESE CUBES?These cubes are more of a conversation piece than they are of normal use around your house, but for a party, they can be a lot of fun. I rarely use my mini cube trays because I rarely have parties.ONLY GEEKS NEED TO READ FURTHERThe rest of my review is based on high school geometry. If you're not that into math (or maths in the UK), you might want to skip down to the very end.WHY DO MINI CUBES COOL FASTER THAN REGULAR CUBES?Let's apply some high school geometry and see what we get. We will compare the efficiency of two different sized cubes.1. Calculate the surface area of one regular ice cube2. Calculate the volume of that same ice cube3. Divide the first number by the second number4. Calculate the surface area of one mini ice cube5. Calculate the volume of that mini ice cube6. Divide the surface area by the volume of the mini cubeThe larger the quotient (the answer to #3 and #6), the faster it cools, but the faster it dilutes.Lets do the calculations for one inch and one-half inch cubes to demonstrate.Surface Area = 6 * length ^ squaredVolume = length ^ cubedOne Inch Ice Cube (all sides equal one inch)--- Surface Area = 6 * 1^2 = 6 * 1 = 6 square inches--- Volume = 1^3 = 1 cubic inch--- Coolness Quotient = 6 / 1 = 6Half Inch Ice Cube (all sides equal half an inch)--- Surface Area = 6 * 0.5 ^ 2 = 6 * 0.25 = 1.5--- Volume = 0.5 ^ 3 = 0.125 cubic inches--- Coolness Quotient = 1.5 / 0.125 = 12Since 12 is twice as large as 6, we can guess that half inch cubes get things colder twice as fast but melt twice as fast. Of course, this is based on similar volumes (weights) of the ice. One regular one inch cube is equal to eight mini half inch cubes in volume or weight.I will leave it to the nerds to try the same things with spherical ice cubes that have the same volume as these mini cubes or regular cubes.RECOMMENDATIONIf you have kids, get these and encourage them to do some experimentation between the two sizes of cubes. I do highly recommend these cubes for their curiosity value. That's the main reason I bought them.

Not only is this a good gag gift, it is an excellent way to carry data with you from computer to computer. It could even be part of the backup plan for your home or office.GIFT?When I bought this a few months ago, a friend of mine enjoyed his beer and occasional other drinks, so I ordered it for him. Now, though, I have managed to convince him to go to AA meetings almost every week, so it might not have been as good a gift as I first thought. (He has not complained, and says that he has had no problems with this data storage device.)A-B-C BACKUP PLAN?Some of my friends have never heard of this relatively simple plan. Always have one backup off-site; it seems so simple.Most people who already have a good backup plan can ignore the rest of this review:DIRECTIONS:1. Label three USB data drives as "Backup A", "Backup B" and "Backup C" (see proofreading note below).2. Decide how often you will backup your data. Some companies do it daily. Some, weekly. Families tend to do it less often.3. After you backup your data, take that data drive off site, and bring the next labeled drive back on site. Actually, you only have one drive off site at a time.SUMMARY OF BACKUP LOCATIONS(ITD = Info Tech Director)(this chart starts with Drive C being the most recent backup)(the most recent backup is always near the computer, just in case)(the second most recent backup is at the ITD's home)(third most recent backup is in another room at your company, e.g. ITD's office)End of Day 1 or Week 1: Backup onto data device A--------------------------------: ITD takes data device C home--------------------------------: Data device A stays in computer room--------------------------------: ITD brings data device B back to office the next morningEnd of Day 2 or Week 2: Backup onto data device B--------------------------------: ITD takes data device A home--------------------------------: Data device B stays in computer room--------------------------------: ITD brings data device C back to office the next morningEnd of Day 3 or Week 3: Backup onto data device C--------------------------------: ITD takes data device B home--------------------------------: Data device C stays in computer room--------------------------------:,ITD brings data device A back to office the next morningKeep repeating 1-2-3-1-2-3-1-2-3-etc.PROOFREADING NOTE:I deliberately chose to use UK style quoting in this review. Personally, I think in cases like this, we should keep the commas outside quotes to make it clear what each label says.RECOMMENDATION:I highly recommend using a USB data device as part of your BACKUP plan, and if the shape and picture of the device is special to you, that's even better.

My purpose in ordering these cheap spoons was so that I'd have something I could use when I didn't want to worry about washing dishes. These spoons are EXCELLENT for that purpose, and at a penny per spoon, I don't mind throwing them out if I don't wash them soon enough.They would also be great for picnics. If your church is having a picnic to celebrate the start or end of the Sunday School year, these are great for that purpose.The box says HEAVY DUTY. They may be Heavy Duty, but there are more expensive spoons that do not twist the way these do (when I deliberately twist them). But, that was perfectly fine with me, because I did not buy them for their heavy duty (alleged) feature.These are great for the price. I highly recommend them to you.

Do read the full page. You will find that the orange masks and the pumpkin cutouts are actually Internet downloads.Go here:  www.hoteltmovie.com/halloweenfunSo, if you already have a Hotel Transylvania DVD, you can download ten pages of PDF file for free and print them on your color printer. This may be why some reviewers are complaining that the package only contained stickers. This may also be why Amazon has made this product temporarily unavailable due to customer complaints.The MOVIE is worth five stars. BUT the deceptiveness of including already-free materials from the web to supposedly increase the value of the package is why I brought the score down to three stars. (One star for their deceptiveness. The average of 5 and 1 is equal to 3.)

Question: Will you enjoy "The Joy of Thinking" ?Answer:It depends, but in general, the answer is yes. I will answer this question in greater detail after the SYNOPSIS and REVIEW.SYNOPSIS:This set from "The Great Courses" contains four DVDs and two coursebooks with a total of 24 lessons, each about half an hour in length. I am not going to list all 24 lesson titles, but oftentimes, the two professors will take several lessons to cover some topics in understandable detail, but I will tell you what disk helped me learn the most new things.Topology, the study of surfaces, is the main topic for lessons 13 through 18. I already knew about Moebius Strips, those loops of paper with one or three half twists in them, but it was fun to review, and even understand better, some of the features of these funny strips, much better than comic strips. I knew, long ago, what a Klein Bottle was (it is a bottle with only one surface and no edges, but can only be constructed in four dimensions). Now that I've watched these lessons, I understand the theoretical method of how we would construct such a bottle. The construction was discussed in detail using tubes of paper. What I had never heard before was what would happen if we could cut an actual Klein bottle in half. (We would get two 3-dimensional Moebius Strips.)I was so fascinated by the discussion of fractals, also on disk 3 (fractals are a subset of Topological manipulation). I was so enamored, the disk inspired me to write a computer program to create two of the fractal images they discussed, and I plan to write at least a third one.Disk 4 does an excellent job of explaining probability. You might never go gambling in Las Vegas once you understand why the average person loses about 5 cents for every dollar that they spend.REVIEWI'm watching these DVD's out of order. I love them so much that I've watched disks 3 and 4 twice each. (The library has requested disks 1 and 2 for me, also.) They are so good, I'm thinking of purchasing my own copy.I did see two mistakes in their graphics, but I am not going to take away any stars for those mistakes. (For example, while the professor states that the probability of something is 999,999 out of one million, the chart on the screen had the fraction "1 over 999,999." Since these lectures were released in 2003, I'm certain they already know of these mistakes, so I'm not going to tell them. Others most certainly already have.Whether you buy this set, rent the program from someone, or borrow the DVD's and books from your library system, if you are lucky enough to have a library that can get them or has them, I highly recommend these lessons to you. If you are not sure whether you'd enjoy them, I invite you to read the next section.I do recommend that you read each topic in the guidebooks. It doesn't matter if you read them before or after watching the DVD. It is a matter of your preference.
