Personally, I found that I learned the topic better by watching one lesson, then reading that topic in the book, then going on to the next. Then after watching all six lessons on one DVD, I watched them again, and was surprised to find I still learned something new the second time, probably because the book helped me understand what I heard the first time, but it wasn't cemented into my mind until I watched it again.WILL YOU ENJOY THESE DVD LESSONS?Do you love math? You will enjoy some of these lessons, because you will almost certainly learn something new. I got an 800 on my Mathematics SAT (Scholastic Aptitude Test, highest possible score) as a Junior in high school, and repeated this 800 score twice on the GRE (Graduate Record Examination) in 1976 and 1996. In spite of my "perfect" math scores (which are, by no means perfect), I learned new things from these programs.Are you trying to understand what your child is learning in school? These lectures are great introduction for parents and grandparents. You will discover that there is new information available now that was not available when some of us were in school decades ago.Do you hate math? These professors actually present mathematics in ways that are easier to understand than the methods that are, unfortunately, used by too many Math Teachers.For example, did you know that you can make fractals randomly? (Sierpinski Triangle.) Have you heard of the Golden Spiral? You will be able to make one for yourself using paper, pencil, ruler, and compass. Did you know that you could fold a piece of paper to create a fractal? Look up the Dragon's Curve, which is made by folding a strip of paper many times, then unfolding it so that every fold is exactly 90 degrees in angle.I hope that I have piqued your interest.( At the bottom of this review, you will see two images, my own computer-created versions of the Dragon's Curve and the Sierpinski Triangle fractals. If enough people ask for the BASIC programs, I will be happy to create a web page that contains the images (each step of the way) and the source code of the program. If these aren't the full size images, I'll try to give you an Internet address for them. )OTHER RECOMMENDATIONSAnother good DVD that will introduce some interesting math concepts to you happens to be part of the very first Disney program ever broadcast in color:Donald in Mathmagic LandAfter you watch the short program, watch all the teacher resources that show clips specific to various grade levels along with questions that students can answer. I was able to answer most of them.

This is a very nice table. I got it for my living room so that I'd have another place to work on my computer. (My main "office" is one entire wall of my bedroom.) I wanted a table that would allow me to put my feet up while sitting at the table, quite a "feat" with a rocking chair recliner. There is plenty of space between the legs for this purpose, as you can see in the picture. You can actually make it fit either way, but I rotated the table so the recliner footrest goes under where the table legs are further apart.The table is sturdy, and when I have guests, it is a convenient place for them to work on their computer while I work on mine in my bedroom office.Of course, this table is also great for meeting rooms, church fellowship halls, and many other uses. I am also happy with National Public Seating's rectangular tables.I highly recommend both the circular and the rectangular tables in their product line.

This is a great little snack, but you need to be careful. The nutritional guidelines say that one tin contains two servings of herring, but if you are like me, you can manage to eat an entire container of herring in one sitting. This means that you need to double the calories (which I don't count) and double the sodium (which I do count).The herring tastes excellent, and the horseradish is a great flavor enhancer. In a way, I like it better in horseradish than I do getting it smoked, but both ways deserve five stars. Of course, if you hate fish, then don't buy this product. But if you do, these are great. No cooking required, just a taste for this type of fish.I highly recommend these herring fillets, but do watch your numbers.

I grew to love herring over the years, especially when it was served at weddings and other special ceremonies. There, it typically was the herring in cream sauce, but even the peppered herring fillets are a great substitute.These are wonderful fillets, easy to eat in an easy-to-open tin. I like opening the tin and eating right out of the tin.I highly recommend these herring fillets, but if you are watching your sodium (as I am) or your calories (which I am not), be aware that the nutrition chart (see below) says that this tin contains two servings, so if you eat the entire tin in one sitting, double those values. One serving is 28% of the recommended daily allowance of sodium, so the full tin is 56%.

I love herring, so it is very easy for me to give Ruegen's Herring Fillets the full five stars. I can eat the entire tin in one sitting. The fillets are easy to separate with a flimsy plastic fork, and they can be eaten right out of the tin, or served on a pretty plate.The lid opens easily. Normally, I don't bother removing it all the way, but instead, use my fork to get the last bits of herring out from under the other end of the tin. I guess I'm too lazy to throw the lid out separately. This way, I throw them both out at once.Fish lovers? I highly recommend these tins of herring to you.

I have watched "Donald in Mathemagic Land" more times than I care to admit. It is a wonderful DVD, and even has curriculum information that can be used by teachers to prepare lessons for the classroom.However, I question why, if Ludolph van Ceulen, an early modern mathematicians correctly calculated pi to an accuracy of 35 digits in the 18th century, and Jurij Vega reached an accuracy of 126 digits in the 19th century, that Disney would make two mistakes about the value of pi in this program. (In the glossary, they say that pi is equal to 22/7 or approximately 3.14; while in the program itself, a talking geometric figure makes a mistake, saying that pi is equal to 3.141592653589747 etc. Change 9747 to 9793 and it agrees, as far as it goes, with the 18th century value calculated by hand.Source for 18th and 19th century details:https :// en.wikipedia.org / wiki / Approximations_of_%CF%80(last symbol is "pi" symbol, if it doesn't show up here correctly)But, this error is NOT enough to penalize them by removing any stars.I understand the "Golden Ratio" and the "Golden Rectangle" much better based on this film, even if they say that the golden ratio is approximately 8 by 5 or eight fifths. Technically true, for the high school students that would also watch this, it would be helpful if they had given a more specific, if still irrational, value. Of course, students can easily double check the value on the Internet.Perhaps "Disney" included these mistakes so that the older students could do the work themselves to find the correct values.Can you learn from this animated movie?I'm 64. I got 800 for my math score on the SAT in 1968, and got 800 for quantitative scores on my GRE in 1976 and 1996. (My 1996 GRE scores qualified me for the Triple Nine Society.) In spite of my great math scores, I still learn from Donald in this film, which I vaguely recall, might have been the main feature on the first ever color broadcast of Walt Disney's television show.If I can learn more about math when I watch this, then so can you. I highly recommend this DVD to you.John, former teacher, M.S. EducationP.S. How do you create a golden rectangle? (see diagram)1. Draw a square (see red lines in diagram)2. Mark a point exactly in the middle of one side of the square.3. Set your compass to make a circle with a radius that is equal to the distance from that halfway point to one of the opposite corners. Draw an arc from that point that extends to the line that extends from the midpoint that you marked in step 2.4. Make a rectangle that uses the point where the circular arc intersects that extended line.These steps may look complicated, but the film makes it look easy. It also shows us many places in ancient and modern times where we can see golden rectangles and golden ratios.

I love these Pickled Eggs. I agree with the reviewer who reminds us what PICKLED means. The hard boiled eggs actually are put in a vinegar solution that also contains other flavors and optional coloring. So yes, pickled eggs will taste like vinegar. That is part of what makes these "pickled". As Merriam-Webster (dot com) can verify (I just looked it up by googling "define pickled"), pickled means: preserved with salt water or vinegarWhen we preserve something in vinegar, the vinegar is partially absorbed by the food, like the egg in this case. In fact, the pickling process continues until you remove an egg from the jar and eat it.I bought some today at Wal-Mart for just a bit over a buck (plus tax) for two eggs in an airtight plastic package. I've already inhaled the contents of one package, though I learned that I also need to have something to drink on hand while eating the eggs.I came to Amazon to see if they carry it, and did not see it. I hope that they will start carrying these convenient two-packs, which you can see below.I highly recommend Big John's Pickled (Vinegary) Eggs

Yes, this is very true. Some college majors require a course called Music Appreciation. The better you know classical music, who wrote what, etc., the higher a grade that you might get. Even if it's not required, it might be a good elective. Amazon even sells textbooks for Music Appreciation, such as Music Appreciation CUSTOM textbook for Eastern Kentucky University (Course number MUH 171 Edition).This album, and similar ones, are great for classical introductions. I highly recommend them. (But don't get the book unless you know your kids might go to EKU.)I highly recommend you add classical music to your home's music appreciation medley. Eventually, your kids will thank you.

I'm sure that these are great for some people, but I never used them once I got them. My good intentions went awry. I should never have ordered these.My advice to others like me:If you think that your legs have gotten fatter because of a medical condition, TALK TO YOUR DOCTOR FIRST. When I finally talked to a doctor and told him that I had compression socks, he said it might be okay to try them, but to limit myself to half an hour at a time.Be sure that you don't need to go far beyond the simplicity of wearing socks for what you have. In my case, I found out that I had something called edemas, water had collected in my legs and arms because my heart had gotten weaker after an attack that I never noticed. After 17 days in two hospitals, I have lost dozens of pounds; my arms and legs are nicely shaped again, not tight; and another certain part of my (male) body again looks like it did last year.Do not put off seeing a doctor if you are not sure of what is happening. You might just need these socks, but you might need something else.

On two occasions, I could not get out of my bathtub after a bath without lots of effort, and one time getting help from a visiting friend and two neighbors.That made me decide to get this product so that, the next time I take a bath (I usually shower), I will be able to get out by sliding my butt backward and upward onto these steps. The third step is the side of the tub, which you can see in my little picture.I highly recommend this Bath Step Seat, which fits perfectly in my tub, yet can be easily moved to outside the tub so you can soak more of yourself until you need the steps, etc.By the way, the picture I've included also shows my Tushies & Toes Long, Purple Rattan Bath Mat and Gear One Men's Rubber Slide Sandal Slipper Comfortable Shower Beach Shoe Slip On Flip Flop. Feel free to check them out to go with your new bath stairs seat.

These pineapple chunks are wonderful, and deserve five stars, but the cans leave something to be desired. I bought them because I read online that pineapple in your diet can help with your heart health. A month or so AFTER I read about that online, I discovered that I need to be careful because my pulse rate varies (controlled fibrillation). In fact, some DOLE cans even remind you that adding fruits and vegetables to your diet is good for your health. Bravo, Dole.Five of my cans were dented, but I ate the contents anyway. (Yes, I know that dented cans are a health risk under certain circumstances, such as a risk of salmonella.Most of the time, it felt like, the pop top broke off right after it had made the initial opening in the can, meaning I couldn't turn the can over to use a regular can opener. Imagine my surprise, later, when I read the fine print on the label and saw a statement telling me that if I had trouble with the pop top that I could do just that, turn the can over and use a regular opener. At least they're acknowledging that some people, even this original 98-pound weakling, now 64, might have trouble with pop tops. I found it was easy to start the process, but continuing to pull the lid off is where the tab usually broke off, then I had to use a knife or fork in the small initial opening to finish the job. I will probably go back to picking up my pineapple at Piggly-Wiggly rather than order through Amazon so that I know what I am going to get.In spite of the above, I highly recommend Dole's Pineapple Chunks.

I can only rave about this collection. If my parents were still with us, I'd buy it for them because, when I was a child, we watched LW every week. Remember, I was born in 1951, so these early shows are obviously in black and white. Back then, even the Adventures of Superman was in black and white and black and white televisions were the norm in homes that had TV at all. (My parents didn't get color TV until about 1969).If you have heard the term "Champagne Music," then you can thank Lawrence. Soap bubbles pop up in introductions, bringing back my fond memories of those nights with my family.If you are not sure if you'll enjoy this on DVD, check to see if it is still free on AMAZON PRIME. That's what I've been watching for the last 45 minutes and will keep watching most of this afternoon. (Six hours later, I finished both volume one and am almost done with volume two, but took a break for the news on TV.)I have attached a picture of when DODGE presented Lawrence Welk with a solid gold gavel after five years on the air.I highly recommend Lawrence Welk to everyone, even if you go for the free music on Amazon Prime.

Parsley is a wonderful product. I got this to make TEA with, but got much more than I imagined I would get. This is a huge amount of parsley for the price in my opinion. It makes a wonderful tea, and can be used in cooking.As a tea, you can use a tea ball, such as Prepworks by Progressive Stainless Steel Mesh Tea Ball to steep the tea, just add boiling (or near boiling water). I think the tea tastes wonderful.Parsley Tea has a side effect that some people will love. It can act like a mild diuretic, helping a person with urination. But if you worry that fluid retention might be a problem in your life, see your doctor.My dad called parsley nature's toothbrush because, as it comes on your dinner plate at an old-fashioned restaurant, it can freshen your breath at the end of the meal. Parsley is a very misunderstood vegetable. It is the one item most likely not to be eaten on the dinner plate, but in its freshly picked form, it is a beautiful addition to the plate. Of course, for what I describe in this second paragraph, you'll want to get fresh parsley at the store, or ask for it at your restaurant if they didn't already put some on your plate. At one restaurant, my brother ordered tomatoes and parsley so often, they just started automatically bringing it to his table with the menus.Of course, parsley flakes can be used as an ingredient in your cooking.

This is a wonderful bargain in spite of the fact that is performed in another language.With this set of composition, Johann imagined each step of the journey that Jesus took during the last days of his physical existence on Earth, as described by Matthew in the first Gospel. Use Google to get the words, so you know better the meaning of each piece of music.I highly recommend this bargain (I could have bought five of these for the price that some restaurants charge for one of those fancy coffees) album that is, in itself, worth much more.

This album full of classical hits is definitely worth the investment in you and your children's future. For less than 2 cents each, you get 61 well known and superbly played numbers by a variety of classical composers, not just Bach.I grew up hearing classical music in my home, not just on the phonograph, but with my Mom taking me with her to the Symphony when Dad was preaching in another town on Season Ticket night (thank you, Springfield Symphony Orchestra in Ohio). Please play this album, and similar albums, in your house so your kids know what people created in our past. Yes, I grew up with the Beatles (I remember them on Ed Sullivan) but I love the Beatles and Classical Music with the same musical heart. I might find myself humming classical music or old rock music almost any day.I got this for a bargain price, and I hope that you can, too.

What can I say? If you love dance music, especially the oldies, you will love this album, and the price is right.If you THINK you hate dance music, but you are willing to plunk down a George Washington down on the counter, you can get all 100 of these songs for a penny each, and I bet you find a few that you love, or you might realize that you have found a new genre to enjoy, even if you only listen to it for a change of pace.I highly recommend this album to you.

I discovered this product because of an enthusiastic review in the Everyday Cheapskate column. (Just Google "Everyday Cheapskate Mary Hunt")This is obviously a great product. It is easy to understand the principles of the security it provides just by looking at the pictures. You can even imagine how hard it will be for you to do the installation by looking at the pictures.If you know that people could break in your house through weak doors, you can put this device on all of your doors, though most of us will have one door that we practically never engage it, if we have other members of the family who need to come in. But you can leave this security bar protecting all the doors that are rarely used, and of course, all but one of your doors protected when you are away from home.(Regarding that one door that you cannot protect with this door club when you are out of the house, be sure that door is your most visible door, and that it is, itself, a more secure than average door. For example, no window that can be broken, giving a thief the ability to reach through and unlock the door.)Obviously, this is a great choice for home security. For the price, it is your BEST choice.

Star Trek: The Next Generation (frequently abbreviated as ST:TNG) was controversial at the time of its release. Many people announced that they would boycott TNG because it did not star the old cast or because it did not use the same characters. Even William Shatner was against the new series, and in interviews, described the problems that the new cast was facing that never faced to old cast.What is ST:TNG? It is, as the next generation (or at least several generations later) after the original Star Trek (ST:TOS). It is 75 years later. Technology is better. The ship is the 1701D, three ships later than Kirk's original 1701 and 1701A. Originally, we know nothing about what happened to the 1701B or 1701C. So, if 25 years is one generation in an average family, and each ship letter is a generation, this new series could have been called,STAR TREK: THREE GENERATIONS LATERPeace has broken out between the Federation and the Klingons, though there are occasional problems. We now see that, just like the Federation includes many people who look different from each other, so does the Klingon federation, as we see a new race of Klingons (that require much more makeup than the original Klingons).Continuity is still a problem. Events in later seasons do not necessarily logically follow events in earlier episodes. For example, in one episode, one-half impulse power might allow the ship to move slowly out of the ship's berth at spacedock, while in another episode, one-half impulse power might be a significant fraction of the speed of light. But ST:TNG does do a better job with continuity than TOS or "Enterprise", but not as good as in Deep Space Nine (ST:DS9) or Voyager (ST:V)All in all, ST:TNG deserves all five stars in spite of the lacks I describe, but it is not the best science fiction show of its kind. No matter how much I love TNG (and Star Trek in general), I love "Babylon 5" even more. It had a five year story line that was planned out 100% in advance, planned out very logically I must say. If you have never seen it, please give it a chance, but when you do, start with "Season One" -- do not start with "In the Beginning" or the other prequel. Do an Internet search on "Babylon 5 viewing order" to figure out what order to watch it in.I highly recommend Star Trek, not only Season Six, but all seven seasons.

As I write this review, I am a patient at a hospital in South Carolina. This is a review of the "urinal" that they gave me so that we could measure my "output" with their help. This particular unit has part number "U-24" molded into the plastic. Amazon does not have "U-24" included in any of their results.In my opinion, the Medegen deluxe urinal, if it is indeed what I am using, is an average urinal for men to be able to use from their beds or from the edge of their bed. (So far, I'm using it from the edge of my bed and from the front edge of my chair cushion while it is necessary for the nurses to measure how much I urinate per day.)I cannot give it five stars because the opening in the top is the same size as the swelling that I am currently experiencing. I wish that the hospital or Amazon had this urinal with a wider opening.I also question the price, it seems to me that a machine-manufactured bottle should have a lower cost. Perhaps the price varies during the year.All in all, I'm happy with the unit, except for the reservations cited above.
If you are purchasing individual songs from this album, you do NOT need the "pitch" files. (unless you want to tune your MP3 player to the computer's oboe.)(But the rest of the album is great.)

I love every "Compleats" flavor that I've tried so far ...EXCEPT THIS ONENormally, Roast Beef and Mashed Potatoes are okay parts of my diet, but these mashed potatoes felt rough on my tongue, like there were tiny crystals of hard substance mixed in.And for the first few bites, the roast beef were okay, but almost immediately, I felt sick, and lost the liquid part of that lunch. The cats outside loved the mixture of Compleats and my 'reaction" to that flavor.I will not be trying this flavor again. I hope it was just a fluke, one box with problems, but I'll go back to Turkey and Dressing, Chicken Alfredo and others of my favorite flavors.

This is a great product!  The idea is similar to standard hook-and-loop fasteners, like Velcro, but there are two very important differences:First, the parts that function the way Velcro does are mushroom-shaped.  This makes them cling MUCH better than any hook-and-loop product.  I can't imagine any vibration that would be strong enough to shake a phone, radio, etc. loose once it was fastened with this product.Second, the adhesive that sticks the closure strips to the dashboard or whatever is high-temperature.  It will maintain its grip in a hot car or in direct sunlight.  Typical hook-and-loop tape will let go at some point when it gets hot enough.There is one potential downside:  The fasteners grip so tightly that you can't just pull whatever you have mounted off, as you can with regular hook-and-loop.  It takes some real effort and a bit of time.If you need a Velcro-type gripping system that REALLY sticks together regardless of vibration and that won't let go in the heat, this is the stuff for you.  I recommend it most highly.

These are outstanding safety glasses at a good price.I have a couple of pair of good safety glasses, but they aren't tinted, so they aren't good for any length of time outside.  These glasses are actually dark-tinted sunglasses with UV block rating.  The result is no glare at all and no squinting.In addition, they're extremely comfortable.  They fit snugly without pinching, and they have foam around the lenses that does a good job keeping sawdust, pollen, etc. out of my eyes.  They look and feel very sturdy, but at the same time, they're very light.  Finally, they come with both over the ear frames and a headband, so if I need real goggles, I can have them in about 30 seconds.  There's a fabric bag to hold everything.One important proviso:  There is no way to order prescription lenses for these glasses, and they're not large enough for regular glasses to fit underneath them.  If you need prescription glasses, shop for a different product.Bottom line:  These are really nice glasses at a very good price.  I recommend them most highly.

Roundup Weed and Grass Killer kills weeds and grass.  That pretty much says it all.  It's an excellent product, and Amazon offers it at an very good price.The most notable thing about Roundup is that kills weeds very quickly.  Apply it in the morning, and the target weeds are looking pretty unhealthy by sunset and dead in a few days.  That, of course, is what you want in a weed killer.  Further, this is a premixed product with a pump dispenser.  This means if you see something sprouting, you can just spritz it immediately, without the need to mix something, put it into a sprayer, clean the sprayer afterward, etc.Now, there's an 800-pound gorilla in the room:  The active ingredient in Roundup is glyphosphate, which the World Health Organization has described as "probably carcinogenic to humans.  Some research links it to other serious health conditions, too.  However, the WHO is referring to dangers associated with large-scale agricultural use, not garden clean up.  Common sense tells you not to spray yourself with it, let kids roll around on plants you've sprayed, etc.  Like every other chemical, if you pay attention to the instructions, you'll be OK.Bottom line:  This stuff works very well.  There's nothing else I've seen that's better, safer, or lower priced.

Since this is pretty much a "Brand X" blade, there's a temptation to assume that it's going to be sub-par in quality.  Happily, that's not the case.  This is good quality at a good price.The blade will cut through wood, metal, and PVC with apparent ease.  Oscillating tool blades are notoriously fragile and quick-wearing.  This one seems to be tougher and more resilient than the name-brand blades I've bought.  I've used it quite a lot, and the teeth seem as sharp as they were when I installed it.  More importantly, it hasn't shed any teeth yet, something I've had name-brand blades do within seconds of their first use.The package says it fits all oscillating tools.  I don't know about that, but it fits my Bosch tool fine.Bottom line:  It seems to be a very good product at a very good price.  When I need more blades, I'll happily buy this one again-- and others by the same manufacturer, too.

I'm not a Deadhead, but I am a fan of the Grateful Dead's music.  I also enjoy insider books by rock 'n' rollers.  That's why I was eager to read Bill Kreutzmann"s book.  The subtitle promises that it details his "three decades of drumming, dreams, and drugs."  I liked the book, but the focus of the book is on the drugs, not the drumming and dreaming.Kreutzmann was a founding member of the Dead, present at ground zero when the psychedelic San Fransisco sound exploded into being in the sixties.  He knew and worked with all of the big names, like Carlos Santana, Janis Joplin, the Jefferson Airplane, the Quicksilver Messenger Service and on and on.  Can you imagine the things he saw and the stories he could tell?"Could" is the operative term here.  Unfortunately for us-- and even more so for him-- he was stoned for most of his career.  In addition, of course, he didn't know nearly fifty years ago that he'd be writing a history some day, so he didn't keep records of what happened.  The result of that combination is a rambling, discursive book with many, many vague, fuzzy spots.In the end, it's a cautionary tale.  Kreutzmann repeatedly tells us that the band's and his personal drug use negatively affected their music, their finances, and most importantly, their health.  The Dead lost four keyboardists to drug-related health issues, and Jerry Garcia died in his early 50s, a sick, old man who could barely stand up on stage.  One wonders what they could have done if they had been recreational drug users, rather than helpless junkies.  Of course, it's possible to argue that the music wouldn't have been the same without the heavy drug use.  It's hard to know.  However, Kreutzmann's account makes it clear that the drugs took a toll.Structurally, the book is a bit frustrating. It's arranged chronologically, but very frequently, it veers out of order.  The co-author, Benjy Eisen, is a professional journalist, so he should have been able to smooth out the narrative.  He didn't.Bottom line:  I liked the book, and I recommend it.  It's certainly not one of the great rock histories, but it is a look inside of one of the most influential bands in rock history, told by one of the few people in a position to know what he's talking about.

This is excellent tea.  I'm more of a coffee drinker, but I like the occasional cup of tea.  However, I don't care for the process-- and the mess-- of making it.  This tea in a K-cup solves that problem.The tea is very nice.  It has a complex combination of flavor hints, but none of them are sharp or cloying.  The name "Cream Earl Grey" is well chosen.  Tea can be somewhat astringent, but this one is not.  It's smooth, rich, and tasty.Bottom line:  I really like the flavor of this tea, and I love the convenience.  I will happily buy more when I run out.

This little sleeve works, but I keep wondering why anyone should bother with it.It's a nylon fabric sleeve with a wire stiffener and a zipper.  The idea is that you stuff a cable or two into it, zip it up, and then...  Well, that's the question.  According to the product insert, you could wrap it around your wrist, you could twist it into a sort of phone stand, or you could make a golf tee out of it.  Sure.It works fine, but I honestly can't think of any reason to have it, especially at about $12 a pop right now on Amazon.  It's a solution in search of a problem-- and not likely to find one.

This is an outstanding shaving cream.  It produces a lot of the rich, long-lasting lather that is essential for a good shave.  That's really it.  The stuff works exactly like you've always hoped shaving cream would work.The instructions on the bottle say to use an almond-sized dab on your brush, but I've found that about half that amount-- maybe a pencil eraser-sized dab-- does the trick.  That means this little bottle will last a long, long time.  They claim 50 shaves, but based on how much I've used so far, I expect to get many more.  That, of course, makes the apparent high cost of a bottle justifiable.  On a per-shave basis, it's a very good deal.It would be possible to use it without a shaving brush, but I think that would be far less satisfying.  The brush allows you to work up a heavy lather and to spread it around evenly.  Definitely buy a brush if you're using this cream.Bottom line:  This is an EXCELLENT product that works exactly as it should.  I recommend it most highly.

Imagine what would happen today if there were six or eight domestic groups of political radicals who decided to start bombing public and corporate buildings at the rate of one blast per day.  Well, that's exactly what was happening in the US from the early '70s through the mid-'80s, and this book is the story of how it happened.It is a remarkable account, one based on years of interviews with the radicals who were underground doing the bombing and the FBI agents and local police officials who were trying to catch them.  Many of these people have kept silent about what they did for decades.  It's hard to imagine the effort the author went to trying to craft an understandable narrative from all of those interviews.  Everyone involved-- including law enforcement-- was very secretive, and no one had an understanding of what was happening beyond his or her portion of the activities.  Add the passage of decades, and the raw material the book is based on must have been a confusing mess.  Despite that, the book is a tightly-organized, fast-paced work that reads like a fictional thriller.  It's a remarkable achievement.One of the take-aways from the book-- and a difficult one to grasp-- is that these tiny groups of revolutionaries were serious.  In fact, deadly serious.  They sincerely believed that eight or ten people planting bombs in office building bathrooms would become a revolutionary vanguard that would cause the people to rise up, overthrow the fascist power structure, and create a socialist workers paradise.  It's hard to even type that with a straight face.  However, these people not only believed it and said it, they lived it.  Of course, there wasn't anything funny about all of this.  Their bombs killed people and did millions of dollars worth of damage, and they robbed dozens of banks to finance their revolutionary lives.  In addition, they ambushed and assassinated a number of police officers.Back in the anti-Vietnam war '60s, there was a poster that said, "Suppose they gave a war and nobody came."  A similar poster for the times described in this book would say, "Suppose they gave a revolution and nobody came.  In fact, nobody even noticed."  That's the final irony here.  These people were so completely absorbed in their own beliefs and perceptions that they didn't know that no one-- almost literally so-- even noticed.This book is a fascinating and valuable account of a now nearly forgotten period in modern American history.  It will richly repay you for the effort of reading it.  I recommend it most highly.

This hook is a perfect example of excellent design:  It does a small, simple thing very well.It's very well made and even attractive.  It's perfectly suited to hang over a closet or bathroom door when you need to hang a towel or article of clothing.  It's thin enough that any door should be able to close with the hook in place.  It's even made with softer plastic on the points where it contacts the door, so it shouldn't mar any paint or finish.It's not designed for heavy duty use.  Clothes on two or three hangers, a couple of bath towels, a coat-- all of those will work fine.  But you wouldn't want to put a dozen full hangers on it.  Like all tools and equipment, you have to know the limits.Bottom line:  A perfectly designed item at a good price.  I recommend it most highly.

This is a great laminator.  It's compact, inexpensive, and exceptionally easy to use.  Plug it in, turn it on, wait a couple of minutes for it to warm up, and feed the lamination pouch into the rollers.  It couldn't be any easier.  If it were to jam (which it hasn't yet), there's a release lever that allows the lamination pouch to be released.  It is important to understand that this is a light-duty, home machine.  It's not suitable for large projects or heavy usage.Bottom line:  If you need a home lamination machine for occasional projects, it would be hard to beat this one.  I recommend it most highly.

These are good covers, which are a cut above the cheap heavy paper covers that are so common.  However, there's nothing about them I'd call "elegant" or "professional.  They're just good reports covers.  They are three-hole-punched heavy folders with a plastic front.  The plastic is described as "frosted," but it's really just slightly cloudy.  The back cover has several precut places for inclusions, business cards, etc.I'd describe these covers as good but not exceptional.

These are excellent shears.  Fiskars is, of course, one of the major names in scissors and shears, and for good reason.  Their products are precision instruments.  That's the case here.These shears look and feel like ordinary scissors.  They're not bulky shears with thick, hard to maneuver blades.  But they cut like heavy shears.  That's because they have a new kind of pivot point/hinge.  It senses when you're cutting something heavy, and it exerts extra leverage if that's the case.  The result is smooth cuts with fairly modest effort.You can cut heavy materials, such as burlap and leather.  It might even be possible to cut light sheet metal, but I don't want to experiment and risk damage to the shears.Bottom line:  This is an excellent piece of precision equipment at a moderate price.  I recommend them most highly.

This book is a mystery/thriller, so I don't want to say much about the plot.  However, it is a fast-paced thriller that would make it a great vacation or airplane trip read.This is the fourth book in which David Levien has featured Frank Behr, a former cop afflicted with various personal problems who is now working as a private eye.  He depends on cooperation from the cops, who don't like him much and threaten him regularly when he interferes with them.  If that sounds familiar, it is.  This formula has been exploited by many other writers.  Lawrence Block's Matt Scudder novels are the gold standard for me.  In my view, Levien executes the book well, but he's not quite up to Block's level.Part of the problem for me was that at several key points in the story, the author mentions something that clearly was described in one of the three earlier books, something that has a major impact on Behr's thinking and feelings.  Of course, he can't retell the earlier stories, but without some detail, it's impossible to really understand what's going on in Behr's mind.  I was left puzzled about why Behr was thinking or doing something and irritated that I'd have to read three other books to find the answer.Another issue for me was the gore factor.  The bad guy is a psycho serial killer, and Levien establishes that by ratcheting up the blood and gore.  Blood and gore don't bother me that much, but at a certain point, it loses it's power to indicate evil.  James Patterson does psycho serial killers very well by making them well rounded characters, not merely by piling up dismembered body parts.  I think Levien could learn something from that.Bottom line:  I thought the book was well worth reading.  It's very fast paced and filled with twists and turns.  It's not the best book of its type, but it's definitely a great page-turner.

These removable hooks are a very good value compared to the much more familiar name-brand Command product.  You get about twice as many for the same cost.  However, there are some things to be aware of:First, it's extremely important to follow the instructions about cleaning and drying the mounting surface.  They will stick to a slightly non-compiant surface, but not very well.  In addition, if the surface has much of a texture, they probably won't work as well as you might hope.  This is important, because they have a weight rating.  I found that the 1-pound hooks I got held 1 pound, but not very much more without letting go.  I assume the same would be true for the higher-rated hooks, too.In addition, these are more functional than attractive.  The hook is chrome metal, and the removal tab sticks out past the bottom of the base very noticeably.  This doesn't affect their workability at all, but you do need to think about it if they're going to be visible in an area where appearance is important to you.Finally, the hooks are most certainly removable, but they're not relocatable.  That is, be sure you're putting it exactly where you want it.  You'll be able to remove it with no problem, but you can't use the hook you've removed again.  (By the way, the hooks come off without a trace of adhesive left behind on the wall.)Bottom line:  They work fine, but they're not as attractive as the more familiar name brand product is.  It will come down to a cost versus appearance issue.  In my view, they're definitely a good value, but I wouldn't put them up in every room.

This gizmo is designed to keep hair and other debris from going down bathtub drains that have "pop up" drain plugs.  It's a flexible, perforated, silicone dome, weighted so it won't float off of the drain.  Generally, it does what it's designed to do.However, it's very easy to accidentally kick it off of the drain when you're showering.  You won't realize you've done that until you look down at the drain.  When it stays in place on the drain, the perforations are small enough that the water will begin to pool.  You can end up nearly ankle-deep in it by the time your shower is over.  Finally, when the water drains away, you need to clean the hair and other debris off of the strainer, which isn't very pleasant.Bottom line:  It works the way it's designed to, and it's well made.  However, there are some usability issues that may or may not be important to you.

Fear of speaking in public is very common.  In fact there are surveys that apparently show it to be the most common fear.  The good news is that there is a readily available, effective, and even low-cost way to reduce that fear: Toastmasters International.  This book is a collection of short essays by and about people who have overcome their fears by joining Toastmasters.Good for them, but so what?  The "so what" is that as many of them say, if they can do it, everyone can do it.  In fact, the author, Sheryl Roush, says that about herself, too.  That's what these stories are about.  Toastmasters works near-miracles for those who take the program seriously.  If you want or need to become a more competent speaker and want to feel more comfortable when you speak, then join one of the 16,000 Toastmasters clubs in over 120 countries around the world.  Read this book first, though, and you'll see what membership has done for many others just like you.This book will richly reward you for the time and effort it takes to read it.

I really like Ridley Pearson's books, particularly "Beyond Recognition," which I think is a classic in the thriller genre.  That's why I was disappointed in "The Red Room."I started it, but couldn't get into it.  It seemed to be an episode in a longer story, rather than an independent story.  I thought that reading the first two books in the "Risk Agent" series might help, so I found "Risk Agent" and "Choke Point" in the library.  The first was OK, but I couldn't finish the second.  For me, the problem is that those two books and "The Red Room" are indeed all part of one story.  Unfortunately, the story-- and worse, the characters-- are one-dimensional.  John Knox and Grace Chu take on mysterious assignments and run around a lot, eying people in restaurants to see if they have sinister intent, getting stalked and stalking bad guys, moving from hotel room to hotel room to stay out of the clutches of the bad guys, beating people up and getting beaten up, and endlessly chasing people and being chased.  The only real difference among the three books is that they are set in different exotic cities.This isn't to say that they're badly written.  They're not; I don't think Ridley Pearson could write badly.  It's just that they're not good enough to capture my interest and hold it to the end.Of course, interest in thrillers is highly individual.  My gem can be your steaming pile of do-do.  All I can say is that for me, this book and the two that precede it in the series are OK genre are OK but no better.  And they just don't measure up to what I know Ridley Pearson is capable of.

Of course, coffee reviews are completely subjective.  My nectar of the gods might be your swill.  However, I think Smile Jamaica is very good coffee.I'm actually a little surprised.  The description and packaging are more than a little cutesy, with Bob Marley quotations, tropical colors, etc.  The coffee inside is the real deal, though.  The product blurb promises "...a rich flavor, balanced acidity and full body..." that "...leaves a sweet, mellow, lingering finish."  Yep, that's exactly what I experienced.I'd happily order more-- except for one thing, the thing that accounts for my 4-star rating, rather than 5-star: The price.  Right now, Amazon offers a box of 24 K-cups for $24.95 plus $4.99 shipping.  Just under $1.25 EACH?!  Yikes.  It's good coffee-- really good, in fact-- but I'll have to think about whether it's good enough to justify that price.  You will, too.

I buy the Best American Sports Writing every year, and it's always worth the price.  Of course, some years are better than others, and that's due to a unique feature of the series:  Every year, there is a different guest editor.  This year's editor, Christopher McDougall, has done an excellent job.Sports writing has always had a difficult time being taken seriously.  Indeed, there are those who claim that writing about what amount to kid games is trivial and amounts to nothing more than reporting the details of those games.  However, the writing in this collection focuses on events at the intersection of kid games and the darker side of the "real world," and there were some major happenings at that intersection during the year.The collection features stories about the Boston Marathon bombing, the Aaron Hernandez murder investigation, the head injury controversies that are consuming football and boxing, and so on.  Further, most of the essays are character-driven.  That is, they focus on the people involved in the events, not simply on the details of the events.  The result is stories that capture one's attention and that remain memorable.This collection demonstrates something that most of us have known all along:  Good sports writing is simply good writing.  This is an excellent addition to the series, and I recommend it most highly.

I buy the Best American Essays every year, and it's always worth the price.  Some years are better than others, and that's due to a unique feature of the series:  There is a different guest editor every year.  This year's guest editor, John Sullivan, has done an excellent job.Having said that, though, I found that the twenty or so essays in the collection were darker and heavier than has been the case in recent past years.  Many of them deal with difficult topics, such as child abuse and neglect, aging and dying, and racism.  The essays were generally shorter than in past years, too, and this, I think, concentrated the effect they had on me.  It's not that I enjoy reading "misery memoirs"; rather, these particular examples had impact.  They were memorable.  I still think about them.Despite what we constantly hear, the essay is not dead as a literary form.  This collection is ample proof of that, and I recommend it most highly.

I buy the Best American Short Stories every year, and though some years are better than others, it's always worth the price.  Of course, that variation is due to a unique feature of the series:  There is a different guest editor every year.  This year's guest editor, Jennifer Egan, has done a very good job.Her "bias" seemed to be for strong characters, people who fix on a principle or a habit and just won't let go.  That, I think, is why more of the twenty or so stories seem memorable to me.  I cared about the characters, what they were doing, and-- most importantly-- why they were doing what they were doing.This is an exceptional addition to the annual series.  I recommend it most highly.

This is a great little table at a fabulous price.  I was a little worried that it might be cheap and flimsy, but it's the opposite.  It looks and feels like a table that would cost three or four times as much in a furniture store.  It does require assembly, but the wrench is included, and it goes together easily.Bottom line:  It's a great little occasional table, and a real bargain.  I recommend it most highly.
This is a well-made utility bag at a very good price.  I bought it to hold a reconditioned tool that came with no carrying case.  I'm very satisfied with my purchase, and I recommend the bag highly.

Waterworks is a classic game from the '70s.  It's simple to learn, doesn't take long to play, and-- most importantly-- stays fun, even after repeated games.  This makes it ideal to fill a few spare minutes.Bottom line:  Fun at a great price.  I recommend it it highly.

This is a very valuable book.  My wife was recently diagnosed with diabetes, and we wanted a readable yet authoritative overview and reference.  This is it.The book is clearly written, and it's very easy to find specific topics in it.  It covers all of the basics:  What diabetes is, what causes it, what the effects are, how it's treated, and so on.  The book is aimed for the non-expert reader, the person who wants to know what's going on and what to do about it.  It doesn't talk down or up.  An important part of that is the tone.  Diabetes is a serious condition that needs to be taken seriously.  However, a diagnosis is no reason to panic.Bottom line:  This is a great, practical reference book, particularly for the newly diagnosed diabetic.  I recommend it most highly.

This is a simple reference card, but a very useful one.  All of the important features and commands for Pages are gathered on one easy-to-use, laminated card.  No more leafing through a reference book when you need to know how to do something right now.It's a perfect blend of function and price.  I recommend it most highly.

This is a simple reference card, but a very useful one.  All of the important features and commands for Numbers are gathered on one easy-to-use, laminated card.  No more leafing through a reference book when you need to know how to do something right now.It's a perfect blend of function and price.  I recommend it most highly.

This is a simple reference card, but a very useful one.  All of the important features and commands for Keynote are gathered on one easy-to-use, laminated card.  No more leafing through a reference book when you need to know how to do something right now.It's a perfect blend of function and price.  I recommend it most highly.

This is an amazing book for anyone who loves maps.  It's a coffee-table book, and it should be.  It's the kind of book that you'll open when you get near it.The maps make up the vast majority of the book, which, of course, they should.  Each map is accompanied by text that discusses the cartographer, the historical context, and the significance of the map.  The maps are arranged in chronological order, and that allows the reader to see the progression of exploration and of the craft and science of cartography.  Most of the maps have a "zoom-in" feature, which focuses on particular parts of the map.  These are extremely interesting and useful, because they draw attention to something in the maps that might otherwise go unnoticed.This book is a fabulous resource for anyone interested in history.  It's also a beautifully crafted book.  I recommend it most highly.

This set of three smoke detectors is an excellent buy.  It could be a life-saving buy.Photoelectric smoke alarms are the best kind to have because they're far better at detecting smoldering fires than the older ionization alarms.  This is important because smoldering fires account for the majority of fire fatalities,  Further, most people don't know that all smoke alarms lose their sensitivity gradually.  After about ten years, they should be replaced.These units are very small.  Unlike the soup-dish size smoke alarms all of us are familiar with, these little units are about 2 inches in diameter, and they'll stick out from the wall or down from the ceiling about 2 inches.  They're a neutral off-white color.Everything you need-- the units, batteries, mounting hardware, and detailed instructions-- is included.My bottom line:  This set of smoke alarms is an excellent buy, one that could save your life.

The "Teach Yourself Visually..." series has always featured excellent, easyt-to-use guides.  This book, however, is a strange and disappointing addition to that series.First, the good:  The material is excellent, though it is clearly intended for those who are completely new to OSX.  It's a hand-holding guide to the basic operations of the operating system.  I can picture someone who's never seen a Mac sitting down with this book and learning how to make it do what they need done.  However, anyone who wants any depth needs to know that these books simply don't offer it.  Those who want detailed guides would be far better off buying "OSX Mavericks: the Missing Manual," by David Pogue.Now, the bad:  The production values for this book are terrible.  Every other "Teach Yourself Visually..." manual I've ever seen features clear color screen shots.  The whole point of these books is that the user can read what to do and then see what the screen should look like.  Unfortunately, in this book, the screen shots are black-and-white; even worse, they're washed out, as if they were several generation old photocopies.  This makes the screen shots very, VERY difficult to use.  You simply cannot see most of them clearly enough.My bottom line:  Buy a different guide to OSX.  The material in this one is excellent, but the production values for the book render it nearly unusable.

These Sparco Hanging Name badge holders are designed to hold a 4 X 3 printed name tag.  They work just like the Avery equivalent, but they're only about half the price of the Avery item.  That alone makes them a must-have purchase when you're preparing a set of name tags for a conference.I recommend them most highly.

I bought this watch for my wife, and she loves it.  Of course, whether it looks good is entirely a matter of personal preference.  She likes the look a lot.The real benefit is the Eco-Drive technology.  The dial is the collector for the battery.  When the watch is exposed to light-- natural or artificial-- the battery is being charged.  The result is that there's no battery replacement at all.  (My own Eco-Drive watch is nearly 15 years old, and it's still working fine.)  This watch replaced my wife's previous Eco-Drive watch.  It was running well, but the clasp wore out and couldn't be replaced.Bottom line:  This is a mature, time-tested technology for powering watches.  It works perfectly.  In addition, the watch is very good looking.  I recommend it most highly.

This is a tape measure, but one with a difference.  When you measure something, it, of course shows you how long the item is.  However, just below the measurement, it also shows you what the center measurement would be.  This is EXTREMELY useful.Think how frustrating it is to be centering a picture on a wall that's 75 inches long.  You can calculate it, of course, but that's not very easy to do with confidence when you;re standing there with the tape stretched out and a pencil in your mouth.  With this tape, you just look at the red number below the 75 inch indicator, and you can see that the midpoint on the wall is at 37 .It saves a lot of frustration, and I recommend it most highly.

Nanoblock kits are oddly relaxing, a way to spend a few pleasant hours.  They look just like Legos, but they're quite a bit smaller.  The package says they're suitable for kids over 8, but the tiny size of the blocks would probably make them very frustrating for young kids.This Sydney Opera House kit is more complex than most, but it's fun to build, and it looks great when it's done.Highly recommended.

This Iwwin folding utility knife is a a very good tool.  I've always had good experiences with Irwin tools, and this knife seems to be well made, too.It's quite heavy, because it's made almost entirely out of metal.  The hinge/locking mechanism seems very rugged, with no looseness at all.  The blade locks securely in the holder.  There's a nice safety feature, too.  The blade can only be removed or inserted with the knife locked in a partially opened position.  I can't see how it could come out unexpectedly.The only issue I can see with this knife isn't a design or operational flaw at all.  Since this is a folding knife, it seems likely that if it were used for something like scoring cuts in sheetrock, the dust and grit could gunk up the mechanism.  It would be pretty simple to clean out, but it would still need to be cleaned regularly.Bottom line:  This is an attractive, well-made pocket tool that looks like it will provide many years of service.

Excellent coffee!  Both flavors are bright, refreshing, real coffee drinks.  I'd happily buy either one of these, if it weren't for one thing: the price.  Even here on Amazon, the pods currently run well over $1 each.  Yikes!  Now, no one buys a K-cup machine to save money, but these are about the most costly pods I've seen.  You'lkl have to decide for yourself if the excellent taste justifies the cost.  For me, it doesn't.

These pods are NOT designed for use in a standard K-cup system.  They're about 1/4 inch shorter than a real K-cup pod, so the needle at the bottom of the holder won't pierce the pod.  I think the designers believed that the coffee would come out of the sides of the pod, but it doesn't.  The result was a mess to clean up.

I buy "The Best American Mystery Stories" every year, and this year's edition is an excellent addition to the series.Other reviewers have commented on specific stories, and-- no surprise-- everyone has different favorites.  Several reviewers have commented that the selection seems inconsistent to them.  Well, yes.  It is, after all, a collection of stories selected by an individual editor.  It would be very surprising to find universal agreement about the wisdom of his or her choices every year.For me, the significance of this collection every year is that it in effect takes the pulse of the mystery writing fraternity.  In my view, the pulse this year is strong, and the fraternity is healthy.  Every year, the series editor, Otto Penzler, reminds us that the definition of mystery is quite broad.  That's true this year, as well, and the stories range from what I'd call literary fiction to classic noir stories.  For me, this is a strength.  It allows me to read some stories I probably wouldn't have considered as mysteries if I had been leafing through the magazines that contained them.I think some of the stories are much stronger than others, but the collection as a whole is very strong.  It's a great read, and I recommend it most highly.

Being a pragmatist, I initially thought that this rack would have been so much better if it were square or rectangular and included more holes. My wife disagreed, and is probably right. Her argument was that were not going to be making 22 stuffed peppers for ourselves. In other words, if were using the capacity of the rack, were probably entertaining; and if were entertaining she feels that the form and presentation is as important as the function. Like I said, shes probably right.As far as function, the rack works quite well in the grill. Just be sure that if your grill has a bun toaster or similar half-rack, mind the spacing. I know that if I were not careful, there is a good chance that my stuffed peepers could become unstuffed in short order. Because the peppers are inserted into the rack vertically, if the temperature is consistent within the grill, the issue of one over cooked side can largely be avoidedand, of course, the stuffing wont fall out. The only relative downside is that the holes in the rack are all the same size, so, unless your peppers are uniformly sized within a fairly narrow band of diameters, there is a risk that they will be too big or too small to utilize the rack.All in all, its a neat little tool that adds some fun to a gathering.

The central heat in our house is such that by setting the thermostat to a point that my wife and I would feel comfortably warm on a cold night in our master bedroom, our sons room is transformed into a veritable sauna. Obviously, we would rather be a little chilly than force this upon our child, so we needed a solution. This heater is our solution.So far weve only had one night cool enough to necessitate its use, but it worked like a charm. Our master bedroom is about 12x20x10 and the Honeywell was more than enough to supplement our central system. Whats more, because of the thermostat on the space heater, we didnt wake up drenched in sweat. It seemed to maintain a fairly consistent temperature throughout the night. I also liked that I could operate the necessities of the unit from bed with the included remote.We have two dogs that sleep in our room at night, and tend to seek out the warm spots. I was a bit concerned that they would curl up next to the unit and activate the motion sensing automatic shut-off. Luckily, they would need to get  and stay  pretty close to the unit for it to turn off and stay off; it seems like the threshold is a few inches. So all in all, Im glad that the safety feature is there, but its not so sensitive that it prevent normal operation.I will say that I dont know if this particular unit would have the juice to heat our entire room if we didnt also have our central system piping in the slightest amount of warmth. That being said, if one is going to try to provide some ambient heat with this unit in a larger  but enclosed  space, I would recommend a little circulation fan like Honeywell TurboForce Fan, HT-900, as well. We have one in our room, and I feel like it provided more of an envelope of heat than the hairdryer effect.

Im sure that anyone other than the most diehard AC fans will be a little hesitant to pick up this latest installment in the franchise if they had early release exposure to Unity. Well, I dont mind saying that  although its not quite at Black Flag status  this is a needed win for AC. That is, it suffers from no more glitches than one would expect from any other newly released title, it captures what has been enjoyable about the AC series from the beginning, and it adds a few new factors to remind you that youre playing a new title.Nothing is shockingly different about the gameplay of Syndicate, but the addition of a rope launcher (it is what it sounds like), and the folding-in of a twin character that essentially divides the main character into two slightly different characters adds enough of a different flavor to justify its addition into to ones library. While the environment does not alter the gameplay experience as drastically as that of Black Flag, the time period chosen seems to fit the heart of the AC series well; it also adds a bit of relevant socioeconomic commentaryif thats your cup of tea.If you have enjoyed Assassins Creed at its best, Syndicate will not let you down. It provides the stunning graphics and enjoyable storyline that fans have grown accustomed to, without the fatal glitches that plagued Unity.

Our son is two and a half, and loves dinosaurs. Although he hasnt seen the movie yet  just the product commercials and film trailers  he is also in love with the kid friendly dinosaur characters from The Good Dinosaur movie. So when his mother and I broke out this game, he was thrilled. Honestly, though, even if it were a terrible game, he probably would have been thrilled. Luckily, for us, I think the game is pretty novel.In reading some of the other reviews I noticed that many people seem to be familiar with the cooperative game model. For me this was a first. Its not that I dont enjoy participating in some goodhearted competition with my family, but this game was a nice change of pace. I think the cooperative nature of the game also made it easier for us to play with our son  instead of just having to play for him in more complex competitive games. The format seemed to get him much more involved and appeared to add to his overall enjoyment in the activity. I suppose seeing him contribute to the team also made it a little more fun for his mother and me, too. After all, one can only derive satisfaction from demolishing a two-year-old in checkers so many times.The game itself is simplistic and a little shaky at times, but I think it is perfect for parents that want to engage in an everybody wins or everybody loses game with their small children.

Its neat that these AAs contain recycled batteries. Its also great that theyre Energizers longest lasting alkaline battery.At the time that this review is being written, a twelve pack of these batteries will set you back $16.72 and Energizer Max AA batteries, 12 Count is priced at $8.79. To me, this begs the question: if these batteries cost nearly twice as much as Energizers comparable alkaline product, do they last nearly twice as long, or are they nearly twice as beneficial to the environment (depending on the factor you plug into your personal impact-on-environment utility formula)?From my own experience, I do not believe that these batteries last anywhere close to twice as long. Compounding an apparent lack of value, while I wish I knew the difference in environmental impact between these batteries and the Max product, I have to imagine that including 4% recycled material  although a positive  does not justify such a price jump. I cant help but think that the $8 one could save by buying the Max batteries could do more environmental good if redirected toward some specific cause, if one were so inclined.Recycling batteries is great! Unfortunately, unless the price comes down quite a bit, this will be the last pack of these batteries I own.

I have developed a bit of a passion for taking pictures of the sky; particularly interesting clouds. I knew that I would be well served to pick up a decent polarizer, but I have only ever had experience with low-end products that created too many other problems to be functional, so I quit looking. This B+W polarizer is not low-end, and, therefore, not necessarily inexpensive, but its results are transformative.Prior to utilizing this polarizer, I was either getting light skies sans polarizer or various unwanted colorations from cheaper polarizers. With the B+W I am getting beautiful color saturation, allowing me to capture the photograph as I see it in my minds eye.This is the real deal. Now that Ive had the opportunity to utilize a higher end filter, I realize that Ive basically been throwing money away on poorly designed/constructed alternatives. I believe that I will be saving up to purchase B+W filters to slowly replace my current economy set of filters over time.I will add that, at the time that this review is being written, the B+W 52mm XS-Pro HTC Kaesemann Circular Polarizer with Multi-Resistant Nano Coating can actually be purchased for about the same price. I have had the opportunity to utilize both polarizers, and they seem to be identical in every way with the exception of the 8th nano-coating layer added, which purports to make the filter easier to clean. So before you pick up this great polarizer, you may want to investigate the cost of the nano-coated version.

I have developed a bit of a passion for taking pictures of the sky; particularly interesting clouds. I knew that I would be well served to pick up a decent polarizer, but I have only ever had experience with low-end products that created too many other problems to be functional, so I quit looking. This B+W polarizer is not low-end, and, therefore, not necessarily inexpensive, but its results are transformative.Prior to utilizing this polarizer, I was either getting light skies sans polarizer or various unwanted colorations from cheaper polarizers. With the B+W I am getting beautiful color saturation, allowing me to capture the photograph as I see it in my minds eye.This is the real deal. Now that Ive had the opportunity to utilize a higher end filter, I realize that Ive basically been throwing money away on poorly designed/constructed alternatives. I believe that I will be saving up to purchase B+W filters to slowly replace my current economy set of filters.

We have two little dogs, a Papillion mix and a Pomeranian. I mention this because the retraction strength on this leash is a little much for our five pound Pom, but no problem for our 12 pound Pap. I dont necessarily mind that it has a bit of tug to it  particularly towards the end of the extension capacity  because it seems to discourage too much pullinga little, anyway.One stand out feature is that this leash is tape-style for the entirety of its length; as opposed to tape-style for the first two feet and chord-style for the remaining length. I like this for two reasons. One, it feels more sturdy, like a traditional leash. Two, if the pup at the end of the leash gets tangled up between our  or our neighbors  legs, there is much less chance for the nasty rope burns that the chord-style leashes are notorious for. The primary drawbacks for this style leash is that it gives up about 5 to 7 feet in length to a similar sized chord-style leash, and, presumably because it takes a little more juice to get it reeled in, it has a little more resistance than a similar sized chord-style leash. The latter issue, as I mentioned before, might pose a problem for the smallest of pups.I also like the 3 action button on this leash. Its a little different than the various sliding/gliding locks that Ive experience on other leases because its just one solid button with, what I like to call, a clutch. I think its a little bit easier to use, but I fear that it might be more prone to future malfunction. Ill come back and update this review if my malfunction fears are ever realized.All in all, its a great little leash that feels comfortable in the hand, is easy to operate, and does its job well!

First of all, if youre reading this, I strongly recommend that you read the review of this knife by Storm. Storm obviously knows their stuff. As for my own, less knowledgeable, opinion; this knife is not worth the $140 that it is listed for at the time that this review is being written.I suspected as soon as I was able to see and handle the packaging in which the knife arrived that this knife is a high margin product for the manufacturer that is meant to look expensive, but did not cost much to produce. Once I held the knife itself in my hands, my initial feelings were confirmed. The balance and form of the knife was all wrong. I have handled a few very nice chef and utility knives, and each felt like they were meant to be used. That is, their balance point and ergonomics promoted ease of use with regard to the typical functions one might expect to use them for. This knife, on the other hand, has the balance of a discount bin hatchet.While it might feel like a $5 hatchet, it looks like an expensive knife. However, for a hundred and forty dollars  if looks are ones goal  it might be possible to pick up a mother of pearl knife that is actually mother of pearl and not acrylic.The one positive that this knife has going for it as a cutting instrument, is that it has a pretty great edge right out of the box. Unfortunately, this edge doesnt hold for too longand then youre just left with a very expensive, albeit attractive, lower-middle of the line knife.Im disappointed. I think it is worth maybe $50 to $60 dollars on the basis of its attractive appearance and out-of-the-box edge, but the current $140 price tag is a premium knife priceand this, in my opinion, is not a premium quality knife.

I expected this watch to be much more toy-like than it is. If this watch were introduced even seven or so years ago, there would have been adults lining up around the block to pick up wristwear with this watchs capabilities. That is to say, for kids  under eight or nine  this is still a lot of pretty functional tech. Even for adults, its not difficult to be amazed by what all theyve packed into this gadget for a reasonable price.When I put it on my sons wrist the first time, I was concerned that the touch screen would be cheap and buggy. Surprisingly, its not. In fact, all of the components are pretty high quality, and the hardware interacts seamlessly with the software. Again, Im impressed.My second concern was that utilization of the watch would not be as intuitive as some of the tablets our child has had access to. Our son is not yet three, and I can say that  with a few occasional exceptions  he can navigate his way around the pretty expansive library of games and functions without much issue. That being said, he did require some first time instruction on how some of the games and functions worked, but navigation is a breeze. Im confident that children as young as three-and-a-half to four would not even have an issue figuring out how everything worked, as many of the apps have handy tutorials.The games and activities arent going to teach your child Mandarin or anything, but most have a thin educational veil, and all are child friendly.Neither the microphone nor the camera quality are great; but I feel silly even saying it, because this is a $60 wrist computer built for five-year-oldsamazing!Unfortunately, I guessor not, our kids have been spoiled by super accessible high tech gadgets, so I think the luster of this device might wear off in the six to seven year old range. For the really little ones, though, I think they still get a pretty big kick out of it.

I read an article a while back that mapped out how much phantom power expenses from devices such as TVs, gaming consoles, sound systems, and various media players could cost over the course of a year. I was pretty surprised, and encourage everyone to search out a similar outline of these potential costs. I mention this because, I was thrilled when I received this power strip due to the potential energy savings without having to do anything other than plug in my biggest energy vampireswithin reach of the strip, of course.This strip will automatically turn off up to four devices (although the description on the product page says three) that are not in use; as in when they are in sleep or idle mode. For me, I chose to plug in the television, PS4, and a sound system  each of which defaults to a sleep state as opposed to turning completely off. By my very rough calculations, I anticipate that I could potentially save a minimum of $45 a year  and a maximum of much more  just with these devices!I saw that other reviewers felt that the outlets were too crowded on this strip, which is true. But, for the anti-phantom power outlets, there is ample space for at least three devices, although there are four controlled outlets.The strip has rotating outlet covers, which is nice but not quite child safe in my mind. That being the case, I would probably consider picking up some old school outlet covers if you have little ones in the house.All in all, for the price, I think this strip is well worth it even with the crowded outlets! One has the opportunity to save some cash from the controlled outlets, and a few other outlets that work as most other power strips do so you dont have to reset your DVR every other day. Considering the lifetime limited product warranty, and the limited connected equipment warranty, I feel comfortable saying that under normal use this product should pay for itself many times over.

At this price point with free shipping - considering that it weighs a little less than a hundred pounds - one can't expect too much, I suppose. Once the piece is assembled it does look pretty sharp, so that's something.My wife was chomping at the bit to get this set up, and so she was all over the assembly. Because I've seen her at work on other pieces, I know that as long as the instructions are accurate and descriptive, and the pieces and holes are machined properly, she's good to go. Unfortunately, in this case, the instructions were not crystal clear, and a couple of the holes were not perfectly sized and/or placed; which dramatically increased the difficulty of the task. By the time I was finished working, and was able to help her out, she had worked around most of the issues, so I went back and bored out a couple of the holes and cleared up the instructional confusion. All in all, it probably took about an hour and a half to get it assembled. Admittedly, some of that was stretched out by the early frustrations my wife experienced.But like I said, when it's completed it doesn't look bad at all. Unfortunately, almost the entire piece is made of particle board. A trait of particle board is that, if it bumps into something or something into it, it doesn't chip or dent like wood. Instead, it crushes and crumbles. While we were moving the assembled chest of drawers into our bedroom, the top surface banged a doorframe, and created a noticeable crush mark. The best option we had was to dig out the affected area and apply the included furniture scratch paint to try to make it look like a wound on real wood. It's not perfect, but from a distance it passes.I mention the construction material because I think that this would be good as a semi-permanent starter piece that might spend a few years in the same spot. I just fear that this piece would not hold up terribly well during a move. So while it might be tempting - unless you're okay with it only lasting a year or so - this might not make the best choice if you're headed to college or are otherwise generally transitory.

Thankfully, I don't suffer from full face breakouts anymore. But I do still battle with my nose pores and the occasional problem spot. So, for my purposes, this cream works well. I believe that applying it prior to bed diminishes the damage caused by my perpetually oily nose pores, as they seemed to have reduced in diameter within a few days of starting the treatment. I also feel like it diminishes the duration of the occasional problem zit.The cream does not feel heavy or oily, and once it's applied I can't tell it's there; which is a big deal for me. I did let my sister-in-law try it out for about a week, and she was applying it to her entire face. This, as one might imagine, created some dry skin issues. So I would recommend that if you are going to try this out, you might want to relegate its application to areas that need a little care - as opposed to your whole face.

My father was an elementary school teacher for much of his adult life, so, while I knew my own child's pleased reaction to the set, I wanted to get his take on whether or not this set might be appropriate for the classroom.His reaction was that it would certainly be appropriate for the classroom, and would probably be best suited for the 8 to 10 year age range. He believed the set would be a good challenging for the eight year olds, and although less so for the 10 year olds it would still be a fun project. He felt that while the projects are neat individually, that kids would get over it quickly - as I found to be true in the case of my own son. To really get the most mileage out of this set, he believes that it would be worth it to pick up a few of the sets and take advantage of the multiple radio frequencies on the controllers to enable several children to let their creations interact.
