He insists that the children will almost inevitably turn their creations into miniature battle-bots, but that it will still progress their mechanical creativity.As for my own thoughts, the set is fun and a great means to introduce children to mechanics and mechanisms. I have to agree with my father that, once each of the critters has been built, there is little to keep a youngster interested; so this set is probably best in multiples over the long-term.

My wife loves a tablescape, and this Halloween table runner is the perfect touch! Unless one is actually handling the runner, it appears to be of a much higher quality than what the price would suggest. Whereas a more expensive runner would have a fabric border sewn onto the woven majority, both the border and the image are printed onto this runner. While it's not going to win any awards as a work of craftsmanship, it gets the job done, and it is probably much more practical than an artisan piece. That is, if someone spills the punchbowl on it, few tears will be shed.Measure your table before you pick this up. Depending on what you're looking for, it might be a little short. 72 inches is six feet - a common dining table length. So if you would like it to hang off the sides of your table, this runner is better suited for a kitchenette, breakfast, or coffee table.

I work in an office where about 15 employees and all of our clients share two his and hers restrooms. Unfortunately, when someone has to use a semi-public restroom, it is often due to a little extra stress on the bowels. Our only remedy for alleviating the resulting odor has traditionally been aerosol air freshener; which usually does not do an excellent job of dealing with the scent it was meant to mask, and frequently provides the additional benefit of being headache inducing when used in quantity.Not to go into too much detail, Poo-Pourri works pretty well - definitely better than its aerosol counterpart - when used as directed. It seems that most of the time only the lingering scent of essential oils remains, which is much more pleasant than Nighttime Jasmine or Tahitian Sunrise or any variety of spray till your face is blue air freshener that I've encountered over the years. Of course, every mess cannot be totally masked...but that's just reality.I strongly recommend that you at least give this a shot if you're tired of more traditional remedies.

I'm not a watch person - for clarity, I should say that I might be a watch person if I weren't so cheap - but it is kind of a "thing" in my profession to wear a ludicrous watch; so, by exposure, I've become quite sensitive to the more subtle factors that can prevent a decent looking watch from producing the desired sense of wonder in others. Another point of clarity - if one were wearing a watch for utilitarian purposes, as opposed to peacocking a bit for others, no one would where anything other than a $25 dollar Timex Ironman.So this watch looks great! Almost every person that I've shown it to has said something to the effect of "Wow that's nice! What kind of watch is that?" It is nice that Swiss Legend is not really a recognizable brand, so some might assume it's a boutique brand. Some. The devil, unfortunately, is in the details.One of my pet peeves is the way a watch band sounds. That's right, the band. In a truly high quality metallic band, when the band comes in contact with a hard surface, like a desk or countertop, it has a heavy, thick sound. I would imagine that this is due to the density of the metal it is made with. A dead giveaway for a watch that only appears to be higher in quality is that, while it looks and might even feel heavy, when the band comes into contact with a desk or countertop it produces a tinny, higher pitched sound. This watch produces that sound. The second giveaway that this watch is not as high in quality as it appears is that, when the individual band links rub together - which is virtually anytime the wearer of the watch moves - it produces a squeaking sound. While I don't know what causes this sound - although I would have to imagine that it is less than perfectly smooth edges creating friction - you will not hear it from a higher quality watch.To top off the looks can be deceiving quotient of this watch, the buttons and dials are a little sticky; or, at least, less than fluid.There is no doubt that this watch is a stunner to look at. So if you're only concerned about how it looks, and you don't believe that the people around you will pick up on some of the telling subtleties, then this watch might get the job done. However, this watch might produce something other than your intentions among folks that have been around nicer watches. That is, it could make you look like you went out and bought a watch that only looks expensive in an effort to peacock a bit...which can result in the opposite effect of truly impressive plumage.If your concern truly is a decent quality, metal band timepiece, Fossil is a reasonable option at this price point. I know that people see Fossil and think inexpensive watch, but if you want people to see a watch and think expensive watch, it's probably better to buy an expensive watch than to look like a faker. No judgement, though. The fact that I don't have the money, or the desire to spend real money on a timepiece is precisely why I won't wear an expensive looking timepiece. It is a matter of opinion for sure but, in my opinion, one could get a higher quality watch for the same amount that one would spend on this watch, but other people would probably be aware that the higher quality watch is not an expensive one, on a relative basis.

Installation was a breeze. It took 15 minutes, tops. And I believe if one were in a rush, it could get done even quicker.My primary concern was that it was not water tight. Although it is mounted far enough forward on the trailer that it should never enter the water, it is not impossible. One dip would probably do the interior components in. My father had the bright idea of sealing the lid with a bead of marine silicone to keep in water tight. After all, this will only be getting used in an emergency, and if I have to pop the seal, I can just clean it and reseal it until the next use.Now this is steel, so it will rust over time, but I feel that if an effort is made to keep it above the water line, and if it is given a fresh water hose down after being around saltwater, it should last at least a few years.For me, the real benefit of this set is that one will never be without a jack in an emergency...because you know that the one time you forget to throw your trailer jack in the back of the truck is the time you'll get a flat. As long as it hangs out in the $60 - $75 price point, it's probably worth it for the peace of mind alone.

My son is two-and-a-half, which is well below the recommended age of 5. But this boy loves his Hot Wheels, so I didn't mind giving him a crack at this set under close supervision.Because he isn't the most patient child, I had to put it together while he was asleep to avoid any major meltdowns. Assembly was actually pretty easy; particularly so once I decided to look at the instructions. This might not seem like a big deal, but I was really pleased to see that most of the stickers had already been applied to the set...which is usually my biggest source of frustration with something like this. The box is also perforated on the back panel, for super easy access to all of the pieces. This was another big help to dear old dad. I would say that total construction time was about 20 minutes. I think I probably could have gotten it done quicker if I needed to, but I was in no hurry and just kind of took my time.The morning after assembly, I placed the set in our living room - primarily because it's one of the only rooms in the house big enough to contain this behemoth (this thing is roughly 7.5 feet wide - including the tracks - by about 2' 3" tall, by about 2 feet deep - again, including the tracks). As soon as I got my son out of bed I told him that he had a surprise in the living room. He picked up his favorite plush toys - which he takes everywhere - and ran into the living room. As soon as he caught a glimpse of the garage, he dropped his plush tagalongs and bum rushed the set! He didn't stop saying "WOW" for the next two hours!I had already put all of his cars on the set, so he was rocking and rolling from jump street. He did require a little council on how to use the tracks without separating the components, but, even at his age, he figured it out. He can now use the side-by-side downhill race component, the elevators, and the simple tracks without assistance. He hasn't quite figured out how to reset the shark stunt yet, but he enjoys it nonetheless. A child even a year or two older probably wouldn't have any problem operating everything included with this set on their own.I have to admit that I cannot comment on the lights and sounds functions of this set. My son is just a little too young to determine that more is sometimes less when it comes to lights and sounds; so for the sanity of my wife and I, I didn't even install batteries...which are not included, by the way.I don't know that I've ever seen my boy so pumped about a toy for so. And watching him enjoy it is so pleasing to me. Hot Wheels has definitely done it again. This set is sturdy and super fun! If you've got about 15 square feet of floor space to spare, and a Hot Wheels enthusiast at home, then I highly recommend this set!

I have the "Chrome" version of this showerhead, which could probably best be described as chromed plastic. My only disappointment with this head is that it feels a little chintzier than I expected. However, with the metal variety costing almost a whole hundred dollars more, chromed plastic might be the way to go. It looks metal, anyway.While I understand that the temperature gauge is a little gimmicky, the shower in our master tends to change temperatures quickly. This isn't a big deal for my wife and I, but when our little one needs a quick spritz, we bath him in our shower. Of course, we always test the temperature regardless of what the thermostat says, but once we have the head off its base and are actively involved in the bathing process, it is nice to be able to see if the temperature begins to rise or fall. Unfortunately, when looking down at the head from above - as we do when we're bathing our son - the temperature reads in reverse...but it's not too difficult to figure it out!The various spray selections are pretty standard issue, and cover all of the bases. I have found that the button utilized to change settings on this head is much more convenient to use that the knobs or spinning head faces that I've encountered in the past. We have been using the head for about a month and have not experienced the difficulties switching between spray settings that other reviewers have. If it goes on the fritz, I'll come back and update this review.If you plan on installing this head yourself, I would recommend that you pick up some plumber's tape and a set of Channellock pliers to diminish the risk of leaks. The hose needed to be secured to the base of the system much tighter than I could accomplish by hand to achieve a leak-free seal.

This is our third shower caddy, in as many years. While we enjoyed both of our previous caddies, they shared a weak link; rust!This caddy has plenty of room for everything we need in the shower, with a deep and wide top shelf, and slot to hold a razor. A second razor slot would have been ideal, but I have managed to hang my razor between the bars on the bottom shelf. I also appreciate the fact that this caddy came with two suction cups that attach to the bottom shelf and adhere to the shower wall. This helps keep the caddy from swinging out of balance when a heavier bottle of shampoo - or anything else - is taken from one side of the caddy.The best feature by far, however, is the promise that this shower caddy will never rust! I am hopeful that we will be putting this thing to use for years to come.

This kettle is a great replacement for our old Chef's Choice cordless kettle. While we enjoyed the old kettle for years, the Aroma provides a few upgrades that are greatly appreciated. Namely, the variable temperature and keep warm settings.My wife and I got into loose teas for a time, and really enjoyed making custom blends. However, with our old kettle, we only had one temperature setting: done. Because we enjoyed different teas, we found ourselves having to wait around for the water to cool down to white and some green temperatures. Likewise, because there was not a keep warm setting on the old kettle we often had to wait quite a while for the kettle to heat back up if we wanted multiple cups of a black or herbal tea.The Aroma conveniently solves these temperature issues while still providing the features we loved about our old kettle, such as a cordless pitcher with corded base, an easy to read water level indicator, and super sturdy construction.We have gotten away from loose teas in favor of the more convenient prepackaged variety, but I believe that I would like to take another crack at the wonderful world of loose teas, now that I can control the water temperature more conveniently.I definitely recommend this kettle!

My only relevant point of comparison is my trusty Toshiba Canvio Basics 3.0 1TB drive, so I'll lean on that heavily for my review.Surprisingly, the Seagate game drive is actually slimmer than the Toshi, while only about an eighth of an inch wider; which is nice for transport and storage. They seem about equivalent in weight and apparent quality of construction.I had a hard time finding any detailed specs for the Seagate, but the disk speed and transfer rates of the Toshiba are 5400RPM and 480 MB/s, respectively. I would say that the Seagate seems just as quick if not slightly quicker than the Toshiba, which, in turn, seems quicker to me than the internal drive.While it's probably not recommended, an issue with heat has not yet arisen from the drive being kept directly on top of the console.I have to admit that I don't have any friends... I mean, I haven't actually taken the drive to any one of my many friends' homes to try to play a game stored on the drive through their console. According to Seagate, as long as the owner of the game has their Xbox live login, it's not an issue; so I guess I'll have to take their word for it for now.At the time that this review is being written, the price is $129 on Amazon. While it's neat to look at, and potentially a touch speedier than a Toshiba, I don't know that the price differential is worth it. However, I strongly suspect that the price will drift closer to sub $100 in short order to become more competitive, in which case I'd put it in the you might as well category. Hopefully, once the official release date hits, the actual specs will be relinquished so we can determine if it's actually superior to the Toshi or if I'm just falling victim to a pretty green placebo.

Our son is two, and he really likes his VTech Go sets. He received the VTech Go! Go! Smart Wheels Train Station Playset and the VTech Go! Go! Smart Wheels Police Station Playset for Christmas and his birthday last year, respectively. While both of these sets are enjoyable, neither hold a candle to this RC set!The advantages that the RC set has over some of the other sets are the remote controlled play, non-forced track interaction, and an easily established circuit.The remote control is great. There are two buttons: forward and reverse. While the reverse button is almost never used, it still gives the operator the feeling of control and choice; as opposed to the fully autonomous, perpetually running cars that come with other sets. I also think that the buttons help the younger users, like our son, establish an awareness of relayed cause and effect.On both of the other tracks that we've used, on at least one segment of the track, the fully autonomous vehicle comes to a point that requires the child to perform some task in order for the vehicle to continue on its path. For older users, this is probably fine, and, perhaps, preferable. However, for those in the 12 - 36 month range, these interactions with the track have a high likelihood of separating track components, requiring older and/or steadier hands to continuously repair the track almost every time the vehicle comes to the point of forced interaction. In my experience this is not fun for the child playing with the set or the guardian forced to play track engineer. On the RC set, however, these interactive segments can be played with manually, if so desired, or they are operated automatically by a small gear on the bottom of the car. Our favorite of these interaction points is the automatically ascending and descending elevator!Finally, and maybe most importantly, the track pieces that come with the RC set easily build into a complete and continuous circuit without much effort, even after the instructions are lost or destroyed. On our other sets, there appear to be more crossways. These pieces always seem to leave a section of the completed track exposed to simply dumping the vehicle off of the circuit. I'm sure it is my fault for unknowingly losing one of the replaceable bumper sections that make these intersections into corners, but I have just found it easier to consistently build a continuous track with the RC set.All in all, I believe that this set provides more bang per buck than any of the other sets we've seen to date.

First let me say that the product dimensions currently listed are way off at 5.8" x 1.6" x 5.4". This unit is much larger than I was expecting. It is about 10.5"W x 3"H x 5.75"D. A pretty large alarm clock. While it's not an issue for us, I wanted to point this out just in case you're working with a crowded nightstand.We've really enjoyed this system so far. From a standard alarm clock standpoint, it's tops! Alarms can be set for every conceivable duration and occasion and, most importantly for me, it's dimmable.As a sound system, it's also great! My wife has been looking for a nice little set of speakers to plug into her phone so she can listen to music while getting ready in the morning. The iHome has filled this void. Bluetooth is a snap to set up, and the speakers are more than capable of filling our bedroom and attached bathroom with pretty high quality sound.I know that there are other standalone Bluetooth speaker systems out there that might produce a higher quality in terms of sonic range, but the difference in sound is almost indiscernible, while the difference in price is not. Plus this system is a great alarm clock.My wife and I have no complaints, and highly recommend this system.

This product is so bad that I have had a hard time coming up with a way to creatively describe it. I'll try to take it step-by-step.The product is difficult to use for an adult, let alone for the age range that the product is intended for. There was no way that my son or nieces would have been able to effectively apply the special DohVinci Play-Doh without my help. That is, it requires a fair amount of strength to force the "doh" out of its tube and onto the project.Unfortunately, once the tacky-ish substance has been manhandled out of its tube, it just kind of worms around without actually adhering to the project. Imagine forcing Play-Doh out of a tube onto a slowly spinning anything, and you've got a pretty decent mental image of what this product is. Yes, the DohVinci doh is stickier than regular Play-Doh, but not nearly sticky enough.After the kids have experienced the disappointment of not being strong enough to apply the dough-like substance themselves, and the substance not being sticky enough to stay on the project without a lot of poking and prodding, they are left with all the excitement of a finished product that is dried up Play-Doh on whatever.The one redeeming - and it's not actually redemptive - quality of this set is the small blinking LED lights. My son and I like to turn these on in a dark room and do funny strobe dances. However, I believe that these lights were added as an afterthought once the creators realized just how dull the toy was. While fun for other reasons, saying that these lights improve the product would probably be akin to celebrating Campbell's for the enjoyment derived from soup can telephones. I can appreciate that they make something that I enjoy, but I can't imagine that they had my means of enjoyment in mind when they designed it.I would avoid this set until they improve the formula of the DohVinci "doh."

My son loves Cars. Naturally, he was thrilled to receive this playset. The excitement waned quickly, however.In my opinion, the lack of sustained enthusiasm was in large part due to the set's design. The color changing car rolls onto a platform on the set's lower level, where it is sprayed from a bottle filled with cold water, changing its color - the color changing is neat, without a doubt. Then the car is manually lifted in place on its platform to the second level where it is dumped onto a ramp that leads the car to a warm water pool, reverting the car back to its original color. Yes, this is an exceptionally short and, after a few circuits, boring process, but the real issue might be with the mechanics of the process. The components, other than the cold water bottle and the car itself, are surprisingly low quality. Combine a bunch of low quality components, add motion, and what one gets is a herky-jerky heap of not much fun. That is, nothing that moves does so smoothly and without much effort.To top things off, additional color changing cars are not inexpensive. As of the time of that this review is being written, additional color changing cars cost at least $12.50 each. One can see how this might add up. Honestly, if the set itself were of a higher quality, and a little more involved, I could see investing in a few additional pieces. As it stands, though, I feel like it would just be throwing good money after bad.My son loves the included car and still plays with it regularly, along with his other cars. Not surprisingly, he could care less about the set at this point. I can't say I blame him. I feel like this was a weak effort from Mattel; particularly because these are the same folks that make the Hot Wheels sets and cars that have yet to disappoint.

My wife has been a Tervis fan for years, and she says that this tumbler is as good, if not better, than any Tervis she has ever had!The HydraTrak fits easily into our car's cup holder - although, because of its height I could see how a shallow cup holder could create problems - and it never sweats, making it perfect for the commute. It also does a great job keeping a beverage cold over prolonged periods of time... even under Florida's hot summer sun.While it might seem silly to some, my wife has been diligently using the bands to monitor her water intake throughout the day. She acknowledges the fact that she gets busy at work and simply doesn't make time to drink enough water because she has other things that require more attention. Since using the tumbler she has set a goal of how much to drink by what time and the bands make it easy to track her progress. She feels like she has definitely upped her intake, and it has decreased the frequency of late afternoon low-grade headaches that she believes were a product of dehydration.It is a quality product, for sure!

My son is 26 months, well below the 36 month recommended age, but I feel comfortable about him playing with Jake's ship under supervision. The only real chokable is Jake's removable sword, other than that, everything is pretty sizable.With the mandatory dad disclosure out of the way, I am pleased to say my boy really enjoys this toy! He is a fan of Jake and the Neverland Pirates, but I'm not sure that he made the connection between the show and the playset; so I believe he enjoys the set on its own merits, as opposed to its connection with the show.The ship is set on wheels that, when rolled across the floor, activate sword fighting action between Jake and a man in a shark suit - whom I don't recognize from the show. The ship is designed to resemble a shark. Accordingly, the front of the ship is shaped like a shark's head, and the lower jaw also performs a chomping motion when the ship's wheels are rotated.To enable the sword fighting action of the two figurines, they must be placed on pegs that, unfortunately, are a touch difficult to line up with the input on the bottom of the figurines... even for dad. When the Jake and Man-in-a-shark-suit figurines are removed from their respective motion activation pegs, they still provide some action, via the suits chomping jaws and Jake's swashbuckling arm lever.The set is a bit stout in price, but I have to say that this set is sturdy compared to some of the other playsets that we've recently come across. It is made from robust plastic, and is well assembled. I have personally seen it repeatedly dropped on a tile floor from approximately two and a half feet about a hundred times, and it's still ticking. While it might not seem like it, this trick is often the death knell for toys in our house.My son hasn't stopped playing with it since we got it, and it looks like it will be around for some time to come.

While it is not one of the headline benefits that are claimed by this product, I was personally excited to give it a shot for its claims about pore reduction. I was also hoping that it might help smooth out the tone of my skin.Being that I have rather large pores, if a product is working towards their reduction, it is relatively easy to tell if it's getting the job done. For example I used bliss Micro Magic Microdermabrasion Treatment, 3 fl. oz. for a while, and, before I stopped using it because it was getting too costly, I could easily discern that my pores were shrinking. In contrast, even after several weeks of using the Face FX, I did not notice even the slightest bit of improvement. The same was true of my skin tone; although I really wasn't expecting results in that arena.My wife was more concerned with the fine lines around her eyes and mouth. She did feel as if, after repeated uses, there were temporary improvements in the appearance of fine lines, but that any improvement quickly faded. She compared it to the reduction of fine lines - due to mild swelling - that might result if one were to pinch themselves, which would ultimately diminish as the swelling subsided. Even though the results, in her mind, are far from permanent, she believed that she might have continued to utilize the product on a regular basis if it were not for the nonexistent battery life. I certainly agree on this point, the battery life is ludicrously limited.At the very best, if this product is working as claimed, the positive effects appear to be brief. I just don't feel as if the very limited results are worth the time, energy, and money.

First, let me say that this tent is amazing. It's light, compact, easy to set up/breakdown, and comfortably sleeps two, considering its packable dimensions. It seems as if all the other reviewers agree on how great the tent is. I ran into a different issue, however, that I think deserves mentioning.Only after we had used the tent did we realize that we also received a little something extra, a sticker which reads "WARNING: This product contains a chemical known to the State of California to cause cancer, birth defects or other reproductive harm." Whoa... what?! We like camping, but not enough to expose ourselves to what sounds like pretty significant health risks.Being a little concerned, I called Kelty to find out what the chemical was, and why they would even offer a product that is so potentially detrimental to one's health. The representative at Kelty was great; super polite, helpful, and forthcoming. He informed me that the tent had to include the warning sticker to be in compliance with California's Proposition 65, the State Drinking Water and Toxic Enforcement Act of 1986. Prop 65, essentially requires the state to maintain a list of chemicals known to the state to cause cancer and/or reproductive harm. Cool... right? Who could complain with the state looking out for consumers? So why would Kelty offer this product if it contains a chemical that is known to be toxic? Of course I had to ask.The Prop 65 list contains some 600 chemicals, and if any one of these chemicals are in a product, it needs to be labeled. So while the Kelty rep couldn't give me the exact chemical or chemicals that necessitated the label, he said that the probable candidate is a chemical called Tris, commonly used as a flame retardant. Well, why is it in the product if it is easily identifiable and known to cause bodily harm? All the rep could tell me was that the tent had to be treated to comply with other state regulations. Like I said, the rep was super helpful, and I didn't want him to feel as if I was beating him up about this, so I thanked him, and started looking around on my own.As it turns out, according to California Code of Regulations, Title 19, tents have to be "treated with an approved exterior chemical process by an approved application concern, or from inherently flame resistant fabric approved and listed by the State Fire Marshal." It seems to me, then, that, in an effort to be in compliance with Title 19 of the California Code of Regulations, manufactures are able to apply a chemical approved by the state that is also known by the state to cause cancer and/or other reproductive harm. A little crazy, right?I did a little more looking around, and it is actually not that easy to find a tent that doesn't contain toxic flame retardants, which, apparently, have not even been demonstrated to be entirely effective. What's more unfortunate is that tris, in particular, has been found to be capable of releasing into the surrounding environment during the lifetime of the product it is applied to. Yikes!While I am not aware of an easy solution for tent users, I guess I just wanted to bring up an unusual situation that manufactures are being placed in by contradictory governmental regulations that might need some reconsideration. As for myself, I don't think my wife is going to let us continue using this, or any other tent, with this chemical in it; so I guess I'll have to figure something else out.As for my rating of this tent, I'm still going to give it 4 out of 5 stars because the tent itself is awesome. It would just be great if the state didn't put them in a position to utilize a known toxin to ineffectively protect their otherwise great product. I'm docking one star, because I assume that Kelty could choose to make their tents out of inherently flame retardant material. However, I'm not docking more stars because I also assume that this would drive up the price of their product to the point that they would be totally unable to compete in the market place. To me, the onus is on the state. Change the regulation to require the use of inherently flame retardant material and level the playing field among all manufactures, or, at least, don't require/permit the manufactures to use a toxic chemical that, according to some, is ineffectual.

This game is insanely addictive. If you liked Jurassic Park Builder, you will love this. Beyond the amazing additional features, such as pitting one's collection of dinos against those of strangers online, I feel like it is just an easier game to get into than its predecessor. Instead of waiting around to generate food or coins, I feel as if I'm always working towards something. I also like the fact that I can earn in-game currency by watching ads and perusing websites instead of coughing up any real coin. Great game... highly recommended!

I wanted so earnestly to like this razor. It's interesting to look at, includes a charging base that self-cleans the razor, and came with its own hard-shell travel case. The moment I got it, I set it up to make sure it would have a charge by the time I finished my dinner, about an hour later, because I was so pumped to try it. I had already shaved that morning, so I was working with about 10 hours of growth. And man oh man did it feel great on my face. So much smoother and gentler than my nearly decade old horizontal cutting surface, discount bin Remington. I thought I was in love.The next morning, I had to shave for work, so my standards were much higher on how good of a job this gliding gizmo was doing. Again, not a full day's worth of growth; but I began to notice that I was having to redouble a lot of ground. This was particularly true in the typical hard to manage areas like just below the nostrils, the crevice in the upper lip, the neck, and just below the sideburns. I had to really work to fit the circular cutting surface into these nooks and crannies. One would think that the circular cutting surface would actually be better suited for many of these areas. Nope. I believe that I spent at least twice as long as I normally require getting the job done that morning. The second kick in the gut was that, as the day progressed, I seemed to find more and more errant hairs.I thought that I was probably just falling victim to the learning curve, and stuck it out. Well, the week went on without better results. Just to make matters worse, when I finally had to address my sideburns - as I was unable to properly attend to them with the razor head - I had to physically pop off the razor head to replace it with the clipper head - which otherwise just sits around waiting to get lost - only to discover that, at best, the clipper head was going to provide for the slowing of sideburn creep, because I couldn't get to the slightly longer clipped hair with the circular razor head.Unfortunately, shortly thereafter came the straw that broke my back on this one. I was rocking some two day growth over the weekend - to be clear, my two day growth is probably similar to a proper man's 5 o' clock shadow - and thought "This is where the circular system is going to shine!" I was very wrong. It was a train wreck. After trying to get the job done for way too long, I had to bust back out the old Remington that, just a week before, I had hoped to finally resign to the trash heap.While I have gained a lot of respect for my aged Remi', I cannot, in good conscience, recommend this Philips Norelco razor to anyone who plans to let their facial hair grow for longer than a lunch break.

I'm not a superb bassist and really only play when I have to. However, I perform with a bassist that is great and we've both had a crack at these strings, so I'll tackle this from two perspectives.Like I said, I don't play frequently. Naturally, my fret fingers are sissified and I can be a bit rough around the frets. What I've found of these strings is that they are very forgiving. Where I would typically expect to get a fair amount of fret buzz, there was much less. Perhaps more importantly, I found that these strings definitely provided my tender digits with noticeably more staying power. I would say, perhaps particularly, for a serious beginner, you will get much more mileage out of each practice/session with these strings than the cheapos. I think this will inspire a lot more satisfaction throughout the learning process, as well!As for my seasoned buddy's experience, he installed them on his Schecter Stilleto Custom 5. They were a little short, as can been seen in the included picture, but he said it didnt seem to produce any adverse consequences. Ideally, an extra-long set would have been better for this guitar.He agreed that these strings produced less fatigue over the course of a several hour performance. Like almost any other strings, he felt that they needed to be broken in a bit before they could hold a solid tune. This process was quick, however, and he said they sounded seasoned comparatively quickly. They also arent too bright out of the box, unlike many uncoated strings. When asked about any stand-out distinctions between these strings and others he has used, he said that the low B produces a fat tone, and the stings are, overall, well balanced in tension in volume.At the end of the day, we both agree that great strings are great strings, regardless of experience level; and these are quality.

While the 1/2 inch drive might be a little beefy for some applications, I like having the extra heft available. I have heard of folks breaking even the comparably hefty 3/8, so I'm not opposed to mixing it up.This particular set will cover the bases for many of the most common applications and, with 72 teeth, will get the job done a little easier. Really, this would be a great set to keep in the trunk or to send off with your child to school. Not to mention the fact that these tools are easy to keep clean, and come with a lifetime guarantee. Unfortunately, the case is not guaranteed; but I can all but guarantee you that this case won't last a lifetime.I'm pumped about the quick-release function! However, I have had a couple of quick-release sets in the past in which the quick release was the first thing to get gummed up and ultimately became the Achilles heel of the set. Although, I do believe this set is of a higher quality than either of those sets, so I'm holding out hope.Overall, it's a solid set at a price that won't break the bank.

This seems like a ridiculous first point of review for a multi-cooker, but this thing is gorgeous. Words really cannot describe the appearance of the Candy Apple Red paint job. Unfortunately, the product picture also does not accurately depict its appearance. I am not kidding when I say that the weekend after we got the appliance two different people walked into our kitchen and said something to the effect of "That is so beautiful...I want one...What does it do?"Aside from its aesthetics, this cooker is pretty great functionally, too! I do believe that its utility to me will grow as I become more comfortable using it versus the appliances it is meant to consolidate. I will say that, for a novice like me - and even a comparative pro like my wife - the user manual is indispensable. Do not discard it!So far I've really only utilized it as a glorified slow cooker. That being said, it is glorified. So this review will be much more meaningful if I include my wife's experience.Her first crack at the multi-cooker was Risotto, utilizing the Step-By-Step cooking mode. The Step-By-Step mode walks the user through several of the preprogramed cooking methods, eliminating some of the fine tuning. According to my wife, risotto can be a bit of a headache. While she did say that she believed having the KitchenAid Stir Tower Accessory for KitchenAid Multi-Cooker, Contour Silver would have made the process much easier and, perhaps, resulted in a better finished product; she nonetheless proclaimed that the multi-cooker produced the best batch she has made to date. Since the risotto success, she has made multiple sauces and soups. All of which turned out fantastically! I would argue that these creations would have been just as great cooked through traditional means, but she insists that, whether or not my argument is true, the multi-cooker is simply more efficient and convenient while providing an extra degree of precision.Both my wife and I like the fact that the cooking pot is not as large and cumbersome as a traditional slow cooker, so it can actually fit into our refrigerator between cooking something and it needing to be heated for serving.Like I said, I think as we grow more comfortable using this appliance to its full capacity, we will appreciate it even more than we already do. However, even from jump-street it has earned its spot on our countertop.I will add this disclaimer: My wife has repeatedly said that the multi-cooker would be exponentially better in several of what she deems to be common applications with the stir-tower accessory. I count this as a disclaimer because the stir tower is not inexpensive, and, if you enjoy the multi-cooker as much as we do, you might be just as compelled to purchase it as we are.

I was having a devil of a time with my Floratam lawn. It was just failing to thrive. After speaking with some neighbors who have paid for their lawn care, I learned that, because our house was relatively new construction, I might want to aerate our lawn to provide some breathing room within the newly compacted earth. I also happen to be a little frugal, so I looked for a discount solution. This set seemed to fit the bill.Honestly, I was quite hesitant to try them out after reading about the problems others seemed to have experienced. However, knowing that the price point was attractive, and that Amazon is cool about returns if something doesnt work, I took the plunge. Im happy to say that I couldnt be more pleased.It has been about two weeks since I used the spikes in my lawn, and Im already seeing improvement in some of my most troublesome areas. Where the grass was doing okay, it is now a little fuller, and where it was really bad, Im finally starting to see signs of growth.I will say that the straps will give you trouble if they are wet. That is just how this type of strap works, by friction. Moisture will reduce that friction. So I would certainly recommend using them on a dry lawn, and/or hitting the straps with a hair dryer before use if they got wet from any other source. I will also recommend that you not expect to walk with a normal gate around your lawn and anticipate that these straps will stay in place. Because of the solid, one piece construction, the natural bend in your foot when you walk will put a disproportionate amount of pressure on the back straps with every step you take. While it looks funny, I found that a lateral stomping motion was much more effective. Of course, this prevents one from wearing the spikes while pushing their mower or a fertilizer, which would be ideally efficient; but I was not too frustrated by having to make a dedicated aeration effort.These are not perfect by any means. Nonetheless, considering the results and the price, I would say that the imperfections are overshadowed by the products effectiveness.

My wife has the gold iPhone 6 and has been looking for a nice gold case. The last case she bought was cheaper, but the build quality was not even close to the level of this one, and it was basically just gold glitter glued to a run of the mill generic case.This Case-Mate is thick and durable, with two piece construction that, although a little difficult to remove, provides excellent protection without being too bulky. I would have to say that my favorite detail of this case is the fact that Case-Mate took the time to make the buttons wonderfully accent the case while maintaining total functionality.As far as the aesthetics of the case, it is tops! Its plain to see that this case is more robust than typical dime-a-dozen cases, and the idea that they used gold leaf instead of glitter is fun.Overall, my wife is quite pleased and Im pleased that shes pleased!

These pants would probably fit the bill for a school uniform perfectly! Our little guy's class doesnt require a uniform, but they look great on occasions that we need him to look a little more put together than usual.I appreciate the fact that these pants are durable. They can take a beating  surprisingly, even on the knees  without being super heavy. I also like the fact that they seem to be wrinkle resistant, so he doesnt look like a ragamuffin half an hour after putting them on.The only difficulty was initially with the D ring belt. A little tricky for small hands at first. But it is nice that they come with a belt at all!Overall, they look great, theyre durable, and they are not ridiculously priced.

Ill try not to muddy the waters too much, but I want to provide the sizing details I was looking for when I made my purchase. I am 61, 205 pounds with broad-ish chest and shoulders, but Im also disproportionately leggy in length. Im not robust or slight but, rather, a true medium build. I went with the Extra-Large expecting it to be a little roomy on me, but hoping that I wouldnt be swimming in it as is often the case with XL garments.I have to say that the XL fits me perfectly. The garment is comfortably snug through the shoulders and chest and drapes naturally from there without looking like Im a child wearing my grandpas sweater. The fit actually feels a little odd to me as it is the perfect length to the waist. As I mentioned, Im mostly legs, so if a garment fits properly in width it is usually also a little longer than I would prefer. I only mention this because, if youre taller than I am with more proportionate upper and lower portions, the XL may be a little short. If you would say that youre on the wider end of the body type spectrum, even the XL might be a little more snug than youre used to.As for the sweater itself, I really like it! It is quality construction without the loose weave that is often present on the larger end of the size scale when it comes to knitted garments. The buttons are sturdily fastened and are placed well into the chest for a greater number of button up or down options. It also has pockets, which was a big deal for me. They are a little on the shallow side, but good enough. I would say that, on the scale of cardigan weight, this one falls on the lighter side of the median, but not too light.Overall, I think its great!

The swing is great in all the right places. It has a built in mobile, with a peek-a-boo mirror at its core, and plays a variety of tolerable baby tunes. It rocks both front to back and side to side. This might not seem like a big deal until your baby decides that side to side no longer soothes him or her to sleep. The ability to change the swing's orientation might just be the difference between the swing hitting the attic or a few more weeks of use. The seat cover is also machine washable... which definitely comes in handy. So, like I said, great in all the right places.The reason why I love this swing, however, is because it has an AC adapter and can run without batteries. I am not kidding when I say that we easily spent over $100 dollars on batteries alone while our last swing was in use. Obviously, the power cord can pose a strangulation hazard, so it should be used with caution. If it is set up properly, and other children are properly supervised in the presence of the power cord, it is a real game changer!Seriously, if you're thinking about getting a swing that only runs on batteries, go ahead and tack at least another $80 on to the price of the swing itself. If you're not into those sorts of shenanigans, go ahead and get this swing.

I have a bad habit of hoarding a collection of single subject, spiral notebooks while studying for this or that. My problem is that I either have to carry around three or four separate notebooks or risk not having the notes I need at any given moment. This binder solves my problem in that it hides my shameful notebook habit, and reduces the number of objects that I have to keep track of for any particular subject of study down to one. Yes, I still have to remove the spiral notebooks to be able to turn the pages, but mine is more of a transport problem anyway. For me, it works.The drawback is that the current price point - as of the writing of this review - is just shy of $14. In my opinion, a little high for what one gets... a three ring binder with zipper and handle. I would feel comfortable picking up a few more of these if they were a little closer to $8. Unfortunately, I am having a difficult time finding a comparable and less expensive product. It might come down to how much work you're willing to put into it for the extra savings.My recommendation would be to first look for a cheaper option. If you know of a less expensive alternative, please let me know in the comment section.

I know it may be poor form, but, with the exception of slicing bread, my wife and I have been using our old Cuisinart 8" slicer to cut just about everything for years. I still love the Cuisinart, but our new OXO has got it beat... and I'll tell you why.Like most knives in this price/quality band, the Cuisinart has a comparatively slick composite-ish handle. With even a touch of moisture, the knife can get a little unwieldy from a likelihood to slip standpoint. While the OXO certainly isn't slip-proof, it takes quite a bit more moisture to get to that worrisome tipping point.Beyond making me feel as if I'm a little less likely to cut myself, the OXO Good Grips Slicer comes with a sharp edge, seems to maintain its edge, and is well balanced.If you're looking for a good slicer that won't break the bank, you won't be disappointed with this one.

The primary benefit of this particular feeder is the top-fill capability. Why? Well, seams are the weakest link when it comes to liquid-filled feeders. The fact that the primary seam on this feeder - that which is separated to pour in the feed - is above the liquid reservoir makes this feeder much less likely to leak over time than its non-top-fill counterparts.Other than its top-fill functionality, the feeder is brightly colored and loved by birds. It is plastic and light, but it is also sturdy and well manufactured.The only problem I can foresee is that feeder might be susceptible to some rocking and rolling under windy conditions. That being the case, something a little heavier than this feeder might be appropriate if you plan on hanging it in an area subject to frequent or heavy breezes.

It has probably been about seven years since I last used a VOIP-ish service. I have to admit that, if BasicTalk is indicative of the broader industry, things have certainly improved. No, in my opinion, call quality is still not quite as good as a standard land-line, but it is so close now that the minor lack in quality is worth the price differential.The BasicTalk hardware is unobtrusive, and the overall system is easy to set up. As far as features are concerned, it is about what you would expect to get if you transferred to any other carrier: number transfer, voicemail, caller id, and call waiting... just at a much cheaper price.If you still want a landline, but just can't stand the big provider prices, BasicTalk is a reasonable solution at a reasonable price.

The placemats look really sharp right out of the box. They are an attractive blue, and are well crafted.Unfortunately, as placemats often do, a couple were eventually soiled with foodstuffs to the point that they required washing. We washed the mats as directed and still found ourselves with two mats that were about an inch smaller than the others and stubbornly curled in all the wrong places. If a case of the shrinks were the only issue, we could just wash the others into the appropriate size. It is really the newly and impossibly curled corners that have banished these mats to that drawer in our kitchen that contains nothing other than inherited dishrags and mismatched placemats.If you just need show mats, these will probably fit the bill quite well. If you plan on keeping these mats underneath or around plates of food, you may want to consider something a little less shrinky.

This is one good looking rag rug! I realize that by this product's very nature each rug should look different, but, with a chance of scoring a real beaut, I think it's worth rolling the dice.I have read that others received rugs with hard inclusions. Ours is zipper and sequent free, however; and actually quite soft.Beyond being easy on the eyes, the rug seems more durable that other rag rugs I've come across in the past.If you like the idea of this rug, I say get it!

It's still Elmo, so our son still wants to love him. However, this iteration seems to occupy the gap between a decent plush toy and a decent educational toy. I'm just not sure this gap needed to be filled.Let's Imagine Elmo is simply too hard, stiff, and heavy to really love on. A bit of a disappointment for our little one. On the other end of the spectrum, Elmo is capable of some interaction. While Elmo's three hats may make it feel like he is really providing a range of interactive capabilities, there is an awful lot of overlap. Playing along with Elmo gets repetitive quickly and just doesn't provide fodder for extended interest; which would be okay if, after getting bored, a child could just snuggle with Elmo, but this Elmo is not for snuggling.Our son was pumped to get Let's Imagine Elmo out of the box, but seemed pretty disappointed after just a couple of minutes. I have to admit, witnessing the rapid decline in satisfaction was a little disappointing for me too.

Our hope was that the Motorola MBP36S would serve as a suitable replacement for our aging Lorex Wireless Video Monitor LW2451.As soon as we set up the Motorola, I believed it was superior in every way. The Motorola includes an unobtrusive kickstand and antenna, as well as a power supply port right on the monitor, eliminating the need for a charging stand.Beyond the physical design advantages, the Motorola monitor possesses two features that I always wished our Lorex possessed; zoom and a video monitor sleep mode. While the inclusion of zoom is an obvious advantage, the video monitor sleep mode probably required some input from users. Our problem with the Lorex was that when it was running on battery power, it would lose its charge so quickly that we really just had to transport the charging base from room to room with us. With the Motorola, however, we can easily turn off the video feed manually - while maintaining audio monitoring - or set it to turn off automatically after a given period of time. This feature greatly increases battery life, and is also nice to prevent a rather bright screen from illuminating our room all night. The video feed is easily restored by pressing any button on the monitor.On top of a better physical design and the addition of some neat features that our Lorex lacks, both the video and audio quality of the Motorola are noticeably superior.If the Motorola is so superior to our Lorex, then why did we go back to our Lorex after one night? The Motorola is lacking one critical feature: ambient noise cancelation.We have a Honeywell Whole Room Air Circulator Floor/Table Fan, HT-908 in our son's room to circulate air without freezing him from above with a ceiling fan. The hum of the fan also seems to comfort him. Yes, if the fan is humming it's obviously not silent; but it's no leaf-blower either. Without the ambient noise cancelation feature, the Motorola picks up this otherwise innocuous hum and transmits it into our bedroom in the form of white noise... all night. The only real option was to turn off the volume - even the lowest setting was annoying - or just endure it until morning. Because we still wanted to monitor our child, we had to endure it. That was one torturous night that sent us clamoring back to the Lorex, which does possess the ambient noise cancelation feature.To be sure that we weren't missing something, we contacted Motorola. Let me first say that they were very pleasant and professional throughout our conversation. The Motorola representative informed us that the system lacked the feature we were looking for and recommended that we move the fan, and/or raise the camera to a higher level. We tried both and neither worked. Their only other recommendation was to get a quieter fan.The fact is, we could get a quieter fan, but our son likes the noise. If we can keep the fan our son likes while still effectively monitoring our child on a slightly inferior monitor that does possess a feature critical to our particular situation, then that is what we'll have to do. We have decided that we'll keep the Motorola system in place for daytime monitoring, as it is more conducive to working around the house during nap time, but the Motorola simply could not serve as a primary monitor due to its one major drawback.To those who might be reading this review that do not have anything that creates ambient noise in their child's room, please note that if I were in your situation I would have given this monitor five stars without hesitation. For us, however, this monitor makes peaceful sleep very difficult, if not impossible.

From my own experience, these batteries are great! Of course, my own experience really only includes the countless batteries I have to continuously replace from the seemingly hundreds of hand-me-down toys my 15-month-old has inherited from his much older cousins. These Panasonics last measurably longer that the store brand cheapos I have to buy in a pinch, and at least as long as the other top shelfers I've used in similar applications.Now to the bug-out bag. I know nothing of it, but my brother is a shade-tree survivalist so I thought I would mention it. For what it's worth, these are the type of batteries he would keep in his bug-out bag; which makes sense if they really do maintain a charge for up to ten years. Let's just hope that whatever he's preparing for takes much longer than ten years to occur.On a serious note, I live in Florida, where we are subject to frequent storms. So a short-term emergency pack is a reasonable preparation. Now that I know that some batteries are better than others when it comes to longevity, a pack of these will be making its way into our storm kit.

I let mine air dry since it is stainless steel no need to worry about rust. The company offers a 5 year money back guarantee so you have nothing to lose. I was able to buy this product during a promotion and am happy to share my experience with it.

I started taking Bromelain to help me with winding down after my long days at work. I am unable to take antidepressants due to weight gain and this Bromelain seems to help.  It also helps with my muscle aches and joint aches. When the rain comes I increase my dosage. Easy to take with no burping. I was able to buy this product at a discount during a promotion and am happy to share my experience with it.

I have heard a lot of people using Vitamin C on their face for wrinkles, acne scars, sun spots, decrease facial lines. My husband has sun spots from years of sun damage and they seem to get worse in the summer. So we decided to start using Vitamin C cream by Alina. We understand this will not happen overnight. He has said that it leaves his skin looking hydrated, bright, and invigorating. He has had no acne outbreaks or oily skin while using. I have started to try it on my lines and wrinkles. I was able to buy this at a discount during a promotion and am happy to share my experience with it.

My husband is a bit of a gym fanatic and after workouts in the afternoon he is usually ready for bed. He has started taking Nitric Oxide Boosters for a couple of days and he has more energy while in the gym and still able to perform his duties at home after a hard workout. Since it is a vasodilator it goes to the right areas. He's reported the want to go to the gym has increased also. It protects his cardio system also. He said the pills are easy to take he usually takes 2-3 before a workout with a bottled water. We received it well packaged and within a reasonable time. I was able to buy this product at a discount during a promotion and am happy to share my experience with it.

I started taking these to help increase my metabolism to help with weight loss. I am almost 40 and have a harder time as I get older to lose weight. I need a pill to help with weight loss. I have been taking one pill a day for almost a week and they have seemed to help. My appetite has changed also. This seems to be my ticket to weight loss. We will see in a couple of months and I'm excited. I was able to buy this product at a discount during a promotion and am happy to share my experience with it.

I use this on my face every night. I've been using it for almost a week and my skin looks so much better! It is so much clearer and less breakouts around my chin and hairline. No harsh smell. I just splash on my face after my shower each night. I was able to buy this at a discount during a promotion and am happy to share my experience with it.

Cute butterfly tie backs. My nieces used these in their room. They love butterflies. These almost look real pasted on sides of the curtains on their wall. Beautiful colors and really easy to install. These are magnetic so that helps with staying in place.

My husband is a bit of a gym fanatic and after workouts in the afternoon he is usually ready for bed. He has started taking Nitric Oxide Boosters for a couple of days and reports more energy while in the gym and still able to perform his duties at home after a hard workout. Since it is a vasodilator it goes to the right areas. He's reported the want to go to the gym has increased also. He said the pills are easy to take he usually takes 2-3 before a workout with a bottled water. We received it in 2 days and it was well packaged. There is a 100% money back guarantee if you have any problems. I was able to buy this product at a discount during a promotion and am happy to share my experience with it.

Ive tried multiple screen protectors. I was unsure how this would fit and work since most you buy are hard to apply without multiples bubbles but I had no problems with the Pleson. It Fit like a glove on my Galaxy. I am so excited my son can use my Galaxy and I don't have to worry about scratches or fingerprints. I was able to buy this product at a discount during a promotion and am happy to share my experience with it.

We all need a great nights sleep! Especially one with no hangover the next morning. Luna Natural Sleep aid is taken at night when your ready to go to sleep and within15 minutes you are relaxed enough to fall off to sleep. I was amazed! Slept all night. Woke up refreshed and energized ready for the day. I was happy to be able to buy this at a discount during a promotion and am happy to share my experience with it.

Upon buying my Iphone 6 I never thought about needing a screen protector. I had researched it and most of the websites said that the IPhone 6 wouldn't need a screen protector and it has a scratch resistant screen. I put it in my purse with my keys and it came out with a scratch so I decided to try the ADFILIC Tempered Glass Screen Protector. Before applying I washed my hands to remove all residue and oil from my palms. I made sure the room was kinda humid to decreased the air particles and static electricity. I cleaned the screen with windex and made sure to dry it good. I applied masking tape to one side to provide as a hinge for my screen protector and measured my screen. The Nozza was thin and that helped and fit like a glove on top of the screen. I then took a credit card and worked from the hinge area first to the other side. While doing this I removed masking tape from bottom side of phone and while I removed the tape from screen protector I used the credit card very simple and no bubbles! I noticed immediately the scratch that was there from my keys was greatly minimized by the screen protector. Texting is not a problem with the screen protector in place and I love it! Sample was provided for evaluation and review purposes.

My 3 1/2 year old daughter recently became interested in the Calico Critter sets and she was so excited to get this houseboat and hasn't stopped playing with it! In the box, you get the expandable houseboat which measures about 22" long by 5 1/2" tall, a Belle Hopscotch bunny figure (3" tall), a separate island, a small rowboat, and over 50 pieces including floats, flippers, and goggles for the Calico Critters to wear, chairs, drinks, fishing poles, pots and pans, a grill, and more. Adult assembly is required, but isn't difficult and doesn't take more than 5 minutes - you just have to snap pieces together and apply the stickers to certain parts of the boat.I love that all of the pieces in this set are high quality and durable. The plastic they are made of is thick and not flimsy in any way, so I don't have to worry that my daughter will break them. While I like that the set comes with so many pieces, many of them are very tiny, such as the cutlery and glasses, so I took those out of the set until my daughter is older because they can be easily lost or misplaced.By far my favorite thing about this set is that there are unlimited play options! My daughter will sit for well over an hour at a time playing with this and she gets excited showing me the different things all the Calico Critters can do on the houseboat. For example, the shower area converts to bunk beds for the critters to sleep in, there are 2 swimming pools and slides for them to go on, the doors actually open, and the fish shaped kiddie pool has a dial you can turn to watch the sea creatures "swim." There is a separate island that the critters can float on the small rowboat to or can pretend to swim to it and the critters can cook a meal on the stove or grill and sit down at the big table. I like that you can fit both the adult critters and babies on all of the chairs and beds. My daughter has used her imagination to make up stories for the critters as they interact, so it definitely encourages imaginative play. She has a few other Calico Critters so it's nice that you can remove some of their fabric clothing and pretend they are wearing a bathing suit to swim. My only criticism is that I wish the set came with more than just one bunny. The box makes it look like you'll at least get a few critters, so that's sort of misleading. You'll definitely need to purchase more Calico Critters, which are quite pricey, but are also very well made and worth the price. She also has several Palace Pets, Kitty in My Pocket, and Littlest Pet Shop characters that she uses with the houseboat to add more characters to the boat. When you're done playing, the houseboat folds up easily to be put away and all of the pieces can go back inside.Overall, this is expensive, but well worth it in terms of play options and quality. Any Calico Critters fan will love this set!

Every Christmas season I like to add to my daughter's collection of Christmas books and this one has vastly become one of her favorites. The story is about Oliver, a young elf who is excited to find out what his job will be for the Christmas season. Each of his family members takes him to work with them and he tries to help in the toy workshop, the bike shop, the bakery, and the writer's workshop, but in each of these places, he finds he's too little or clumsy to complete the tasks. He is sad because he feels he has nothing to contribute to Santa's team until he meets a small reindeer named Dot, who is having trouble learning to fly. They find friendship together and they also find their niche making small ornaments and cards as gifts for the other elves.I like the moral of the story that no matter how young you are, you can always find a way to help or find something that you are good at. It's very relatable to young children. The illustrations are colorful and engaging and the text keeps a young child's interest through the entire story without being too short or too wordy. There is also a sheet of stickers included with the book. Overall, this is a great addition to our Christmas collection that we will read for years to come.

My 3 1/2 year old daughter loves playing board games and she really enjoyed the new Peanuts movie, so she was thrilled to play this. In the box, you will get the foldable, circular playing board, a cardboard 3D Eiffel Tower, a 2 piece spinner mechanism, a Red Baron airplane, a Snoopy doghouse pilot, 24 character cards in each of the four colors for each player (red, black, purple, blue), 9 tokens per color for each player, and an instruction sheet. The game box is very sturdy and all of the game's pieces are well made and durable, made from thick cardboard or plastic. The only thing I could see breaking is the cloud tail on the Snoopy doghouse because it's literally made out of thin paper towel material. If that were to break off, you'd be out of luck as far as playing because the cloud tail serves as an integral part of the game. Setting up the game is very quick and easy with very little assembly: simply unfold the game board, squeeze the Eiffel Tower to expand it and place it in the slots on the game board, and attach the spinning arm to the top of the Eiffel Tower. You'll need to snap the Red Baron plane and Snoopy's doghouse to the ends of the spinning arm and you are ready to play. The game is recommended for ages 4 and up.The game is for 2-4 players and each player takes a colored deck of cards and the tokens of that color as well. On each card is a Peanuts character (Charlie Brown, Lucy, Linus, Sally, etc.). Each player places their cards face down in a stack in front of them. One player spins the spinning arm as fast as they can (the spinning arm serves as a timer during each round) and while it's spinning, players take turns flipping over their top card face up into their own pile next to the face down cards. If the card you flip over matches any other player's face up card, you made a match and can place one of your tokens on that character on the game board. You take turns flipping and making matches until the spinning arm stops spinning. If you run out of cards during the round, you have to shuffle them and continue. To win the game, when the spinning arm stops spinning, if Snoopy's cloud tail lands on a space with one of your tokens on it, then you win. If the cloud tail lands on a space with no one's token on it, then you spin again and keep playing. Even though the spinning arm moves really fast and makes the plane and Snoopy look like they are flying (my daughter's favorite part!), it never topples over or falls apart, which speaks to the nice craftsmanship of the game.I like that this game is fast paced and helps work on matching skills and reaction time for younger players. The concept of the game took my daughter a little while to catch on, but after playing a few times, she got the hang of it and really enjoys playing it. I also like that there is an Advanced Play option for older kids or adults who find the game concept too simple or not challenging. In the Advanced Play option, you play the same way except that instead of taking turns flipping over cards, all players flip their cards at the same time and you have to be very quick to spot a match between your card and any other player's face up card. You have to call out the name of the character first before the player with the matching card can.Overall, this game is really fun and easy to play, is made of high quality materials, and would be a favorite of any Peanuts fan!

Fisher Price has once again created an innovative product! In the box you get a large plastic storage tub and 20 plastic flashcards to help baby learn common first vocabulary words. I absolutely love the idea of these thick plastic flashcards because they are so much more durable than paper flashcards and can withstand the roughness of a baby or toddler without the worry of the cards being bent or torn. The cards have large stickers on them that showcase the word with a very colorful and engaging illustration of the vocabulary word. I like that the cards themselves are bright and colorful as well. Some of the first words are bottle, pig, apple, car, house, ball, shoe, cat, dog, banana, and airplane. The cards are large and perfect size for little hands to manipulate and put into the slot at the top of the storage case.While I like the construction of the cards, I'm disappointed that the cards are geared more towards Spanish than English. The Spanish word is at the top of the card, while the English word is at the bottom, not to mention that the entire back of the box and product description on the back of the package is written in Spanish. I get that Shakira speaks Spanish, but it's a bit much. I find that both words being on the same card as well as the picture very distracting and cluttered and I think it would've been better to put the Spanish word on one side and the English word on the other side. I like the idea of teaching both languages when the child is older, but for a product that is targeted towards children 6 months and up, (realistically a child older than 2 or 3 wouldn't use this product), it seems unnecessary. The item description mentions nothing about these being bilingual or the fact that Spanish is the main focal point. As the child gets older, you can expand the learning by asking questions about the pictures on them like what color things are or what each of the letters in the word are. The storage tub is fantastic and made of thick plastic with a removable lid and carrying handle so you can take these on the go.Overall, these are really well made and an excellent learning tool, but I'd prefer an English word only set.

My 3 year old loves giraffes and when I saw this book, I knew she'd be excited to read it. The story is about Gerald, a giraffe who isn't the best dancer, and how he has low self esteem about his dance skills because the other animals made fun of him and his clumsy dancing. Gerald feels sad and a cricket, who had been watching him, encourages him to find the music he loves inside himself and dance to it his way. Once he followed this advice and let go of what other animals thought and danced to the beat of his own drum so to speak, he found he really could dance and at the party he impressed the other animals by being himself.I absolutely love the morals of this story because they apply to all people, old and young: when you let the opinions of others get to you, you begin to doubt yourself and become so self conscious that you forget to be yourself; and you may not be the best at any given activity, but if you do your personal best and believe in yourself, you will shine anyway. Gerald was able to let go of the opinions of others when he was alone in the field with the cricket and he found his own rhythm and realized he really could do what others said he couldn't do. He started to believe in himself and it showed as he did his best dancing. The morals make great conversation starters with your children about what things they have doubted themselves about and why it's important to believe in yourself. This book touches on bullying and the negative feelings it brings in an easy to understand way for young children as well and opens dialogue about what the animals could have done differently instead of laughing at Gerald.I love the rhyming text and the bright and engaging illustrations.  I like that the pages are made of thick cardboard since it's a board book and I don't have to worry about her bending or tearing the pages. Overall, this is an awesome book with a great message!

I've always used traditional power style eye shadow and was excited to try this because it is a cream gel shadow. I loved the smoky gray/silver color, but unfortunately, I was disappointed with how clumpy it was, how dried out it was when it arrived, and how difficult it was to spread it across my eyelids. I tried using a shadow applicator but because the gel's consistency was so dry, it just scraped a big clump out. Spreading it with my finger was no better and if you accidentally spread it a little farther out than you wanted, it is VERY difficult to wipe off your face - you have to scrub very hard to get it off and for someone with sensitive skin like me, it made this unusable.Additionally, it claims that the color lasts 24 hours, but it creases and fades in just a few hours like every other eye shadow. After trying to use this two or three times, I just threw it in the trash. I definitely wouldn't waste my money on this color tattoo brand again.

I purchased this set for my 3 1/2 year old daughter and she loves them! I've been teaching her about the planets and these are a great learning tool and a hands on way to learn about the planets. After using these a few times, she's able to identify each planet. In the set you get the 8 main planets, Pluto, and a sheet of 200 glow in the dark star/comet stickers. The planets are not exactly to scale, but they are mostly accurate in their sizes relative to each other; for example, Venus and Earth are often called twin planets because they are about the same size and in the set, they are the same size. Also, Jupiter is the largest planet and is the largest in the set.While I think that these make a great teaching tool, there are quite a few things that could use improvement. First of all, the planets are made of flimsy, thin Easter egg plastic, so when my daughter tries to open and close the few planets that open, I'm always worried she's going to crack one of the halves. Also, the center of the entire solar system, the Sun, is NOT included! I find that so disappointing, especially if you are going to hang them from the ceiling and want to create an accurate model of the solar system. The colors of the planets are mainly accurate, although Uranus is an odd purple color with spots, when in reality it is supposed to be a pale blue color. I do like the detailing on some of the planets, such as Jupiter's lines and red spot. I am disappointed in the Saturn planet because the ring will NOT stay on it - it keeps falling off even when I popped open the planet to insert the thin ring around the edges and tried to close it between the two halves.I do like that you can hang these from the ceiling, but in order to do that, the instructions state you have to use adhesive putty or tack the string into the ceiling. Because she may not be interested in these for too long, I chose not to put holes in the ceiling and also because she likes to hold them as we are talking about them. The other selling point of these planets is that they glow in the dark. Based on the item photos, I thought these would glow really bright, but unfortunately, they glow pretty faintly. I also find it disappointing that the planets do not come labeled. Unless the parent is savvy about the solar system, it may be hard for a child to tell which planets are which. Lastly, the stickers that come with it are very cheap and nearly impossible to peel off the sheet! I ended up ripping lots of them in trying to get my nail under the edge to peel it up, so we just threw them away.It seems as though there are more cons than pros to this set quality wise,  but my daughter does love it and they make the planets more real to her than just looking at pictures of them.

I absolutely love this Lenox Cold Dip Bowl set and am so excited to use them again during my parties this holiday season. The set comes in a thick, red cardboard box that you can use to store the set year after year and also is nicely packaged if you are giving it as a gift. You get two ivory colored bowls in the set that will match any table decor: a smaller, shallow bowl with a diameter of 4.25" and a larger, deeper bowl with a diameter of 6.5." It has a capacity to hold 16 ounces. The bowls are made of heavy duty, high quality porcelain and feature a beautiful holly berry design on the outside of the larger bowl and the bottom of the smaller bowl. The smaller bowl has a gold rim around the top.I like that the set is versatile because you can use them together, the smaller bowl to hold the dip and the larger bowl to hold ice underneath the smaller bowl to keep the dip cold, or you can use them separately, one for the chips and one for the dip. The smaller bowl can also be used as a candy dish as well.
