I needed a replacement for my 579 lightbulbs in my 1998 Dodge Grand Caravan.  The bulbs are used in the dome/reading light in the front seating area.  Other LED bulbs sold as direct 579 replacements were in fact too long to fit.These bulbs are shorter and thus function as a 579 replacement in terms of size and fit.The connector is a T15 socket.  Basically, the T10 and T15 are the same base; the number refers to the width at the *top* of the socket.In terms of light output, these lights are what I would call average.  I think they put out just about the same light as my original incandescent bulbs, but use less energy in doing so.  And of course, they are estimated to have a much longer lifespan, upwards of 12 years and probably longer in the real world, as the dome light doesn't stay on very long or get used other than when opening/closing the doors.The light quality is white/blue, in the range of noon daylight.  Not yellowish or warm like an incandescent bulb.I can recommend these as a direct replacement for the 579 light bulb, especially in terms of size.

I purchased these lights for my 1998 Dodge Grand Caravan, as they work for the rear seat reading/courtesy lamps.  They are extremely bright and are much brighter than the incandescent lamps they replaced.  I did have to squeeze the light contacts so they would have a firm grip on the light's metal surfaces, but that was about it for installation concerns (and making sure the orientation was correct, as the lights are sensitive to polarity).The light quality is very good--a white/blue similar to daylight at noon.  Definitely not the warm incandescent look.Highly recommended as a replacement for the Automotive 569 bulb, although note:  there are no loops on the end of this LED bulb.  If you need loops, get a different bulb.

I purchased these LEDs for the cargo area in my 1998 Dodge Grand Caravan, and they work great!  I was able to pop off the light fixtures in seconds and swap the incandescent bulbs in there for these LEDs, which give off a white-blue light.  I also found that thanks to the flat design, I could put two LED bulbs into each fixture, so I'm getting a lot more light than before.  All I did was put them back to back when I installed them.  Works great.Light is white, towards the blue end of white.  All four of my lights worked perfectly.Bottom-line: these lights work great, they were easy to install, and they use less energy than the incandescent bulb(s) they replaced.

With a variety of performances available for purchase for this famous classical piece, it's hard to know which one to buy.  This version has good, clear sound and you can pick out the individual instruments as the orchestra performs faithfully to the composer's intent.  Many of the other versions on Amazon are muddled, not as clear, or recorded on older technology and just don't sound as good.  A stirring performance!  Now if I can just remember where I first heard this song as a child...because it really bothers me that I can't remember exactly where I remember it from, but it feels so familiar!

Purchased an 18" neck 34" sleeve fitted shirt.  Nice shirt, neck size is good, but for a slim fit it's a bit closer to a normal-sized shirt than I would have expected.  High quality material, comfortable to wear and looks sharp.  Washes and irons easily; material is a little thin for heavy starching, but the cuffs and collar will hold starch okay.I am short and stocky (5'5") with a thick neck; with me, the shirt has a neck that's good for me (18") but has shoulders that are a tiny bit too large, even though I have slightly larger than average shoulders--a little surprising on a fitted cut.  It's hard to find a perfect shirt that's the right size, so while the fit isn't perfect (hence the loss of star), it's still a very good professional shirt.  I have other shirts that are 18" fitted that have a better cut and fit than this shirt so I have some idea of what to expect.As a plain white shirt, it's perfect for business or business casual (e.g. a sport coat and no tie).  Looks sharp under a jacket.  Van Heusen is a brand with a long history, so I feel better about buying this shirt over a no-name shirt.  Will probably buy more shirts.

I gambled that this Andrew Fezza shirt with a 17.5" neck and "slim fit" would fit my short, stocky body and large neck.  I won the gamble--this shirt looks great.  It's high quality material, a cotton-poly blend.  More importantly, it's a woven pattern, not a printed pattern, so the shirt looks incredibly expensive, even though it's not.The fit is right for me; the 17.5" neck is generously sized (I would say it's closer to 17-3/4") and the slim fit works for a shorter, stocky person like me so that the shirt doesn't billow like a standard shirt often does.  It's not so slim fit that it's skin tight, and it would probably look even better on a thinner person than me, but it still looks great.  Definitely not a shirt for anyone with a large gut though.Basically, a great shirt if you need a dressy casual look that seems expensive but isn't.  The high quality material and woven pattern are major pluses.  Highly recommended.

I bought the 17.5" neck size shirt, hoping that it would fit my neck.  I am short and stocky with a thick neck for my height.  As a result, standard 18" neck shirts tend to fit right around the neck but then look like sails with shoulders too wide for my body.  This shirt however doesn't have that problem, being more towards the fitted size.  Indeed, the shirt has a label that says "Slim Fit."  I am not slim, but the shirt is just fine on me, so it's not that tight.I was extremely pleased that the 17.5" neck is generously sized (probably around 17-3/4") so that I could comfortably button the top button if needed.  Major plus there.The shirt itself is a cotton-poly blend, good material.  The pattern you see in the images is an actual weave and not a print.  In other words, it looks extremely expensive, far more expensive than the actual current Amazon price of just over 18 dollars.  I have seen shirts costing 4x this price that didn't look as nice as this shirt.If you need a dressy casual shirt, want something that looks expensive but isn't, and need a fitted look that isn't skin tight, this shirt is precisely what you are looking for.

Bright LED lights, fits well, easy to install.  Works great on my 1998 Dodge Grand Caravan as a replacement lamp for a burned out license plate bulb.  T10 base means it can fit other applications in my vehicle, although not as well because it's not bright enough to make a good 579 bulb replacement (which has the same base).As others have mentioned, the cover over the LED has a tendency to come off if you aren't careful and need to rotate the bulb to get it to the right polarity to light up.  The trick is to pull on the white base and not the cap, and that is tougher than it sounds, because the bulb seats very low once installed.Otherwise, this bulb is an easy recommendation for a 194 bulb replacement.

I used this costume for a photo shoot and it's a great replica and a great price.  Normally, to get a replica that looks this good, you'd need to go on an auction website and pay a couple hundred dollars or more.  It fit my model perfectly, and even the wig in the cowl looked good in my digital images.The only thing you'd really need to get to complete the look are purple boots, but other than that, you get the rest of the costume.It does get a bit warm to wear, according to the model, and it probably won't take abuse if worn regularly, as opposed to a couple of times a year for parties and Halloween.  Nevertheless, it's a nearly perfect Batgirl costume and a great value.  The fit is as expected and is very flattering/forgiving.  An A+ Batgirl costume.

Small and portable, the Transcend Information USB 3.0 Card Reader is an absolute winner.  I tested it with a Sony UHS-1 U3 speed rated card and got a write speed of 65 MB/sec and a read speed of 93 MB/sec, which essentially exceeds the claimed specifications (60 MB/sec write; 90 read).  I like that it's small enough to take with me in my camera/computer bag, with no annoying cable hanging off.  At under $7.00 as of this writing, this is a bargain: unbeatable performance, unbeatable price.  I wish it took compact flash cards, but you're limited to SD, micro SD, SDHC, and SDXC cards.  It's backwards compatible with USB 2.0, although you'll get lower speeds because the 2.0 bus acts like a bottleneck, slowing down data transfers.  If you're looking for a USB 3.0 reader for your micro SD or SD card, then look no further:  this is the best USB 3.0 card reader for those formats.

I purchased these ankle boots for photography shoots, because I needed a glamourous purple boot with a rebellious vibe for the images. The boots fit as expected, according to my model.  She reported that the boots are not super-comfortable, because of the pointed toes and the high heel, but they are acceptable for normal use as long as it doesn't involve long-distance walking.From a purely visual standpoint, these boots look great.  They were flattering to the model and photographed well.  A bit flashy, but it was exactly what I wanted.

This is an absolutely "must have" book for hiking in the area around Portland, Oregon, which includes hikes near Mount Hood, Mt. Ste. Helens, the Coast, hikes within Portland, and various National Forests and State Parks.  I had and used an earlier version of this book and absolutely loved it, and this update is fantastic.  The descriptions of each hike are useful, personal, and practical.  Directions to the starting point are easy to follow, and the hike profile showing altitude changes is very useful at gauging how difficult a particular hike might turn out to be.  While I would love to see more photos, the photos that are in the book are a good start and allow me to know what to expect on the hike.I got other hiking books for the area, as well as using websites, but I found myself going back to this book again and again because it's so well-written and practical.  I really wish I had discovered this book earlier, because quite honestly, I wasted years missing out on some fantastic, easy-to-do hikes out of simple ignorance.  So, don't make the same mistake I did--get this book and get out there.Since each hike listed includes an evaluation of difficulty--easy, moderate, strenuous--as well as distance, it's easy to find a hike that suits your level of skill and how long you want to hike.  For example, when my parents came to visit, I was able to find a hike that wasn't going to be too long or difficult for them (Trillium Lake), and when my young nephew came to visit, I selected longer, moderate hikes (Ramona Falls and Silver Falls State Park).  This particular edition, the 5th edition, has some useful features:  in the first few pages of the book are summary charts showing each listed hike, distance, difficulty, and best time, as well as whether they are wheelchair-friendly, have good views, or are good for runners.  In the back of the book are appendices listing additional resources.This is a great book that I am confident you will love.  It's a practical and well-balanced book, well-written and interesting, with a great selection of hikes.  It's a must have book and one that is best purchased as a hard-copy rather than as a Kindle version.

I needed a memory card capable of sustaining enough write speed for 4K video, and a U3 speed card was what my camera manufacturer recommended.  Luckily, Transcend makes this affordable U3 card with a claimed read speed of 95 MB/sec and a claimed write speed of 60 MB/sec.  I immediately ordered two cards to use in my Panasonic LX100.As soon as the cards arrived, I grabbed one and tested it in my UHS-capable card reader (to get the most speed, your reader must be able to take advantage of UHS controllers).  Long story short:  I got write speeds onto the card of 59 to 60 MB/sec, exactly as advertised.  Read speeds exceeded the 95 MB/sec claimed speed, going into the triple digits.Just for comparison, I compared this card against the U1 Transcend 32 GB SDHC card to see if there was a speed difference.  Yes, there was:  the U1 rated card moved at about 36 to 37 MB/sec (write speed) and read speed was again in the triple digits.  That's actually enough to meet the U3 specification of 30 MB/sec, but there isn't a lot of "headroom."So, if you're writing 4K video and/or if your camera can take advantage of UHS-I, I can highly recommend this card to obtain the best possible U3 speed for writing to the card.  It really does do exactly what the label says.

I wanted a USB 3.0 card reader that's capable of taking advantage of the UHS-1 controllers built into the latest memory cards.  While my current SIIG and Lexar USB 3.0 readers are pretty good, technology marches on and it's important to keep up, if only to save time during transfers of large files.After getting the reader, I tested it with my Windows 8.1 system that has built-in USB 3.0 ports(a Lenovo laptop).  And boy does this card reader deliver the speed.  With my Transcend U3 speed capable cards, I got write speeds of 59 to 60 MB/sec, exactly as claimed, through this card reader.  Even with older U1 speed cards, it was writing to them at 36-37 MB/sec steadily, sufficient to actually meet the U3 speed specification of 30 MB/sec.Read speeds were ridiculous in triple digits.  I could move a 1 gig file so fast off the card that it was too quick to notice--less than 5 seconds.In brief, this card reader works well, delivers the speeds claimed, and is easy to carry with you when you need it.  It has slots for microSD, SDXC/SDHC/SD, and compact flash.  Other reviews have pointed out that you cannot use the microSD and SD slots simultaneously, so please be aware of that.  Otherwise, this is an excellent card reader/writer that delivers exactly as advertised!

I got this pan in June 2014 and waited to see how it would hold up after several months of use.  And it's going great--with proper care, this pan should last a long time.  I notice that most of the reviews for this rectangular 13X9 inch pan are actually for the heart shaped cake pan, so my review is specific to the 13" x 9" pan.First, I ain't cooking cakes in this thing. I'm putting greasy, meaty things into this baby.  Porch chops, chicken, lasagnas--you know what I'm talking about.  These are things that tend to ruin pans by sticking just enough to ruin the non-stick coatings over time.  Thankfully, this pan has held up very, very well.  I've noticed some light staining but it hasn't seemed to affect the non-stick properties of the pan.Non-stick is a bit hard to claim; stick-resistant would be more accurate.  I still have to do a bit of rubbing to get stuff off the pan, but it's nothing like it would be if this was just a regular pan.  Supposedly the pan has a 10-year warranty, but I would be very happy to get 5 years out of any pan the way I like to cook.This may not be the most expensive pan out there, but it is pretty darn good.  I don't use metal utensils on this pan; you can find safe utensils for things like cutting lasagna that won't scratch the coating like a metal knife will.  Cared for properly, there's no reason why this pan shouldn't provide years of service.  A great bargain choice for pan!

Most ovens these days seem to cheap out and come with uncoated aluminum broiling pans, which are a pain to use and keep clean.  As someone who enjoys cooking (and eating) but doesn't enjoy cleaning up the mess associated with cooking, I HAD to get something better than el cheapo pan (which is Spanglish for the usual uncoated pan).Enter the Range Kleen 2 Porcelain Pan.  Well, deliver the pan actually; I carried it into the house myself since I would have been scared if this thing could enter the house by itself.  I used it to cook some foods directly on the surface, then went to clean it off.  And voila!  Things didn't stick and the pan looks great.  With the older uncoated pan, I would be scrubbing and worrying about whether I was going to be getting aluminium into my food, as well as getting wrinkly dishpan hands.  This porcelain pan has made using and cleaning much easier for me.It's not as big as the standard pan that came with my oven--same length but not as wide.  Since I don't need the extra space, the lost width (about 25%) is unimportant to me.  I don't have the need to overcompensate for my shortcomings.  But if you really need that space, it might be a consideration for you.  Some people have really large families and might need a bigger broiler pan.  Me, I just give them smaller portions <wink, wink>The pan is made out of better, heavier material than you might expect for the price.  My top pan fits nicely into the lower pan, which sounds kind of dirty, but actually is a good thing--no warping noted.  When heated, the pans don't warp either as far as I've noticed, but I haven't really put my head into the oven to check (despite repeated suggestions from others that I do so).Since people always are looking for negatives, I will say that the edges while not sharp are definitely not baby-smooth rounded.  Since I use oven mitts (my skin isn't strong enough to just grab this right out of the oven), I don't think the risk of cutting yourself is that high, but reasonable care should be exercised when washing the pan.After several uses, the pan still fits well, it still looks like new, and I'm just a little bit fatter and more satisfied, since less food is sticking to the pan and more food is sticking to me.  I think if you are unhappy with your uncoated aluminum broiler pan or if some unscrupulous former resident has taken your broiler pan, this is an excellent replacement.  It only comes in the exciting dark grey color though, so be still your beating heart.

I have hair that is so tough, it could be used to clean the barrel of a cannon.  In fact, when I had a beard and short hair, the guys nick-named me bore brush.  So, no ordinary razor blade is just going to shave this face.  Oh, I've used those 5-bladed razors; you know the kind--with the big heads and even bigger marketing budgets.  But like an Internet whore, they're all promise and no satisfaction.  Give me my razor with some real moves, some real satisfaction.I stared into the mirror.  Some ugly mug stared back at me.  Quickly, I splashed warm water on my face, and the guy in the mirror was still just as ugly, but with a wet face.  A bit of shaving cream, and it was time to transform that ugly guy into the superhero everyone loves.  But like Underdog without his Super Energy Pill, I noticed that my razor was completely dull and powerless.  Thankfully, the geniuses at Amazon had responded quickly to my Polly Purebred call for help and delivered this product--fresh Mach 3 blades--just the day before.  Quickly swapping the blades, I appreciated the thoughtfulness of how Gillette had put the blades into a clear plastic safety case.I wet the blade under the stream of water and began to shave.  Stroke after stroke, my hairs were cut down like trees being mowed down by lumberjack clearcutters on meth.  The sharp blades were like Star Trek Borg--resistance was futile.  No hair could stand against them.  And yet, miraculously, the blades never broke the surface of my skin.  It's the exact opposite experience of shaving with a sander, but I digress.Rinsing the lather off my face, I gazed into the mirror and saw some baby-faced superhero staring back.  I almost wished I could grow my beard again, just so I could shave it off.  But I'll settle for waiting a day or so and coming back again for another round of shaving pleasure.Sure, these Mach 3 blades are great and fit both my Mach 3 and my Mach 3 Turbo handles (which are the same, except the color of the Turbo grip is black, which as we all know makes it faster somehow).  Some people see these as replacement razor cartridges.  I see these guys as Adventure in a Clear Plastic Case.Your mileage may vary.  Batteries not included.  Not valid where prohibited by law.

I love this movie, so I was very excited to see that it's available on Blu-ray. But this transfer is so horrible that I cannot recommend anyone purchase the Flesh & Blood blu-ray.  You would absolutely be wasting your money.  Adding insult to injury, my older DVD version actually upscales better to an HD TV than this blu-ray disc, that's how bad this blu-ray is.The story itself is fairly simple:  set in medieval times, with plague ravaging the land, virginal Agnes gets kidnapped by a gang of mercenaries, who soon take over a castle.  Her noble boyfriend sets off in pursuit of her, but in the meantime, Agnes has started manipulating mercenary leader Rutger Hauer.  It's gory but entertaining, with sex, nudity, violence, and a bit of questionable science thrown in for more fun.Jennifer Jason Leigh plays Agnes, and she's something to see.  However, the poor transfer ruins virtually all the fun scenes with her, which take place in dim light.  This is a problem that does not exist in the DVD version, which means that it's a problem with the transfer itself and not the original material.Thus, while I find the story to be entertaining and about 4-stars, this product is a zero-star product.  Save your money and avoid frustration:  Do NOT buy the blu-ray.  You will be bitterly disappointed.

I got this bed as a prop for a photography shoot, and I needed something inexpensive that could hold a twin-sized mattress (which I already had).  This bed was exactly what I was looking for, with only some minor drawbacks.Assembly is required, and it took me an hour and 15 minutes to complete with the included tools (a simple wrench and an allen hex key).  The box arrives in a surprisingly small package.  My box had partially broken open during shipping, but none of the parts had gotten lost.  A single person can assemble this bed in about an hour and 15 minutes; don't let the many pieces or screws intimidate you when you open the package.  The instructions are easy to figure out (simple diagrams) but I would have preferred some actual wording to explain things too.So once assembled, it looks pretty good.  It's study and level.  So here's the drawbacks:  1)  the bed is not easy to take apart if you ever need to move or store.  The way it's assembled require you to almost completely disassemble it if you ever want to change residences or just store the frame; 2)  the rounded rods on the bottom make it too easy to slide the mattress around; 3) while the rods are reasonably close together, I can't help but feel that a flat surface would be better for the mattress on top.  I'm thinking a thin sheet of masonite might be a good addition for this bed if you plan on using it for any length of time.Anyway, this bed looks as it is pictured, it's certainly sturdy enough, and it wasn't too hard to put together.  It's inexpensive, though you might find a used frame and headboard combo on your local Craigslist for less.  I can recommend this bed frame, but please keep in mind the drawbacks I mentioned above, as they may be deal-breakers for some people.

I purchased this screen to use for my photography as an interesting backdrop and it's gorgeous.  I now wish I'd gotten the 4-panel version, because this 3-panel version looks and works so dang nice and I'd like a little more width in my photos.  If you actually need it as a changing screen, it works quite well too!When shipped, it arrives folded and flat.  No assembly is required, you simply get it out of the box and unfold it.  And for storage, you can fold it back up  again so it's flat and only 1-panel wide and a few inches thick.  Mine arrived with a couple of the cross pieces pushed out of place, but simply pushing them back into position fixed that.  Just be aware that the screen part is fragile and inspect your screen on delivery.It seems obvious, but I'll state it explicitly:  the screen cannot stand on its own if completely unfolded.  You need to have the panels at an angle to keep it upright.  The cherry finish is gorgeous and adds a touch of class to any room with furniture that has a matching finish.  The hinges are properly attached and are not loose.Whether it's for photography, as a set piece, or for a practical changing screen, this is a great addition.  About the only thing you should be thinking about if you're looking for a screen like this is whether you should get the 4-panel screen instead.  If you're doing photography like me, get the 4-panel.  If you just need to create a little bit of privacy in a smaller area, the 3-panel does that.  No matter which one you get, it'll look great!

I purchased the Nikon D3200 with 18-55mm lens as a Christmas gift for my sister's boyfriend, who has an older Canon 40D SLR.  He LOVES it, and I've "converted him to the Darkside."  Even though his 40D is a good camera in its own right, the more modern technology, better out of camera color, and menu system of the Nikon D3200 have re-ignited his love of photography.  The D3200 is being phased out at the moment, resulting in great bargains for camera and lens kits.With the capability to do both video and still photography, the D3200 is a great step for budding filmmakers and family photographers.  The quality of the images far surpasses what can be done with a cell phone camera, but at the cost of more weight and larger physical size.  The ability to change lenses to suit a particular situation is a huge plus, as well as the ability to control exposure.The camera itself has a nice large screen on the back, a pop-up flash, and the ability to be used in all the camera modes you'd expect from full manual control to aperture or shutter automation to a program mode that turns the camera into a point and shoot machine.  A helpful guide feature in the menu system greatly assists inexperienced photographers, and the large screen on the back makes it easy to see camera settings (although I prefer a screen on the top panel, which this camera lacks).  You can shoot at up to 4 frames per second, which is as fast as expensive film cameras of the 1980's.The drawbacks for this camera include its smaller size, which may not accomodate some large handed shooters; settings which can only be accessed via the menu instead of a dedicated button; and the fact that the newer D3300 offers improved performance and reduced size for about $100 more.So, what to do with your hard-earned money?  As of this writing the D3200 is an incredible bargain, with features suitable for all levels of shooters from beginners to professionals.  Quite frankly, for someone who knows how to properly use a camera, you will only get better images from a more expensive camera in highly specialized situations (like virtually no light or where you might need 11 frames or more per second).  The feature set difference between the D3200 and D3300 is negligible, making the D3200 the better buy.  If you're in the market for a digital SLR and money is tight, look no futher:  The D3200 will re-ignite your passion for photography just like it did for my sister's boyfriend.  He's already bugging me for lens recommendations.

This is a review of the DVD version of Gator Bait 2: Cajun Justice. To make a long story short, this is a 3-star movie with a 1-star transfer to DVD.  The movie is okay, with a fairly straightforward rape and revenge storyline with an attractive female lead, but the DVD transfer is just horrible with artifacts everwhere.  If you liked the movie on VHS, you will be mad at spending money to get this DVD which looks horrible.Gator Bait 2: Cajun Justice is not really much of a sequel to the original Gator Bait.  Jan MacKenzie plays a city girl who marries a Cajun guy so they can go live in the Bayou.  A bunch of inbred-types kidnap her after she takes a bath, torment and eventually gang rape her.  She escapes and then takes revenge on them.  End of story.  Like I said, a fairly straightforward storyline, made more watchable by the charms of Jan MacKenzie who plays sexy and vulnerable very well in this story.So, you'd expect the DVD to be much, much better than the VHS version in which the movie was originally released.  It's not.  Not only are there no extras but the transfer itself is just poor.  I can't help but feel that if I simply did my own transfer from LaserDisc (I own the LaserDisc version) to digital that it would be a lot better than this DVD.  About the only reason to buy the DVD version is so you can put the VHS machine away.  Just don't expect it to look any better (and indeed it often looks worse) than watching it on VHS.

Good for an elementary-level student like me, an adult who has been taking piano lessons for about a year and a half.  Some pieces are fairly easy; others are very challenging and beyond my skill level.  Thus, the book is one that can grow as my skills grow.The song choices are good and traditional.  It's hard to find anything to fault with this book. A great choice for just about anyone learning to play the piano.

This may be a mediocre miniseries, but it's 5 stars for Hayley Atwell (Captain America, Agent Carter) and Ruth Wilson (The Affair), who play the lead female roles.  I purchased the Blu-ray version, which is available as an import from Spain.  All six episodes are one one disk.The blu-ray plays just fine in my U.S. region LG blu-ray player.  So, it is region-free.  The image quality is what you would expect from a high definition source.  Colors are good, the picture quality is sharp.  While the default language is Spanish, the menu option "idiomas" allows you to select "ingles" or English as the language for viewing, just like when it aired on American TV.Sadly, despite the radiant and memorable appearances of Hayley Atwell and Ruth Wilson, the miniseries suffers from the sin of being boring and does not compare well with the original Patrick McGoohan series.  The ultimate mystery of why Jim Cavaziel is in the village gets lost in an confused and unclear storyline.So, while I cannot be enthusiastic about the miniseries, I can say that it's worth watching just to see Ruth Wilson and Hayley Atwell in early roles.  Fans of The Walking Dead will also be pleased to see Lennie James in a key role as well.  Ian McKellan is his usual articulate self. With all the ingredients for success, the miniseries falls down with a confused, boring story.So:  miniseries overall, 3 starsHayley Atwell and Ruth Wilson, 5 starsPlot and story, 1 starBlu-ray quality, excellent. Plays in U.S. players. English language available.

I have never used a wet saw before, so I can't compare this to another product.  What I can say is that for me, a complete and utter beginner with using a wet saw, this wet saw works great.  The set up of the product was easy, taking only a few minutes.  The hardest part was getting the circular blade properly mounted; that took a couple of minutes.After that, it was simply a matter of adding water into the reservoir and using the saw.  I cut 3/8" granite tiles, 18" x 18".  As others advised, I took my time, but the blade had no problem cutting the granite.  The dual ruler markings make it easy to align and make straight cuts.  The guard over the blade works great--it keeps the saw from spitting water everywhere.  The top of the saw has channels which capture water and direct it back into the reservoir.  Nice.There's a side extension, which was somewhat useful.  The guide locks well and the engraved rulers are accurate and extremely useful.  I made about 50 different cuts of all my granite tiles and they were all perfect.Yes, this saw is slightly more pricey than the other saw that's really popular here.  But for me, the extra price of this Skil saw was worth it for the power and relative lack of water spitting.  I feel pretty confident that I could tackle some more tile jobs around the house, saving me a lot of money.  If a complete beginner/amateur like me can use this saw and feel good about it, then this must be a five-star product.  Highly recommended.

I've been taking adult piano for just over a year now, and this Easy Movie Fake book is perfect for me!  It's perfect for any advanced beginner piano student.  The chords are listed in the back and there's plenty of easy to play songs inside.  The book is out of print, so it's easy to overpay because it's in demand.  The arrangements themselves are very simple, so players who are above the beginner stage may find the songs less than challenging.  Still, the book is exactly what the title says:  the Easy Move Fake Book.  Hence, it deserves five stars for being exactly what it claims to be, at a reasonable price.

It's a cover port for the Nikon 1 V1...one of the most "easy to lose" items ever invented.  At least the replacement is easy to find, order, and it's reasonably priced.  Since this is identical to the OEM product, it fits perfectly.  There's not much else to say, so if you lost your port cover for the Nikon V1, this is the replacement.

I ordered the floral corset lace up bustier as a gift for a friend of mine who models.  One of the challenges with Internet ordering is making sure things are the right size and will fit.  As it turned out, this corset fits her perfectly and she's happy with it.  For the price as well, it's an excellent value.  Shipping is from China, so it won't be as quick as ordering from Amazon normally would be, but getting a nice-looking corset that fits is worth the short delay for shipping.  A good value, a proper fit, and a reasonable quality item means 5 stars.

Got this Moen drain for my new stainless steel sink.  Fits perfectly, looks good and works great.  The stopper holds water in the sink without any problem.  If you're buying any kind of standard sink, this is the drain to get.It is a chromed-stainless steel look, not brushed.  So if you need it to perfectly match a brushed-stainless steel sink, this won't.  However, it's barely noticeable if you do install it in a brushed steel finish, and I doubt anyone would ever notice or care.

This is a good sink.  I needed an undermount sink to go with my new granite countertops, and like most people shopping on Amazon, I wanted to get the best one possible while not spending a ton of money.  Having gotten a stainless steel sink before for a prior home, I was concerned about getting a sink without a tinny sound.  What got my attention first was the price--this sink is far less expensive than competitive sinks.  The second thing that got my attention was that it has sound-dampening pads underneath the sink.I was concerned about the thickness of the sink--18 gauge steel is pretty thin; 16 gauge would be preferable.  And when the sink arrived, the light weight made me a bit more concerned, especially compared to the cast iron sink it replaced.  Once the sink and new faucet got installed though, all my fears evaporated and turned to joy.  Because this sink is an absolutely fantastic value and it works great!Turning on the tap, the sound of the water hitting the sink was soft like with the cast iron sink, not tinny at all.  The sound dampening pads really work great!  I don't need to add any kind of insulation or coating on the bottom to make it more solid.  It looks and fits great inside my kitchen sink cabinet, which is 35 inches wide.  It's a deep sink too, 9" plus the height of the granite.  It came without drains, so I had to buy those separately (one for a disposal and a regular one with a strainer basket stopper).Both bowls are equal-sized, so if you have particularly large pots, you might want to consider a sink with one bowl larger than the other or even a single bowl sink.  Otherwise, this sink is fine for most dishes, pots, and pans.  The stainless steel with the brushed finish is perfect for hiding normal wear and tear.Bottom-line:  great sink, great price, has sound dampening, and sounds good and solid when water hits the sink (no tinny sound).  A little thin and light, but you can't tell that once it's mounted.  An excellent value and good choice.

After getting my kitchen and bathroom counters replaced, I decided to do the new backsplashes myself, which necessitated getting some drywall spackling to repair the holes and scrapes from when the old backsplashes were removed.  Initially, I got a generic drywall spackle from the local "HD" store, and that worked pretty well.  However, I ran out with a couple of rooms left to do, so I ran out to the other big-box hardware store competitor "L" and found that DAP Vinyl Spackling was available for the same price as the generic, so I picked that up.  What a big mistake!Unlike the generic, this vinyl spackling ran down the drywall like slowly melting ice cream.  It did fine on really small gouges, but if the damage was wide or deep, it didn't work as well as the generic.  It seems to be significantly wetter than the generic and this made it a problem.  It also really likes to stick to itself, but it doesn't seem to like sticking to the drywall.  So, I would apply it to the wall, then watched as it slowly oozed down the gouge, leaving a depression at the top of the gouge and a beer belly of spackling hanging off the bottom of the gouge.Working it with a straight edge to get it flat was also a problem.  Again, it's okay for small gouges, but for anything deeper than 1/8" or wider than an inch, I found that the straight edge tended to grab this spackle and pull it out of the hole or gouge.  Instead of a nice flat surface, I often either had the spackle pull out of the hole or make pointy spackle mountains.  Using a wet straight edge had its own problems, making the spackle even wetter so it would run faster out of the gouge.The instructions say to use it above 50 degrees.  Well, I can't even recommend using it at any temperature.  Sure, it's spackle and yes, it's going to eventually cover the holes with repeated applications.  I'm sure it'll last a long time and is less likely to crumble compared to generic spackle.  But given the two different experiences I had today, where the generic stuff applied well, stuck to the drywall, and was way easier to work with, I cannot give this vinyl spackle more than two stars.I really hate to rate it this low, because I've used and liked DAP products in the past.  But I can't let anyone else waste their time by using this stuff when the generic spackling works better.  From what I've read online, vinyl spackling is supposed to be for bigger and deeper gouges, but this stuff would require you to apply it in multiple coats to fill the gouge/hole.  Unless you specifically need vinyl spackling, I suggest staying with the generic drywall stuff which is easier to apply and less frustrating.

This is a beautiful, entry-level Swiss automatic watch. With its classic look, which include a date complication at the three o'clock position and Arabic numerals at 12, 6, and 9 positions, the Hamilton is a great introduction to collecting watches.  The band is brown leather, with a buckle.  The face of this model has gold markings against an off-white background, with a patterned-center.  Lume is dim, but sufficient. The hands have a nice shape to them.In terms of accuracy, mechanical watches are generally not up to the accuracy of a quartz watch.  My particular Hamilton was is no exception,  sometimes gaining 10 seconds a day or losing about 6 seconds a day, depending upon how the watch is moved during the day.  Over the course of a week, it's within 30 seconds of the correct time.If I had to cite a weakness for this design, it would be the power reserve of this self-winder.  A couple of time, after wearing it all day, the watch would be dead the next day, having run down about 12 hours after I took it off.  That seems a little short to me.  Either I'm not moving my wrist enough or the watch isn't very efficient at capturing my movements. Since the watch is dressy, odds are that most users will move their wrists/arms in a typical office environment,  that is to say, not as active as someone constantly doing physical labor.  Compared to my cheap Invictas with their Japanese movements, the Hamilton doesn't apparently have a large reserve or perhaps only winds in one rotational direction.Compared to my Oris, this watch is quite favorable, with its conservative good looks and Swiss mechanics.  It's priced much more moderately too.Tissot makes a similar watch that you might also consider.Overall, not the best Swiss watch, but certainly a good choice to start with.  It has the classic look, Swiss internals which are found in more expensive watches, and a price that makes it affordable.

Beautiful watch; the photos really don't do it justice.  The face has some dimensionality and depth to it, making it a good looking watch.It keeps perfect time.  Over the last two weeks, it has been 100% accurate, with no deviation from the time I initially set it to.  It matches my radio-controlled Casio watch (which is synchronized to an atomic clock daily).  I expect that it will hold fairly close to the claimed 10 seconds accuracy per year.The hand sweeps quite nicely, better than mechanical automatic watches.  It helps to set it apart from other quartz watches.Bottom-line, it feels good to have a watch that keeps accurate time that doesn't require a daily synchronization and that looks much more expensive than it really is.  This precisionist movement is really worth the investment, although your experience may vary.

Trying to make the home more energy efficient can be difficult when the outdoor lights have the tiny candelabra base instead of the standard light bulb base.  But instead of getting all new outdoor fixtures, I decided to use these Feit 4.8 Watt LED bulbs to replace the 40 watt incandescent bulbs in the fixtures.The good news:  they fit the candelabra base just fine.  The bulbs are a little fatter than the standard incandescent bulbs, but this turned out not to be a problem for my light fixture.  If you have a tight squeeze in a fixture with regular bulbs, you may find these ones a little too fat.More good news:  I had to replace nine incandescent bulbs, but since these use so little energy I'm basically getting light from nine bulbs while using the same power as one of the old incandescent bulbs.The so-so news:  The light is not as bright/penetrating as the old incandescent bulbs.  I would say that they put out more than a 25 watt bulb, but less than a new 40 watt bulb.  Since incandescent bulbs exhibit worse performance over time, these bulbs should be much more consistent.  The light is more white than warm; 3000 degrees Kelvin is pretty generous, and I think it's closer to 4000 as the light is fairly white.  It works just fine for my outdoor application.Overall I am happy with my bulbs.  I ordered three packages and all nine bulbs are working fine.  The bulbs are marked as suitable for a damp environment, so outdoors in an enclosure should be fine.  I can't give them the full five stars because they simply aren't as bright as they claim (although they are pretty close).  The relatively high price will be offset by cost savings and reliability over time, so hopefully the claimed life is accurate.  And using 1/10 the energy of my old lights makes me feel better.

I've now had this watch for over a year, so I can definitely say a few things about it.  This is a diver-style watch, with silver face and rose-gold colored markings, including the rotating bezel and arrowhead hash marks.  In keeping with current styles, it's quite large, quite thick and heavy, which makes it somewhat impractical as a daily dress watch.  Indeed, it's so thick that some people may have trouble with dress shirt cuffs and this watch.  That's a shame, because it's (in my opinion) a beautiful watch to look at.  It looks far more expensive than it actually is, and the contrast of the rose gold with the silver face draws plenty of eyes to look at it.Dress watches are usually much thinner, but many people now wear diver's watches as their "daily beater" to work.  The style of this watch would seem more suited to the office than the garage though, and that's where the size becomes something of a drawback.  Unless your have some room in your shirt cuffs or wear (horrors!) short-sleeve shirts, you're going to notice your shirt catching on this watch.Invicta has placed a Japanese Seiko NH35a self-winding movement inside the beautiful case, and this movement has some really nice features.  For example, unlike less expensive Seiko movements, this one "hacks" (e.g. the sweeping second hand stops when the crown is pulled all the way out) and can be hand wound when the crown is loosened from its locked-down position.  The hand-winding is a particularly nice feature if you haven't worn the watch recently and need to get it set and running quickly; it's better than twisting your wrist repeatedly to self-wind.As with most mechanical watches, the accuracy of this watch depends on day-to-day wear.  As a practical matter, I noticed the time was off by a minute or two after a couple of weeks.  This is to be expected with a self-winding watch in this price range.  It is normal and not a defect.The crystal does not have a "Cyclops" or magnifying glass over the date, which may be hard for some people to see.  I myself do not have an issue with this, but some people might.  I think leaving the Cyclops off gives the watch a better look, and I don't have a problem reading the date.The case back is see through, allowing you to show off the details of the essentially unadorned movement to interested parties.  It is pretty nice to be able to see the mechanism at work.Overall, this is a large, beautiful watch in search of the right audience.  Its size doesn't quite go with its dressy style.  Its sporty diver's look is contrasted by its dressy, rose gold accents on a silver face.  Its modern sizing contrasts with the classic look.  The pairing of a reliable Japanese automatic movement at this price point is remarkable.  If you can handle the size and the look, it's a good value.  Just know that it's not your granddaddy's watch and it won't be as thin or as small as you might expect.  Think of it as the BBW of watches.

This is a truly beautiful timepiece, with a clean classic look.  While some prefer a watch with Roman numerals, I prefer the Arabic numbers instead.  The silver-faced dial is clean, with raised numerals and hash marks.  The date complication is located at the 6 o'clock position, which gives this watch a very balanced, even look that doesn't exist with watches where the date is displayed at the 3 o'clock position.The exhibition back displays the Oris movement, with the red Oris balance wheel.  It's actually an ETA 2895-2 movement that is just a modification of the ETA 2892 for a small second hand.  Oris does some decorating, but at its base, it's an ETA movement, found in many other Swiss watches.In terms of time keeping, the watch has been accurate over the last two days, varying only by a second.  Since the calendar must be adjusted periodically, the variation of a few seconds over a couple of months can easily be corrected when adjusting the calendar.The leather band is attractive.  Initially I was planning on swapping for a black band, but the dark brown band has really grown on me.  Adjusting it is very easy with Oris' band deployment.Overall, an excellent choice for anyone who needs a classic, understated dress watch with a Swiss movement.About the only flaw is that as a dress watch, it's not rated for anything other than hand-washing water resistance.  The watch isn't designed for swimming.

This is a great, stylish watch that keeps very good time, but its success in styling is marred by a truly horrible band attachment that prevents the band from curving down my wrist.  This is a good to great watch for someone with a wrist above 7-1/2 or 7-3/4 inches, but below that, the horns/connectors of the watch will cause the band to stick out slightly from the wrist.  Unfortunately, the connectors are not flexible.  It's a real shame, as this is a stylish, nice looking dress watch that isn't expensive.Besides being stylish, a major plus for this watch is the easy adjusting band, which features infinite adjustments which can be done by just about anyone at home.  The band itself is comfortable and the double-clasp system seems sturdy enough for me on this model.  The watch face is beautiful, with carbon fiber edging.  The white numbers are legible.  The date complication is somewhat small though and the watch will have to be held somewhat closer to be able to read the date (black numbers on a white background).  The crown is small, and doesn't feel terribly sturdy.  In fact, it feels like the cheapest thing on the watch, which is a shame because the watch itself is really beautiful.The date can be adjusted by pulling the crown out halfway and turning the crown so the top rotates counter-clockwise (when viewed from the side).Given the cheap feel of the crown and the limitation of the band attachments, I can't rate this watch higher than 3 stars for people with wrists 7-1/2" or smaller.  Indeed, while the watch case is 40mm, with the band issue, the watch is effectively 50mm in size on the wrist.  Definitely a beautiful watch but only for those with large diameter wrists.

I attended the Comic-Con panel on July 24, 2014, which featured Adam West, Julie Newmar, and Burt Ward, as well as clips from the Blu-ray release and information on extras. I can confirm that the Limited Edition Blu-Ray will include never before seen photos, a Hot Wheels Batmobile, and several featurettes on the disks.  The episodes themselves look gorgeous--scratches cleaned up, colors corrected, modest sharpening done.  At the split screens showing the old TV broadcast vs. the new Blu-Ray, the improvements were stunning.  This will be a "must-own" for physical media.  Episodes will be complete and uncut. They even showed cameos by Dick Clark, the Green Hornet and Kato, and Bill Dana as Jos Jimenez. Fans will not be disappointed.UPDATE:Here's an update on the set after actual delivery:The Blu-ray completely lives up to the picture quality shown at Comic-Con.  Colors pop off the screen, the image is sharp with no annoying noise or grain, even in dark scenes.  For example, you can make out when Batman needs a shave, the natural grain in Batman's cowl, even the ragged threads of Batman's cape.  For the first time, I noticed that Batman's "ears" are a different color than most of his cowl. Simply amazing.Because the original show was not wide screen, on modern HDTVs, you can expect black bars on the side of your screen.The seasons are individually-cased, and each season has disks that are color-coded, so you won't accidentally mix up the disks.  Special features are on the last disk in the Season 3 set.I can also confirm that the "Batgirl Pilot" is included in the special features, under the section entitled "Bat Rarities! Straight from the Vault".  Also included there are Burt Ward's screen test with Adam West, Screen tests of Lyle Waggoner and Peter Deyell, and a tribute to James Blakeley, production manager on Batman and The Green Horner.The Batgirl Pilot is not re-mastered, so the colors are faded with scratches and other defects visible.The included Episode Guide is okay, but while it gives a short description of each episode, lists the villain, original airdate, writer and director, it doesn't list the guest star(s) for each episode.  The actors playing the villains are named only the first time they make an appearance in an episode; subsequent episodes only list the villains name, which is fine unless you have to want to view a later episode and can't remember which actor is playing the villain.This set is exactly what it was promised to be--the best color, the best imagery, the most complete set of the Batman TV-series ever.  It's the pinnacle of what Blu-ray was meant to deliver.  Gripe about the price, but it's well worth it if you love Batman and have a high-definition set.  Five stars.

I love these USB 2.0 Mediabridge cables.  I use them primarily as charging cables for my cell phones and other devices that have a micro-USB connection and need maximum power.With these cables and a 2.1 amp charger, my Samsung S4 charges at the maximum rate--a much quicker recharge than plain USB.  With ordinary cables, the phone will charge at a much slower level.As a data cable, it works just fine for transferring files.  The connections are reliable.Quality-wise, you can't beat these cables.  The insulation is thick.  I like the 10 foot length--makes it easy to plug a phone into a wall charger and keep the phone on a nightstand or table.  The usual 6 foot cables never seem to be long enough.  The connectors are sturdy and are gold-plated, just as advertised.It's tempting to buy cheaper cables, but don't do it.  These Mediabridge cables are the best you can get and they're worth it.

I can only echo what everyone else here has said:  the Karcher T350 surface cleaner works and it's a real time saver.  Setup is less than 5 minutes, and the unit itself has options for power (moving the heads closer or further from the surface to be cleaned) and lift (opening doors for how much the unit "hovers" over the surface).On my dirty driveway, it took what would be about 3 to 4 hours with a wand into an almost pleasant 45 minute session with minimal splash back.  Yes, some dirt and debris will still leak out, so expect to get the bottom 4 inches or so of you pants covered in grime.  Likewise, some debris will fly out and stick onto walls several inches above the ground, but this easily washes off with a regular water rinse.On a sloping driveway, the water does run downhill carrying most, but not all of the dirt.  You can lift the unit to get a blast of water to help clear the remaining dirt, lest it sit and dry in place.The unit actually does hover quite nicely, and bit of care is needed or the unit will fly up from the water pressure.  The Karcher T350 does come with a two-piece metal hose tube that screws directly into the trigger wand of many pressure washers.  An adapter is included to fit with some types of wands from non-Karcher pressure washers.  The user holds onto the tube much like a broom, only with a grip to keep the unit from lifting off the ground.Definitely a "must buy" for anyone who uses a pressure washer to clean areas like driveways.  It's a huge time saver and easy to use.

I ordered the Generac 6596 2,800 pressure washer and when it arrived, I couldn't wait to start using it to clean my driveway.  Setup was very easy, taking about 20 minutes to get the pieces out of the box, get the handle onto the frame, screwing on some hoses, and adding oil and fuel.  No tools were required, so even the most unskilled person could get this thing working easily.The instructions remind you in multiple places never to start without having your water hooked up and turned on, so as long as you follow the setup instructions, it shouldn't be a problem getting the washer working.  Mine started on the first pull, which is pretty impressive.This model of Generac comes with 4 wand tips, ranging from a cleaning solution tip to a 0 degree "blast" tip.  I paired mine up with a Karcher T350 surface cleaner (rated at 2650 psi, so use at your own risk), and it worked great cleaning my driveway.  It made a normally 2 to 4 hour job a 45 minute job, plus it didn't leave streaks or areas where I missed.The large wheels and upright orientation make the pressure washer easy to move around, and the placement of the hose connectors made it easy NOT to accidentally get the hose up against the hot engine (a cause of failure in other models).  This Generac also comes with a detergent reservoir, although since I didn't use it, I can't say how well it works.Bottom-line for me:  this is an affordable power washer that does the job.  It cost me less than what I would have paid a professional, it accepted an inexpensive surface cleaner attachment, and it's powerful enough to get a dirt and moss encrusted driveway clean.  I can't speak to long-term reliability, but I will update if there are any significant changes in performance.

This movie is one of my favorites from when I was a child.  The images of flying saucers attacking Washington DC stuck with me for decades (and in fact, the scenes are basically stolen again for "Mars Attacks!").  While Mars Attacks! is a bore, Earth vs. the Flying Saucers has a distinct 1950's charm to it.  From the idea that 1950's technology could somehow match the civilization of an interstellar race to the boss marrying his secretary employee,  it's a snapshot of an optimistic yet paranoid time long gone by.One of the more interesting scenes involves a "differential analyzer," a primitive type of computer seen both here and in "When Worlds Collide" (another great classic sci-fi movie).  Today, we have phones that are way more powerful than a device that took up half a room.  There's reel to reel tape recorders, V2 style rockets, and some primitive but effective special effects miniatures.The plot is fairly simple:  aliens intend to force the Earth to surrender, and make contact with a rocket scientist to act as their go-between.  Earth decides to resist of course, so it's up to the rocket scientist to come up with a way to drive the invaders away, culminating in a spectacular battle in Washington, DC.Today, we know far more from movies about things like lasers, kinetic energy weapons, computers, etc. so this movie definitely will feel dated to today's more sophisticated audience.  But it's still enjoyable as a classic and as a snapshot of the life/society was like back then.  It's practically begging for a modern remake that isn't a boring parody (I'm looking at you, Mars Attacks!).  Definitely a must own for fanatical movie sci-fi fans, for someone looking for something to entertain young kids (a few people do die though), and for people who just like older movies.  Nit-pickers and people in love with modern special effects won't enjoy this movie as much.

I needed a replacement sensor after my original sensor disappeared from outside.  I was pleased to find out that a new sensor was inexpensive and this one was fully compatible with my base station (just check the back of your readout station for the IT-915 logo if you need to check compatibility with this sensor).When I received it, it was as simple as popping batteries into the remote sensor, then into the base station and waiting 30 seconds for them to sync up.My wireless sensor has been outdoors in some heavy rain, sheltered under a plant.  It's working fine and keeps accurate temperatures (I like it a lot better than the competing Acurite weather station I also own).  If you need a replacement temperature sensor for the IT-915 system, this is the one.

I got two sets of these chairs for my round patio table, and they look really nice.  As others have noted, you can't really keep them folded up unless you use a strap or rope on the seat, and turning them upside down to keep it folded will likely scratch the top of the seat and the arm tips.  The chairs seem sturdy enough, but I wouldn't put someone over 250 lbs. into one of these chairs.  The connections appear to be good quality brass, so they should last even in bad weather.  The seat width at the front is 18" and at the rear seat, the width is 14.5".  The height of the arms is 25.5".I also ordered some teak oil to keep the chairs looking nice.  Bottom-line on these chairs:  they look good, appear to be good quality, and arrived in perfect condition.  5 stars.  I will update if there's a material change as these chairs age.

I purchased this carpet cleaner because I realized it was half the price of having a commercial carpet cleaner come in.  I had previously owned a Hoover, which I liked but I had given it away several moves ago.  This model is a more advanced version of what I had owned.  Quite simply, this is an excellent cleaner that sucks up a lot of dirt without soaking the carpet.  The brushes work great and help to loosen the dirt.What sets this cleaner apart is the clean water rinse ability.  Most other cleaners spray a mix of detergent and water, then vacuum it up.  This Hoover allows for a plain water rinse, which not only pulls up more dirt, but leftover detergent as well.My carpets dried within a few hours and look better than when I had the carpets professionally cleaned.  Plus, I can clean them any time I want for just the cost of detergent.Disassembly and cleaning are easy.  It's shocking to pour out the dirty water tank.  A quick rinse in the tub and the tanks are good to go.I really like this cleaner and it earns 5 stars for value and performance.

Somehow, I always pictured Harry Bosch as more rumpled and heavier, but Titus Welliver does a credible job at capturing the rough-edged detective.  The LA locations and supporting actors, coupled with a good storyline, really help to make this Pilot work, and I hope Amazon approves it as a series, although I don't want them to take 10 episodes to solve a murder.(spoilers follow)In the pilot, Harry Bosch is a driven LA homicide detective who lives alone and has no life except for his murder cases.  He's so driven that he'll even take overtime work from other cops, just to have a puzzle to solve.  While working overtime, he's called to meet with a retired doctor, whose dog has found what appears to be the bone of a child.  Complicating matters for Bosch is the fact that he's also facing a civil suit for killing a serial killer suspect, that he doesn't trust his assistant chief, and that he's under media scrutiny for his civil trial.Compared to the books, the live action version makes a few changes.  Obviously, unlike the book Bosch, the Amazon Bosch is not a Vietnam veteran.  Deputy Chief Irvin Irving is now an African-American, where in the books, he seemed more like an angry, uptight white guy.  However, he still likes jazz and still lives on a hillside.Overall, this pilot is very refreshing.  The characters are interesting and the acting and dialogue are believable.  Titus Welliver is watchable as Harry Bosch, and he conveys the essential pain and emotional walling off of Harry Bosch, without ever revealing it to the other characters.  A few things bothered me--the skull of the murder victim looked too adult (the bones shouldn't be joined together like that); Bosch is just a little too smooth with the ladies; there aren't any real angry exchanges between Irving and Bosch.  But given a chance, this show has the capability to hit some real high notes.  Definitely worth investing in, not only for Amazon, but for the viewer as well.

(spoilers follow, although I don't know how something rotten can be spoiled more).I had great hopes when I saw that Chris Carter of the X-files was the writer and director.  However, within seconds of the show starting, those hopes were dashed by the truly horrific acting of French actress Louise Monot, who practices completely unconvincingly for her audition.  Apparently, she's in LA looking for an acting gig, while her husband and daughter are in NYC, where there are apparently no acting gigs.  Right.This is followed by a bunch of really annoying people all getting together on an elevator, just like that Twilight Zone episode where all the characters turn out to be dolls stuck in the donation bin.  Drunk/rude Irishman? Check.  Rich old lady?  Check.  Bad French actress? Check.  Lady cop wearing vest but no patches/badge?  Check.  When the elevator stops and the bickering begins, I instantly hated every one of these characters, mostly because they don't talk or behave like real people do.After escaping the elevator and finding themselves trapped in the garage (which conveniently doesn't have a fire exit), our group is joined by the snooty lawyer dude from Heroes and his prostitute girlfriend, along with an escaped African-American convict who claims to have been wrongly convicted.  At this point, you'd be correct in thinking that Chris Carter thinks we're mushrooms, because he's feeding us crap and keeping us in the dark.  None of this story works.  It only gets worse as the story progresses, and we see what's happening outside the building.The characters don't act like normal people.  They don't talk like normal people. Worse, the "event" that keeps them together makes no sense either.  Having been in real disasters, I can tell you that people do not walk about aimlessly in downtown cities, nor do they start behaving badly.  Indeed, disasters in the real world have a tendency to bring out the best in people helping each other.  Not for Chris Carter apparently.  His extras just walk around with no apparent purpose except for eye candy; there's no logic at all to why the group never bothers to ask each others' names; and we have no idea why this group of people sticks together when clearly, they don't even like each other.  Imagine being trapped in a room with a guy who smells of alcohol, an obnoxious lawyer, a gay clown, and a cop who just shot someone; and then imagine what you might do after you got away from them.  Yeah, that's not what the stupid French actress does.This intrepid band of losers decamps to the rich old lady's Bel Air mansion (so the hooker can get naked in front of strangers for a swim and quote the Bible), only later to flee to the well-known Bel Air National Forest (?), conveniently located behind the house (?), because they're too stupid to recognize a bunch of gang members with guns ("They're here to rescue us!").  There in the forest, they encounter a demon creature and the show ends, mercifully.Now the show has some possible good points.  I like the creepiness as the characters all discover they have something in common.  The demon creature is good.  And I don't mind that the hooker character gets nekkid and goes swimming while LA burns.Sadly though, this is like picking corn out of a dung heap.  I really expected more from Amazon and Chris Carter.  The truly bad acting, the unlikeable characters, the bad writing, and the implausible behaviors all act like lead weights on a boat, sinking this pilot show.  Clearly, Chris Carter was aiming for some kind of Neil Gaiman-like story but ended up with a bad Tim LaHaye "Left Behind" interpretation instead.  You deserve better--don't watch this loser.

When Worlds Collide is based on a book of the same name, which influenced movies from this one to Deep Impact and Armegeddon.  Parts of the book have been changed to make the movie more entertaining.Produced by legendary sci-fi producer George Pal, When Worlds Collide tells the story of what happens when astronomers discover that the world is on a collision course with a rogue star.  Scientists desperately try to create a "space ark" to send survivors to a planet accompanying the rogue star, in the hopes of saving a small remnant of the human race.Released in 1951, the movie offers some good color and good acting.  The lead male reminds me a bit of Danny Kaye, but thankfully never bursts into song or starts dancing.  Sharp-eyed viewers will notice Hayden Rourke (Doctor Bellows from I Dream of Jeannie) or Stuart Whitman (Those Magnificent Men and Their Flying Machines), but the real star is the 1951 special effects, which look pretty good even today, although they use a lot of miniatures and matte paintings.Definitely a "must see" for anyone who is serious about their science fiction movie collection.

The app is easy to install and to operate on the Fire HDX.  It establishes a presence in the top drop-down menu that allows you to temporarily turn the camera back on when you need it. It prevents both the front and back cameras from operating so apps can't turn them on without your permission. You may have to go into your Settings > Privacy > Administrators and give Camera Block administrator permission for it lock down the cameras.

This is regarding the full, paid version of the game.I would probably have given this game a four-star rating, but unfortunately when I was on the next-to-last chapter and opened up the game to play, the game opened up a window and said that the file had been corrupted and that the game would restart. So after hours of play, I was kicked back to the beginning of the game and all of my progress was lost.Also once you got beyond the blue dragon's gatekeeper scenes, the map only showed the location of the chapter's main objective, e.g. gathering the dragon eggs, rather than the scenes where the player needed to completely an action - as it had previously been showing.The game otherwise was enjoyable. Artwork was beautiful. Hidden object scenes had items appropriate to the setting and time, and seemed to be paced nicely throughout the story; there were plenty of them for those who like them (I do, when they are well done). There was a nice mix of puzzles; I only skipped one. The map allowed you to travel from one location to another.  Setting the story in ancient China made it a nice change from the usual fantasy locales.  There are three game difficulty modes; I played the middle one which only put sparkles on the HO scenes, and no glints on points of action.I played the other Myths of the World game (IIRC, Spirit Wolf)  in this series on this same device and had no problem with it.I liked this game, but since the "whodunit" was known right from the start, I have no interest in replaying it to see if I can even get past the point where it glitched.  Too bad; it's getting deleted.

Did a marathon read of Sweep In Peace, because once I started I couldn't put it aside. What a well-plotted story, with the plot and subplots alll twisting and turning on each other throughout the story, yet all meeting up at the same place in the end. It's not "great literature", just a really well-told story. A number of other authors in the urban fantasy field (we all know who they are) should use this book as a primer regarding pacing and character development. There were a lot of characters in this book, but each of them was nuanced just enough to let them remain distinctive in the reader's mind, and their behaviors made sense in the context of who they were and what cultures they represented. The author(s) took the time to shade the characters with gray, so they weren't merely stereotypes of typical "alien" races, and in doing so they also did a lot of great world-building for those cultures - something other authors can't achieve even with multiple books.I would recommend reading "Clean Sweep" first, because although this book can be read as a stand-alone, "Clean Sweep" first introduces some characters that appear in this book and begins a loose story arc that this book continues.Here's hoping there are many more books in this series. So far, I've never read a book by Ilona Andrews that I didn't enjoy, and there aren't all that many authors that I can say that about.

I've reached the stage where all of my umbrellas have one edge that no longer attaches to the spokes, so it was time to get a new one.  I usually try to get the Totes brand, because I've had good luck with them over the years.  I've already had auto-open umbrellas, but this one has the extra feature of auto-close, so how could I resist?The umbrella comes with a mesh holding case, which shows that someone was thinking, because it's much easier for a closed umbrella to dry out that way.  The case also has a stretchy cord shoulder strap, in addition to the strap that is on the umbrella itself, giving you two carrying options.  The open/close function worked without a problem.  Unfortunately, they haven't yet figured out a way to make the stem collapse down by itself, once it has been extended, but it's no problem to close it down and lock it back into placeThe opened umbrella is not as large as a golf umbrella, not is it as small as one of those Totes that you can fit into a a pocketbook easily.  To me, it is the perfect size.  It will shield me, my pocketbook and any items I might be carrying.  It is also a good two-person umbrella.  I got this one with with colored stripes because it reminded me of a beach umbrella that my family used to have - a cheery thought when used on a gloomy rainy day.

This was a total impulse buy for me (darn Daily Deals!).  I wanted it to use in the kitchen.  I've got an old oven and I have had no way of knowing exactly whether or not the set temperature equals the actual temperature.  I also want to do some frying and didn't want to bother getting a specific thermometer to attach to the pan/pot to measue the oil temperature.  So I picked this little gadget up and it does exactly what I need it to do.  I just point, click the trigger and the temperature readout occurs on the lighted LED screen.  It's very easy to use and to operate.  If you want to use it to, say, check the temperature of walls and ceilings and the like, it also has a red laser light that you can turn on/off to use to pinpoint the exact spot you want to check.  It uses a 9 volt battery that installs into the handle, and the battery is included - which is much appreciated.

This is a boom box that it built to boom; it's not one of those things that you're going to put on an end table or a night stand.  This thing is big and heavy, with speakers that look like they mean business.  Fortunately, the sound this thing puts out substantiates its big bad look, and a carrying strap is also included. The sound was great across the spectrum - treble, mid-range, and base.  Cranking it up put out a lot of sound without distortion.Bluetooth connected without a problem.  There's no CD player, but with every device and its brother having Bluetooth capability now, it's not really missed.  The FM tuner worked well.  The thing takes 10 D cell batteries to operate, so you can figure what the added weight of that is, but it can also be operated via AC if you're going to be near an electrical outlet.

When I first chose this book to review, I was initially put off by the title, because I thought that it was going to be a Hunger Games clone, and I am one of the few people in this world who apparently has no interest in the Hunger Games series.  Thankfully, it's not like it at all.  It is more of a space opera, more akin as another reviewer mentioned to Catherine Asaro's Skolian Empire in that the characters' backstories are just as interesting as the current plot (or subplot). The setting isn't static, and there's interesting world-building begun (this is obviously the beginning of a series) that can lead to a lot of off-shoot stories if the author handles them correctly.I found this to be one of those books that once you start reading, time passes without you really realizing it.  And I was surprised at that, because I was reading a paper book, when for the past couple of years most of my reading has been mainly ebooks and I wasn't quite sure if dead tree versions would still hold my interest as well, since I can't fiddle with the type size and fonts.I'll definitely be looking for the next book by this author.

This was a good book for kids who have moved away from picture books and have entered the chapter book phase, but who still like to see some pictures in their books.  The story was well-written, involving girls spending a summer at their grandmother's ranch, with the main storyline involving the horses and dogs, and the lessons learned from interacting with and caring for animals.  It's perfect for the young girl who is in that horse-crazy stage.  The vocabulary used allowed reading without stumbling over the words, and the story was nicely plotted to hold the reader's interest.  My test girl kidlet enjoyed the book (age 9).

I've had a number of Swiffer products over the years but I think this is one of my favorites.  It's basically a cordless vacuum with a Swiffer dust pad on the bottom.  It contains a rechargeable battery so when you're done using it, you just plug it into an outlet to charge until its next use.  This isn't a powerful vacuum for picking up things on carpets, for example, but for hard surfaces it works very well.  My test kidlets make a mess every time I feed them so there's always crumbs and such on the kitchen floor.  This Swiffer makes it very easy to pick up their mess with very little effort.  The pads are easy to change (and can be reused if the floor isn't super dirty) and I had no problems emptying out the dust cup.  It's easy to operate, to move around, and isn't especially noisy.  I'd definitely recommend this product, especially for someone who has to do a lot of quick clean-ups, or for someone who's starting to have difficulty bending down to hold the dustpan when sweeping the floor.

This is one of those toys that's just cool to have.  It's not some itsy-bitsy little dinosaur; it's a great big honking thing that no one is ever going to trip over by accident.  It wasn't hard to assemble, though I did need help slamming one piece in. It has lights and sound and motion and everything.  It's designed so that it's not simply a dinosaur moving forward on the floor; kids can use their imaginations and create scenarios for the characters that accompany the dinosaur and the various perches that exist on the creature itself. The majority of the actions that can be done with the creature are non-motorized, so if the batteries die, the dinosaur can still be played with while waiting for the battery replacement.  My test kidlet (now 7) has had a blast playing with this toy, and it's one of the ones that he still pulls out to play with.

The test truck for this review was Dodge Ram 1500 Quad-Cab.The mats were well-made, and the set consists of two front mats and a single-piece back mat.  The back mat is designed so that it can be cut into two separate mats for a better fit.  In our instance, they had to be cut that way.  The mats are black with some gray inserts in the front mats.  Since these are somewhat universal mats, they are designed to be cut to fit the individual vehicle.  The mats can be cut easily with scissors but for fine trimming a razor is best.The front mats fit the 1500 well, with only minor trimming.  The mat gripped to the floor well under use - no slipping or sliding.  The back mat had to be cut into two separate mats for a better fit.  The back mats also required a lot of trimming to get them to fit properly under the back chair; they were a little too long.  So the front mats fit well, the rear mats not so well, but they are still very usable.While there are a lot of little channels and indents to hold water and snow and dirt, these mats are not the kind that are really going to hold a lot of liquid.  They aren't designed with large channels with high edges to really prevent spillover onto the carpet; the design seems to be geared for more everyday use.  It'll probably handle the wetness from a rainstorm okay but not for multiple days of melting snow, for example.Compared to the original equipment mats, these are not as thick.  You could perhaps call them "heavy duty" if all you do with your truck is general driving, similar to car driving.  But if you use your truck for work, where you are climbing in and out all the time, wearing heavy work boots and depositing a lot of dirt and grit on the mats, we're estimating that the mats will probably last a couple of years.  They aren't really "heavy duty" in the context of that type of use.  But for the average suburban truck owner they will probably last longer than a non-"heavy duty" mat.All in all, you get value for the price you're paying, and if the mats fit your particular truck well then you are ahead of the game and can avoid the cost of custom mats.  These are good mats and the price is good for a full set.
