Thought was put into the design to allow for higher wear by the gas pedal, and in the ways the mats could be trimmed to fit a particular truck model.  I'd recommend them.

Oh, this rug feels so good under my feet!  If I had this wall-to-wall, I would sleep on it - lol.It's very plush, very thickly woven and has a nice rubberized underside which prevents it from slipping on my bathroom's tile floor.  The size (21x36) is perfect for alongside the tub.  The linen color of this particular rug looks like it will go with most neutral-toned bathrooms, or if you want to add a neutral tone to a bolder-colored room.  I have odd-colored porcelain fixtures in my bathroom, so the linen tone doesn't quite go with the sort of pinkish/mauve-ish pale color (I call the color "fleh") they are.  That's the only thing that's giving me pause on whether or not I should buy the contour and a smaller rug to make a complete set - even though they are rather high-priced.  But I've found with bathroom rugs that you get what you pay for, so if this rug can stand up to wear and tear, and multiple washings, then it is worth its price.

I chose this product to review because while I don't thankfully have a problem with dandruff, every now and then I do get an itchy scalp and I've found in the past that using Head & Shoulders usually solves that problem, so I figured having a container of it around would be useful.This size container (14.2oz) provides a substantial amount of shampoo, so I expect it to last.  The shampoo itself is white and creamy, not too thick, not too thin.  It has a nice fresh scent that isn't overpowering.  My one minor quibble is with the design of the lid: the opening hole for the shampoo to squirt out from should have a little more of a lip around it so that when pressure on the sides of the bottle is released the remaining shampoo is sucked back into the container; that would result in less smearing of the shampoo on the container's surface.The shampoo itself suds nicely and rinses out cleanly.  I have thick hair to begin with so I was initially a little apprehensive that this would really bush it out, but my hair remained manageable which was good.  What I was also surprised at was how my hair retained its own wavy style after a night's sleep.  Usually when I wake up, my hair looks like it belongs to one of the Kazon Nistrim from Star Trek: Deep Space Nine (look up the image) - very scary.  But after using the H&S shampoo, I can just brush it out and it looks fine, which is a very strange but welcome experience for me.  The kidlets were playing hair salon with me as their customer and they complimented me on how soft my hair was.So I am very positive about this shampoo and would recommend it even if you don't have a dandruff problem.

I chose this product to review because I wanted to create recovery disks and some backups for my laptop.  Even though this is only USB 2.0, it took me only about 15 minutes to take care of business, so the transfer speed for multi-GB loads is good.  I found the ability to insert and remove the micro SDHC card from the USB plug-in a useful design, even though I do have a card reader on this computer.  I like the fact that I can pop-out the card and insert a new one; it's easier to store micro SD cards in a labeled envelope than to have a drawer full of unknown thumb drives.I found this to be a useful and worthwhile product.

For those who don't know Jon Gnagy, he started the learn-to-draw how-to shows on TV.  Back in the day, I always watched his show in fascination - how he would take simple lines and create a beautiful scene.  I had his Learn-To-Draw set as a kid and it helped teach me how to draw, understanding and using shading and perspective.  It was one of my favorite creative toys for years, and I learned so much from it.  I was adding depth and movement to my drawings way beyond what my schoolmates were doing, because of it.  One of the kidlets in my family (a 9 year old) is very artistic so I gave this to her as a birthday gift and she really appreciates it.The contents of the set are almost exactly the same as the one that I had as a child, from the artist's drawing and carbon pencils to black chalk to the smudge sticks/smudge pad to the pliable white eraser to the pencil sharpener.  Since it is the "Master Set" it also includes colored pastels, two trays of water color paints, and two paint brushes. Large sheets of white paper are included.Of course, the gem of the product - and the thing alone worth getting it for is the "Learn To Draw" booklet which, I'm happy to say, is exactly the same one I remembered.  What a walk down memory lane that was, to see those lessons on how to draw a still life with that large pumpkin, and the one about drawing the harlequin Great Dane.  I was reading over the instructions on how to create depth and perspective and they are just as clear now as they were then, and after having quite a few art classes in life, I realize how much I learned from that book.  There are also booklets on learning to draw the human figure (no genitalia shown) and a color booklet on drawing landscapes.  There are fold-out instruction on drawing with pastels and painting with watercolors.The only lack in this set is that there is no separate drawing board.  I suppose the sturdy cardboard storage section of the box could be used for that, but I missed the one that came with the set that I had as a kid.  That thing lasted forever, way beyond the time that the art supplies had all been used up.  It looks like a different Jon Gnagy set still contains a drawing board though: Jon Gnagy Original Learn to Draw SetIf you've got a kid in your family who loves to draw, I would recommend getting either this set or the one mentioned above.  The key is the learning to DRAW aspect, because once you learn the lines, perspective, vanishing point and shading of simple drawing, it is very easy to apply those things to other mediums like watercolors and oil paints.(P.S. If you're interested in seeing Jon Gnagy in action, there's videos of him up on the 'Tubes.)

If you're like me, you've been addicted to PEZ since you were a little kid.  The PEZ dispensers are all well and good, but it's the candy I crave and I eat it so fast that it wasn't even worth the effort to put it into the dispenser in the first place - lol.I've been getting my fix by buying those 6-stick refill packs that are in candy aisle in stores, but they get home and they're immediately gone.  Now, this 2lb. bag of PEZ is like having a security blanket of PEZ; I know that they aren't going to disappear at one sitting.I have Amazon Prime so I got delivery of my order fast.  What's weird was that I actually got a Sunday delivery, even though the means of shipment was shown as the USPS.  I'm not complaining, though.There seems to be a relatively even mix of all the single fruit flavors in the package - cherry, raspberry, strawberry, grape, orange and lemon.  There are none of the two-fruit combos, no chocolate, no cola, and no "Sourz".  The candy is fresh; you will not crack your teeth on the tabs if you crunch them.  The candy is delivered in a sealed plastic bag in a box that would work nicely as a gift box.An interesting fact about why it is named PEZ: the letters are taken from the German word for peppermint, "pfefferminz" - the "P" from the first letter, the "E" from the middle letter, and the "Z" from the last letter.  It was created originally as a breath mint in 1927 in Austria.  If you used to have one of the original-style dispensers like I did with the plain flip top (no cartoon characters back then), the reason why it was designed that way was so that it would mimic a cigarette lighter, to encourage people to take a PEZ instead of lighting up a cigarette.The price is good, the candy is fresh, and the delivery is fast.  Go for it.  Now.

I used to take the nephews on day-trips through New Jersey, Delaware, and Maryland when they were young, and a lot of the routes mentioned in this guide were ones that we pretty closely followed.  I've also visited some of the Pennsylvania sights mentioned, so I have practical experience of the recommendations and they are sound and worth making the effort to see.I liked the way the book is designed.  There are a lot of full-color pictures, clear maps, sightseeing detours, and historical and cultural informative tidbits about the various areas.  There are some lodgings and restaurants listed, but the main focus is on the various area sights to be seen.My only quibble was that I thought that they short-changed New Jersey a bit in the listing of places to see, a number of interesting Revolutionary era sites weren't mentioned. And they also omitted NASA's Wallops Island Visitor Center from the Delmarva trip route.  It's a neat little space museum near Chincoteague which is nice for a quick stop, and if you're lucky you might actually see a rocket launch.For me, this is a great book to pick up, thumb through and pick somewhere to take a ride to see.  Sometimes unless you have a book like this one at hand, you don't even realize all the interesting places that are within a day's drive.  The trips themselves are designed to last two to five days if you're going to follow their planned route, so they are perfect for a long getaway weekend. or a short vacation without expensive travel costs.  Sometime all you need is just a few days away from the usual hustle and bustle of normal life; it gives you a chance to recharge your mental batteries.

I chose this product to review for Vine because, frankly, I wanted to try one of these men's razor to shave my legs.  Guys always have these razors that look like they were designed in some tech whiz's lab, while we women get the small-headed, rigid pink razors.  So boring and so easy to nick oneself with them if one doesn't have model-thin legs.  If you've got a lot of leg acreage like me, using one of those little pink things takes forever.  Hence my choice to give this a try.I really liked it.  I liked the movement of the razor head along the curves of my legs, it did a good job without nicks and left smooth skin behind.  It was easy to hold and use.  I don't know yet how long the blades will hold their edge, but in my opinion, it's a better product than my usual disposable pink razors.

At the moment, for health reasons, I can't be outside as much as I'd like to be, so I gave this product to my sister to use and and asked her report back to me.  She works outdoors all day in a park system so she's constantly out in meadows, gardens, fields and woods, all those places where there are more bugs than you can shake a stick at.  She's used a lot of insect repellents over the years so she knows what works.  She liked the way this product dried instantly on the skin and said that she had no problem applying it over sunscreen - no oiliness or greasiness, no damage to clothing.  The scent was mild and didn't bother her; she said it quickly dissipated.  She has various allergies and this didn't bother any of them.  She said that it worked well against mosquitoes and other insects; she didn't get any bites while she was using the product.  She said that she would buy this Cutter product for herself to use at work; that's how well it worked for her.  She gave it a longer and more intensive workout than someone who would be just using it casually, so since it worked for her in her situation, it's a good product for general outdoor use.

This was my first experience with an infuser pitcher.  I've been trying to cut the soda habit recently and have been drinking more water and lemonade, so this is the perfect item to give the water more flavor (and probably get more Vitamin C into me, too).  I like this pitcher because it is large enough (3qt) to hold enough liquid to make it worthwhile using, yet it will fit on my refrigerator door.  I like the fact that it is dishwasher safe and BPA-free - and that the manufacturer put that info right on the label (a previous product I reviewed from Amazon didn't even have the country of manufacture listed on the product).I didn't have much of a problem figuring out how to open it, because I saw that button on the handle that opens up the center section, but I would suggest to the manufacturer that perhaps a secondary label on the device showing precisely how to open it would be helpful (having the instructions inside were somewhat redundant).  The lid twist-seals nice and tight.  It comes with an insert that contains a few recipes to get the user started.  The infuser takes up the full length of the pitcher, so you can put in as little or as much fruit as you like.  You can also remove the infuser and just use it as a regular pitcher.  The plastic seems sturdy and well-designed, and it didn't have any odd plastic smell.I like this product and I think that I'll be getting a lot of use out of it.

It's always good to have an extra micro SDHC card around for ereaders, cell phones, and cameras.  Although this Class 6 card isn't the fastest out there, it's a perfectly fine speed for the types of files that are usually stored on the previously-mentioned devices, and this class will usually work on most devices without a problem.  It does come with an adapter so you can use it with devices that use non-micro SD cards.  And I always prefer to use cards from known manufacturers because they always scan clean before use.  Although my review of the product is through the Vine program, the $5.99 price Amazon is currently charging  for 8GB of storage is a good one, and is worth getting.

I've been reading this series since its start.  It's one of my favorites, to the point where I tend to give the entire series a re-read before a new book comes out (and I also have all of the audiobook versions, too), so reading this book was a bittersweet experience for me since it is the official end of The Walker Papers where Joanne Walker is the primary character.The series is about Joanne Walker, born Siobhan Grainne McNamarra Walkingstick, the daughter of an Irish woman and a Cherokee man, born in Ireland but given to her father to raise at the age of six months.  We meet her for the first time in the book "Urban Shaman", living in Seattle and working as a police mechanic there.  She's a woman with some serious issues regarding her parents and her life.  Our introduction to her coincides with the apparent awakening of her shamanic nature while on an airplane returning from her mother's funeral in Ireland, and the series takes off from there.  She starts off as a very reluctant shaman, and only takes on the mantle because the alternative is death. This is an urban fantasy series involving the Celtic and Native American mythic pantheons and various other aspects of the paranormal and magical world.  It is set mainly in the Seattle Washington area, though there are forays to Ireland and North Carolina in later books.  One thing I've always liked about this series is the wry sense of humor that underlines it.  Horrific things happen to people along the way but it's leavened by the camaraderie between Joanne, her co-workers, and her friends.For those of you who may not have ever read this series, the author provides a concise  summary of the action in each of the previous books in the story arc so far, so if you are coming into it cold, you're brought up to speed story-wise.  But I would sincerely recommend that you begin with the first book in the series, "Urban Shaman", first rather than this one - not because you won't enjoy it - but just to prolong the pleasure of the series and to really enjoy each character's personality to the fullest, not to mention their interactions. You may learn in this book that Morrison is Joanne's main squeeze, but unless you've followed the course of their unusually convoluted relationship over the course of the series, you won't really appreciate how much she has evolved to reach the point she's at in this book in relation to him.  Cernunnos isn't merely the Celtic god of the Wild Hunt; he's been an integral part of the series from its start and his presence has forced Joanne to confront who and what she is, not to mention what she will be.Just a note for those who have been reading the series from the start.  I would highly recommend reading Ms. Murphy's book, "No Dominion", which contains parts of the story from Gary Muldoon's point of view, and recounts what happened with him and the Wild Hunt while in Ireland, and his life with his wife Annie.  It really adds another layer to the understanding of the background to this current book.For those who have been faithful readers of the series, I think you will enjoy this book; I know that I did.  While I was sad that the series has ended, Ms. Murphy ended it well.  Think of the end of a play when all the cast comes out for a bow; that's what happens in this book with various characters from all the books having either cameo appearances or mentions so we can touch base with them one last time.  It was good to be reminded of all of them and they were incorporated well into the storyline of this book so that their inclusion made sense.With the previous book in this series, "Mountain Echoes", we were left with a cliffhanger.  Joanne gets a call from her septuagenarian sidekick Gary that is wife - who died about four years ago - is alive.  This book kicks off from there, and leads to the final showdown between Joanne and the being known as The Master, whom she's been in conflict with since she came into her shamanic powers.  We've known that this confrontation has been inevitable, because it's been the underlying source of a lot of the conflicts that Joanne has faced, that it was the cause of her mother's death, and that it was basically the reason why Joanne was born as a new soul.Sometimes when there's an upcoming fight with "the big bad" in a series, the actual face-to-face conflict becomes anticlimactic and is given short shrift by the author because it's clear that the author his-or-herself has become bored with the whole storyline.  Not so with this book.  The entire book is basically the final confrontation between Joanne and The Master, with its ebb and flow highlighting the various other characters of the series.  You can tell that Ms. Murphy had a definite idea how this story arc should end, and it's a good one.I don't want to give away real spoilers but I confess I was slightly reluctant to start this book because I didn't want the series to end, and I was afraid of what might happen, because I've been burned before with the directions that certain authors have taken their characters. But having finished the book, I'm happy with it because Ms. Murphy ended it well, and in a way that was true to the characters.  Not everyone makes it through unscathed nor does everyone makes it through, period; how could they with such a cataclysmic confrontation basically between good and evil?  Seattle once again pays a  physical and emotional price for being Joanne's home.  So while I am sad over some of the things that happened, I am happy, too, over other things.  This isn't one of those books that you will throw against a wall when you're done because you're so upset over the events, or that you'll refuse to re-read (if you're like me who enjoys re-reading favorite series).  Everything that happens does so for a purpose, not on a whim, and I as a reader and a fan can accept that, and can celebrate where the conclusion leaves us.So get this book, read this book, and enjoy this book.  And let's all hope that someday in the future Ms. Murphy decides to revisit this particular universe of hers and gives us more stories.

The six-year old kidlet got this as a birthday gift, and decided that this was going to be the craft project for the day and I was going to be the one to help him with it.The reason why I decided to write this review is because I was really impressed on how well Crayola thought out the design and manufacture of this product.  It is probably the most well-designed and sturdy one that I have come across.  The case that will hold all the supplies, first of all, comes fully assembled - so that's one less step for the adults. Someone really put some thought into it because it contains a tray to store the instructions and labels and color chart, a tray to hold the measuring containers (and designed so you can temporarily lock them in place to avoid spills, while containing any that might occur), the clear side lids flip open to form upright holders for the markers while the color is being absorbed into the tip, while the interior of the container is divided into segments to hold the dye bottles and unused marker pieces securely.  Everything locks into place by means of a handle that also doubles as the device you use to snap the competed marker together tightly.  And, they included two cardboard boxes that you fold together to store the created markers; the boxes are designed so that they can be colored in themselves. And a set of tweezers to hold the markers. Oh, and there are also labels included so you can write down the names of the colors you created and affix them to the markers.  Importantly of all, the instructions are clear - with pictures.There is enough dye and marker pieces to create 16 markers in the set.  There is a color chart coordinated with the measuring cups that allows you to create a wide range of specific colors.  My little guy had great fun making the colors shown, and then he decided that he was going to mix his own colors so we also managed to get black, brown, olive green and army green.  As a result of this project, he understood color creation better, not to mention the various ways to add numbers to reach the number 15 - since each color on the chart was created by adding two different color amounts so that the sum would total to the number 15 mark on the measuring cup.I can't stress how much he loved this toy.  We made all sixteen markers at one sitting, though I'd imagine that most kids would make the project last a bit longer.  There was still some dye left over and a few extra pieces.  I see that Crayola offers refill packages and I'm definitely going to get some.  What also impressed me about this product was how tidy it was.  The kids and I have done projects with dyes in the past, so the little guy automatically went looking for some plastic gloves and I cut out a plastic trash bag for him to use as a smock - but they were totally unnecessary.  The kid played with color dyes and stayed clean!  I stayed clean!  It was unprecedented in our experience.  The dyes also rinsed off easily from the measuring cups and from the tray they were in, just under running water.This was truly one of the best-designed and fun projects we've ever worked on and I can't recommend it highly enough.

This is a handy little guide to carry around in your pocketbook, backpack or pocket if it's your first or second trip to San Francisco.  It's designed to be a pocket guide, and that's exactly what it is. It's slightly wider than a paperback with a cover and pages that are sturdy.  It contains 224 pages and has a map of San Francisco's neighborhoods (as Lonely Planet defines them) on the inner cover, and a city map of San Francisco attached to the inner back cover that you can fold out.The neighborhoods are broken out into: Golden Gate Park & the Avenues, Golden Gate Bridge & the Marina, the Haight and NoPa, Fisherman's Wharf & the Piers, North Beach & Chinatown, Hayes Valley & Civic Center, Downtown & SoMa, and the Mission.  Each neighborhood had segments entitled "Explore", "The Sights in a Day", "Best of San Francisco", "Getting There", "Top Sites", "Don't Miss", "Sights", "Eating", "Drinking", "Entertainment", "Shopping" and includes a map of the area.Like all Lonely Planet travel guides it also includes a chapter called "Survival Guide" which give brief information regarding where to stay, transportation information, emergency services, and other information essential to travelers.This is not the travel guide you want if you are trying to choose a lodging, because that's not the focus of this book.  This is something easy to carry around, so that when you're traveling around the city, you can always find something to see or do, find a place to eat or stop for a drink, and you won't miss out on any of the must-see's of the city.  The book is filled with full-color pictures and maps, with colored break-out boxes with tips and hints and historical facts.  Stand-out dishes in the restaurants are mentioned.  Each recommended site or location gets a small paragraph of information.I found this to be a very interesting and useful book.  My only quibble with it is that the font size is just a little too small for these aging eyes; for me I was doing the glasses-on/glasses-off thing with my bifocals.  But I would imagine that most people wouldn't have a problem with it at all, and of course, the smaller font allows for more information to be packed into the book.I enjoyed it and would recommend it.

"The Dead Will Tell" is the sixth book in the Kate Burkholder series.  When an author hits a fifth or sixth book in a series, that's usually the point where the reader can tell if the storyline has started to stagnate and the books become formulaic.  I am happy to report that this series is still going strong.  I have been following the trials and tribulations of Kate Burkholder in her job as Painters Mills Chief of Police from the first book, and it amazes me how Ms. Castillo manages to keep the characters fresh, the murders gruesome, and the people of Painters Mills from fleeing en masse.I like the tension that Ms. Castillo has created by having Chief Burkholder being a former member of the same Amish community that she now has police jurisdiction over, having her now be on the "English" side but still with the sensibilities of her Amish heritage.  The Amish are a hot topic on reality TV, but I think that this series gives a better, non-sensationalized portrayal of the community and showcases the commonality of humanity. As with each of her previous books, the crime that drives the story is horrific - there are no "clean" murders in this series - and Kate has to reconcile her public and private lives in order to get to the bottom of it.  Her love interest, John Tomasetti, is a man with ghosts of his own and his subplot interweaves with Kate's and with that of the murders.  There is an element of romance in the series as their relationship has developed, but it doesn't overwhelm the mystery aspect.I've always found the locations in this series to be very easy to visualize; the characters never act in a vacuum to me.  I always seem to get a good sense of place and season, even though I've never been to the Amish areas of Ohio.  This is just a very good series and this book is a fine addition to it.  I'm looking forward to the next one.

This one of those devices that I always think of getting whenever I see one being used, but have never gotten around to actually getting for myself.  I happen to like to marinate chicken so I was happy to give this product a try.I found this OXO meat tenderizer very easy to use.  On the top, the lock/unlock slider was clear to see.  The product was easy to use and it was easy to see where it had been used on the meat and where it was still needed.  I didn't have any problem applying the pressure needed to piece the meat.  The blades were sharp.  The design of the product precludes any inadvertent self-injury.  The two buttons on the side of the top portion are pressed simultaneously to take apart the tenderizer for washing, and it is top-rack dishwasher-safe.  It seems to be made well.This tenderizer resulted in the marinade penetrating the meat much faster, meaning less waiting time before cooking.  The food was, I thought, more flavorful than marinating it the old way.I would recommend this product.

I've used Mr. Clean throughout my life to clean floors, so I was interested to see what they came up with as a new cleaning product.Mr. Clean Liquid Muscle is a liquid gel concentrate product.  The gel is not one of the thick, gloppy ones; it's more like a thicker dishwashing liquid-type.  It is bright yellow and has a pleasant lemon scent.  It has a flip top that allows you to use it as you need it - a few drops on a sponge or a squirt into a pail of water.  The squirt is a pre-measured amount, so it's easy to make sure that you're using the proper amount - as opposed to just pouring it out of a bottle the way you do with regular Mr. Clean.  If you're using it in water, there's no need to rinse afterwards; the instructions do advise rinsing if you are using the product straight from the bottle.I thought that it did a great job of cleaning both ceramic and vinyl tile.  It was easy to remove stuck-on dirt, greasiness and stickiness.  The 30 oz. size of the bottle means that I'll get a lot of use out of it.I would recommend it.

Although these cups are nicely packaged to give as a gift, there is absolutely no information on the box, in the package or on the cups themselves stating where they were made, if they are lead-free, and whether or not they are microwave/dishwasher safe.  The Amazon blub states that they were made in China, are FDA-certified lead-free, and are microwave/dishwasher safe, but the product itself makes no claims as to that.  The cups do not even have a manufacturer's name stamp on the bottom. Because of that, I would be loathe to give these as a gift to anyone because I have no way of verifying their safety.The six stoneware cups are a nice size for a hot beverage and are pleasant to look at.  The colors are bright and coat the cups evenly.  They seem to be nicely made, and hold a good-sized beverage portion.  I have larger hands and could only fit three fingers through the cup handle, which was a little awkward for me, but wouldn't be so for someone with a smaller hand.  The cups were well-packaged and arrived with no damage.Given the multiple problems with lead paint in items made in China (assuming these actually were made in China), and given that the packaging doesn't even any make any claims of safe manufacture, I wouldn't recommend them.  There are plenty other manufacturers who are proud to list their company name on their product and to provide information as to place of manufacture and correct care.

I've never really tried any cheddar popcorn before, but since I like cheddar cheese and am a lifelong consumer of Cheez Doodles/Cheetos I figured that I'd give these a try.  I picked up a box of unbuttered microwave popcorn (my preferred method of popping corn), popped it up and sprinkled this white cheddar seasoning on it.It gave the popcorn a rather salty, cheddar flavor that was pleasant.  You control the degree of flavor by the amount of the product that you sprinkle on it, and can always sprinkle more as you empty out the popcorn.  Since it's white cheddar, there's no orange cheese dust left on your fingers, which is nice.  It comes in a container with a snap lid over a perforated cover, so it's easy to control the amount you put on your popcorn.All in all, I found it to be a tasty product, and a nice change of pace from regular buttered popcorn.

I've played with K'nex construction sets in the past with the kidlets - most recently put together a suspension bridge and they are fun.  However, in this particular incarnation, K'nex is trying to be like Legos, and they failed miserably.Apparently the K'nex people didn't realize that the same people who buy Legos would be attracted to this product due to its similarities and didn't pay attention to how clearly the Lego instructions are laid out.  With the K'nex instructions (all graphics, no words) it wasn't clear if you were supposed to use two of one item or if the arrow between the items meant that you were moving the piece in that direction.  It wasn't clear if you were using two really tiny pieces or one tiny piece in certain sections.  I am the family instruction reader so I know good instructions from bad, and these could have been much clearer graphically.One of the main problems, though, was that the blocks didn't lock together very tightly in instances when they had to overlap rather than be exactly on top of one another, and the design didn't allow for reinforcement of those weak spots, as the Lego constructs are designed to do.  We never actually got the car fully put together because it would break in half before we could put the top section on; after five attempts we just gave up on it.I would reiterate the manufacturer's warning about a choking hazard.  There are a lot of very small pieces in this kit that would be dangerous to small children.  And some of those pieces were very tiny and easy to drop.  It didn't seem as though the package contained any extra pieces to possibly compensate for those that might drop and disappear in carpets.I have to agree with the other reviewers that it was amusing that the there were instructions for assembling the Peter character, when he came fully assembled, and that in order to place him within the car you have to remove the lower half of his body.  I don't watch the TV show "Family Guy" so I can't comment on whether a toy based on that program is age-appropriate; to me it was just a K'nex toy that I thought the kidlets might like.So, in summary, don't waste your money.  While the plastic pieces appear to be well-made, the same care wasn't taken in the creation of the instructions or the interlocking design for the car.  If you can't actually make it stay together, it's rather useless and becomes just an exercise in frustration.  As the kidlets told me to tell you folks, "this one gets a bad review".

I burned this fuel in an Aladdin Genie III kerosene lamp.  The fuel has a full on kerosene stink to it and quickly filled our 2000 square foot house with enough odor to bother our throats and sinuses.  It burned well, but the fumes and odor were unbearable.  In the future, I would burn it only for outdoor use.It mixed well with Ultra Pure paraffin fuel in the Aladdin lamp and a Danforth round-wick lamp.  Neither lamp experienced any burning problems switching back and forth between the fuel types.

Pros:- Good quantity for the price.- Appears to be an upstanding company.- A tasty balance that's not as sharp/acidic as black tea, but isn't as grassy as green tea.Cons:- Not quite as nutty as I like...but that's just a preference thing.I'd buy it again.

If you want to stack the deck in your favor, purchase these supplemental disks along with the primary Litter Kwitter kit and just plan on using them.  By all rights, the company should have included these with the primary kit if it really wanted to increase the odds of training success.Might your cat be able to transition stress free through the disks that come with the primary kit?  Sure.  He also might experience anxiety from the huge increase in hole size that interferes with training and causes unneeded frustration for the owner.  My thought was, why take the chance if it's not necessary?  The less stress and anxiety he experiences, the more likely that training will go smoothly.  Small, smooth changes are best.  I would have used even more transition trays if they were available.My wife and I used the extra trays to train our two 14+ year old rescue furballs.  Start to finish, training took about 4 months.  We've been completely litter free for 10 months.  I am convinced the extra stages (along with clicker training...see my review on the main Litter Kwitter kit) helped the process go rather smoothly.

My wife and I used the system to train our 2 adult cats (14+ year old rescues) and we have been litter box free for 10 months.  Using the additional techniques below, we went from start to finish in about 4 months.Why did I choose Litter Kwitter?  When it comes down to it, any system or method on the market today is designed to condition a cat to relieve itself in the toilet.  Whether you're making the contraption yourself with a book like How to Toilet-Train Your Cat: 21 Days to a Litter-Free Home, or purchasing a commercial kit, the bulk of the effort comes down to commitment and training.  I think the Litter Kwitter system is the sturdiest, most versatile system on the market to get the process started.Before you even think about starting, I highly recommend you purchase the Litter Kwitter MultiKatKit even if you only have 1 cat.  (-1 star for not including this in the primary kit.)  This process is about conditioning the animal and slowly introducing him to a new behavior.  Having multiple steps eases the transition and stacks the odds in your favor.  One of the advantages of the Litter Kwitter tray system is that you can move back and forth between stages if you encounter transition problems; however, I didn't move to a new stage unless I was pretty much positive that the cats were comfortable with the existing stage.I also recommend you visit the forums at litterkwitter dotcom.  It's chocked full of ideas for attaining success, such as putting tinfoil on the floor to discourage accidents or putting friction tape on the toilet seat to reduce slipping.  The training process requires active participation and yes, there will be accidents that you'll have to clean up.  It's messy, and we found ourselves cleaning the tray, the plastic adapter, and the toilet daily.  If you expect a perfectly clean, hands-off process, I think you'll be very disappointed in the results.In addition to following the general instructions, here are some things we did to ensure success:1.  Night Light.  We noticed that a lot of the initial pee aiming problems were happening at night and I realized there was absolutely no ambient light whatsoever in the spare bathroom.  Yet I was expecting our felines to jump up onto a small platform, position themselves, and hit a small pan in pitch black conditions.  Our motion-sensing night light wouldn't always register cat movement, so we installed a bright, always-on LED night light and it reduced aiming mishaps by half during training.  We've kept the light in place and no longer have aiming mishaps.2.  Clicker Training.  To help get the cats used to correct positioning, I started clicker training with them (Big Button Clicker).  No need to buy a special book.  Just do an internet search for "clicker training" and you'll be able to get all the info you need.  After 10 days and about 5 minutes per day with each cat, they would both squat on cue in the proper location and proper position in order to receive a treat.  Whereas leaving them to their own accord might only put them in contact with the toilet seat for a couple minutes per day, clicker training put them on the toilet seat for much longer.  It helped condition them to enjoy the toilet seat and helped them learn balance.  By being present while they were on the toilet seat, we were also able to "rescue" them a few times when they slipped and almost ended up in the drink...an act that could have caused enough anxiety to turn them off from further training.  Additionally, I immediately performed clicker training with them the moment I moved to another stage.  That served two purposes:  It distracted them from the change in tray size during the crucial first moments; and, it helped them associate good things with a new stage.  Repetition, repetition, repetition.3.  Irresistible Treats.  My cats are finicky, but there's one thing they go nuts for--fresh tuna.  Rather than buying expensive, processed treats--which they didn't respond to during clicker training--I used canned tuna in water.  Plus, we feed our cats on a schedule rather then letting them constantly graze, so I did my training when they were hungry.  I put a little bit of mushed tuna in the center of my palm.  When a cat moved into the correct position, I'd click and then open my hand and cup it around his face.  Not only did it help keep him in the proper position (lift the face up and the butt goes down) but by turning my palm into a little bowl, it was easy for him to lick/eat the tuna without it flying all over the place.  Very effective.4.  Make the Toilet a Pleasurable Place.  I must admit, I have historically incorporated negative consequence training into litter training.  I decided to try just the opposite this time.  I ignored accidents and did everything I could to make the toilet seat a pleasurable place for the cats to be.  I'd regularly carry them into the bathroom, set them down on the toilet seat, and then pet and praise them.  To this day, whenever we hear a cat pooping or peeing, we say "Good boy, {name}!" or "Good girl, {name}!"  I am honestly surprised by its effectiveness and the additional attention I seemed to get from them.5.  Step Stool.  We bought a cheap plastic step stool (easy to clean) and put it in front of the toilet. It helps the cats get up on the toilet more slowly without their fearing that a misjudged jump from the floor may land them in a toilet bowl full of water.6.  Paper Towel Trick.  As we progressed to larger openings, the cats seemed to be spooked either by the water or by getting wet from their poop and pee splashing in the water.  We floated a paper towel on the surface of the water and then sprinkled a little bit of litter on the paper towel.  Seemed to do the trick until they got completely comfortable with the water.7.  Cleanliness.  The trays hold much less litter than a litter box, and part of the training process is to continually reduce the amount of litter used.  The contraption, therefore, must be kept soap-and-water clean lest the felines seek out a clean place elsewhere to do their business.  With two cats, we thoroughly cleaned everything every time there was significant unabsorbed pee in, on, or around the tray.  We discovered that our cats did their darndest--despite the shrinking tray--to pee in the tray or in the litter.  When we moved to the "white stage" (adapter only with a little bit of litter around the tiny rim that holds the tray), they'd even try their darndest to pee on the litter there.  It wasn't until we completely removed the adapter that they started peeing more in the center of the toilet seat.  So, make sure you check around and under the adapter, too, in case pee has migrated to hidden places.8.  Enzymatic Cleaner. The stuff is miraculous. We've used OUT! Enzymatic Cleaner for years. Its smell is more fragrant and not as harsh as some other enzymatic cleaners we've used. It makes problems disappear and helped salve some of the frustration of the training process.  An enzymatic cleaner is also a good way to completely remove smells so that cats are discouraged from revisiting a spot where they aren't supposed to be relieving themselves.I believe the single most important factor in our quick success was the clicker training.  Even 10 months later, I still occasionally do clicker training with them on the toilet seat.  I wish I had done this 14 years ago, and I'll certainly be doing it with all future felines.  The quickest success, I think, comes from patience and from having a heart for understanding animal training/conditioning.

Good fit in my 1997 Ford Ranger with 60/40 split and non-adjustable (integrated, one-piece) headrest.Pros:- The seat and seat back are separate pieces, so sitting on the seat does not pull down on the material on the seatback.- Neoprene-like material makes for a glove-like fit and is comfortable to sit on.- The main straps holding the seat cover in place are front-to-back non-stretching nylon straps.- Good fit and good coverage around the bottom of the seat.- Very wide and strong Velcro closure on the seatback covers.- Seatback rear pockets are built well and are tight.- Seams are clean and sewn nicely.Cons:- The side-to-side straps on the seat cushion covers are small elastic straps.  They will stretch and wear out in time.- The armrest cover is a terrible fit and is held in place with elastic straps that run across the opening of the armrest.  The elastic straps aren't strong enough to hold it up onto the armrest, so the cover works its way down over time, which means material ends up covering the lid release button.- Like all neoprene-like material I've seen, human hair and pet hear will thread its way into the fabric, making for more difficult removal.- The material has stretched a bit with time, which will require occasional retightening.I give the seat covers an A and the armrest cover a C.

I purchased this feeder to replace a Duncraft triple tube feeder.  After several years of faithful service (and a few falls), the Duncraft polycarbonate tubes were starting to show their age.  I decided to purchase an all-metal feeder in the hopes it wouldn't show age so quickly.  This Stokes feeder fits the bill.Pros:- No issues with bird entrapment.  I've had thousands and thousand of birds visit the feeder in the last year, ranging from goldfinches to flickers, and have never observed any kind of entrapment.  I checked the inside of each feeding port and didn't detect anything sharp or catchy.  The ports appear to be the same size as on all my other feeders.- All metal with a robust finish.  Should last years in any weather.- HUGE capacity.  Easily holds twice as much as my Duncraft triple tube feeder.  I estimate it holds about 10 scoops from my Heath Feed Scoop.- No, it's not squirrel proof, but squirrels won't be able to chew on and damage the metal.- Great drainage and drying.  In Nebraska weather, I've never had a problem with black oil sunflower seeds drying out and being consumed before they spoil.  The tray is the only thing that gets a little goopy because of all the seed waste.Cons:-  The screw-on top ring is secure, but I've had at least one instance on a different Stokes feeder (Stokes Select 38069 Squirrel Proof Double Suet Feeder) where a raccoon was able unscrew the feeder (which was hanging from a solid hook) from the top ring and drop the entire feeder to the ground.  Consider hanging this feeder from a swivel or a rope so that larger animals can't use resistance to unscrew it.

The Pioneers suffers from the same fatal production flaw as many other reality shows on TV today:  It tries too hard to be overly dramatic.  Nonstop high tempo background music overlays most of the scenes and crescendos at "dun da dun!" scenes that really aren't that big of a deal.  The participants seem to spend most of their time focusing on conflict, problems, and the negative.  It's more of a performance for the camera than it is a documentary.  If you'd like to watch something that leans more toward the documentary side and has less artificial crisis and conflict, check out Frontier House by PBS.

I watched the first 7 episodes of the show.  It started out nicely:  Great scenery, interesting, diverse characters taking care of everyday things.  Unfortunately, the scripted drama started to take over around episode 7 and I lost interest.  The show quickly started revolving around an F-bomb laced conflict between the town's bar owner and the rest of the community as the bar owner attempted to install a more stable power system in town.  Other dramatized conflicts, such as the one resident's farm animals getting loose, start to pop up.  The producers take normal daily events (like the sighting of a bear) and try to turn every one of them into dramatic life-or-death events.  You can tell that the characters are putting on a show for the camera.  And cue the dramatic music.I may try again if the producers tone down the fakery and the residents stop acting for the camera.

There are generally two genres of Great North reality shows today:  Programs that lean more toward the documentary side and programs that lean more toward the scripted drama side.  Dr. Oakley, Yukon Vet definitely falls into the documentary side and therein lies its strength and interest.  After one is tired of the overly scripted drama in other reality shows, it's nice to watch what appears--at least on camera--to be the normal life and normal responses of a normal person.  Dr. Oakley is a professional with a heart and that clearly comes through on camera.  She's calm, cool, and collected.  It's enjoyable and educational to watch her interact with Alaska's and Canada's domestic and wild animals.  Her presence on camera seems natural and I don't see any of the telltale signs that she is putting on an act.Another strength is that the show truly is family friendly.  Whereas most Alaska reality shows today are full of bleeped out cussing, this program has no bleeped out language in most episodes, and only a few in the remaining episodes.

I watched the first episode and quickly lost interest.  I love the concept...western culture, hunting, guiding, family life.  I hoped it would be an Idaho version of Alaska, The Last Frontier.  Unfortunately, the producers take a very "scripted reality show drama" type approach to the show.  The drama seemed manufactured and the on-camera interviews/segments with each person just seemed scripted rather than natural.  The "competition" between the families is the primary angle of the show, so you can imagine all the conflict that might be scripted in to build up that storyline.  I just seemed too fake--too much acting--for my tastes.

We, too, purchased this Danforth pewter lamp after watching the How It's Made episode.  The price through Amazon is significantly less expensive than purchasing through the Danforth website because of free shipping.  It's smaller than we thought it would be because size reference pictures were very difficult to find online prior to purchasing.  It's 1/2 to 1/3rd the size of an Aladdin Genie III lamp.Pros:- Contemporary styling.  The flame on top of a hollow, round wick is a sight to behold.- Beautifully manufactured.  The font is precisely finished to a satin sheen.  The burner is a highly polished silver.  The threads on the burner-to-font connection are clean and tight.  All parts fit together perfectly.- The round wick and center draft result in the same amount of light as 7 to 10 single-wick candles.  Its brightness is uncomfortable to look directly at when it's set to put out the maximum amount of light.- The chimney on mine is easy to remove and replace during lighting.  It's also quite secure.  (I know some have to adjust the metal tabs because they are too tight.)- Low, stable design.  Easy to carry around by the font once it's lit.- Holds a surprising amount of fuel.- Burns quite nicely and cleanly with my kerosene-based (non-paraffin) fuel.  Also burns well with Ultra-pure.Cons:- The wick adjustment knob doesn't have any real knurling on it, so it's a little difficult to get a purchase on it to raise and lower the wick.- The wick on our lamp was not trimmed properly before leaving the factory, so it burned very irregularly.  I had to trim it so that it was perfectly round and even at the top.- Ours arrived with a circumferential manufacturing scratch on the glass around the bulbous portion of the chimney. (Checking with customer service).  Edit:  Danforth sent us another chimney, no questions asked.- One fuels this lamp by unscrewing and removing the entire burner and pouring fuel into the font.  After the first fueling, subsequent fueling will be a little messy because the wick tail will drip fuel.We like it and plan to purchase additional ones in the series.

It was o.k. It has the requisite and completely unnecessary F-Bomb three quarters of the way through in order to get the PG-13 rating that drives the "if it's not at least PG-13, it can't be any good" consumer interest.  Everything but the humans is CGI. It's really good CGI for today, but lacks the more realistic and lifelike look of the primates in the two earlier movies.  The movie ends in the typical and dissatisfying 'expect a sequel' fashion.

In the show's intro clip--which I assume will be played at the beginning of every episode--one of the participants walks to the top of a small hill and at the top of his lungs yells out "I'M THE KING OF THE MOTHERF***ING WORLD!"Is that supposed to entice me to watch the show or to have my children enjoy a bit of the Alaskan outdoors?  No thanks, if that's an indication of the participants' limited vocabulary and maturity.

I've purchased many Mediabridge HDMI cables over the past 4 years as the HDMI specs have changed.  Previous cables had specs printed in white characters on the cable itself.  While the ad states that this cable meets the "Newest Standard" (which would be HDMI v2.0) and the specs show support for 4K and 3D (which would also tend to indicate that it's HDMI 2.0), there are no unique markings on the cable.  Rather, it just has a generic "Mediabridge ULTRA High Speed HDMI with Ethernet" print on it.  Nowhere on the cable does it list the its spec.  Unless I put my own label on it, it'll be difficult to differentiate this series of Mediabridge cables from other cables when I need to use them for 4K devices.C'mon, Mediabridge.  White ink on the cable with the proper specs should never be overlooked.

Season 4 has the same enjoyable content as previous seasons.  It seems far less scripted with much less fake drama as compared to other Alaska reality shows.  The dialog seems credible and the characters appear natural and genuine.  But profanity/vulgarity is getting worse as compared to previous seasons.  F-bombs are more regular now and some of the cast are starting to test how vulgar/creative they can get with it.  It seems to be a trend in Alaska reality shows (Gold Rush Alaska, Life Below Zero, etc.).  "Oh my F****** God" is now a favorite phrase among a couple.  Listening to bleeped out dialog every minute or so is increasingly distracting and detracts from the show's quality.

Sorry, guys.  You lost me on this season.  Profanity has increased steadily through the seasons, and in this one it seems the crews don't know how to communicate unless they're dropping the F-bomb every other sentence.  It's not as if I have virgin ears, but watching a show with bleeped out profanity every minute or so is distracting and uninviting.  This season is also a little more drama-queenish where the actors fight, argue, and lose their tempers more often.  They seem to be inserting scripted drama and acting out dramatically in order to fulfill some perceived audience expectation of a "reality show".

This review is for the 2-bay unit:  Model FD2002.  Disclaimer:  I actually bought my own dock.  ;-)Pros:- Supports 6TB drives.  Confirmed with Western Digital Red 3.5" 6TB drives.  Note:  My retail box said "Supports 4TB".  (Old packaging??)- Lightweight but hearty plastic.  Has rubber feet but moves around easily without the weight of hard drives in it.- Can access both drives simultaneously while doing normal file operations like reading, writing, etc.- Crystal Disk Mark shows 197MB/s sequential write speeds over USB3.0 to a Western Digital Red 3.5" 6TB drive spinning at 5700 rpm.  USB diagnostics indicate that it is indeed connecting at SuperSpeed.- No issues connecting at USB2.0 speeds on my old laptop.- Auto-installed all drivers in Windows 7 Home Premium x64.- Comes with a clear plastic form-fitting cover to keep out dust.  The plastic is the same as the thick plastic used in retail packaging these days...the stuff that requires scissors to get into the package.- Comes with one USB3.0 data cable.Cons:- You might experience conflicts trying to perform simultaneous operations that require locking a disk.  I experienced lockups that necessitated powering down the dock if I attempted to run Checkdisk or Western Digital Data Lifeguard Diagnostics on both disks simultaneously.- It's been a little glitchy a couple times when I inserted two drives simultaneously, as if it had difficulty recognizing both hard drives if they were spinning up simultaneously.  I've had the best luck in those situations by turning off the dock with the power button, inserting the drives, and turning the dock back on.  Or, inserting one drive, letting it be fully recognized in Win7, then inserting the second drive.- Standard 9mm 2.5" or thinner hard drives are easy to flex back and forth once they're installed.  There's a slight gap between the drives and the dock plastic, so the drives don't have a lot of lateral support.  Be careful that you don't put undue stress on the drive connections after installation.I'm quite pleased with quality and performance thus far.

I installed this Gold Plug in a 1997 Ford Ranger v6 4.0L with 95,000 miles.  As demonstrated in videos, the magnet is indeed strong enough to pick up large crescent wrenches.After a recent oil change, I had about 1mm of buildup on the the magnet.  I don't change the metal washer unless I detect leakage.I give it a hearty 5 stars for being a rather inexpensive way to keep ferrous metal out of the oil circuit.

This is just 3/32" vinyl coated stainless steel braided wire.  I expected something a little more robust...say, 1/8" or a touch larger.  3/32" braided wire can easily be cut with a good pair of wire cutters.  This'll keep kids from carrying it away, but it'll do nothing to deter a criminal with basic tools.  I didn't bother installing it.

I upgraded my Lenovo Y530 laptop with this Samsung SSD. While some Y530 owners have had problems getting their SSDs to work in AHCI mode, I had no problem with the 850 Pro. My BIOS is AMI EFI BIOS version 10CN38WW (220) which is the original BIOS that came with the laptop when I purchased it in 2009. The SATA interface was already set to AHCI with the original hard drive.Installation was easy and no additional hard drive spacer or adapter was necessary for it to fit properly in the hard drive caddy: The existing mounting holes and screws lined up perfectly. A fresh install of Windows 7 Home Premium x64 from CD went flawlessly and I did not have to load any additional SATA drivers. Using Crystal Disk Mark, I get around 270 MBps sequential transfer rates on this old system...a little over twice the speed of the original 5400 RPM hard drive.After installation, I ran the Windows Experience Index function. Some blogs indicate that doing so allows Windows 7 to detect the new SSD and to make necessary system changes such as activating TRIM and deactivating automatic defragmentation. While TRIM was indeed activated, automatic defragmentation did not get disabled. I recommend doing a manual check of the system to make sure the most effective SSD settings are correct. A Google search for "best SSD settings" brings up several very good how-to articles.

I installed the black Husky Weatherbeater floorliners in my black interior 2013 Rav4. I uploaded several pics of how they look in place. Note: apparent color differences between the liners and the black carpet are just camera deception. The color is nearly the same.I purchased these at realtruck dotcom for $159.95 and free shipping. After comparing these side-by-side with the Weathertech Digital floor liners, I decided to purchase the Husky floor liners because of their thicker, more rubbery texture.Pros:- More rubbery & flexible than the Weathertech liners. A bit heavier as well.- Driver's side integrates with the OEM floor mat connectors. Holes are already present--no cutting necessary.- Driver's side has a recess for the gas tank door release.- Area under gas tank release is protected.- Sharp nibs on the bottom hold mats in place.- Full coverage of the "false pedal" on the driver's side.- The Rav4 model has contemporary styling rather than the star pattern available for truck models.Cons:- The seams aren't perfectly flush against the carpet in all places.- The Husky model for the 2013 Rav4 does not overlap the door thresholds the way some other Husky liners do for other vehicle models. The thresholds will get dirty and dirt will slip down in between the liner and the threshold over time.- The sides are not as tall as the Weathertech liners in some places.I still prefer the Husky liners because of their more flexible, more rubbery texture.

I had a coolant leak in a 1997 Ford Ranger V6 4.0L.  It was leaking either from the lower intake gasket or from the cylinder head gasket (hard to tell because I couldn't easily see the area and both gaskets are rather close together).  It was leaking about 5 drops per minute.  I added one container of K-Seal and drove it for 40 minutes.  The leak has completely stopped.  I'm impressed with its immediate effect.I'll update over time to give long term results or to note any clogging/cooling system damage caused by the product.

I purchased this tray feeder to replace a Birdscapes Clear Window Feeder 348 which didn't make it to a second season.  I primarily get doves, goldfinches, house finches, chickadees, and cardinals at my feeder.  It is positioned just a couple feet away from a human chair on the other side of the glass, so I think regular interior movement may be pushing some species to the feeders further from the house.Pros:- Robust design.  Mine took a 12-foot fall after a raccoon raid and was nary worse for the wear- I really like the new poly lumber designs, which should hold up extremely well to multiple seasons- Hardware is stainless steel- The metal grating has strong black paint and is held in place by a set screw- Rain drainage and seed drying is very good unless there's too much seed (see cons)- Because it's plastic, metal, and stainless steel, it's very easy to disassemble and clean in the kitchen sinkCons:- Zero protection from the weather.  If the seed depth is too great, the seed in my feeder rots before it dries out after a rain.  I keep a smaller amount of seed in the tray so that it'll dry quickly after a rain.  I'm considering a Birds Choice 23X12 Acrylic Window Mount Cover.- The grating is installed a little tight on my feeder and requires needle nose pliers to get it out after the set screw is removed- The window glass and window sill tend to get a bit mucky from bits of seeds the birds fling aboutAt first, I didn't think birds would dare come so close.  Now that they've gotten used to movement inside the house, birds feed at it constantly.  Humans can sit quietly just inches away from the glass and enjoy the feathered critters.Tip:  To increase suction cup strength, clean the window and suction cups very well and then put a minute amount of cooking oil on the suction cups.

It's a basic, inflatable pillow.  A good choice for backpacking, bike-camping, motorcycle camping, or any other activity where space is limited.Pros:- Low price (when it sells for about $5).- Holds air well.  My pillow lost only a bit of air after sitting in storage for a month.- Lightweight.- Easy to cover with a shirt to provide extra comfort.- It's wide enough to support my head even as I move around in the night.Cons:- The "flocking" is nothing more than some texturing in the plastic.  Don't expect to lay your face directly against its surface and be comfortable.- Because it's just plastic with welded seams, I'm not sure how long it'll last.  I plan to roll it rather than fold it for storage.I bought this inflatable pillow when it was a little over $5.  At $10 now, I think I'd look for another option.

These sure beat using metal rings and lids after a canned product is opened.  I use Tattler Reusable Regular Canning Lids and Rubber Rings, and they're even more troublesome to keep on a jar after opening it, so the plastic lids are especially useful.  They also work quite nicely for using Mason jars to temporarily store products in the refrigerator or the freezer.The plastic is thick and the threads are pronounced.  I can't imagine breaking these even during rough use.

I use this rack to cook jalapeno poppers in the oven.  It's not perfect, but I like it.Pros:- Stainless steel is easy to clean and is thick enough for use at oven temperatures without warping.- The coring tool works really well on larger jalapenos.  However, it's too big for smaller jalapenos (the size I usually harvest in my garden).  To fix this problem, I bent the end of the coring tool further inward so that it would fit into smaller jalapenos.Cons:- There is no bottom.  That's good if using it on a BBQ grill, but not so good if using it in an oven.  When I use it in the oven, I place it on a cookie sheet to catch dripping cheese or bacon grease.- The holes are usually going to be too large or too small because of the wide size difference among jalapenos.  I use toothpicks through the jalapenos to hold smaller ones.  On larger jalapenos, I can usually push them far enough into the hole to hold them.  If the jalapenos are tall enough, I can insert them through the holes and let the bottoms rest on the cookie sheet I put underneath it.It's not perfect, but it's sufficient.  Until someone invents a rack with auto-adjusting holes, this'll do nicely.

I found these Toyota OEM filters cheaper here on Amazon than elsewhere.  It came in an OEM box with all the parts pictured.  Detailed instructions and diagrams are clearly printed on the box.The filter media seems effective.  Used filters are intact, show no indications of decaying or falling apart, and are easy to remove from the filter cap.  I don't bother going through the trouble of using the drain tube to drain the housing before removing the housing.  It's a little messier, but it means I don't have to remove the housing plug or replace the smaller o-ring on the housing plug.  Additionally, I don't replace the large o-ring unless I see significant problems with the installed one.  After a recent 9,000 mile oil change, for example, the o-ring still appeared brand new.  I saved the replacement o-ring for a future day.Multiple used oil analyses on my 2013 Toyota Rav4 show that these filters are quite satisfactory for 10,000 mile oil change intervals.

I have a Gold Plug installed in my 2013 Toyota Rav4 with 29,000 miles.  At the end of a recent oil change (9,000 miles on Toyota oil and OEM filter), I had approximately 1/2 mm of buildup on the magnetic drain plug.I don't plan to replace the aluminum seal after every oil change.  After 20,000 miles and 2 oils changes, I have no leaks.  I'll keep an eye on it and change the seal when I start to see leaks.I give it a hearty 5 stars for being a cheap way to keep ferrous metal out of the oil circuit.

I purchased the Kuat NV2 gunmetal gray add-on from bikepartsexpressdotcom in July 2014 for $340 with free shipping.  The quality, like the main Kuat NV2, is absolutely amazing and better than any other platform bike rack on the market.Pros:- Easy to assemble with all included tools and instructions.- Comes with three keys and a Kuat aluminum bottle opener keychain.- The rack is still rock solid with the extension.  It does flex a touch more in the rearview mirror while traveling as a result of the extended length.- Once assembled, the extension can quickly be removed by taking out 4 allen head bolts (and reinstalling the end cap if so desired).  The two original platforms are still installed in their closer-together positions, but I think that's a small price to pay in order to quickly switch back and forth as the situation dictates.  (Note:  consider intertwining the cable locks between the main unit and the extension so that an educated thief can't remove those 4 allen head bolts and walk off with two of your bikes.)Cons:- In order to keep the rack from being excessively long when the add-on is installed, the main two platforms are installed closer together and all four platforms are ultimately closer together.  This reduces clearance between bikes and may require adjusting seat heights or pedals in order to have appropriate clearance.- Because of the additional length, when the rack is lowered to the "open the tailgate" position, the rack rests on the hitch tightener knob.- There's no guarantee the add-on will come with the same lockset number as your original rack, so you will likely have to use two different keys on the security locks.  The good news is that replacement cables can be purchased from Kuat with your desired lockset number if one must have everything keyed alike.  I chose to keep different locksets in order to deter thieves a touch more.- If you damage or break the hitch tightening knob (say, you drag it on a low driveway), you have to buy the entire tightening mechanism (about $30) rather than just buying a new knob.This add-on is a no brainer if you want to use the Kuat NV2 to carry 4 bikes.  Pricey...just like the main unit...but likely to last a lifetime.

I haven't had much luck with this feeder.  Clinging birds and birds interested in nyjer or finch mix chose easier sources (my Droll Yankees tube feeders) and normal rainfall soaked the feed to the point that it began sprouting.  I've gone back to using tube feeders to present finch mixes.Pros:- Well built.  I'm a big fan of the new poly lumber feeders.- Screens easily slide out for cleaning.- The paint on the screens is robust.- Holes are small enough to provide easy access for nyjer or finch mixes.- Stood up to at least one raccoon attack.Cons:- Birds seem to choose easier feeding sources if they are available.- Zero protection from the weather and seed at the bottom of the feeder never dries out.  A single rain requires me to empty the feeder, clean it and refill.  I don't have that problem with my tube feeders.

It is certainly true that debates rage on about the quality of Fram air filters and oil filters.  I have used them almost exclusively on 5 different vehicles for a total of about 440,000 miles and I haven't had any mechanical problems associated with either air or oil.  Those are my personal experiences.  Take it for what it's worth.This filter is a direct fit for the 2013 Toyota Rav4.  Construction quality is the same as other Fram air filters.  The orange rubber seal makes for a good fit in the air intake and seemed to be a little more compliant than the rubber seal on the OEM filter.  This filter, unlike other panel filters I've used, also has a bead of embedded glue down the middle of the filter pleats in order to prevent the pleats from bunching up and reducing surface area.  I saw no discernible difference, including paper media quality, between the OEM Toyota filter and this Fram filter.  Prices are cheaper online than at Walmart or auto parts stores.Multiple used oil analyses through Blackstone Labs on my Rav4 indicate there is no dirt/silicon based foreign matter making it into the engine or oil circuit.

Blackfish is not a pure documentary in the strictest sense--a movie in which the producer endeavors to evenly display information from both sides of the argument.  Rather, Blackfish should be considered an advocacy documentary.  The producer is most certainly using facts and opinions to advocate for one side of the argument and to advocate for action.  There is only about 1 minute of film where a proponent of Sea World provides an antagonistic viewpoint to the producer's theory.  The rest of the video is designed to express, convincingly so, that imprisoning killer whales is animal cruelty and often results in aggressive behavior.I think it's a good documentary and worth watching a couple times.  When I was young, I though Sea World was a terrific place where captive animals were well cared for and where humans could be educated about the plight of sea mammals.  I also believed that exposing humans to sea life in such close quarters would raise awareness and make humans more sensitive to appropriate ocean conservation efforts.  It accomplishes those things, but at what cost?  Do the ends justify the means?  Is a "little bit" of animal cruelty acceptable if it brings in money and raises awareness?As I grew older and attended more Sea World venues, I began to recognize that these animals did not reside in captivity voluntarily and that restricting animals to little concrete swimming pools or metal cages was unnatural.  Comparing animal behavior in the wild with animal behavior in captivity solidified this understanding for me.  I no longer frequent zoos or places like Sea World because of this realization.  We humans are smart:  We can certainly come up with a way of appreciating and learning about animals without keeping them as prisoners in cages.Blackfish is worth the watch.  It provides a perspective that Sea World purposely tries to keep out of the public eye.

I purchased these for use on a Trek DS8.5 hybrid mountain bike.  They are my first experience with a clipless setup and I now can't imagine *not* having a clipless setup on each of my bikes.  I have them paired with a  Shimano SH56 SPD Cleat Set and Shimano SH-MT43G Bike Shoes For Men.Pros- I initially thought clipless shoes and pedals weren't "necessary".  After using them, I was surprised by just how much they increase pedaling efficiency.  It's surprising how much I can relax my upper legs when I don't have to concentrate on keeping my feet from slipping off the pedals.  Being able to pull up during the pedal stroke also adds a significant amount of extra power when needed.- The dual platform lets me use regular shoes--or simply not clip in when wearing clipless shoes.  It's also nice to have the platform side to get the bike up to speed (or out of a difficult spot) before clipping in.- Plenty of adjustability.  I have the cages set to a loose setting.  With the SH56 cleats, it's easy to twist out of the cages but it's nearly impossible to unclip from the cages by pulling straight up (i.e., they're working as designed).- Good, sturdy metals.- They don't look as aggressive as some other mountain bike clipless pedals, so they match the styling of hybrid bikes or leisure bikes a bit better.Cons- Because the nubs on the platform side are broad and blunt, they don't offer much traction, and my shoes slip around on them more than I'd prefer.- The black paint scratches off very easily.- The cages are a little more difficult to clip into than I would prefer:  I have to fish around a bit to get the cleat to engage.  This could be the result of the shoe and cleat combination as much as the pedal.  (I'm comparing this setup with the same shoes on Shimano PD-M324 SPD Dual Platform Pedal, which are quite a bit easier to clip into.)The pedals would be nearly perfect if the platform side had a bit more traction.

After scouring the market for a set of gaiters, I decided on these for a 5-day elk hunt in the Wyoming mountains.  They're pricey, but I am very pleased with their performance.Pros:- They fit very well with room to spare.  I wore them over thick knee-high wool socks, long johns, BDU pants, and 800-gram size 11.5 Danner hunting boots.- The under-boot straps are a heavily rubberized cloth material.  It'd take a lot to damage them.  They also have buckle holes along all but the first 2 inches on the opposite side from where they buckle.  The strap can be lengthened or shortened (which allows the gaiter to sit lower or higher on the boot) to account for different ankle and boot circumferences.- The top cinch is a nylon strap with a lever-type buckle.  It holds very well.  I rejected a pair of Cabela's gaiters because their elastic cord stretched too easily around the top of my calf and the spring loaded elastic cord lock would not hold.- They're essentially silent while in use.  The outer material is a soft, flannel like material and the inner material is not stiff or "crunchy".  A friend wore a pair of Outdoor Research black gaiters and they "swish, swish, swished" like a pair of nylon rain pants.- They seemed plenty "waterproof" as I spent 4 hours wading through knee high snow.  The tight fit around my boots also kept snow out of my boots and pants.- They seem to be snag-proof or at least highly snag resistant.  I didn't have a single snag in mine after tromping around in the Rockies for 5 days.- They did provide some additional insulation for my lower leg.- The Velcro is more than adequate for holding the gaiter on my leg.  Also, there's a standard hook at the bottom that connects to a shoe lace to help keep the gaiter from riding up.- A little tag on the inside tells you which is the (L)eft and (R)ight sides.- The lower snap is a nice touch but not essential.  One could partially overlap the Velcro, not use the snap, and still have enough holding power.Cons:- Perhaps the Velcro might wear out over time?Sizing Help:- I purchased the Large (9-12).- When the Velcro is fully overlapped, the top circumference of the gaiter is 19 1/4" and the bottom is 18 1/4".  One could overlap the Velcro less and gain about an additional 1" of circumference, yet still have enough Velcro holding power.- My leg circumference just below the knee (where the top of the gaiter cinches down) is 12 3/4".  I essentially had to tighten down the top strap as far as it would go in order to get a snug fit at the top.- My calf circumference is 14 1/2" at the widest point.- I had comfortable room to spare with this size.  I estimate I could add another couple layers of clothing (in addition to that mentioned above)--say, a pair of sweat pants and another pair of long johns--before I'd have to worry about the gaiters being too tight around my calves.

I'm quite pleased with this cargo rack.  I'm using it on a 2013 Toyota Rav4 with the Curt 13149 Black Class 3 Trailer Hitch.  The rack has a 500lb weight limit and the hitch is rated for 525lb tongue weight, so it's a good match.  I've hauled firewood, game hauling carts, and coolers.  It's a great buy.Pros:- Wow, it's big!- No license/registration required.  Can't say the same for a trailer.- Easy to assemble with common hand tools.  It comes in five pieces: two rack halves, the main square mount tube, and the two flat plates that hold the rack halves together.  Rock solid but heavy once assembled.- Good fit and finish.  Paint is robust, though the metal will rust if I scratch off the paint.- Has a slight upward tilt so that it tends to sit flat as weight is added to the rack or to the back of the vehicle.- Easy to secure with an anti-rattle hitch pin.  I'm using the Tow Ready 63201 J-Pin Anti-Rattle Pin and Barrel Lockset for 2" Square Receivers and it stops all movement and rattle.- The additional cross bars underneath the diamond grate add confidence and keep the diamond grate from sagging.- A convenient place to temporarily set gear if out hunting, fishing, or camping.  Also serves as a convenient place to sit while afield.Cons:- It's heavy.  You may wish to use two people for assembly and installation.- Takes up significant storage space when not in use.- Depending on clearance, you may have to remove stuff from the rack to get your rear gate open.- The diamond grating is a tighter weave, so only small strap hooks will fit through the grating if one needs to attach straps to something other than the side bars.- It blends in to the back of the vehicle and could be struck by following drivers.  I applied Incom RE800 1.5-Inch by 4-Foot Highly Reflective Tape, Red and Silver to the top bar to make it more visible.- The rear of the hitch tube is open, so it can collect dirt & water, and makes the rack look a tad unfinished.I have no regrets on this purchase.

These game bags are a heavy canvas, similar in thickness, toughness, and threadcount to a heavy duty pillow case.  They do an excellent job of protecting the meat from dirt; however, they are not "waterproof" (so to speak) so blood will still saturate and drip through the fibers.  I had no problem fitting a hide-on hind cow elk quarter with room to spare.  On another hunt, I fit an entire doe antelope into a bag.  There was about a 4-inch tear in one of the seams after use, but I don't know if it was due to my roughhousing or because of weak stitching at that location.  At any rate, it's an easy repair.
