There are plenty of life lessons to be learned in this thoughtful but amusing episode in the life of the number 1 Ladies' Detective Agency.I do like this series which are really modern morality tales.  Yes the writing is simple and straightforward but how to get on with the other people in your life is the same however sophisticated and grown up you think you are.I didn't think this latest story was quite as good as previous ones but then sometimes they improve on second reading.  I always find them amusing with plenty of food for thought and insight into human behaviour and motivation,  If you want something gentle in the mystery line then you could do worse than read this. While it helps to understand the series characters if you've read previous books in the series they don't have to be read in order and can be read as standalone novels.

Bill is a newspaper reporter.  His editor sends him to Wales to report on a vicar who has apparently had a great many affairs with parishioners and is on trial by the Church of Wales authorities. One person has already successfully challenged an article in another newspaper on the grounds that she didn't have an affair with the vicar and she refuses to have anything to do with any reporters now.  Bill needs a new angle on the story so he wonders whether the lady concerned will speak to him.The book reveals a network of lies and personal feuds as well as the manuscript of a novel which may have been based on a fair proportion of truth.  Who is lying and who is telling the truth and who is manipulating others for their own ends?  Can Bill discover a new angle on the case and keep his editor happy and what is the truth anyway?The book includes the story told in the novel as well as evidence given by the various witnesses in the case - both for and against the vicar - the Rev William Clifford.  I must admit I really liked Bill as a character though I wasn't too keen on some of the others though I don't think the reader is meant to like them.  What I found most interesting was the way the lies, truths and half truths are woven together and it is almost open to the reader to make up their own minds about what is truth and what isn't.Overall this is an enjoyable and interesting read though I found it quite frightening at times the way gossip and rumour - as well as truth - can very quickly distort reputations and destroy or radically change lives both for better and worse.  I received a free copy of this book from NetGalley for review purposes.

This is a totally fascinating story of how gin has waxed and waned in popularity over the centuries.  From its origins in the Dutch drink 'genevra ' to modern 'limited edition' varieties.  I don't actually like gin myself but having read this book I wonder whether that is because I haven't yet found the right flavour.I did disagree with one statement in the book - that there is no scientific proof that gin makes drinkers depressed.  The only time I have drunk gin I felt very depressed afterwards in a way that no other form of alcohol had ever made me feel.  I'm willing to try it again to see if it still has that effect or whether it was a particular combination of circumstances which led to the depression.  I wasn't too keen on the taste either but I have learned from this book that there are many different flavours and combinations of flavours available.The book covers the early days of gin in England and how it became the drink of choice for many poor people.  There were many - largely unsuccessful - attempts by parliament to prevent the excessive drunkenness which plagued not just London but other cities.  Gin was cheap and could be produced by anyone with the equipment to do so because restrictions on who could produce it were largely ignored.From its heyday in the eighteenth century when Hogarth drew Gin Lane to gin's current popularity as the basis for all sorts of cocktails this is a roller coaster of a story taking in a great deal of social history which is fascinating to read.  There are brief histories of all the wel known distillers as well together with details of gin varieties currently available and distilleries which welcome visitors.If you enjoy reading social history - even if you don't like gin itself - this is an interesting read. It is well written in a lively and entertaining style and it is well researched too.  I received a free copy of the book from NetGalley for review purposes.

The book is described by its author as a polemic.  It isn't only about women it is about bigotry and prejudice and about how those affect everyone in their daily lives.  It is about rigid gender roles and how they affect the choices of everyone.  Rigid roles affect those men who want to be nurses and carers just as much as they affect women who want to be engineers and airline pilots or computer programmers.  Rigid gender definitions of qualities and aptitudes stop people taking on the roles they as individuals are best suited for.The book talks about issues which many people hesitate to voice and it talks about people being individuals first and foremost before they are either gender - or somewhere in between.  It talks about cyberbullying, trolling and stalking and how it seeks to shut women up on the internet.  Women should not speak out about anything and need to be silenced because good women and girls - rather like children - should be seen and not heard.  To say you disagree with someone is to invite a tirade of abuse.  Freedom of speech is fine for everyone except women because if they exercise their right to free speech they are 'mouthy c . . s or whining women always moaning about something'.  Or there's nothing wrong with them which plenty of sex wouldn't cure. This sort of treatment on the internet - you rarely meet it in real life - makes my blood boil and it clearly does the same to the author.  Freedom of speech is a right but with it goes the responsibility not to abuse, insult or denigrate others.The book covers subjects such as the beauty industry and the celebrity culture and how it tries to impose certain rigid parameters on the appearance women and girls present to the world.  I must admit that having grown up in the 1950s and 1960s I realise I would hate to be growing up now.  There seems to be so much pressure on young women to look and behave in certain ways.  I wasn't conscious of this at all when I was growing up and differences were welcomed or at least tolerated far more than they are today.As well as focussing on women- she also looks at how men and boys are treated these days and finds they are not served well by stereotypes imposed on them.  Not all men want to be into violence and what tend to be thought of as traditional masculine stereotypes - real men don't cry and real men definitely don't do the housework.  Some men enjoy the housework and want to give vent to their feelings by crying. We need to be less rigid in our expected gender roles - in fact why have gender roles?  What is wrong with looking at people as individuals?I think for me one of the most frightening chapters was about sex and the internet and the way violent pornography is so much a part of it.  There are plenty of men in real life who are not interested in being violent towards women and yet so much of pornography contains violence towards women.This is an angry book as you might expect but it also contains plenty of references to other sources - comprehensive notes on each chapter and a bibliography.  It contains rather more uses of the F word than I am quite comfortable with but that is a personal preference.I think the sentence which made most impression on me is this one from close to the end of the book:'Feminism and radical politics are about demanding more than a choice between one type of servitude and another'That pretty well sums it up for me.

I found this book a little strange to say the least and it seemed more like a vehicle for the author to showcase her writing skills than any sort of story.  I felt there was perhaps a bigger more complex and potentially more interesting story trying to get out.A woman writer, who narrates the story such as it is, travels to Athens to teach on a writing course and the various people she encounters tell their stories - which may or may not be true.  Much of it is told by means of reported speech though at times this switches to dialogue for a short period and then back again.  I was most disturbed by the man she met on the flight out - referred to only as 'My Neighbour' throughout.  On the strength of a few hours on a plane she agrees to meet him later for a trip on his boat.My Neighbour appears several more times in the book and each time I found him slightly more sinister and the narrator's behaviour nave in the extreme.  Would you really go on a boat trip with a stranger?I thought the writing was good but I despaired of the story line because really there isn't one.  It's a series of conversations held together by the fact that each conversation features the narrator. Others may enjoy the book but I found it a little tedious and I couldn't work up any enthusiasm for the characters at all.  I received a free copy of this book from NetGalley for review purposes.

The shelf wasn't quite as randomly chosen as the blurb for this book implies.  The author wanted to pick a shelf which contained one classic she wanted to read and no more than five books by any one author.  The shelf which went from LEQ - LES fitted her criteria and she embarked on reading the books contained on that shelf.  She decided that if there were five books by a particular author then she would only undertake to read three of them.  As the library she chose for her adventure in reading is a lending library she ran the risk of the shelf changing while she read but she managed to accommodate the changes.I found it a fascinating book to read as it didn't just cover the books she read but also took a look at libraries and how they decide what to keep and what to buy in the first place.  She discussed different formats of the various books and found that in some instances she found the format of the book got in the way of her enjoyment of it.  If the book was very old and tatty or was printed in a very small font it was easier and much more enjoyable to read an e-book version where there was nothing to get between the reader and the text.I particularly enjoyed the chapter on 'Phantom of the Opera' as it takes in not just the original text but film adaptations of the story as well as the musical versions.  I enjoyed the author's comments on literature in translation and how the translators desire to over inform the reader with a plethora of footnotes and explanations can interfere with the enjoyment of the text.  Nabokov apparently did this with his translation of A Hero of Our Time and the author turned to other translations which she found she could read with much more enjoyment.If you enjoy books about books then you will probably enjoy this one.  The author writes in an easy low key style and while she makes references to other more famous authors I think she succeeded admirably in her stated aim of reading outside the perceived canon of literature as taught in schools and universities.  I enjoyed the book so much that I even forgave the author her trenchant comments on mystery and crime novels  which are my particular favourites.  The book contains notes and an index.

I need to make it clear from the start that this is a review of the book and does not contain my opinions on the case of the missing Madeleine McCann.  This is neither the time nor the place to express my opinions about what happened to her.The authors have aimed to produce an objective account of the evidence available to the public.  They do look at some of the theories current about the case but only in as far as they can be traced to individuals who have been reliably identified.  No of course they haven't covered everything which is in the public domain - that would take many thousands of pages.  As far as is possible I think they have succeeded in recounting known and verified facts.  They clearly interviewed a great many people in the process of researching the book and waded through a great deal of information and mis-information.What are the known facts about the case? Madeleine disappeared from the family's holiday apartment on the evening of May 3rd 2007.  She has not been seen since by anyone who is prepared to admit to seeing her.  No evidence has been found of her death - or of  her alive after that night.  That is really all that is known.  Many people saw suspicious looking strangers hanging around the apartment complex in the few days before Madeleine's disappearance.  None of those have been traced - as far as is known to the public.The police in Portugal did investigate the disappearance but mistakes were made which could have fatally compromised the investigation.  Mistakes were also made by the British police involved at the time. Probably the biggest mistake of all was to have so many people tramping all over the apartment immediately after Madeleine's disappearance.  The authors do say here this was probably only natural in the circumstances.  A child goes missing from an apartment so of course people search for the child in that apartment before the search moves outside.This is a well written book which covers such issues as the publicity generated for the case and the way the tabloid media especially have sailed rather too close to the edge of libel in what they have published at times. It also looks at how the internet facilitated the world wide publicity for the case and how this may have had a deleterious effect on the ultimate outcome of the case.This would be a good book to start with if you would like a summary of the case up to the point where Scotland Yard started their mammoth investigation.  It only covers the statements subsequently made by the investigation and does not speculate about what that investigation may or may not have discovered.The e-book edition contains working footnotes, a separate picture section with active links in the text to relevant pictures and an interactive index as well as links in the text to relevant web sites.  The full definitive account of this case remains to be written though it is made clear in this book that there is a great deal of information which remains unavailable to the public for obvious reasons.

Angela Marchmont is on holiday in Italy and has plans to go on to Venice when she receives a telegram from a friend who is married to the vicar of an English church elsewhere in Italy asking her if she can help with a problem.  Reluctantly Angela changes her plans and goes to see Mary.  Her husband, Jonathan believes a local spiritualist is enticing his congregation away from him and wants Angela to investigate.Angela is a little reluctant to get involved but decides it can't do any harm to book a consultation with Mrs Quinn and her daughter and perhaps to invent a dead husband for the occasion.  In the meantime Angela finds herself being introduced to many of the English community and being invited to social occasions.  She is staying in a very pleasant hotel and really quite enjoying herself.  Then she bumps into someone (literally) who she knows under another name.  Could it be that she retains a soft spot for an engaging villain?Humour, excellent characters and interesting plots are the main ingredients of this episode in the Angela Marchmont series.  This is a genuine Golden Age mystery - written in the nineteen twenties and only now being published by the author's family.  The book is well written, as are all of the books so far in this series.  If you enjoy authors such as Agatha Christie then you will probably enjoy this book and this series.

Old age is regarded by many as something which happens to other people. We try and defy it by means of cosmetic surgery, dressing in the clothes we wore when young or in the latest fashions aimed at people in their twenties. Once they are over fifty many people report that they are invisible to most others and disregarded. The world seems to be organised round the young and the old and infirm are regarded as an unnacceptable drain on everyone's resources.But are there other ways of looking at old age? Having reached my seventh decade and starting to think that maybe I ought to investigate the subject, I find that I don't try and avoid my age. I'm a glass half full person and I look for the advantages and many of the writers quoted in this fascinating study and thought provoking study look for the advantages too. I have had many positive examples of old age from close relatives in my life so I tend to think of it in a different way. I live in an area where there are a high proportion of retired people and I am constantly presented with examples of people in their sixties, seventies or eighties getting around under their own steam and enjoying life apparently to the full.The author writes well and quotes many optimistic views of aspects of old age as well as many less optimistic views. Some even go so far as to say that anyone who can see good things about ageing much be morons or at the very least seriously deluded. This is a life affriming - and age affirming - book and it will cause anyone approaching their more mature years to examine their own hopes, views and fears of and for their own future. However it doesn't seek to gloss over the disadvantages and of course there are disadvantages to every age.There are notes to accompany the text and I'm sure many readers will find themselves launched on a journey of exploration into the subject of ageing and old age in literature, art, politics, sociology and psychology. If you want to find out how our leading writers, philosophers and celebrities have looked at old age - both good and bad - then read this book. I received a free copy of this book from NetGalley for review.

Father Vincent Ross - a Catholic priest - finds himself in the middle of a scandal where he has actually done nothing wrong. He is accused of an inappropriate relationship with a parishioner. He is sent on a retreat to get him out of the way. He has also heard the confession of a man who claims to have killed the Bishop. But the confessional is sacrosanct and he can do nothing about it and in any case he doesn't know who it was. In an attempt to salvage his own reputation and his life he sets out to solve the crime and to find out exactly what is going on with some of his fellow priests.I started off being enthusiastic about this book - reading the first hundred pages very quickly but after that it somehow lost my interest. I think this may well be an interesting crime series and I will give the next one a chance when it comes out. The writing is excellent and I liked the characters though there were rather too many of them, in my opinion for a book this length. The flashes of humour were well done too.If you enjoy your crime novels with an unusual background then this may be one for you.

This is the first part of a four part novel which is published between July and October 2014. If you don't like having to wait for the conclusion of a story I suggest buying all four parts before you start reading part one! In this episode, the reader is introduced to the characters and some of their back story but we are left wondering about precisely what it is that Martha wants to announce at her eightieth birthday party which will tear her family apart.I felt there were just too many characters in this episode to really assimilate. There is Martha and her husband, their three children and their significant others and their own offspring plus a few other people who are clearly going to play a bigger part in the rest of the story. I kept wanting to shout 'too much information'! All the characters have secrets both past and present and it looks as though the conclusion is going to be earth shattering when it finally comes.I liked some of the characters - Bill, the doctor for example, though I didn't take to his wife, Karen. I didn't like Daisy's daughter, Cat and thought she was bit flaky to say the least. I was intrigued by Florence and want to know more about her. This is the sort of book where you almost need to read with pencil and paper in hand so that you can jot down notes about the characters for future reference.I am sufficiently interested to read the rest of it but I think I shall wait until I can read all four parts straight through. I'm sure Harriet Evans' many fans will love it as will anyone who loves family sagas. I received a free copy of this book from NetGalley for review purposes

This is a well written short story featuring Simon Serrailler. He is living in his sister Cat's house and looking after Sam, one of her sons, and enjoying some off duty time when there is an attack my a far right organisation on a Gay Pride parade in Lafferton. But there is worse to come for the police and for Lafferton. I found it gripping reading and would recommend it to all Susan Hill fans as well as to those who have not tried her crime series.The book also features the opening of the new novel featuring Simon which is released in October 2014.

Dulcie is studying for a doctorate and combining it with teaching a few students as well as poking her nose into mysteries which don't concern her aided by her affinity with felines. Worrying about whether her boyfriend, Chris, is really a Werewolf and why her friend, Trista, seems to have changed, Dulicie thinks she has seen a very handsome man dragged off the street one night by wolves. In attempting to run after him to try and rescue him she falls and hits her head. Everyone thinks she imagined it but Dulice knows what she saw.This experience leads to her attending a modern production of Ovid's Metamorphoses which leaves her even more puzzled and disturbed than before. Then there's her conversations with a dead cat - Mr Grey - which make her wonder what she's missing and whom she can trust. I wanted to shake Dulcie and try and make her get on with the work she should have been doing. In fact I completely shared her supervisor's exasperation!I'm sure others will enjoy this mystery but Dulice was too much of a flaky heroine for me. I could accept her conversations with cats but considering how well educated she was she seemed not to have very much common sense - or if she did she certainly didn't use it. It was an average read and I didn't actually get bored with it which is why I have given it three stars. It is the latest in a series so maybe if you've read all the others it becomes more enjoyable - unfortunately I didn't enjoy it sufficiently to want to read the rest of the series. I received a free copy of this book from NetGalley for review purposes.

This is an interesting academic study of how women's magazines have grown and developed in the digital age. It is mainly aimed at an academic readership with plenty of notes, a bibliography and quotes from other researchers in this and related fields.What I found most interesting about the whole book was the evidence which shows that the advent of the internet and the growth of online magazines has led to an increase in print sales as well. In fact print magazines and online magazines each fuel the growth of the other.Online magazines have resulted in even more interaction and communications with readers and consumers and presumably has resulted in magazines becoming more and more relevant to the lives of their readers and consumers.This is an interesting book for anyone who is interested in magazines in the digital age and in consumer issues in general. I received a free copy of this book for review purposes from NetGalley.

I enjoyed reading this memoir about the author's year working for a literary agency in New York. She'd just left university in London and returned home to the US and didn't want to live at home with her family so she needed to earn enough money to support herself and stay living with her boyfriend - and keep that knowledge from her parents. She got the job as assistant to what turned out to be the head of the agency and at first she just felt she was a glorified secretary but gradually the job got a hold of her and she found it fascinating.I thought her descriptions of office life were excellent. She highlighted something that I've come across in some offices in which I've worked - no one told her anything and unless she asked the right questions she had to struggle to work out how things were done. As you don't know what you don't know this often resulted in trial and error before she finally worked things out.Before she went to work for the agency the author had never read J D Salinger but she soon found out that he was their most prestigious client and there was a long list of dos and don'ts when it came to dealing with him. These were the only things she was told without asking. Early on she was given the J D Salinger fan letters to deal with and a stock letter which she was told to use to reply to them. Salinger himself did not want to see his fan letters. These letters started to haunt the author and she began to reply to them individually - with mixed results.There is something quirky and individual about this memoir and I really loved the way the author gradually came to understand things about literary life and found her original ideas about it were often totally wrong. I liked the glimpses into her home life too - the ramshackle apartment with no heating and no kitchen sink and her unsatisfactory boyfriend who was working on his novel. Recommended to anyone who enjoys biography or autobiography and anyone who is interested in learning about life in a literary agency.

A sparkling collection of short stories some of which feature Inspector Sloan and his sidekick, Crosby. Others feature an interesting character called Henry Tyler who works for the Foreign Office in the nineteen thirties and who regularly visits his sister, Wendy in Calleshire. I enjoyed them all and would be hard pushed to single out my favourites though I did particularly like the second story in the collection - 'The Hard Lesson' - about the stand-in teacher who unexpectedly manages to capture the class's attention.Another favourite was 'A Managed Retreat' - revenge at its most delightful. 'In the Family Way' was interesting for its family dynamics and 'The Language of Flowers' was extremely clever too. Altogether this is a marvellous collection of stories with plenty of twists just at the last moment when you think you've worked out what is going in.If you enjoy crime short stories then I would recommend this book.

The theft from a museum of a painting of no apparent worth together with a few small items from a display case leaves Sloan and Crosby baffled as there seems no motivation for the crime at all. Then someone sets fire to a house that used to belong to the subject of the painting and the plot thickens. The reader is taken into a dubious world of planning applications, disputed land ownership and threatened takeover bids before Sloan and Crosby manage to unravel both cases and solve the mystery.I love this series with it's wry humour and likeable police characters and this episode is well up to the author's usual standard. The books bear re-reading as I first started reading them back in the nineteen seventies and have re-read all of them more than once. If you like cosy crime series by authors such as Veronica Heley and Hazel Holt then try Catherine Aird.

Anna Gosforth falls in love with a handsome face but maybe she is being taken in by good looks and not considering what it would be like to actually be married to the gentleman concerned. Then there's Mr Vere who seems to materialise out of nothing every time she needs someone to rescue her from a socially awkward situation. Set against the background of the fragile and temporary peace with Napoleon, Anna starts to realise that she is intelligent and she does want to know what is going on in France.This is an entertaining short story which can be read at a sitting. If you enjoy a light-hearted Regency romance with a touch of humour and a sprinkling of danger then this might be for you. For those who have read and enjoyed this author's Mountjoy series then this one features a cameo appearance by an early nineteenth century Lord Mountjoy.

If you have a serious case of SAD, I don't think this Happy Light will work for you. If you are looking for something to augment your use of another natural spectrum lamp, or just something to brighten up a winter day, perhaps take it to work for your office, then it is OK. I developed SAD after menopause and it took me a couple of years to figure out what was going on every winter. Once I bought a natural spectrum lamp and used it every winter morning (and increased my Vitamin D3 intake to 5,000 IU daily), I was a new person. As long as I consistently do that during the winter, I do not get intense anxiety and/or feelings of sadness that can pop up out of nowhere in the winter. I have reviewed the NatureBright lamp that I use elsewhere on Amazon. I like it so much I bought a second one for my husband, who spends a lot of time in the basement working on projects.A major shortcoming of this unit is that it is only 5,000 LUX. All the research I have read says 10,000 LUX is what you need, and that is what I use. Additionally, right on the box it states that for this unit, 5,000 LUX is attainable if the lamp is anywhere from 6 to 10 inches away. That is pretty darn close-up and you have to be sitting with it practically in your face. So 5,000 LUX may or may not be achievable for you.The other feature I wish it had was a timer. My NatureBright lamp has a timer on it, so that I don't sit for TOO long in front of it. As tempting as it is to sit there all day with the bright light on, that isn't necessarily a good thing for your melatonin production and your circadian rhythms. It is possible to actually sit in front of a light box for too long, leading to disrupted sleep patterns and even feelings of anxiety.If you have SAD that can be disruptive to your normal life, my suggestion would be to look for a light box that has 10,000 LUX as the standard. The unit that I own has come way down in price over the years and for what you get, is a bargain.PROS:Small, compact, goes just about anywhereHas an on/off switchBrightens up the area it is in quite a bitInexpensiveCONS:Not 10,000 LuxNo timer

As you might expect of a pink dollhouse backpack, this toy is very cute. But the first thing I thought when I opened it was wow, this won't last. It is made of very cheap material covering a very thin cardboard. The zipper feels like it will break after a few uses. The other problem with this toy is that it is VERY small (backpack is tiny and straps are very short) and would be suitable for a 2-year-old or maybe a very petite 3-year-old, but that is it. What 2-3 year old plays delicately with their toys?

I would say this is OK for medium-duty use. But if you are giving this to a kid who is going to carry it every day, shove it in a locker, etc., I doesn't seem sturdy enough to hold up to that kind of every day abuse. There aren't any folders in this Trapper, which was a nice feature in the older units. And a zipper would help keep everything inside of the unit better, rather than the snap closure. One plus is the number of colors it is available in. And you can customize it with an 8x10 photo.

This is a very nice, sturdy binder. The D-ring means that papers are less likely to slip out than they are with the old-fashioned "C" rings. I like the fact that the covers and spine can be customized by adding paper or designs of your choosing. I have found that binder buyers can be quite diverse in their opinions of what is best for a particular use. So if you are contemplating these binders, I would say buy one and see how you like it before you commit to buying a bunch of them. Oh yeah. One can never have too many binders, right? :) I originally thought they were quite pricey, but later realized that Amazon only sent me one binder and the price on the page is for a pack of 4.

I like to keep a few emergency flashlights around the house so I took a chance on these. When they arrived and I opened the package I was disappointed at how small they were. Then I put the batteries in and turned it on I was really Wowed! Where have I been and when did flashlights change? I am used to the old 2 D-battery mostly dim bulb models. When did flashlights get so bright and tiny?

For the price I wasn't expecting much, but I was pleasantly surprised. The calipers work great, the display is easy to read, and they even give you two batteries. For my needs these are the perfect starter calipers.

I bought this stand for my Ukulele and Mandolin. The Ukulele fit fine. The Mandolin didn't fit at first.  My Mandolin is an old style round bowl back. The trick to using this stand with a bowl back Mandolin is to put it on the stand backwards with the strings and finger board facing away from you. When the Mandolin is on the stand you should be looking at the bowl back. Works great!

My husband loves to draw and was excited to get this product. He said Tombow pencils are always very high quality, and this set is no exception. As others have noted, they tend to run darker than other brands. But what really excited him was that eraser. It is tiny, mechanical and it can get into small spaces. It erases cleanly. Great set, good value for the money.

These diapers are great! They don't shift around when your active toddler is being active! They don't leak. Gripper strips work great to keep the diapers in place. Love the Disney theme, and so does the little one. I think this is a good value for the money, as well.

Different people will buy this for different reasons. Some will want it for camping and some will want it for emergencies, and some will be building a larger store of emergency food. I think for emergencies, this bucket is great. The food is tasty and easy to prepare. No, it won't taste like your great homemade meals, but that is not the point. I live in an area where do sometimes have emergencies: hurricanes, nor'easters, ice storms and blizzards. Sometimes the emergencies last longer than anyone anticipated. It is reassuring to have food like Mountain House ready "just in case". The bucket will keep the packages dry and provides compact storage.

If you are looking for a comprehensive book on ophthalmology, this is definitely not the right book. I am an NP in a family practice, and found the illustrations and short, concise text helpful. I also appreciate the "key points" and "warnings" boxes. I do wish there were more emphasis on which eye injuries require immediate referral to an ophthalmologist and/or are considered emergencies. I was hoping that certain injuries would say, in giant, bright red letters, "Emergency Condition!". I suppose that is because I am extremely cautious about eye injuries. Treating an eye problem as less serious than it is could lead to permanent vision damage in my patients. I am lucky that we have a 24-hour eye emergency room in a large specialty hospital nearby, so I don't hesitate to refer my patients if I have even the slightest concern. This is not to say that the book does not indicate when something is an emergency (such as bacterial keratitis), it just seems more laid-back about eye emergencies than I, as a general practitioner, might care for. I was also surprised how little space (one short paragraph and an illustration) was devoted to Herpes zoster ophthalmicus ("shingles" that affects the eyes), as this really does require a consult with an ophthalmologist and should be treated as an urgent eye problem.

This is a BIG binder. It will hold a LOT of paper. And it weighs a ton when it is filled! If you're looking for a binder that will hold a large project, or multiple projects, this may be the ticket for you. As others have noted, the D-Rings are very nice, operate smoothly and don't accidentally slip open like traditional binder rings. I like the fact that you can customize the cover. Not sure how "heavy duty" it is, as only time and repeated use will tell. But for the money, I think this large binder is worth it.

I didn't think my husband would even try this out on his iPad, but he did. It has been almost 2 months now, and it is always on his iPad. He keeps telling me he loves it. Here's what he likes:- It is very sturdy, kind of like an otterbox. He has dropped his iPad a couple of times with no damage whatsoever to the unit.- It lets him read in bed without the bright light driving me crazy! I have to say, it does darken the light a lot. You might or might not find that an advantage, as others have mentioned they feel they have to turn up the brightness. My husband does not.- It has dependable magnets that keep it firmly attached.- The little "kickstand" is great for reading when he puts the iPad on a table. And the "kickstand" is also very sturdy.- It protects his iPad's screen.- It does provide privacy when he takes it to the doctor's office and is sitting in the waiting room.Stuff he is not too thrilled about:- There is only a "kickstand" in landscape mode. Why call it "portrait" then?- If he wants to use the bottom pull-up tool bar on his iPad, he has to flip the privacy cover down/open. He says this is not a big deal, but you might think it is if you use that tool bar all the time.- It did add a lot of weight to the iPad.Overall, he keeps telling me how glad he is that I got this for him.

This compound was easy to set up. It was a lot bigger (even just the tent itself) than I thought it would be, so pay attention to the dimensions! I actually use it for my ferals to give them some shade and a sense of enclosure in a place where they can keep a watchful eye on the world. (Yes, they are all spayed and neutered! Some are quite elderly now.)I must point out that a frightened, determined cat could rip or chew through the mesh. No doubt about it. I have had enough cats over many years that I know what a cat is capable of. If you are using this for an indoor cat that you are bringing outdoors, please keep a very close eye on him or her. Someone else wrote a review that detailed how her cat chewed through the fabric.

There is little I can say that won't duplicate what others have said. It's a great idea that I loved. But the execution of the idea is completely flawed. The darn thing doesn't hold water. What good is a bird waterer if it can't hold water? Perhaps if the bottom pan were wider and deeper, it would hold water; I am not sure. I am going to try to repurpose it somehow and will edit my review if I find a way to make this useful.

Edit, 8/16/14. I decided I really don't like this unit at all. As soon as I can afford it, I am going to order a second Keystone 70-pint unit. We recently had very heavy rain, where we got 6" of rain in about 12 hours. My basement took on some water, which I was able to ShopVac up in a few go-rounds. Then I put this unit on and the Keystone unit on, in 2 different spots that had both been wet. The DeLonghi ran and ran and ran and ran. And cycled into and out of defrost mode numerous times. After 24 hours, I shut it off, as the noise level from this unit when it is on full-speed can be exasperating. The pan was only about 3/4 full of water. To boot, it had developed a small leak in the pan, so I had a little puddle on the floor (not enough to account for the pan being only 3/4 full). Meanwhile, the Keystone was running like a champ, filling up, being emptied, and filling up again several times. All while running quietly and only rarely cycling into defrost mode. That sealed the deal for me. No sense wasting electricity on a unit that is highly inefficient, loud and leaky. I will buy another Keystone for those occasions when a substantial portion of my basement gets wet. I have no idea how this unit got an Energy Star rating.************(Original review)Our basement is not normally damp, but in the summer it can get humid (and chilly), so we do run the dehumidifier frequently on summer days. And about 1-2 times per year, we get enough water in our basement to require dehumidifying around the clock in order to get the moisture out. We typically have 2 units, one on each side of our basement. We had 2 Sunpentowns, which were great right up until they both died at about the 18-month mark. So I bought a Keystone and then had the opportunity to get the DeLonghi. That has enabled me to compare them side by side.Full disclosure: I don't care about the pump feature. I am OK with emptying the pan about once a day, because we only run the units when the basement is damp or it is hot and humid outside. If you don't need the pump due to heavy use, then save yourself the money and get a cheaper unit without a pump. Having said that, if you do need the pump, be sure to read reviews of this dehumidifier that mention the pump dying versus the pump doing a fabulous job and decide for yourself.Pros:- Fantastic packaging. Everything was taped down and secured. This unit could have fallen off a truck and arrived safely.- Easy set-up. Really, I just took everything out of the pan (hoses, etc.) and plugged it in. Took me a second or two to decipher the icons on the display, but that was easy.- The unit does dehumidify, no doubt about it. But our comparably-sized Keystone is a much bigger water hog and takes far more moisture out of the air. That's why I would not depend on it as the sole unit in a basement that needs dehumidifying every day.- The pan is nice and solid. The Keystone pan is lightweight.- Some smartie figured out that you can secure the float so that it doesn't tip over every time you dump the pan. Yeah! I have to hold the float in place on the Keystone as I empty the pan.- You can tell it to run until the humidity is a certain percentage, which is a nice energy-saving feature.Cons:- Very heavy. But all of these bigger units are heavy.- The LOUDEST of all 3 brands I have tried. Even on the normal setting it is very loud. On the maximum setting, my husband and I were shouting at each other, just to be heard. Definitely NOT something you want in your living space.- Removes less moisture than the Keystone, as I've already mentioned.- Forgets what your settings were when you power it off, and the settings have to be reset each time.- Goes into "defrost" mode far more frequently than the Keystone, and about as often as the Sunpentowns did. Annoying, in my opinion, as that ramps up the noise level and the energy use. And it's not dehumidifying when it is in defrost mode, of course.Overall, it's a nice unit. But for the money, I think there are better units out there. Unfortunately, I have yet to find one that lasts as long as my old Sears dehumidifier that I had for 20 years!

Admittedly, bowl/round back mandolin hardshell case cases are getting very hard to find. So in desperation, I ordered this one. As soon as it came out of the box, I knew it was going back. It is made of thin, cheap cardboard and has NO padding or fabric whatsoever inside. In fact, I would be afraid that the textured surface placed over the cardboard on the inside would scratch the surface of the mandolin. There is a cheap, thin cardboard center storage area that looks like the top would break off from use fairly quickly. I decided to get a gig bag instead for now, and will continue to look for a good hardshell case. At least the gig bag will provide some padding!

My dogs liked this food but honestly, they would eat anything I put in their bowl. I have never seen them refuse food. There have been no GI upsets, foul stools, etc. with this product.The first ingredient is chicken, but there is a lot of corn in this product. That does not distress me, but if it is important to you, then don't buy it.Here is a complete list of ingredients: Chicken, corn gluten meal, brewers rice, animal fat preserved with mixed-tocopherols (form of Vitamin E), poultry by-product meal (natural source of glucosamine), whole grain corn, corn germ meal, fish meal (natural source of glucosamine), animal digest, fish oil, dried egg product, salt, calcium carbonate, potassium chloride, calcium phosphate, Vitamin E supplement, choline chloride, L-Lysine monohydrochloride, L-ascorbyl-2-polyphosphate (source of Vitamin C), zinc sulfate, ferrous sulfate, manganese sulfate, niacin, Vitamin A supplement, calcium pantothenate, thiamine mononitrate, copper sulfate, riboflavin supplement, Vitamin B-12 supplement, pyridoxine hydrochloride, garlic oil, folic acid, Vitamin D-3 supplement, calcium iodate, biotin, menadione sodium bisulfite complex (source of Vitamin K activity), sodium selenite.Here is the Guaranteed Analysis:Crude Protein (Min)  30.0%Crude Fat (Min)  20.0%Crude Fiber (Max)  3.0%Moisture (Max)  12.0%Linoleic Acid (Min)  1.8%Calcium (Ca) (Min)  0.9%Phosphorus (P) (Min)  0.7%Selenium (Se) (Min)  0.30 mg/kgVitamin A (Min)  15,000 IU/kgVitamin E (Min)  500 IU/kgAscorbic Acid* (Min)  100 mg/kgDocosahexaenoic Acid (DHA)* (Min)  0.12%Eicosapentaenoic Acid (EPA)* (Min)  0.12%Glucosamine* (Min)  500 ppm*Not recognized as an essential nutrient by the AAFCO Dog Food Nutrient ProfilesCalorie Content (calculated):Metabolizable Energy (ME)4,250  kcal/kg1,928  kcal/lb475  kcal/cupI don't know why Purina doesn't put a link to the nutritional information on this page, but thought that might be helpful for people trying to decide.The food ingredient is definitely a giant step up from cheapie store brands and some other junky dog foods that are mostly filler. I would feel comfortable feeding this to my dogs. But you and your dogs have to decide for yourself.

This book covers the topic of cardiac arrhythmias comprehensively, with many, MANY illustrations. The accompanying text is clear and concise, although perhaps a bit *too* concise for people who don't have a lot of experience reading ECGs. There are many examples for you to try to interpret at the end of the book; fortunately, the answers *and* explanations are given, so you can understand why it was one arrhythmia and not another.This book is NOT a beginners book, and it assumes you already know how to read an ECG. If you need to learn how to read an ECG, I can recommend The Only EKG Book You'll Ever Need, by Thaler, as a good starting point.I am an NP, and found this book invaluable.

I normally feed my 4 cats Wellness cat food, which they love. So I was excited to get this bag of Nutrience. I must say the ingredient list is impressive, since it is grain-free and has no fillers. The first ingredient is "deboned turkey". But my cats will only eat it if I leave it in their bowl long enough. They go over, sniff, look up at me and walk away otherwise. But if I put some Wellness food out, they gobble it up. I've tried mixing the two, and I can see that they pick the Wellness out and eat the Nutrience only when they absolutely have to.PROS:- No grains, lots of meat and fish.- Large size is convenient if you have a bunch of catsCONS:- The ingredient list is longer than your arm, and you will have to read it carefully to see if your cat is allergic to any of the ingredients. Do my cats really need licorice root and tumeric? Apples and blueberries? I like the idea of the probiotics in it, but I question if they are the right probiotics for cats and how "live" the probiotic strains are after they sit in that bag for a while.- Large bag is heavy.- VERY EXPENSIVE. Eye-poppingly so. And for some reason, the price is different every time I look at the product page. Right now, it is about $3 less than when I reviewed it, but about $5 more than it was a few months ago.If you want to try this, get a small bag and see if your cats are less fussy than mine.My original review had all the ingredients and nutritional breakdown listed. For some reason, that part was edited out. Pity, because the company does not make it easy to find out the ingredient list. If you do a search engine search for the ingredient list, you will find it more easily than if you go directly to the company website and click on the links it provides.

It's beautifully packaged and pretty.I recommend you look at ALL the pictures...because it's a lot smaller than I imagined. A standard pencil eraser end, laid on top of it, would completely cover it. The chain appears to be linked solidly so it would not fall apart, but with a solid yank, I suspect it would easily break. I  recommend this for petite, delicate women/teenage girls. On my larger frame, it looks out of place. My daughter will love it, though.Overall, it's a subtle, elegant, and delicate piece of jewelry.

This bunny is bright, educational and fun. Somehow the color combination works...it's bright and fun. There are 3 layers for each ear which say things in different languages. His tummy glows.  Even newborn can tell the contrast in the arms! Quality made. The size is small enough to fit in a crib, and probably a swing. But may be a bit big for a diaper bag. Don't hesitate to buy as a baby gift for boy or girl.

I recently got a drying rack from Amazon and wanted another. This one is even nicer than the one I picked before. All the moving parts are metal, solid and reliable even though it's incredibly lightweight. It sets up in seconds without needing instructions (although, I imagine some people may need to think about it carefully the first time). Basically, You unfold it, and swing the top over to catch the latch. Voil!It unfolds in seconds (lift the top, then collapse it).It's going to last years and is working well for me.
So incredibly adorable! Better than in the pictures...IMO. Just LOVE these.

Elegant heirloom ornament. We love character to our Christmas Tree, so she is going in with our Hallmark ornaments to make a beauty and fun-to-explore Christmas tree. IF you have cats or toddlers, tie this TO the tree so she doesn't fall off and break. Lenox is known for quality and I wasn't disappointed.We don't have our tree up yet, but if I notice anything more when I do, I'll let you know.

Setting up the printer was easy. There are step by step instructions and I do recommend you use them. Once set up, I tried printing from my computer and it went smoothly.A lot can be done on the printer itself (without the computer) and it's pretty simple to maneuver. There are several ways to scan and they all do the scan a little differently.  You can use your computer with the software provided on the disk. Or there are two ways on the printer itself, each which save the scan in different places on my computer. Scanning from the printer autosaves in two different places (depending on option used). Using the HP software, it opens it up in their software where you can edit, then you have to manually save where you want.Printing is a little slower than I'd like. Ideally there'd be document feeders (I prefer that). But the print and photos print well for this price point.You have to manually scan 2-sided docs, but you can scan them as pdf, or (if you don't know this trick) you can make sure they are named in order like jaguar1, jaguar2 (etc) then select them and on your print menu, choose PDF as your printer. Voil PDF. If you KNOW you want PDF in the first place, and only PDF, then definitely choose PDF on the printer.It was quite painless to set it up on my smartphone. Because I couldn't see a print app, I went to the website listed in the setup booklet, and I downloaded the app on my phone. Then I just chose it under my "share" option and it printed no problem.For what it is, and the price: 4 stars. I don't yet know how well this ink lasts and the value of that (you often end up paying more on ink when you get a cheap printer), but it sounds like they are trying to keep those costs down. There is also a subscription if you don't want to mess with getting ink. It reports being a great money saver, but I don't quite understand how it works yet.The 5540 is quite similar, and the retail is $30 more (currently $10 more on Amazon), so I wondered what the exact differences were. I made a chart to give you an idea of the differences from information gathered on the HP site.HP has given us a lot of options for these printers, so you don't need to pay for anything you don't want, but you may consider the value of upgrading as well.

Setting up the printer was easy. There are step by step instructions and I do recommend you use them (I promise, it's painless). Once set up, I tried printing from my computer and it went smoothly.A lot can be done on the printer itself (without the computer) and it's pretty simple to maneuver. There are several ways to scan and they all do the scan a little differently. Using the HP software (on my computer) for the scan fixed the contrast automatically--which actually was an improvement, but not if I'd wanted more of a photograph of the document as-is. You can also choose two ways on the printer itself, each which save the scan in different places on my computer. So, I'm going to have to figure this out...probably just pick the most convenient at the moment. Using the HP software, it opens it up in their software where you can edit, then you have to manually save where you want.Printing is a little slower than I'd like. Ideally there'd be more document feeders (I prefer that). But the print is excellent and love the little tray that slides out when you print to hold the printed paper, and then slides in to look more sleek and minimize dust/debris from entering. My Epson is almost always hanging open even though it can close up manually.You have to manually scan 2-sided docs, but you can scan them as pdf, or (if you don't know this trick) you can make sure they are named in order like jaguar1, jaguar2 (etc) then select them and on your print menu, choose PDF as your printer. Voil PDF. If you KNOW you want PDF in the first place, and only PDF, then definitely choose PDF on the printer.Although I've understood text printers to excel at text and photo printers to excel at photos, I'd say this will satisfy most people on both fronts. If you're a professional photographer, you're probably going to go with something fancier, but for most people, this print quality will keep you from needing to have a Photo lab do your printing. Also, it was quite painless to set it up on my smartphone. Because I couldn't see a print app, I went to the website listed in the setup booklet, and I downloaded the app on my phone. Then I just chose it under my "share" option and it printed no problem.For what it is, and the price: 5 stars. I cannot make any statements about ink cost (where you often end up paying more for cheap printers), but it sounds like they are trying to keep those costs down. There is also a subscription if you don't want to mess with getting ink. It reports being a great money saver, but I don't quite understand how it works and whether it would be valuable to me.The 4520 looks so similar, and the retail is $30 less (but currently $10 less on Amazon), so I wondered what the real differences were. I made a chart to give you an idea of the differences. HP has given us a lot of options for these printers, so you don't need to pay for anything you don't want.

These were larger than expected. And when I put them on, hubby said I looked like big bird. Gee, thanks! But I do like them better than the silicone mitts I have because it's easier to grab things with "gloves" vs "mittens." They are quite long which is helpful in not burning yourself when you're hurrying to grab some burning food off some coals. They are relatively comfortable and you can hand them on a hook because they have hanging holes.-------------After using a few times, I have found that my hands get too hot for my comfort. I work fast to avoid a burn, but it's not impossible to get burned pulling out a cookie sheet at 375 degree oven. :( I have to knock them down, because I'm afraid to use them for anything beyond 300.

Although it's a bit pricey (think of a smaller market than legos, which are already pricey themselves), I feel it's more unique and educational than a simple lego set. It's insects, but not in a creepy way that would intimidate some children, and not in a cutesy way that would take away the educational value. In addition to building model insects, there is a whole science/technology benefit.It includes solar power aspect which deserves some attention in a child's education. If you can afford it, this is a great gift for a child or a child-like grownup. It's definitely taking science into a FUN realm and covers technology, ecology & biology.

If you are wanting more than just virus protection... McAfee's Total Protection protects your computers and phones from break-ins, protects from viruses and it regularly optimizes your PC performance and even gives you 1 GB data backup. With those features come a higher pricetag than the 3 PC Virus protection version.It's a great value verses subscriptions that work on one computer only. I haven't yet tried the True Key Identity Manager to make log-in easier and safer, but it's a nice feature.McAfee has lots of options. You can search around their site for a quick comparison of what each one offers..Since this product provides so much for all our computers (I think we're computer junkies--but hey--family of 6) AND phones...it's really worth coughing up the extra money.I installed windows 10 around the time I installed this, and the computer is acting a bit slower. I can't say whether it's windows 10 or McAfee, but it's something to think about.

Ok, to be fair, there's not some life-changing quality here to send this to the peak of freezer bag perfection. But the quality is excellent for this category. The zippers zip easily and smoothly and hold up when I yank them harshly at the end. Just in case you can't tell which side is locked (it happens), they have an arrow and the word "closed".  In addition, there's the popular white label area which makes it easy to write the contents and date becuase it's easy to forget both one frozen hard and piled in the freezer.You get 4 generous boxes here, which makes them a nice value. And they don't take up much room if you're storing them for future use.

I like this and the cord is longer than my cell phone cord, so that alone makes it easier. I wouldn't say it's made a major difference in my life, but it's quality made and pretty. It charges well and quickly!

Luxurious headphones with awesome sound quality! They do make it difficult to catch people talking to you (in case that's important). You just enter your own world. The quality is wonderful, and I love the bass.

LOVE Just Dance, and here is a version for young children (3-8) that would be a great gift for a families with an xbox. The songs are fun and memorable, but there's one about being evil which I don't want my children practicing singing. So they will just be told to skip it. Just Dance, in general, is a fantastic way to exercise because it's more fun than most workouts and gets the heart pumping.

My daughter is a bit MLP fan and she LOVES this. It's a great gift for Christmas for girls who love MLP or horses or scooters. lol. The controls are easy to figure out and the pony stays on most of the time. This Pinkie Pie is the the larger size than the standard ponies. You'll need 5 AA batteries for the scooter and remote. A good time for rechargeables, but so far one set has lasted.It comes with a code for an app for IPhone etc, and Android. My daughter loves these games.WARNING: CHOKING HAZARD - Small parts will be generated. Not for children under 3 years.

For me, the belly area was a bit tight compared to other jeans, but the legs fit very well. They are died to a super rich dark blue (in fact, the label says to wash before wearing because the color may bleed initially). The legs were very comfortable. But I'm going to have to lose some weight and do some crunches before I can wear them without being stuffed into them like a sausage. lol. I do have a pretty generous belly, so I can't fault the jeans, since no jeans will fit every shape, so I'm giving them 4 stars.UPDATE... I realized I've been wearing 16W and these are just 16. I believe that is the difference in sizing. So I cannot blame the jeans for this error, but myself. And I will update the rating to 5 stars. They are excellent color/durability and style.

So clever! For salads that you don't want marinating/ soggifying in the dressing all morning, this is a perfect solution. Really, even if you don't use the dressing container (which is easy to attach or leave off), it's a great way to bring along a salad--even just chicken salad or pasta salad. Although some may prefer the glass, I worry too much about breaking glass which is a mess and ruins the salad, of course. This is a pretty large jar and will hold plenty of salad for lunch. Great invention!

This is an awesome thing to buy. Computers can be so difficult and taking them in to be repaired can cost a FORTUNE and you never know how much. Here, you have a knowledgable person who can just listen to your issues...no matter what... and help you fix them. It's a fabulous product and I'm glad to have it, for my sense of security. A huge leap from the days when I had to pay long distance fees to wait on hold for an hour with Microsoft before even getting help!

I really lack for words when describing music, but I wanted to add a review to this under-celebrated artist. Fabulous voice and fabulous music. Had this album for a long while now and it's just as beautiful, nuanced and kind of haunting as when i first listened.

This is great quality for business-grade toilet paper. I prefer Charmin, being more of a single-ply, but this one is very soft and does "the job" without having to pull out a ton. Each one is individually wrapped so you can put a few under different sinks without them getting dirty. It shipped in the box pictured (within a larger box, for protection). There are punctured lines for easy access opening. If you're thinking of buying crappy hazy-thin toilet paper, your customers and employees will understand that you are cheap. Georgia-Pacific Angel Soft is, by all accounts, acceptable grade and won't cause people problems or concerns of the flimsy bargain basement kind. And the  price is pretty reasonable, too.

So far, this is a fabulous gate. This is a screw-in gate, so it's more sturdy/reliable than a spring-held gate, however, it does require screwing in to the wall. When baby gets bigger, patching the holes in wood or wall is relatively easy but you'll need paint/stain to match the wood/wall.The gate is quite beautiful wood--it's such a smooth finish it seems almost metal, but it's very stylish/classy. If you have a beautiful home, this will be a big asset versus some of the eyesore gates I've seen.The hardware worked ok for install. But I did end up using a replacement screw for one of the screws. The Hinges have held up well so far and it swings beautifully. the non-toddlers in our house have to adjust to using it, but it soon will be just normal. I love that it can swing two ways.One review complained about the height. Be sure to keep it fairly close to the ground, so baby cannot slide under it, but obviously it be off the ground some. The actual wood is  Tall. And with the bottom hinges installed straight at floor level, it measures  " to the top rail. If you have really tall people in your house, you might look for a taller gate. Check online the current safety regulations of baby gates. I would share them with you, but they might change.

This came packaged very carefully with a lto of layers. This ensures the chocolates arrive intact and in place. It also creates anticipation as you open the mailing box, the cardboard box with hinges. Then peel off the protective seal. And finally arrive at a gorgeous array of enticing treats. The quality is very good. They have a hazelnut edge, which is very European (they use hazelnut as we use peanut/peanut butter). The texture is smooth and creamy and the flavor is excellent. An elegant gift.

This beautiful hardbound cookbook is a great modern edition of some of my favorite health-conscious cookbooks made by Alice Waters. Fanny at Chez Panisse holds many favorites and I've kept it over the years for the recipes and the illustrations. I only compare this to Alice Waters because she writes the introduction. Instead of just classic vegetarian and health-conscious foods, we get some innovative new flavors here.The book is quality made and beautiful throughout. The photos are inviting and the recipes are delicious so far. I haven't had a salad like the citrus salad and it's a really beautiful, fun take on having a side salad. Just know, that if you sub blood oranges, the whole thing will get a purple hue (not so pretty).Don't skip the introduction because that's the heart of the cookbook and will help you feel a kinship with the author and the book as a whole.Personally, I love grabbing cookbooks for meal planning, knowing they are time-tested and I can grab and go--planning as I'm stuck in waiting rooms, etc. I write downt he recipes I want to try most on a sheet and store it in the front so I can quickly remember what I wanted to make the most.I don't believe you'll be disappointed with this book and it's going to be a great gift for new wives, new young chefs and anyone who loves cooking healthy foods.

This is something I personally would have loved as a child. And it's fun for quite an age range. So if you need something for your 4 year old and the 10 year old who visits, it would be a good bet. The pieces all magnetize together and can be configured and re-configured in a variety of ways. Some spots have a little symbol which means you can put the small magnetic pieces on top. It can be entertaining in a lot of ways and is very bright and solidly built. I could see myself playing with this while watching t.v. just for therapeutic value. I think the reason it's not for younger children is simply because it takes a little skill to match the magnets properly to keep the pieces together. It feels very sturdy and the decals should handle some good wear & tear

I was a bit skeptical...I mean, I knew it would heat up and light the newspaper we use to light our grill, but I had no idea how awesome it would be.I plugged this baby in, and let it heat for 2 seconds. Then I went to light the newspaper and within 2 more seconds, it was wildly aflame. I went ahead and lit it on the other side. and KABLAM...I had a roaring fire that light my charcoal up with evenness and intensity I don't normally experience. My grill is a smoker grill and it lights this way, but I am highly confident it would quickly light charcoal itself. Maybe as long as 5 seconds. I will try to figure out how to directly light the charcoal rather that use the method with the newspaper that my smoker grill is designed for--it would certainly be easier to set up!It stays a bit hot afterwards, so absolutely MUST be careful with this. But I'm sold.

I love the design of this thing. It's elegant for a baby tub and very modern. But what is even better, are the features. I keeps the baby cuddled in the soft plastic/rubber base and allows water to pool up until it might get too deep and it pours out. It easily separate into two pieces for all around cleaning, but so far, just a rinse and spray/wipe is working fine. It would be an impressive gift for a new mom.

Gorgeous! Quality made with solid clasps and well-set gems. This is a great gift for any woman who dresses up on occasion. Casual enough for many work environments, but formal enough for formal events. It's well-priced for the quality. From top to bottom it's 2 centimeters (approx 3/4"). It comes in a box that is nicely coated, sturdy black cardboard. Honestly, I find the more expensive hinge boxes with faux-velvet lining to be dated and pretentious anyway.

My daughter and her friends have so much fun taking turns with the bow and all dancing silly together. It's kind of like "just dance" but their own thing. She's about the size of the regular lalaloopsies and just as cute. This would be a great Christmas gift because it has the cuteness of the lalaloopsy doll and the fun interactive & active aspects as well. Holding up really well, but we haven't had it long.
Solid product. Works well. Soft and supple..

I use the 360 dusters, and I love this new version all the more. It's got a lot more surfaces to grab and works better on those darn blinds! And is even better on the molding, of which I have way too much and it all loves to hug the dust. You can spray polish on it to shine things up, too.

This is a newer version of the Lalaloopsy Surprise Potty. She comes with FOOD! Such an awesome toy. Adorable, easy to clean, and teaches about the body processes. Super Birthday Gift for a toddler in your life!

My husband is the Beef Jerky aficionado, so he did the taste testing for me. And he says these are "quite delicious." and he "rates them: awesome!" They are not tough and hard to chew, but not too soft. I guess like little bear's chair, they are "just right."

Ok. these aren't 5 star paper towels, even though they are a great value for what you get. So, I don't want to mislead anyone by giving it 5 stars.That said, for the price, these are quite absorbent and stay together.  IF you've spoiled yourself with extra soft paper towels, these will seem lacking, but for the budget-conscious, these will really fit the bill. My only preference would be more sheets per roll because I don't like changing them out as often.

I tried this on an envelope with preprinted writing. But since that is all pretty boxy and the stamp figures are boxy, I added some handwriting on the envelop (see picture). IT demolished it. You can't read it AT ALL. Coloring it black didn't allow it to show throughThen I tried the pill bottle (see 2nd picture). Unfortunately, just overlapping the two stripes created enough darkness to make the elevated letters to stand out. And that increased with black marker. Sooo, it's not gonna work with any sort of raised or textured/waxed letters. Too bad, because it's the round pill bottles I hoped mostly to use this with. However, I do not know that every prescription bottle uses this type of ink/printing, so it may work for yours.

Corel Painter 2015 was a decent upgrade with improved the performance speed, new images, papers, gradients, & user-interface palettes. They added jitter smoothing so you could create realistically random brushstrokes, and app support. So, what would draw a person to paying for Corel 2016 which is a retail price of $229 for the upgrade.Thankfully, Corel Painter 2016 kept those useful upgrades they made in 2015, then took a good-sized step forward. They did, however, stop from creating things for you. Yes, that was my little joke.For starters, they added 4 types of BRUSH Upgrades:1. Audio Expression:  This unique feature gives you brushes that react to sound from music played in the background or on the computer.  Play music (or your  voice) and the strokes go along with it, getting larger strokes with louder sounds and so on.  Because it syncs with the  sound, it can create a natural randomness with some rhythm and order, just like music.2. Dynamic Speckles:  Using particle system physics (you'll have ask Corel more on that) and brush thickness, you can control to splatter  the pictures for a different look. This mode works best with Bristle, RealBristle and Particle brushes, to create natural-  media brushstrokes. They are dynamic and generated as you paint.3. Special Media Mixing:  Here they offer new tools such as Liquid Ink, Watercolor, or Impasto to create more realism.4. Paper and Flow Map Rotation:  You can change the angle of paper textures and flow maps, which adds realism and freshness to your design.Brushes:Painter 2016 has a wide range of brushes, which are grouped into different categories, such as Airbrushes, Artists Oils, Acrylics, Calligraphy, Cloners, Pencils, and Watercolor. You can create custom brushes, and can easily see what brushes you used recently.  You can check out the most recently used brushes and create custom brushes. 131 new brushes including special media brushes (more specifically, dab types that can be used for applying media to the canvas: Liquid Ink Gravity Particles, Liquid Ink Flow Particles, Liquid Ink Spring Particles, Watercolor Gravity Particles, Watercolor Flow Particles, and Watercolor Spring Particles), and layer blending for producing brushstrokes without white fringes.Default settings (with personalization):When you restore the default settings, you can set it to preserve your custom features such as scripts, textures, palettes, custom brushes. It's a relief knowing you can go back to "start" and still preserve your personal features.Document Views:It is easier than before, to switch between document views and presentation views via the toolbox, Window menu, and keyboard shortcuts. The Single Document View focuses shows the active design, while the Presentation Mode hides the menu and taskbar,  leaving only the main controls and giving you a cleaner, large surface to work with.User Interface:you can now personalize the workspace by modifying the color scheme to Dark, Frost, Sepia & Grey (default). You can also change the background color to any color in the color wheel.Integrated learning:The learning curve for using Corel has been quite high for the average user. To simplify that process, Paint 2016 automatically updates training content as you work, basing on what you have already seen. And gives you "hints" in context. For example, the new Brush Hints tool provides context-sensitive brush suggestions, while Visual Tooltips provides illustrations. The Welcome Screen that appears when you start the app, helps you find out information and the tools you need.Content sharing:Enhanced features to help you export custom brushes, papers, patterns, and flow maps via a custom Toolbox file.Faster/Better Performance:New features are great, so long as they don't lag and slow your work. Corel improved performance and stability. Brushes are up to three times faster than the previous version. Painter 2016 also makes it faster and easier to blend strokes across layers and media types. Plus, you can now import the brush stamps of pixel-based Adobe Photoshop brushes for further customization in Painter.If you want to be the top of your game, you'll invest in the newest version. For the beginner, there are benefits in the new Integrated learning. I suspect it's the mid-range users who  will have to think the hardest whether to pay for this upgrade. Photoshop users can import their brushes if they want to give Painter a try. It's a good time to move over.

Attractive, medium-quality fire pit. The cover isn't going to last two summers in Georgia, so we'll keep it in the shed when possible. There are more durable canvas covers that will fit. You'll want protection from snow and sun because the finish isn't  as solid as I'd like. I love that it's so open, but you have the mesh to keep stray cinders from spilling out. Once you burn a couple fires in it, it looks pretty used, so the cover should make it more attractive when its sitting in the open. Obviously, the cover is plastic and should not be placed on a hot fire pit (unless you want it permanently attached). The mesh isn't rock solid. It has some bend to it. The lid is good for protection, but won't allow for tall fires, so if you want more height (teepee style), then the lid won't fit.It's sturdiness is midrange. There are less expensive, less sturdy fire pits, and more expensive more sturdy fire pits. So if you are just an occasional fire pit user, this should work well for you.
So far these are wonderful. Fit comfortably and are easy to put on. They are soft and durable. It's a BIG pack. A great baby gift on its own!

These are truly the softest cloths I've ever felt. Awesome!! They do have a bit of a smell that I don't care for, so I will wash them before using. If you were going to make a baby toy out of washcloths (we used to make rabbit ones), these are PERFECT! And perfect for anyone that wants a soft and gentle washcloth.

I love the clever idea here and reuse options. Our van can get smelly and we have a trunk that has picked up some funky odors, so I'm sticking this inside to reduce odor without any worry of toxic residue or allergen-chemicals. It's a bit rough and large for someone looking for discrete odor removal. All in all, very eco-cool.

Super easy to figure out. You just do 5 mil on thicker materials and 3 mil on standard materials.1. Turn on by pushing power button2. Push 3 mil or 5 mil3. When the "ready light" lights up, you stick the item in the chute. It did not take long..like 1 minute.4. Once it grabs the item itself, then you let go.Mistake...if you don't let go and let it do its thing, it can create a line in the finished lamination where you changed the speed.I love the slim profile for this larger scale laminator. You can do larger pages when you need to.It comes with a pack of laminate sheets to get you started. (there are quite a lot of Scotch brand laminate options if you check them out on Amazon).
Luxuriously soft! It's stylish and cuts across country girls and city girls... fits both styles. It's going to last well and wash well... it's just that well made. I want a blanket version!

This product is loads of fun for children ages 2-9 or so. It cleverly converts from Cruise to House and had some fun little accessories inside. LIke the table is attached tot he chairs (thank you for less pieces, Vtech!) and you can flip open the "food pot" and find a treasure inside. The doll is adorable and my daughter thinks it's super fun to press a gem (LOVES gems) to get her to speak. Like other MagicPoint sets, you can move the character around and hear her say different things.The box shows several characters that come in the series,  but only the one character comes with this set. So, if your child loves this, there are more options for other gifts later on.

Someone mentioned this containing "chemicals", it doesn't. Other than the fact everything is a chemistry... it's just pure maca powder. Bake muffins with it, or put some in your pancakes, breads etc. Great way to BOOST your nutrition and I feel better when I take it.

Legos have grown up a bit here. With a push for girls to go into Science Technology Engineering Math (STEM), this is a perfect way to get them started. It's all in this compact container. Each project helps them think of solutions to problems as they fix the roller coaster and do their own things. The quality is very good and the colors/design appearance is very good. Geared for younger children, but still fun for older children (me!) There are 18 separate projects to get them started and a cool clear case with flip down locks.

I love listening to tunes with my device in the shower or bath, but I can't bring it near me. I put this on the side of the shower so it doesn't get soaked (not wanting to test its ability to be submerged) and I place it by my bathtub so I can listen to music or even plug in my laptop on the counter and have the sound near me. It's really nice for these purposes. The sound is quite nice. I think the enclosed space gives it a bit of an echo, so I don't know about big rooms. It feels like a small torpedo... like it will last forever. For improvements, I do wish I could grab it by the handle more easily.
