It's a bit of an effort and although it does dump water, it only shoots about 12' at best  I also found that the Flash Flood trigger, being as arduous as it was, is not ideal for under 10 since they don't appear to have the strength to keep loading the water and dumping it.  It's an impressive looking Supersoaker, but when you're in an actual water attack, it doesn't work as well as the others to defend yourself.

This super soaker arrived just in time for Memorial Day weekend and was a favorite with kids and adults alike by the pool.  What else can I say in general about super soakers except they are loads of fun.  This particular model delivers four streams of water at once and has a very easy pump action trigger.  I would say that the distance for firing is more around 25' as opposed to 30' and after a couple of pumps, the bottom water stream doesn't fire.  It apparently only fires when the gun is completely full, however the other three work consistently throughout and you have a pretty accurate shot since the water doesn't fire in all different directions like the crossbow version.  Either way, you can't go wrong with any of these options.

What can I say , except Ms. Jones has done it again.  This remains in my top 5 favorite series of all time and a lot happens in this installment.  If you've never read the previous books, you can't appreciate the characters and their nuances and you definitely wouldn't get the full blast of fun this series often brings since this particular book is much deeper and darker than her previous installments.  The story starts off much the same way with a fast forward of 8 months and the usual light bantering, but quickly spirals into sinister plots, schemes, spies, and an epic reveal.  Unfortunately, it also ends on a bit of a downer as well as a cliffhanger which knocked it down a star in my estimation.It's very difficult not to give the book away with a synopsis, however the story begins with Charley and the gang preparing for the wedding of Cookie and Ubie while Charley is 9 months pregnant and ready to pop.  They've been living on sacred ground for 8 months and have a touch more than cabin fever, but are making the best of things.  Charley gets involved in an investigation remotely of a missing niece to an FBI agent and does all she can to help, meanwhile she's secretly investigating several personal issues on her own including looking up Reyes' real parents, to which she was told not to, as well as investigating who killed her father, to which she was also told not to.  In classic Charley and Reyes fashion, they are keeping many secrets from one another that culminate to an ending that will leave you blindsided.Overall, this was an epic installment that brings every character ever featured in past installments, WOW Mr. Wong, as well as some new characters including Lucifer himself.  It also features many major reveals and kick starts what could potentially be a spinoff or Charley Davidson 2.0, but don't think that all your questions will be answered.  For now, I'm feeling rather maudlin at the end of book 8, with reservations about book 9, but it hasn't prevented me from already having it on pre-order.

I have to be honest and say I'm not sure what the overall effectiveness of the product is, but I can say that I enjoy the smell and plan on using these this winter which will be the real test.  We live near deep woods and of course in an old house, there's bound to be mice to which we've seen the evidence.  Since using these, I haven't seen any new evidence of mice, however, it may also be due to the time of the year with spring, they likely all went outdoors.  The scent starts out strong but turns into a pleasant and fresh minty air freshener within a week.  Overall, I enjoy the smell and if it deters rodents, all the better.Whether or not they're truly a deterrent remains to be seen.

It certainly took me long enough to write a review for this because I fell into the category of those who's brains shut down when trying to get started.  I have no experience with either sewing or embroidery, and although I'm quite handy, I'm not crafty.  That spoke volumes as I was setting up the machine.  Snapping the two primary pieces of the machine together wasn't an issue and is really simple.  It was getting the threads setup and through the needle that took me a bit of time.  The one piece of advice I can give is do not bother with the "Quick Reference Guide" if you've never used an embroidery machine before.  The instructions come in four languages and although one of them is English, it might as well have been Chinese for me.  I did well enough with the operation manual and once the threading was complete, the instructions for setting up an embroidery pattern was like using a combo printer where you can select letters and designs.Overall, I suspect that it will get easier with time.  My first attempt and I had too much tension on the fabric which didn't turn out right, but if you hold it still and leave it a little loose, it works much better.  I haven't worked up the bravado to actually try it on a shirt since I don't want to ruin them, but my husband loves initials on his shirt cuffs so I'm working my way to it.  Overall, it's an easy machine to use and if you have some experience, it's probably a great value.  I did notice that Brother also makes a sewing machine and embroidery machine in one and think overall that is more reliable.  Also, if you're looking to do this professionally, the 700 series seems to be the machine of choice and I've seen them stationed at several arts and craft fairs, but this certainly gets the job done for an amateur like myself.

What else is there to say about a super soaker aside from they're hours of endless fun for kids and adults alike?  This particular model is a about 18" long and requires two hands, one to hold the device, and the other to pump the water. It emits three streams and would work on multiple targets but if you're looking to soak a single person, then only one of the three streams will likely hit its mark.  The middle stream blasts about 20', with the two side streams about 15'.  We love these for the pool area and for some unknown reason, even though everyone's already wet, a blast from the super soaker always jump starts a bout of screaming and laughing.Super soakers are also a great training device with cats and dogs, but not this particular model because of the three streams.  If you're looking to discipline your pet, it's best to go with a single stream.

This cover fits over just about any set of stacking chairs with a lot of give to accommodate stackable chairs with a wider arm dimension and the cover is a well made burlap material.  This is the third outdoor cover that I've received in the last four months to prepare for winter and the rainy season and although I have to say this ranks #2 in the quality department.  The reason is that the inside is almost a rubbery coating on the burlap and although clearly waterproof, it doesn't have as much slipping to easily go over the chairs but rather clings to it which requires more adjusting and pulling down the cover over the chairs.  On the plus side, it's not easy for this to slip off or blow away.With that I prefer the Ravenna covers that have a thick burlap on the outside and a smooth waterproof plastic on the inside that makes it easier to adjust and slip over furniture, but this is still better than my first purchase which was basically a plastic cover that isn't as durable.  This will easily last ten years and is very hard to tear.

This is a nice mattress cover but I wouldn't say it's anything to write home about.  It's nice and thin and the weave does keep the bed comfortable and cool, but I tend to go for slightly thicker covers and cooling the mattress is not usually a goal of mine.  The website description says this fits 22" mattresses at certain places, however the packaging states that it fits up to 20" mattresses.  Regardless of what you have, the elastic sheer sides will easily fit over 22" and there's no struggling to get over all four corners.  If you have the older slimmer mattress, this is actually going to be too large which would contribute to shifting.  The cover will certainly protect the mattress from everyday wear, but it has no waterproofing properties if that's what you're looking for.  The upside of this is that the materials are not only machine washable,  but it will survive the dryer which has managed to demolish many a mattress pad for me in the past.One thing to mention in terms of wear and tear is that the underside is a scratchier material that will prevent shifting and movement, but it also tends to pill and collect all residual lint and hair, but only time will tell how this all holds up.Overall, It's a decent quality, but I've seen better made covers and around the $50.00 price tag, I find this cover to be more expensive than what you may be able to pick up at Homegoods.  It's also designed in size for newer thicker mattresses and strictly designed for comfort, not protection.

I have to say I'm impressed with this Micro Magic Microdermabrasion and it works very well for evening out my complexion and eliminating dry skin.  I've been disappointed in general with most microdermabrasion products since they're so mild, you don't feel the grains working on your skin.  The only exception would be Kiehls which is easily the most abrasive product I've used, but my skin type warrants it and when I'm looking for something slightly milder, I can always water it down.  I still love my Kiehls, but this product, which is comparable in price, is just as good without the harshness.  The grains are much smaller and with the addition of vitamin E and a minty essence, it felt more like it was polishing my skin and it left my face smooth and refreshed.  It's definitely a winner in this category.

This is a pretty sturdy and reliable juicer that is easy to use and easy to clean with the maximum amount of juice to be had from the fruit, whether big or small.  I noticed another review said that it didn't work well with limes because they were too small, but when I used this, it squashed my lime practically flat and breaking the peel to ensure the juice came out.  I also did not have any issues with seeds coming out, although there is little splinters of smaller seeds that I would drink anyway as part of the pulp.What you see if basically what you get.  The juicer is not adjustable in height so you have about a 5" clearance for a cup which doesn't fit my standard kitchen glasses.  It's heavy duty and supposedly has suction feet, but although it has sturdy rubber feet, they don't provide any suction, so if you're overly eager in pressing the handle, it can be a little tippy.  Not enough to actually tip the juicer since it's so heavy, but it will wobble a bit.Overall, it's a great juicer for a variety of fruits and is large enough in size for grapefruits, and although I haven't tried it, you could very likely throw a bunch of grapes in here as well to smash the juice out.  The only thing I can't see it working well for are apples since the mush would clog the drain holes.

Like all reviews, this one needs to be taken with a grain of salt.  First and foremost, I was able to setup this up on my Ipad seamlessly, however still cannot get it to sync with my Samsung S5.  For the Ipad the setup is fairly easy after some initial annoyance.  I had to read the directions to find the actual place to charge the device.  You need to peel back the ear bud rubber cover to access it and my concern is that constantly pulling back the rubber will cause deterioration.  Also, when I plugged it in, the connection doesn't insert all the way.  It looks like it's only half way in, but the red light came on so I knew it was working.  A complete charge took about 2 hours and the light changes to green.  Once the device is synced, a popup message links you to the app store to download the appropriate app, but that didn't work. When I searched for the app, I couldn't find it either, so had to go to the website to search for the app, link to the app store, and finally download the app.That done, everything else worked just fine for me.  The ear buds themselves are extremely comfortable.  Probably the most comfortable I've worn and as I jumped around and ran like a maniac, they remained secure.  Although the heart rate monitor sporadically spikes here and there, it's pretty accurate on average.  I wouldn't call the sound quality state of the art, but it's decent and has a good range of volume to suit my needs. There's also an additional app that you can download to enhance the overall sound quality.  The short cord that can wrap around the back of your neck is a good length and leaves easy access to the multi-function button which serves as the Bluetooth sync, on/off, and answer call/hang up call functionality.Any instructions and voiceover from the application plays with your music or audiobook in the background so it won't bring your workout to a screeching halt in tempo.  All information comes directly from the app such as heart rate and battery power left so there's nothing on the headset itself that states the battery is low.I can't comment right now on the call answer quality until I can get it working on Samsung phone.  For now, my phone recognizes the device, but when I try to pair it, all I get is an error message stating "Unable to communicate with the Jabra Pulse Smart."  At the end of the day, I'm not going to be running around with an Ipad so I'll provide an update once I've spoken with Jabra.

Admittedly, I am not a avid fan of this series, but more of a lurker, having read the beginning, the middle and a couple towards the end.  These stories are not bad, but I find myself forgetting them, almost before I finish the book and they're not part of my reread pile like Jeanienne Frost or Kresley Cole who qualify for multiple rereads.  That being said, I was very curious how this final installment would play out and although one of the more interesting stories in the series, with a few surprises, I found this final installment to be a rather bland recipe by the numbers for paranormal romance.  It had all the components to a chohesive story, with sexy scenes, some surprises and danger lurking, but I never felt lost in the story or the dialogue.Jia is an extremely naive royal princess weretiger who's paretns and sibling were slaughtered by Master Han.  She's sworn to avenge their deaths and is constantly plotting ways to track him, but the effort is doubly hard since she usually has to escape her cousins who love and watch out for her very closely.  Russell is also Hell bent on revenge, literally, since waking up from an almost 40 year coma to find himself a vampire created by Master Han, but when he gets a shot at killing Master Han after 2 years of covert ops and spying, his attempt is thwarted by a meddlesome woman in dire need of rescue.As far as finales go, this did not go out with a bang, but it did bring all the characters together for a reunion of happily ever after.  The final showdown was bittersweet, if not a bit anticlimactic and the happiness that ensued is stuff of fairlytales.  All in all I felt almost like I was watching a movie instead of losing myself in a story, and although I liked Russell's character, I was not enamored of Jia, who although competent in skill, was generally feather brained.  That being said, fans surely won't miss out on this final installment, but as far as a recommended read, I could have taken or left it.

This is a very cute apron and although many reviewers are not happy with the lightweight cotton, it's actually one of the things I like.  I have several aprons and they're a very heavy material, but really all you need is something lightweight to prevent splashing.  Since it's such a thin cotton material, it will cinch at the waist to give you a dress like look and feel, but it's also on the smaller side if you're a larger woman.  I am by no means petite at 5'8" and 160lbs with an ample top, but the apron covers me just fine.  It may not look like a cute dress on me as displayed in the picture, but I suppose that to be more my problem than the apron's.  I had no problems with it covering my entire front to keep me clean, and it still looks cute.Since it's cotton, it does shrink in the dryer, but not by a whole size.  The ribboning at the skirt also came out wrinkled looking after washing and drying, so if you want this to look meticulous, you will need to haul out the iron.  Overall, I wouldn't call it a top quality apron, but it does the job and I like the lightness and colors.

What a complete change of pace coming from Darkness into Smiley, both five star reads, but the names are synonymous of the stories themselves, of course, since the heroes chose these names for a reason. 13 books into the series and it is still going strong while each story is completely unique and satisfying.  I would say any of these books could be read as a standalone, but they're just so good, I would recommend starting at the beginning with Fury, which to date, still remains my personal favorite and lays the foundation for all other installments.  Smiley is the first primate species featured in the series and overall, it was great to discover some of the differences about them, but what stood out the most is that is the most romantic and tender of all the books to date.Vanni is tricked by her fiance into attending an important benefit for her soon to be father in law's "church" which very specifically targets New Species as not only an abomination but a threat to the world.  When she discovers she's not there for a romantic weekend getaway, she's seriously pissed off and instead of going to her room, she heads off to the bar where she meets Smiley, a new species.  At first, Vanni is nervous because she doesn't want Smiley to know she's with people who are anti New Species, but as the night progresses, they end up connecting really well, until Vanni starts experiencing hot flashes and dizziness.  Smiley soon realizes that while they've been sitting together with drinks, they've both been drugged, very specifically with the breeding drug from his Mercile days.  From there all hell breaks loose.  Smiley is drawn to Vanni and although she seems to be the primary suspect for their drugging, he can't help but believe her innocent.The story has a kick start and things progress rather rapidly, with plenty of mistrust and danger past the half way point, but then things slow down and progress into a lovely courtship to win Vanni's heart.  Smiley remains stalwart and completely supportive of Vanni's innocence and he'll stop at absolutely nothing to protect her.  This is not a story of miscommunication or stubborn denial of one's feelings, but a slower progression of getting to know one another and trusting one another to build a lasting relationship.  It's a different pace than Ms. Dohner's typical Alpha male role since primates are evidently much more sensitive than canines or felines and quite frankly, this makes me even more eager to read about Jericho. We have a short reunion with Fury, Justice, and Slade along with a quick cameo of Darkness, and I loved how supportive the New Species were in this installment overall.  All I can say is, thank you and please keep them coming!

This is book 2 of the Tales of the Djinn and I was pleasantly surprised that the second story remained on our main characters from book 1.  The way the first book, The Guardian, was laid out, I thought for sure we would have a total of four books based on the foundation of four main characters, The Guardian, The Magician, The Artist, and The Sultan, who duplicated part of themselves so they could escape to come back and rescue their city from an evil sorceress.  That being said, you do not want to start the series here and should go back to the first book which I found to be a five star read.Elyse Soloman was your run of the mill landlady of a brownstone apartment in New York when she met up with two very strange new tenants, Arcadius (Cade) and Joseph, and found there was a whole other world of Djinn that she has very close ties to.  Elyse ended up falling for Cade and helps them to save their people who are frozen in stone, but they only managed to bring back half of the people so far.  One such person brought back, was Arcadius' original form.  For some reason, when the curse was lifted, the two Arcadius' did not merge back into one and when the three of them work together to help find missing teenage Djinn, Elyse finds herself not only falling deeper in love with Cade, but she can't help but fall for his double, Arcadius.The premise of this story was absolutely fantastic and I was completely prepared for a magical journey into a scorching threesome, but although technically it worked out that way, it wasn't quite as hot and spicy as I'd hoped.  To be honest, there was too much insecurity and awkwardness  and overall I found the two badass Arcadius' turned into marshmallows, instead of the take charge studmuffins they originally were.  Joseph, the magician's story was progressed a bit and I found I would have rather read about him and his angst versus all the angst that was attached to Elyse, Cade and Arcadius.  Mario and Cara are back for round two, but this time they seemed more like a nuisance than true villains.  I was also hoping we'd get a little more on where the Sultan and the Artist are, but the story never even touched on them.  Regardless, I enjoyed the book, but was not caught up in the magic I felt from the first book.  I'm still looking forward to reading future installments and hope they'll be more action packed and progressive with alot less angst.

First and foremost, I had never heard of Viva Labs, but apparently it was formed in 2011 by doctors and homeopaths to build all natural health aids.  3 years isn't long enough to know if they are simply a trend or if they're in it for the long haul as a trusted provider, but I've yet to see any negative press on their company.In terms of the prenatal DHA, like so many others, I am actually not pregnant, but the source of DHA from small fish like sardines and anchovies is safer and contain less mercury than fish like salmon which seems to be the go to source for essential fatty acids.  What I truly liked about these softgels is that there is no strong smell you'll get from many others and they did not upset my stomach.  When taking other prenatal vitamins with DHA, some have actually made me naseaus which is not the case here.In terms of ingredients, this contains sardines, anchovies, vitamin E, vitamin D3, gelatin and glycerin, and although it does give you the does EPA, DHA, and other Omega 3's, there is no recommended daily allowance so it's not proven how much is enough.  What I didn't like with the addition of vitamin E and D3 is that it doesn't tell you how much is in there.  I have no idea if it's 100% daily value or if it's so insignifcant you need additional.The supply will last you 3 months, with two pills per day and seems comparable to Nordic Naturals in dose, but much higher than Nature Made multi-vitamin with DHA.  At least Nordic Naturals tells you how much Vitamin E they've put in so you have a baseline.

This is a very cool gadget and when I saw this as a vine selection, I wasn't sure if I really needed it, but thought it would come in handy to confirm the laziness factor of my dogs.  I typically work from home, but when I'm away, I wondered if my dogs would act differently.  The setup was fairly easy with wifi, however I did have some issues.  The footprint of my house is very large being a non traditional ranch and we actually have three wireless routers setup throughout, all with different names for the rooms they're in.  This device essentially let me hook up to one of the routers consistently and did not automatically switch to the best strength connectivty, but my dogs have their favorite spaces and apparently they don't move much when they're at home.  My bluetooth also works intermittently, but I have often have this problem with a lot of devices since we have so many bluetooth connections setup through the house as well.The capabilities of the monitor are pretty expansive to allow you to manage your dog's daily activity, medications, and overall well being, but with my youngest being at 9 years old, they're so set in their ways, that this device ended up being more of a curiosity resolver than anything else.  It has pretty much proven that my dogs do not move for much of the day and I can only assume that when the mailman or a random delivery person shows is when we have any activity at all.  If you're serious about ensuring your dog receives a minimum amount of exercise each day, this is the perfect way to track and adjust when you're spending time with them, but if you're like me, who's probably more lazy than the dogs, and have no intentions of doing any regimen based on the results, then it's probably not worth it.  I'll definitely hang on to it, though since we're constantly fostering pets for adoption.  One work of caution, is that it is a decent, slightly smaller than hockey puck size so it's really not idea for small dogs.  Although people have been successful with 15lbs or up, I'm actually thinking it's for 30lbs+ for it to be comfortable.

Everything about this product was designed right, with one exception, the size.  The bed protectors are clearly made extremely well with a waterproof, slip proof covering on the back and a soft absorbent and actually pretty striped material that absorbs a lot of water at a fairly fast pace.  I tested with two, three and four cups of hot water and it essentially absorbs into the pad and disperses evenly.  When I lifted the pad, there is water run off on the short side so you would want to fold this up to dispose of, but the the back was bone dry.  It's true that when pressed, water will pool but with the weight distribution of a body it will leave a body moist, but not wet.  That would go without saying in any accident situation, no matter what you try.  The bottom line is that this is made to protect the bed, not the person, necessarily.As I mentioned before, the only real problem is the size.  It measures about 35'x20' and quite frankly, the 20" length is much too small.  If you so much as roll from one side to the other, you'll very likely "fall off" the pad in some capacity.  My father is bedridden and partially paralyzed and even with his limited motion, would manage to flail off the space.  For him, I actually use, the Sofnit 300 Washable Underpad,34x36 or even better, the Champion Washable Underpad 2X-Large, 36x60, which last about 300 washloads and it is a sturdy material so that it can be used to move him around and readjust him on his bed.What I see this being used for is actually a chair protector.  My mother is accident prone these days, and although she wears protection, there are always leaks, so she uses these on the sofa, in the car, and even at the dining table for extra protection.  Overall, the quality is fantastic, but they are going to have to make this available in multiple sizes or simply a larger size for it to truly work for nightime sleeping.

When I finished reading this book, I thought to myself, how did this book get even better than the last?  I'll leave the credit all to Ms. Darynda Jones who clearly has one Hell of a plan for this series, pun intended.  If you've never read the series before, you do not want to start here, and there's no reason for it.  You'll start at the beginning and won't come up for air until you're all caught up in no time.  The Charley Davidson series is easily the most unique story around, that is also clever, funny, engaging, entertaining, fast paced, and simply magical which rides on the fringes of urban fantasy, paranormal romance, and mystery.  If you haven't read previous stories, then this book will have spoilers of previous installments, so if you don't want to know, stop here.Book 7 picks up right where we left off with Sixth Grave from the Edge and Ms. Jones does not drag this story out but moves full steam ahead in her usual fashion to progress the story forward.  Charley is now engaged, expecting a baby girl who's prophesized to be the fall of Satan, and is being hunted by the Hounds of Hell, but she still has a job to do and it seems more and more people keep getting in the way of her living her life. There are several mysteries taking place once again, but Charley manages to clear some up early on, while others take place throughout the story.  Most prominent is that there are a string of "suicides" where no bodies can actually be found and Charley hasn't received any visits from the dearly departed to truly know what's going on.  As she tries to investigate, she has Reyes on her heels at every step, and although they are constantly clashing wills, I still find the relationship between the Son of Satan and the Grim Reaper to be the most compelling couple in fiction, and that's saying something for you Kate and Curran or Cat and Bones fans.The story is written in its typical Attention Deficit fashion where Charley is easily distracted by caffeine withdrawal, practicing motherhood on a goldfish, and other stray thoughts that constantly pop into her head, that always keep me chuckling and with the deeper than usual revelations, sacrifices, and, yes, losses, the style of writing was very helpful in keeping me from weeping.  Charley learns alot more about her abilities and we as readers, learn alot more about the other characters from Amber to The Dealer that are clearly in Charley's life as part of a much bigger picture.  As the events unfold, we're left with a very different Charley Davidson and I cannot wait to see how her vengeance will unfold.

This truly is the best tasting coconut water I've had and I've tried alot including Vita Coco, C20, and ZCO.  I especially enjoy the pulp which are soft chunks of coconut and not a lot of mush.  Like another reviewer, I would prefer these in a smaller can since 16.2 oz is a lot to drink in one sitting, and the company does make a 9.5 oz which sounds perfect, but the cost of the smaller bottles is a lot more expensive than the larger can and quite frankly, more than $2.00/can is already a lot of money for a single non-alcoholic beverage.  Amazon has a vendor that sells a 24 pack which saves you a little more than the 12 pack as well.If cost is not a concern, I recommend you give it a try.  If you enjoy coconut water or are looking for the health benefits without sacrificing taste, this is definitely my first choice.

I feel like I'm cheating a bit here since I haven't read all of the books, and essentially gave up after Spirit Dances even though that one was my favorite up until that time.  These stories clearly got better and better with the passing of time because you have a some ground rules on the story that hops back and forth from the real world to the otherworld and I have to admit, it took me alot of time to digest the goings on, since I would read things incorrectly and then have to go back and reread it to understand parts.  What I can truly say I enjoyed with this conclusion, is just that, I finally have a sense of completion whereas before, I never felt satisfied, mostly with the cliffhangers or a determination to battle things to come, but never getting there.  If you haven't read the series before, you get a brief summary of each of the books that brings you here, but it's not nearly enough to grasp the magnitude of the final battle between Joanne and her friends against the Master.  I would recommend starting from the beginning and have you decide if it's enough to keep your attention till the end.For those of you who, like me, enjoy her smexy scenes, you're not going to get much of that.  This is pure Urban Fantasy and although there's romance, it's not to the level of details you'll find in comparable series.  For many, that's what makes this so unique and special, and for others, falls a little flat.  Although I fall into the latter category, this book certainly pulls on the heart strings and does not disappoint.

I had previously read the first in this series a long time ago, but as I was searching for an audiobook to purchase for a long drive, I thought to give this series another try.  I recall enjoying the first in the series, but wasn't completely hooked.  After listening to this book, I have to say, I'll go back and give the whole series a try again.  I was a little hesitant after reading one and two star reviews claiming this is nothing but porn and there was no story, but I guess that's where people's opinions can truly differ.  I personally enjoyed the book because of the interesting story line that went above and beyond just sex.When the evil opposing pack, the Centrals, kidnap Hannah a powerful earth witch, as well as Reed, one of the Red Wolf Jamensons, their plight truly seems hopeless.  It's been days for Reed and weeks for Hannah, with nothing but torture to look forward to.  Reed is especially tormented by the fact that Hannah, whom he's never met before, is his mate, and there's nothing he can do to protect her.  When former Navy Seal, Josh, learns of the two missing persons, he gets a flash of who and where they are.  He's always had this power to help find people, but only if he's met them before.  He knows there's a reason he was sent the image of these two and he makes plans to help them escape.  As the three come together, they realize there is a powerful bond between them, but all their conceptions of fated mates and rules of attraction get completely scrambled as they struggle to not only survive, but to figure out the importance of one another in their lives.Let's face it, if you're reading a story about witches and shifters, the power of a fated bond should not be an over the top concept, even if it does involve men who were not previously bisexual.  That being said, although there's certainly some yummy sex scenes that include man on man, threesomes, and of course back door action, it did not overpower the story.  The bad guys are really bad, and the side characters who are all eventually spotlighted in their own novels were engaging and interesting.  If threesomes and bisexuality are not your thing, then I wouldn't bother with this book.  Otherwise, I found it a fast paced and entertaining story that makes this series overall unique.

I have to say that I truly enjoyed this film.  Being a longtime Koontz fan, when we hosted a movie weekend, I nominated this film and my friends grudgingly obliged.  Of the six of us, two read the book and 4 did not.  Unanimously, whether you've read the book or not, it rated a solid four across the board for differing reasons.  Why share this?  Well, essentially whether you've read the book or not, you're in for a special treat.  The movie stays very true to the book which is a wonderful thing since I gave the book a five star rating.  The special effects were surprisingly good and with such a good story to tell, Hollywood didn't flub it up.The stories of Odd Thomas have always been dark, with lots of quirk, humor, sadness, tension, action, and interesting characters.  That being said, I enjoyed who was cast as Odd, but I have to say, the only transformation that disrupted my enjoyment was the portrayal of Stormy.  Is it me, or did she seem a little slutty?  She's such a focal point of sun and smiles in the story but not in a midriff baring, sultry sort of way. Don't get me wrong, if you see the reviews I write, they're mostly about smutty romance novels, so I'm not a prude.  I just didn't appreciate the transformation of such an innocent and beautiful character.That being said, it starts off a little campy and I got concerned, but it really pulled together into an entertaining, action packed, and satisfying film.  I would not hesitate to watch the sequels if they're ever made.

This is a conveniently sized printer that doesn't take up too much space but I found it limited in it's functionality and the wifi was spotty depending on the computer.In terms of setup, there was no auto-recognition of any kind.  For twoof the laptops I had running on this printer, each one forced us to perform a manual install of the software to recognize the printer and then only one would actually detect the wifi, even though the other laptop had no problems connecting to our other hp printer.  The quality of black and white as well as color printing was much better than the HP, so there were no concerns with the quality when it did work.  When I wired the other laptop to this printer, it also worked fine.Both scanning and fax capabilities were of good quality and overall for the price point, I would prefer Epson printers over HP.  HP has been such a long recognized name that they seem to run off the brand instead of providing top quality, economical solutions.  Even the ink cartridges for the Epson printer is more affordable.

I'm a big fan of grilling and although we have natural gas piped directly to our grill and use it year round, sometimes I just get lazy and want to stay indoors.  That and living in New England, there's snow to deal with.  I thought this pan looked pretty interesting, even though I have a George Forman and an Indoor grill, they tend to cause a lot of smoke and the only place where I have a vent is right on the stovetop so I thought I'd give this pan a try.  All I can say is wow.  This worked really well.  I was completely impressed with how well the heat distributed evenly over the entire pan so the steaks on the edge cooked at the same timing as the steaks in the middle.  Leaving them on five minutes each side cooked them to medium rare - medium perfection and they looked cookbok cover perfect with even browning and beautiful "grill lines."  Vegetables cooked just as well since the rivets actually create a steam that manages to steam them while giving that grilled pattern look.All this and the clean up was practically non-existent.  The teflon coating appears to be scratch resistant and a good rinse got most of the grease off.  I have a feeling that the gas grill won't be used much this winter with this pan.

I have to say that this is one of my top three favorite New Species for a whole host of reasons, starting with loving the kick butt heroine, the pace, the intermingling of new species we know and love, bringing the overarching storyline full circle, as well as a truly damaged new species who's been more damaged than most.  If you haven't been reading the series, I wouldn't recommend starting here since the storyline has its roots all the way back to book 1, Fury,  through the last, True.  You could skip some books in between, but those two are the most important to this particular book.Kat is an FBI agent who's been sent undercover into Homeland under the guise of instructor from a forensic crime lab, except she blows her cover immediately by kicking some serious a$$, as this book starts with a bang... literally.  She's really been sent to search and recover someone for her boss, but Kat knows something is not right about the operation and uses the opportunity as a break instead, with all intentions of returning empty handed, except now she has to tap dance her way around her impressive combat techniques.  After the NSO discover she's with the FBI, they decide to play along with her pathetic story to see why she's truly at Homeland.  Something along the lines of keep your friends close and your enemies closer, Darkness is determined to uncover Kat's secrets by any means possible.The lowdown is that there is a significant amount of angst, but it felt right in this context.  Darkness has been through some pretty bad stuff and I felt the story explained well enough why he is the way he is.  Kat was certainly a strong enough character to handle the crap he kept dishing out and at the end of the day, he didn't quite get to three strikes, so I'm okay with the patience and forgiveness Kat specifically had to demonstrate.  I especially enjoyed the dynamics between Darkness and all the other New Species, especially Fury.  This story, more than most, weaved in a host of supporting, once starring, characters, and it felt nice to catch up with some of my favorites as well as some new characters. Something was brewing with Trey Roberts, and I'm wondering if this is a hint at the first new species female and human male story Laurann has talked about.  All in all, a great addition that was action packed from the start and wouldn't let me put it down.

This is definitely a handy product to have, especially camping or as a car emergency pack, but needs to be used through user error since there isn't any instructions for the device. Don't get me wrong, it comes with a tiny user guide, but the guide is for models XGB3, 3L, XGB6 and XGB12, but not for the XGS9.  I have a feeling if it did include the one page of tips, it still wouldn't help me since my device only has two modes to inidcate if it is on or not.  Either a flashing red/green indicating it's charging, and a solid red, which I'm not sure what it means.  Perhaps fully charged?  If so, then it's a bad choice of colors since green is the universal color for go and red usually means stop.  With that all aside, it works, but not without some quirks.I first tried the device on a cloudy day since that was what the weather was like and it did not do anything.  No lights coming on here, so I'm assuming it's not going to work very well without direct sunlight.  I then charged in the direct sun the next day and everything fired up nicely. For my Samsung S5 phone, it charged at the same rate it would have if I plugged it into the wall so it's strong enough to keep your phone working.  I next tried it on my Ipad and while it took me a couple of clicks on the power button, it did start to charge the Ipad, but at about 70% the speed as if it was plugged into a wall socket.  This did not surprise me since charging an Ipad on anything but Apple products is always slow for an Ipad.The flashlight works extremely well and lights up at least 50 ft x 50 ft in the dark and I could see clear into the woods.  The device also has pass through charging so your flashlight is always charging while you charge your device.  One of the quirks is that I couldn't get my Ipad or phone to charge without the flashlight pass through so disconnecting the flashlight isn't an option for me.Overall, it works if not by trial and error, but I have to say that it is rather sizeable and at around 5x13".  It's not heavy and about a half an inch thick, but will take up some space in a backpack.  I especially find the interlocking velcro a bit annoying since it's overkill and the velcro is always catching the case and closing automatically.  I guess they really want to ensure the charger stays closed and protected.  Lastly, I have no clue to tell if it's fully charged or not once I brought it inside.  There's no measure for how long the battery is draining through usage so i would definitely recommend keeping it in the sun to be safe rather than sorry.

Just to be clear, this review is for the Epson EX-7230 Pro and NOT the 7235.  For some reason, this product page contains both reviews.  The difference is that this projector does not have wifi, but it is wifi ready if you purchase the additional adapter.  I was confused when I read some of the reviews because they noted the wireless was poor, but there is no wireless on this particular model stock.With that out of the way, this is a really good projector for presentations and it's portable enough that it would make a decent, but not great, projection for movies.  The technical specifications are already reviewed so I'm reviewing on user experience.  I do presentations all the time and this projector is the brightest I've used and crystal clear for sharing directly from your pc or tablet.  Be forewarned, that this model comes with a standard VGA connector and a USB connector so it's PC ready, but if you want to use it with an IPAD or other tablet, you will need to purchase additional converters, which I had available to test.  The picture is extremely clear and has some easy slide controls for clarity and to angle the picture left or right.  It also has a zoom feature which is great if you need to place the projector close to a screen.  On the downside, if you're placing the projector far away, it does not have sufficient depth adjustment to make the picture smaller.  In a nutshell, you'll want this about 10 feet or closer from whatever you're projecting to.  I would throw it in the category of small room projection.Another great feature is the sound.  I tried hooking a dvd player to the projector directly with the HDMI connector and the standard audio cables and the sound was good.  It has 10 levels so although you're not getting stereo quality, it's loud enough for a room.  The picture was also bright, but I could see grid-like pixels during the movie.  It wasn't enough to distract me, but long term, probably not great for the eyes.I should also point out that the projector has auto detection of devices so if you only have one source plugged into the projector whether it's a cable box, dvd player or a computer, the projector automatically adjusts the souce setting.  The only thing I couldn't make work is the pointer on the remote control.  The remote has full access to the functions including volume, but I could only make the pointer appear, but not move it around.If you're looking to travel through airports with this, it's still rather sizable so I would consider a slimmer profile.  These are about the same size as projectors from 10 years ago so it's not something you slip easily next to your laptop or IPAD.  It does come with it's own over the shoulder carrying case but the projector and cables are all you can fit it in.  As mentioned earlier there's an option for a wireless module but I can't find the part number or how much it costs, so if you're looking for wireless, you'll want to EX-7235 instead.Overall, it's a really good value and perfect for on the road presentations if you're driving to your meetings.  It's dummy proof so you don't need to use the ctrl functions on your laptop to start projecting.  This can be good or bad if you're starting up and you don't want everyone to see what's on your desktop so you may want to wait until your presentation is on the computer before making the connection.

I can see how some of the reviewers may have found this installment boring.  I personally did not find it so, but I can't say there was pulse pounding excitement or danger lurking around every corner.  I mean, let's face it, EVERY installment can't have Eve's or Roarke's life on the line and I would not wish it so.  For those of you who have never read the In Death series, it's not the place to start.  For those who are looking for action, this one's also not right for you.  For those long standing fans of the series who cherish catching up with Eve, her quirks, her family and her friends, then this one is a winner.When Lt Eve Dallas receives a phone call at 2:00am from none other than Trina, the bane of Eve's existence, claiming there's a dead body, Eve isn't convinced the whole thing isn't a joke.  That is until Eve finds herself staring at a dead man, tucked in his bed, apparently bludgeoned to death, along with a knife through the heart.  From then on, Eve's investigation leads her through interview after interview with the most unstable group of suspects who all have a motive to want the man dead.Overall, I would say this is 50% quality Eve time and the other 50% a murder mystery.  There's plenty of yummy Eve and Roarke scenes along with some comical moments of Eve <shudder> shopping, as well as helping with Christmas party preparations after making a deal with the devil.  The story is very matter of fact, slow paced and methodical, but nonetheless enjoyable since I always enjoy reading about these characters.  It's a great holiday edition to the series and I look forward to more.

Not your typical fan of Rachel Morgan and the Hollows as a series, I've had mixed emotions all the way leading to this final conclusion.  My biggest gripe of the entire series is not the writing, the action, the plots or secondary characters, but more of oftentimes whiny, shallow, and inept glimpses of Rachel herself.  I was not particularly patient trying to watch her develop and grow into a person worthy of the power she possessed.  That being said, this book was absolute perfection and the heroine that is Rachel shines through with maturity, bravery, loyalty, cunning, and love.  If you haven't read any of the series, you absolutely cannot start here, however you may be able to start around Black Magic Sanction or even Pale Demon which are about five books back.The story comes to a head immediately with the vampires wanting their souls.  Rachel knows this is paramount to suicide for any vampire, but she's backed into a corner when those she loves are used against her.  With Rachel's prognosis coming true, the elves convince the vampires that all the vampires can have their souls back without consequence, but even though the vampires don't trust the elves, their obsession with their souls is their priority.  With the process of bringing them back, all of the demons are released and the story becomes a clash of powers with demons vs. vampires vs. elves with Rachel and her crew stuck in the middle.With so many loose ends to tie up, all of the major points are covered and where we generally get glimpses of side characters, they become solidly integrated into this final book where Rachel is not running off into danger alone and underwhelming, but with an entourage of support.  In fact, I can't think of a time when Rachel was even alone, giving Jenks, Ivy, Al, and a whole lot of Trent, precious story time.  The results were absolutely magical and the ending did not disappoint.  Kudos to Dawn Cook/Kim Harrison for such a wonderful conclusion to this wild roller coaster ride of a series.

I remember when I received an ARC of The Last Victim through Amazon Vine and had no idea what I was in store for.  The reviews were mixed, because of all things, the "hero" in the story appeared to be a serial killer, which grossed people out, but following the genre of paranormal romance and urban fanstasy, I knew there was more to this than meets the eye.  For Karen Robards fans, this series is very different than what you're used to and some people love it, while others hate it, but I for one, love the series. One of the biggest differences is the frenetic way the book is written.  It's edgy with lots of long, disrupted sentences that give it a crazy, fast paced quality.  The first installment is very similar to Darynda Jones's Charlie Davidson series, which is another fantastic urban fantasy/paranormal romance suspense series, but over the last three books, this series has come into it's own and although I love the journey so far, I do think we need a major leap forward to get this series on sturdy ground. If you haven't read this series from the beginning, you could pick it up here, but the dynamics will not be as fulfilling so it's best if you're already on this ride to pick up book 3.Dr. Charlie Stone is an expert psychologist who profiles serial killers.  She's determined to find a correlation in their nature or nuture that leads to this behavior.  She often helps the FBI in profiling, but since the last novel, where she was almost killed, she's a little slow to join the hunt these days.  That, and she's distracted not only by the ghosts she can see and hear, but also by the gorgeous ghost whom she's apparently falling in love with.This go around, we learn alot more about Michael's past as he gets closer and closer to leaving this earthly plane forever.  Charlie is desperate to keep him with her, but constantly jeopardizes the situation by running into scrape after scrape which calls for desperate measures from Michael to protect her, thus thrusting him out of the human realm of the living.  This viscious cycle is what leaves this a four star instead of a five for me.  Charlie is absolutely deranged and can't make up her mind about what she wants and what is good for her.  This angst dragged on quite a bit and the push pull of her feelings for Michael get a bit tiring.  The ending is definitely a bit of a cliff hanger and I'm curious to see where it brings us, but if we go back to denials or worse yet, the end of Michael, then this series has no place to go.  He is the very essence of what makes this series so good.

Before writing this review, I had to read what others had to say.  I'm not sure what posessed me to get a laughing monkey, but when I saw it in my Vine selection, I was thinking it would be great for my two year old nephew.  That being said, he did enjoy it for quite some time, but only under strict supervision.  The sensor is very sensitive on this thing and it's essentially belly laughing constantly.  I say belly laughing because it's kicks and flails and waives it's hands around almost grabbing its belly to contain the laughter.  The bottom of the monkey is also ship shaped so that it essentially rocks back and forth on its back.  Each cycle of laughter goes on for about 10 seconds, which although not a long amount of time, seems really long with how obnoxious it is.With that out of the way, it's actually not a plush toy at all.  The motion detector box is actually quite hard so I wouldn't leave this toy unsupervised since you could throw it at someone and it would hurt or if you accidentally fell on it, definitive ouchies there.  It comes with batteries, thank God, since it's a tiny screw cap to get batteries replaced and the velcro opening to access to battery and power panel doesn't open wide enough for me to fudge around in there.With all the logistics out of the way, I ended up scratching my head wondering what you do with it in the long term.  Ultimately, it has its appeal but after a while, I can only see turning this off and putting it somewhere as a fixture since it annoys parents in about 5 minutes or less.  The one thing I have to agree with my fellow reviewers which I hadn't really thought of is that this would scare the pants off anyone if you left it randomly around the house, including critters.  My dogs barked at this thing the whole time I let it run and everytime they went to investigate it, the monkey would start up again, thus more barking ensued. I was also able to scare the pants off my sister and nephew. Overall, it's a good little gag gift, but for the long haul, you'd have to get creative with it's purpose.

I tried this printer through the Vine program along side a smaller version of the 4640.  I was curious about the legal sized capabilities of this printer, having recently gone through two home closings for family members, I struggled with legal document sized copying and scanning and found myself having to go to the bank to get the scans completed.  Well, if you're managing large paper formats, this is definitely the printer for you.The printer, once again, is easy to setup with a step by step walkthrough process.  It's wifi enabled so you can print from multiple devices and the range for printing wireless is pretty easy.  The quality of the copies and prints is fantastic and it comes with four separate ink cartridges for black and colors which makes the colors vibrant overall.The only downside to this printer is that when it says wide format, it means it.  This printer is enormous and takes up a good sized space on my desk, but again, if you find yourself working with legal sized documents, this is the printer for you.  I had no problems printing and scanning legal sized documents and the quality is as crisp as printing letter size.  If you feel you don't need to print or manage large format documents however, this printer would pretty much be overkill.  It comes with an sk and ms slot for photos, although I haven't used them since I don't have these, but I would imagine it could print some pretty incredible at home panoramic large scale photos.All in all, I would say I'm very impressed with Epson's printers and have left HP behind.

This is a manageable size printer in that, although it's large, it's actually tall and doesn't take up much space on a desktop and absolutely cranks out printing.  It's the fastest print job I've seen after going through about 4 printers including other Epson's and HP's.  There's two paper feeders, one that fits a full ream of paper so running out shouldn't be an issue.  I've not run through the ink cartridges yet, and that's saying something since it comes with the smaller sized ink cartridges, but I'd say it depletes at a fairly normal rate compared to other inkjets.  The duplex printing is one of my favorite features since you can print on both sides of the paper and inkjet printers have come such a long way in that there isn't smudging of the ink since it goes through a dual print process.Scanning is also extremely easy and the only quirk is that it will automatically name the file which cannot be overridden at time of scanning, but you can rename the file onces it's saved.  I have not been successful in scanning legal size documents to capture the whole thing, but I'm wondering if that has more to do with my install.  It's just not an option in the scan control panel for me.For a home office and at the price point, this is an extremely efficient printer, copier, and scanner all in one with excellent, vibrant colors.  Even photos come out nicely.The printer was extremely easy to setup and the control panel essentially walks you through the process.  I've been successful in printing directly from my pc as well as from my Ipad so the wireless feature is sound.  Great value.

No matter what Ms. Frost writes, I will read it and that is completely attributed to the Night Huntress series.  The wit, humor and chemistry of the characters in that series is simply magical, which makes it such a tough act to follow.  That being said, this is something completely different and although action packed with an intriguing new universe of demons and angels, I am not hooked yet.20 year old Ivy is having the worst week of her life.  Her sister went missing a week ago and when her parents went to search for her, they were both killed in an accident.  Ivy doesn't know heads from tails anymore, but she's determined to find her sister.  When Ivy trails her sister's and parent's steps, she finds herself in a creepy town where her delusions are stronger than ever.  Ivy is on medication since she's seen things all her life that weren't really there, or at least no one else can see them, but when she gets caught in the battle between angels and demons, she realizes she's not crazy and she finds herself in a new world that is too horrific to imagine.This is a solid foundation to a new series that is extremely reminiscent of the TV series, Supernatural, which I happen to love.  All in all, there is some very clever writing and Ivy is a likeable, if not overly innocent, protagonist, however I was slightly disappointed by the underlying love story.  Cat and Bones chemistry, this is not.  It would have been better if the hero and heroine actually liked one another as a precursor to falling in love.  The story is very angsty and reads more like a young adult vs. a new adult (whatever that means) novel. Alas, I will be reading the next installment to see where the series will take us, but for now, I have not found myself invested in the characters and look forward to more dialogue and interaction instead of the inner thoughts and angst.

This had a very decent premise, but I have to admit, I didn't really care for either the hero or the heroine.  As the author writes that she loves classic romance such as Judith McNaught and Julie Garwood, you can truly see the influence of the typical damsel in distress romance with a slow building love between the two characters.  What took away from that is that the hero is a tyrannical dumba$$ and the heroine, who was the leader of her people, is a helpless twit who only dreams of love and has no business leading people.  These characters really needed some depth and a demonstration of logical thinking for me to truly enjoy it.Under the tyranny of a wannabe Warlord, Thenl, a planet falls to war and strife under the leadership of a murderer and betrayer.  Three years ago, Thenl betrayed the true Overlord, Vaan and poisoned Vaan and his 15 most trusted warriors. Vaan's mother learns of the plot and manages to switch the poison to a sleeping draught.  With the warriors safely tucked away in a cave, Vaan's mother dies before she can revive them and three years later, Mikayla, ruler of her people, has come under the scrutiny of Thenl.  To save her people she knows she must find the warriors and revive them to keep her safe.  Once revived, one of them is honor bound to mate with Mikayla and unbeknownst to her at first, she chooses Vaan.All in all the premise is interesting, and the writing is good, but right from the start, Vaan is just not smart.  He's wary Mikayla wants to hurt him and his men..... hmmm, she revived them from a three year sleep.  If she wanted to hurt them, she could have done it while they were sleeping!  Regardless, Vaan is attracted to Mikayla and believes they will make many children together and proceeds to mate with his wife, but apparently his cultural belief is for a woman to simply lie still while he takes his pleasure and rolls over to fall asleep.  Mikayla is very sensual and teaches Vaan about intimacy, but somewhere along the lines, the author forgot Mikayla was actually a ruler and she essentially becomes a witless piece of fluff who rushes into danger and causes distractions everywhere she goes.  I wasn't happy with the turn of events.  Eventually, many of the characters grow on you, but it could have been better if the lead characters showed a modicum of intelligence, but at the end, I likely won't continue with the series.

Gerogette St. Clair is an auto read for me.  She turns books out quickly and every single one of them is wrought with humor, tension and romance.  Although a fairly easy and slightly predictable story overall, Ms. St Clair manages to keep this story engaging with a few twists and turns that I was not expecting but enjoyed all the more.  Technically a second story in a series, you can easily read it as a standalone, but the first book is so good too, why wouldn't you read that too?Karen Padfoot is a struggling lynx shifter who's had to raise her younger brother and sister in a world where the name Padfoot is lower than dirt.  Her father is a drunk and a thief and is getting into scrape after scrape where Karen is constantly bailing him out of trouble.  In spite of her no good father, she's put herself through law school, but can't get a job with the reputable shifter firm so starts her own practice.  Ty Battle is a wolf shifter Alpha and he's had the hots for Karen since they were in highschool, but due to his philandering ways, he always misses his opportunity with Karen.  When the Battle family catches her father stealing from them, Ty sees this as the perfect leverage to finally get Karen in his clutches.This is another story where I find the main characters suffering a bit for the development of side characters, but that development is so wonderful, I didn't really mind.  Although there are a few crossovers from book 1, it truly is a standalone read that's fast paced, engaging, sexy, and simple.  In general, this is a short and sweet story that clearly leaves the series open for much more interesting stories with fairly ominous danger around the corner.  Ms. St. Clair's wit, sense of humor and sensuality makes any story a good one and I'm sure this story sets up for many entertaining stories to come.

A happy day is the day SE Smith releases a new story.  I am never disappointed reading her books and overall, her books generaly get a five star rating.  As much as I enjoyed this latest release, it is true that a certain spark was missing. With a Touch of Frost, we get a truly unique story that ultimately comes down to Aliens vs. Paranormal.  I never would have dreamed up such a universe but there you have it.  I devoured the book in one sitting, but at the end, I have to admit that the characters were not flushed out and developed as well as her other stories.  We have a little back story on some of the people, but not enough for you to feel invested in their well being.Frost is an intergalactic law enforcer who must track down a truly evil alien creature, Taar, who has escaped to the primitive world called Earth.  His mission this go around is to kill Taar and return with the inhabitants of the planet none the wiser, but when Frost tracks Taar down in a place called Magic, New Mexico, both Taar and Frost are in for a total shock when they meet a beautiful young woman named Lacey.  Magic, is a place where there's, well, magic.  Witches, werewolves, vampires, ghosts, trolls, shapeshifters and every other creature call Magic home and it's a place where the unique and special can be left alone.  So when the showdown of Alien vs Paranormal come to a head, Aliens have got nothing on these creatures!One thing that was special about the book is that you have no idea where it's going.  There are so many twists and turns, with danger around every corner you have no clue where the story is going to take you.  When you think the danger is over, more comes at you.  The love story between Frost and Lacey comes much too quickly and there wasn't enough time for you to feel the spark between the main characters, but we clearly sacrifice depth with the protagonists due to the development of many side characters who made up for it.  As many first books go, this lays the foundation for wonderful future installments, but was spread to thin for it to be a home run as a standalone.  This is still an engaging story, but not the best work down by this author.  Still, I will read anything she has to write.

This is the perfect little spongeholder and is designed to easily clean based on the fact that most water has a lot of muck that builds up over time.  There are two slots for holding sponges and although the holder is metal, it has slits in the bottom for the water to drain into a plastic bottom.  The stainless steel does acquire a rusty buildup but it cleans off easily.  I also like the clear plastic bottom since it pops apart and is easy to detect dirt as well as easy to clean. Overall, it's a tasteful holder for sponges that doesn't look all cluttered on the coutertop next to the sink.

When I got these, I thought for some reason that they were border covers, but they only cover the side rails of the crib.  My particular crib has slats on the side so you can only velcro together at certain intervals but it does seem to do the job.  The cotton is extremely soft and although slightly slippery, the covers do not slip around as much as you might think.  Overall, I would have liked to have seen a little extra padding for protection in case my Godson hit his head on the rail.  It's a quality product, but not extraordinary and it appears to provide more protection for the crib from scratching than it does for the baby.

I've been waiting five years for this story and as Melanthe describes her own love story, it is indeed, EPIC.  This story was certainly different in that it was sweeping novel of trials and tribulations for Melanthe and Thronos to come together, but at the end of it all, I actually thought it was slightly dragged out and slightly anticlimactic at the end.  It took me longer to read this story than any of her others because at times it was almost on a repeat mode of Melanthe and Thronos about to get together, interruption, fight some peril, and then the same loop over and over again.  At one point, I was really thinking, enough already!  That being said, it was still a really good story with action around every corner and a love for the ages.Sorceress Melanthe has known her intended mate since she was a small girl, except that her mate is a vrekener and sworn enemy to the sorceri.  They had a secret friendship as children and but one night when she's 11 years old, the vrekener attack her family, killing her parents and sister.  Melanthe, a powerful sorceress at a young age, wills her sister to live and thralls her future mate to jump out a window to fall to his doom, except the extrodinairy happens and he doesn't die.  Ever since that moment, they became the enemies they were meant to be and 500 years later, Thronos finally captures Melanthe to exact his revenge.The journey and quality couple time is fantastic if not a bit drawn out.  In the beginning, the two have nothing but insults to sling at one another but over time and through much turmoil, they learn to work together and build trust with one another.  Like many bad romances, there is no switch that's flipped where they're instantly in love, but at the same time, when you realize these two truly belong together, it gets delayed over and over again.  On the downside, neither character is particularly likeable.  I especially didn't care for Melanthe, although I've found her to be dazzling in Sabine's story, when you break down her past, quite frankly, she should be a little ashamed getting her powers stolen over and over again.What truly makes the book memorable are side stories with Nix and finally..... Furie!!  This story trumps the Dacians and Macrieve by a mile, but it still isn't in the leagues of Mariketa and Bowen or any of her earlier works if I think on it.  The series is still going strong and I certainly look forward to future installments.

In paranormal romance, some authors know how to write sexy love scenes and some know how to write an engaging story, but Emma Holly, consistently, does both and that is certainly the case with this new and unique series about the Djinn.  The down and dirty is that this reads like a smoking hot fairy tale that is as engaging as any Disney quest but with graphic smexiness rolled into one.  One of Ms. Holly's strengths is that she knows how to write extremely likable and unforgettable characters and when the story is over, regrettably, you move on to the next set of characters who are also likeable so you get over it quickly, but I've always wanted to read more about the same characters, being the serial addict that I am.  It looks like this go around, I'm getting a happy compromise since this series surrounds, what I believe will likely be four main storylines that all interweave together so we don't quite have to say goodbye to the happy couples.Book 1, The Guardian, focuses on Djinni Arcadius, commander of his great city, who, with his trusted servant and magician Joseph, has come to modern day New York to help save his homeland.  He and Jospeh barely escape their plight and now need to find a way home to overtake a great and powerful sorceress.  His instincts bring him to a lonely for rent brownstone where he meets landlady, Elyse Soloman.  Elyse is still grieving the loss of both her husband and father under tragic and suspicious circumstances, but when she meets these two men, something about them compels her to help them.  From there, we are swept away in a fantastical tale with danger around every corner and literal magic carpet rides.  Although entirely out of her element,Elyse is a believable, brave and smart heroine.  No too stupid to live moments here.  She's in danger and she does what needs to be done to keep her and her friends safe.  Arcadius is intense, honorable and fierce when it comes to protecting what he loves.  And then there's Joseph, who simply steals your heart and although you're wrapped up in the beauty of Elyse and Arcadius, he's never far from your thoughts and all you want is his happily ever after.For those of you looking for instant gratification, there's no ending for this book.  It is definitely to be continued, but it leaves you satisfied and looking forward to the next installment.  Although I'd be more than happy to pick up where we left off with Arcadius and Elyse, being titled the Guardian, I have a sneaking suspicion that Arcadius and Elyse's story will go to the back burner so that we may learn more about the artist, the magician and the sultan.  Regardless, the story is simply magical, with love, laughter, heartbreak, and peril throughout.

I'm not sure there are the right words to describe how fantastic this 7th installment to the series is.  It's what you expected, what you didn't expect and completely mixed with laugh, love and heartbreak around every corner.  Congratulations to team Ilona Andrews on their first Hardcover story, they knocked it out of the park.  For anyone still buying the paper format, this is worth the price in any format and leaves you wanting more, more and more.  For those of you who have never read the series, you can actually pick this book up and read it.  It won't have the full impact us fans have from the building to this moment, but this book comes with a introduction to the series as well as a glossary of characters that is done extremely well.In terms of a book synopsis, all you need to know is Roland has arrived.  Enough said there.  It actually goes down in a way I had expected, but the action, twists and turns on the journey getting there was an absolute thrill ride.  Hugh continues to be one of the most delicious villains I've ever read and his chemistry with Kate is absolutely off the charts.  The quality Ghastek time in this book was filled with laughter and poignancy.  Derek and Ascanio had some great scene stealing moments together that left me grinning hours later. And most importantly, Kate and Curran remain an insititution where, individually, they are a force to be reckoned with, but together are unstoppable.  Kate's magic breaks through in a way we've never seen before and we find many answers to lingering questions throughout the series.  There's also the untimely death of something very dear to Kate that I hadn't realized became a character unto it's own.Overall, Magic Breaks raises the depth of the characters to a new level and you can see how much Kate and Curran have matured.  Once you get into the second chapter, it's a complete roller coaster ride that has you gripped one moment and then lets you relax another.  The ending is what is most surprising and I'm dying with curiosity to see how this series continues with the new dynamics.  I know the authors have at least three more books planned, but this series could go on for ages and I, for one, hope it does.  Seven books and counting have proven this is the best series in Urban Fantasy.

I've been hooked on this series ever since the first, even with the repetition and the constant reminders that Gin Blanco is the bad$$ Spider.  For those of you who have read the series, you know what I mean.  Even when I think it's a good time to break away, I simply can't.  As a series overall, it's just that good and I've grown to love the characters.  If you haven't read the series before, this is not the best book to pick up.  It's not that you won't understand what's going on since there's always some back story to help you catch up, it's just that this installment is not the best to get a sense of how special these characters are.In this installment, Gin matches against the local vampire drug lord, Beauregard Benson, who has a special air elemental talent and is not only extremely dangerous, but an immediate threat to Gin's sister, Bria.  Although the story is action packed and Gin comes out for the first time ever as a true player in Ashland's community, there's someone lurking around every corner throughout the whole story who you know is the real threat.  That being said, although entertaining, this installment is really a filler for the next installment, The Black Widow which promises to be as good as the first books.In terms of character dynamics, all the usual suspects make an appearance, but there was something bland about their roles.  Bria is uncharacteristically crazy, Owen was just there and there was no spark between him and Gin, and even Finn was a shell of himself taking a back seat to the family drama.  The ending comes with a not so surprise, but it's still good enough to get you pumped for the next one and I thank Ms. Estep that she writes more than one of these installments each year.  I am looking forward to the next, but this 11th book did not have me in its grip like they usually do.

This was a Fourth of July blast!  Great price on Amazon and very easy to use.  Kids and adults of all ages were on equal footing battling it out with the easy pump action and the accuracy was fantastic with a good amount of water shooting with each pump.  There's so many to choose from but I'd recommend these in a heartbeat.

I'm completely in love with the Kate Daniel series and to a lesser extent, the edge series.  I was thrilled to see Burn for Me as an Amazon vine selection and couldn't wait to read it.  I had no expectations going into it and had no clue what it was about, except that it was a romance with magical elements.  So with that in mind, this was completely unexpected to me.  I'll start by saying that this is not a romance so if you've never read Ilona Andrews before, this could throw you for a loop.  It may likely get there the way Kate and Curran got there in their other series, but after one book, I could take them or leave them as a couple.  Secondly, this is a series that focuses on the same characters, but with equal billing.  I had assumed it was a new universe with a new couple featured in each book like the Edge, but that's not the case.  Nor is it about a girl who ultimately builds a network around her.  With the Hidden Legacy series, the two main characters are introduced separately and eventually meet and that's not until you're almost 100 pages in and the meeting is a lot of things, but romantic certainly isn't one of them.  So romance?  Not yet, but it certainly looks promising. For now, I'd categorize it as straight action packed urban fantasy set in modern day Houston.  If you're looking for some hardcore smex, you won't find it here since it will likely build out over an unknown amount of books.With that out of the way, as always, Ilona Andrews is completely engaging, intelligent, witty and fast paced so fans won't be disappointed.  Nevada Baylor is a caring, intelligent, compassionate and talented young woman who is trying to keep her family afloat.  Connor "Mad" Rogan is an enigmatic, sensual, unrepetant rogue who we've yet to touch the surface of in terms of all he represents.  It's not perfectly clear who the bad guys are yet, but they're there and they're really bad and the world building is once again, unique, well thought out and well developed.  Although the book does wrap up the main storyline, there's something about this book in particular that leaves me wanting... something that makes it more obvious than usual that this is to be continued and you'll just have to wait.  Since there is an excerpt for the next book already, I hope these are released alot sooner than one year in between.  I'm not sure it would carry the time distance between books as well as Kate Daniels does.

It's not easy finding shower chairs that have back support and when you do, they're usually over $100.00.
