I recently purchased one such chair for my mom and it was over 2ft long and pretty much takes up most of the shower space.  When I received this Moen chair, I was thrilled.  The chair comes in 6 pieces, 4 legs, the seat and the back and snaps into place in less than a minute.  It's very sturdy, has about an 18" seat size and doesn't take up the whole shower.  The legs screw to adjust the height and it has a niche on each side of the chair to place a handheld shower head.  The only thing that is a little tricky for my mom is that the seat curves upwards making it a little awkward trying to get out of the chair.  I noticed that they have a version that has handles on the side to help you stand up and that would have been the ideal chair overall.  Still, this is a great value, the perfect size and ensures my mom will not tumble over the back while showering.

This bright white fondant is easy to work with. The 1.5-pound size is perfect for covering and decorating one 8" cake. The fondant can be colored (preferably with gel food colors), cut, and dried to make the stand-up decorations you see on the packaging.This fondant has a much better taste and creamier appearance than the Wilton brand. As such, I would recommend it to beginners.My only complaint is that the packaging box was beat up and open when it arrived. Thankfully, the fondant was well secured in air-tight plastic packaging within the cardboard box. I would recommend the manufacturer switch to the standard plastic tubs most decorators prefer for fondant.

This book is adorable and educational! My daughter is in second grade, and she just loved this book on sight. After reading it, she asked for more of the Larry Gets Lost series.As a parent, what I liked is that the book has multiple levels of reading built into it. For the early readers, there is the rhyming story verses about Larry. For the higher level readers, there is the information about the ocean (ocean layers, vocabulary, and plant life). For teachers, there is page in the back with Group Discussion ideas, Independent Activities, Group Activity, and a teacher's guide that can be downloaded from the Sasquatch Books website.The illustrations are vivid, bright, and inviting. This book is a friendly winner!

This card game is suitable for elementary school ages and up.The play of the game is straight forward: each player receives Guest cards and Dessert cards. The objective of the game is to match guests with a dessert they don't object to. It's a game about fussy eaters and their preferences.My daughters are in second and fifth grade, and they played three hands of the game before they got bored with it.

This bulk pack of scissors is great for schools, preschools, and even church classes. The scissors are all the same green color.While the package says they are pointed tips, they are not a triangular point. They have a soft point, more in between a point and a true rounded tip.I found a little bit of a hitch in the action of the scissors, meaning that they are a little sticky when opening and closing them. If your kids have a hard time opening and closing them, you may need to apply something to them like WD-40 to get them moving easier.My daughters are in fifth grade and second grade, and they found the handles a little small. While the package says ages "6+" I think that kids older than first grade may have issues with the handle sizing.

My daughter is in fifth grade, and an avid Percy Jackson fan. She was thrilled to get the chance to help me review this book for Vine.This is the second book in the Tombquest series. I like that they combine the familiarity of the Harry Potter books (the setting is London), with the upper elementary/middle school vocabulary and plots.The tombquest.scholastic.com website also has a Tombquest game that kids can play, which adds another dimension to this world.

These Crayola coloring pages are used the Crayola Color Alive app (free, downloadable app from the App Store). The set comes with the coloring book, Crayola crayons, a special effects crayon, and you download the free app.To get started, your child colors in the sheets using the included crayons. Once they are finished coloring, then they use the app to scan the special effects crayon (take a picture). After scanning their crayon, then they take a second picture of the colored design. The app then pops up a 3D image of their colored Barbie that moves. The Barbie walks like a model, and tosses her hair. My children wished it was slightly more interactive and would talk. The 3D image appears against the backdrop of wherever you took the picture (your house, the car, whatever is behind the picture). That was fun for my girls, they liked that Barbie was in "their" house.

This tiny drive has a whole lot of space - 32 GB! This is the perfect size to take movies along on a business trip, or cram in a whole lot of graphic-dense files. Even the heaviest of business users will appreciate this drive.USB 3.0 was the right technical choice, you really need a speed boost for this much storage.Very satisfied!

My daughter is in second grade, and she really enjoyed this Equestria Girls My Little Pony doll. She watches all of the My Little Pony cartoons, so she was thrilled to have a chance to get her hands on this doll. This doll series is an intermediate toy for the girls that are too old for Little People, but too young for the Monster High and Ever After High series.This is a sleepover-themed doll, so she comes with pajama tops and bottoms, a sleeping mask, and slipper-like boots. Her pet comes with a sleeping cap (which also fits on the doll). All of the clothes and shoes are removable.The only thing we did not like about the doll is that she cannot stand on her own. Her top-heavy design and jointed legs make it impossible for her to stand upright without some kind of support. The Ever After High dolls include a stand to remediate this problem, and I would suggest the same for this doll.

This enormous bag of miniature Reese's Peanut Butter cups has 43 servings of five pieces, for a total of 215 individually wrapped candies. This is the right size for bulk use: holiday baking, goodie bags, parties and more. Gigantic!

These pencils are a fun twist on the ordinary. My daughters are both in elementary school and really liked the surprise factor of the colored wood inside the brightly-colored exteriors.The pencils sharpened neatly, and there were no issues with the lead breaking or being soft.A standard pencil with a touch of color. This is a nice change of pace.

Butlers stories are crafted in such a way that I felt like many parts of them happened to him.  Recurrent scenes of abandoned children, evil lurking in otherwise normal small towns, alcoholism and it's results. There are nightmarish scenes and sweet ones too. This is raw stuff and some run a bit long for my tastes and could use some chopping. The set ends nicely on an up-note with Apples, easily the "nicest" story of the bunch, but for my money the most interesting story was Western Counties because of the revenge factor. Evil doesn't always win.Synopsis:Chainsaw Soiree:  Lust, greed, envy and rural types mix in what could only be described as bachannal meets annual firewood gathering. Yes, there are chainsaws mixed in. Run away, run away fast!Rainwater: A grandfather and boy experience's in a slice of life wherein the boy's mother is not present and may never be again.Sven and Lily: Two buddies, one is the other's caretaker in bar situations when the other almost crosses a line into adultery.Morels: (play on the word morals) Three old buddies get away with a horrible crime during a dark, drunken, pot-fueled mushroom gathering weekend.Leftovers: A man and his wife clean up the rest of his dead mother's house. The man's breakthrough: realizing he loves his wife but he can easily live without her.Beneath the bonfire: A woman almost meets her end during an eerie nighttime, winter scuba dive. Her boyfriend is a vet who finally finds love but she misreads his actions and freaks out.Sweet Light Crude: Old guy goes off the deep end over an oil spill, kidnaps an oil executive with bad results. Tasty!Western Counties: Abusive, psycho "fighting dog" owner slithers into town and corrupts everyone - almost. Lady cop to the rescue!Train People Move Slow: Alcoholic skank with two kids takes advantage of nice guy, moves in, then abandons them all. That's a happy ending.Apples: Late middle-aged man loses job and finds sweeter things in store working on his own.

My nephew is a medium-size 11 year old kid. He tried this on and it seemed like the sleeves were too short and the shoulders were too narrow. It looked really tight on him. The fabric is OK, but doesn't breathe very well. The tag was almost impossible to get off of the button without using a pocket knife. All in all, not a good shirt for anyone here in my family circle. I'd get this if your boys are extremely small and don't mind fabric that does not breathe very well. Three stars.

Pristine white, soft, luxuriant feeling (Really, in polyester? Yes!) this is a standard sized shower curtain. As others have stated, it needs a liner and paired with my clear, frosted liner and clear shower curtain rings, this looks very elegant in my white bathroom. I already was going for a total white look anyway and this fits the ticket very well.I got it out of the package and there were some very strong fold marks in it, so I tossed it in the dryer for 20 minutes and they disappeared, much as I expected they would. It hangs beautifully, no odd angles or flaws. It's about an inch shorter than my older outer curtain, but It's not that noticeable.What I like:  The feel is nice, very soft like cotton.  The color is a pure white-white, not a blue-white or yellow white.  The curtain has two magnets at the bottom corners to help keep it in place. It was extremely easy to hang. The waffle-weave puts an interesting texture in the bath where most of the surfaces are either porcelain or shiny tile.What I don't like: NOTHING. I can't find a thing wrong with this.Five stars, highly recommended.

These are high-quality CZ earrings with a very nice, clean mounting of rhodium-plated sterling silver. The stones are quite large, clear and very good quality for CZ, no flaws on the surfaces from what I could see with my loop. The bezel is very deep and nearly without flaws, although one of this set had a small pit in the very bottom, positioned well as it's doubtful anyone would see it. The connection between the top and the dangle is strong as are the posts. I found the posts to be somewhat long, but if you wanted to go to the trouble, a jeweler could shorten them and re-crimp them for the clasps. They feel heavy and important for a set of earrings of this size and any woman would be please to wear them in place of something far more expensive.All in all this is a beautiful set of earrings and seemingly of high quality for the current price. Four stars, highly recommended for those with high taste suffering under a low budget.

Got this a couple days ago, took it to a friend's pool today to test it out and had fun splashing around and diving. A caveat is needed here, I've never owned snorkel equipment before so I may not be using the right terminology, but it's not rocket science after all.Breathing tube: My breathing tube portion worked fine, did not leak at all.  It held up when I went down to the bottom of the pool, only let air out, did not let water in. Did not taste odd at all. No problems.Mask: The mask felt good and tight when I put it on, but as I got wetter and wetter, it seemed to get more loose. It fit my face well, except around the nose, seemed loose there no matter what and tightening it did not help. A friend tried it on and it didn't fit his face at all, was way too small and he had a lot of leaks. I think this mask was designed for thinner faces or smaller faces, not big or flat faced skulls (and no offense intended, humans come in a lot of different sizes and shapes). The glass in the goggles is great, stayed clear and did not distort images at all.  Stayed tight in a dive, no fall-offs. The plastic is very comfortable, not rough or hard.The colors are nice, helps to find them in a mix of gear. I also like the carrying case which makes a nice travel pouch for these so they're not flopping around loose in your vehicle or your luggage.I think there needs to be some more design done, this mask may be problematic for some people.

When I'm in the mood to be a little nutty, these pistachio nuts are the perfect answer. While these don't hit the sweet spot that salted nuts do, they're still good and the salt isn't good for me anyway. I am going to save half this bag and add them to my banana bread as I know they'll be great in that. I just sat here and ate half the bag without stopping, so next time I'm getting the larger size. A few of these had that "not quite right" flavor that you always get with a few of every batch of ANY nut you eat, so I'm not going to hold that against Diamond. It's part of the package deal with nuts, you know there's going to be at least one of those. Otherwise, I'm sure these would be great in recipes (too hot to bake right now) and I look forward to using them and eating them just right out of the bag. You'd be nuts not to like these nuts. Five stars.

Making firewood is something that takes up much of my time in the late summer and entire fall. I've used axes, mauls and hatchets of all kinds over the last 30 years of wood stove ownership. I've never owned a throwing tomahawk and have never thrown a hatchet. However, I lost my hatchet last fall and decided to choose this one to replace it.Not only is this tool beautiful, it's incredibly sharp and very well balanced. The end opposite the blade is handy as well for sticking into the end of a small log and splitting it for kindling. The handle seems very sturdy and has a good grip that fits in my hand. I also like the handy case it came in that I'll be able to wear on my belt while using the chain saw. I've already used this to clear off logs of small branches and it whittles them off easily. So far, it's held up nicely with no looseness at all.A very beautifully-designed tool that not only looks stunning but is one I'm sure I'll enjoy using for a long time.

We love this range. There's something about the style, the ease of cleaning and the overall operation of this range that feels almost retro and more solid than any gas range I've owned. There are zero electronic panels, which I love because we live in a wooded, rural area and there are tons of power outages here which mess up ANY computerized panels and eventually kill them. This is very basic, electric starters for the burners and a standard "glow coil" for the oven. The entire thing is a joy to clean, no crevices and odd places that don't allow for easy cleaning. I don't know who designed this thing but it's a shame that GE has discontinued it's Artistry series. The only thing I'm taking away a star for is the clock. Two things about it seem a little off. The finish is chrome, but the handles and other accents are brushed steel, so it doesn't really match well. And the other, (which many other reviews elsewhere state) is how loud the clock is. It doesn't bother me and actually I've grown used to it, but there is a slight, low "grinding" noise that comes from it which sounds a little like tiny gears are grinding away which might get on the nerves of some people. Where I live is totally noise-free so it seems louder on a quiet day than normal. The white color has a blue cast to it, which doesn't necessarily match today's white cabinet styles well, so be sure and keep that in mind if you are doing a "white kitchen" look. It's a bit whiter/bluish look, the standard appliance white instead of cream.

I've been running this air cleaner for about 4 days now and it has really made a big difference. I have both a pollen and dust problem here as I'm surrounded by trees and flowers and there is a lot of construction in the area, forcing me to keep the windows closed most of the time. I'm running it in the bedroom so I can sleep better at night. It doesn't heat up the air that much, which is good and it's really fairly quiet on the lowest setting. I normally wake up and cough about 3 times a night, the last two nights I've slept almost all the way through.Very easy to operate, just pop open the grill, put in the charcoal filters on top of the ones in place, shut and turn on. I run the high setting during the day and the lowest setting at night. I'm still checking out a set of new filters to buy for this because I know they'll be hard to find, but they always are for these things.It's sort of confusing as there is feet on two sides, so when looking at the instructions, just pay attention to the visuals. Not sure why they designed it like that as it's about the same height as it is deep. Otherwise this is a good product and hopefully the filters won't cost too much.  Four stars, recommended.

Valerie Martin's stories are interesting and there are a few in this collection that are interesting and good reads. However, I found the bulk of them to be somewhat unfulfilling in that the endings or plot summaries seemed unfinished or perhaps the author could not resolve things artfully.Back in my heyday we had a line that we'd say to wrap up a story: "They all became strippers and died."  In many cases, the author seemed to end her works in this way as if she were bored with the story and wanted to move on. This happens, that happens and BOOM, the end. These are not short stories in many cases, they are ideas and concepts which could easily become novels. Some border on science fiction or fantasy, others could be classified as literature. Some are far too long and could be easily chopped in half.I found the title story to be a little odd, written in a different style and ironically did not seem to fit with the rest. The best story by far was "His Blue Period" as it felt the most real for me. The worst was "The Unfinished Novel" which weaved to and fro until it's incredibly unsatisfying ending: we never get even a glimpse of the novel in question and it is literally buried. ( I'd sure have written a different ending for that one!)Don't get me wrong, it's quality writing and that kept me in the game. I never had the urge to walk away from her works, but overall felt like this is an author who is emerging (though I know this isn't the case), still honing not her writing skills, but her story creation skills. The concepts were 50/50 for me, I liked about half of these.Three generous stars.

There are office chairs for being comfy and semi-lounging at work and there are office chairs which seem to say "Back to work!" and command you to sit up. The basyx chair does the latter and is aptly named a "task chair".  The chair is easy to put together, it took me about 15 minutes. The directions are visuals only, zero written instructions, but if you can count the holes on the seat and deduce from them which screws go where (4 small for the center mount, 6 medium for the arms, and 4 long for the back) you will do fine. Once it was together, I rolled it into my office and am now sitting in front of this very review screen while using it. The vertically adjustable arms are stiffly padded, there's some give to them. The back is straight and somewhat severe, it's going to teach me good posture whether I like it or not. There is an adjustable lumbar insert behind the mesh back which helps the lower back. And you can adjust the height, but for my small frame, the lowest it can go is good. There's a knob which supposedly increases or decreases the tilt flexibility, but I didn't notice anything either way.The seat padding is what I have the most problem with, due to a hip injury I'm very sensitive about seats. I had to put my gel pillow down, even with the lack of "bucket" shape in the seat (which is not good for me anyway) because the seat is cushioned but extremely firm, my weight hardly puts a dent in it.It's a solid chair, but not for maximum comfort. Three stars for great posture in the back, 2 taken away for lack of tilt and lack of rear comfort in the seat.

Not being a regular tea-drinker, I do, however, enjoy a cup of tea in the afternoon when one's energy levels occasionally start to flag and thoughts of afternoon siestas begin to taunt one's periphery. I normally reach for my favorite, Constant Comment, which I find to be a superior representative of the black teas that are available on the grocer's shelf. From my perspective, Taylors of Harrogate Yorkshire Tea is a distant third from my favorite, with - astoundingly - Lipton's standard tea being second in line, which I'm sure many will find rather pedestrian or of low character.Upon awakening this morning, I reached for the kettle and brewed a cup with boiling water for the requisite 5 minutes (my normal steep time). Upon tasting without any additives, felt that it was somewhat bland. I re-inserted the now-sodden bag and heated it up again in the microwave on high for an additional 3 minutes and found that it had a much richer flavor. I also must admit that the flavor changed slightly once it cooled down a bit as it became less sharp and more mellow. This mellowness was heightened further once I added my normal stevia and vanilla soy milk. It is, admittedly, a passable cup of tea in a pinch. However, for my tastes, I'd rather drink my favorite. It seems richer and a bit more exotic than this one, with a few slight notes of orange and spice.Naturally, there are those who would have differing opinions, but tea and coffee are such personal drinks, it's hard to get a solid consensus on these things. Hopefully, I will not be looked at with low regard for my confessions, having a somewhat limited exposure to the world of teas and much less than those well-traveled sorts who I'm sure could offer a well-educated treatise on the various qualities of many teas which I may have never had the pleasure of meeting. Even so, I am tasked with offering my simple, well-worded opinion here and in doing so hope that it is received with open minds and hearts, which is the same manner by which I have elucidated and revealed my thoughts on this lovely product.

I've never owned a piece of exercise equipment before this because I'm physically active most of the time (gardening, construction, lawn care, ect), but I decided to choose this item due to winter and lack of activity which is impacting my waistline a bit more every year.The box arrived while I was gone and it took every ounce of strength I have to get it into the garage. I had a friend help me get the main piece out of the box and then between the two of us reading the instructions and figuring things out, about 2 hours later (with long breaks) we had the unit together. It's not that hard to do, just a little tedious. The main thing (which they stress in the manual) is to be careful to not get any of the wires caught while fastening various parts onto the main unit. (Make sure you build this thing near where you're going to leave it, we nearly died getting it down into my basement!)I've used this about 5 times since it arrived last week and still have yet to get the hang of the programming, but I think it will get easier with time. It probably helps to have some past experience with an indoor cycle or have a friend that has that experience to help you. After adjusting the unit to fit my small frame, it works better for me. I like the instant brake very much. Standing while spinning is about the hardest part, it's not exactly like a real bike as the unit does not dip to the sides like a real bike, your body is forced to work harder. I guess that's a good thing. It's very quiet, you could easily listen to music or a TV while doing your workout. I've also used it without any programming at all and I think I like that the best, just doing a 30-minute ride/workout and once my heart rate slows back down, it's off to the shower. Probably not what a purist would do, but like I said, I'm new at this. I'll read up on the manual some more and try to make sense of the programs through time.  The seat is the biggest hurdle for me as I have a very flat cushioned seat on my actual bicycle, so I might try to get another seat for this unit to make it more comfortable for me. I had a hip injury and the seat that comes with the unit seems to make it flare up and ache.I'd recommend this cycle, it seems like a very solid piece of equipment which will serve well for a nice aerobic workout in the winters. The rest of the year I'm extremely active, so I may not use it as much until cold weather comes. Four stars.

While it may seem a bit odd that a man would want to choose a moisturizer such as this one, please let me explain. First, I have a few areas which get extremely dry and I work in ceramics which are very drying to my hands. As well, I'm a sucker for anything that has a citrus or orange blossom smell, so this product intrigued me.Scent: If you've ever been lucky enough to walk through an orange grove while they're blooming, this cream will take you right back to that moment. It's not heavy or cloying, but you'll find yourself sniffing your hand over and over once you apply some of this. While it might smell a bit on the feminine side for a guy, I don't care. I'm already addicted to the scent! I can imagine if this were re-formulated to have a bit of patchouli, bergamot and lavender added, it could be made to smell more masculine, still have the same orange blossom effect and be marketed toward men.Texture: This is almost like a butter. It seems thick at first, but as you apply it, it melts onto your skin and blends right in. Afterwards, it's not oily at all, just a nice even moist feeling.Effects: I tested this on my knees, probably the most dry, scaly area on my body. Of course, any moisturizer is going to feel good for the first hour, but the next morning my knees are virtually as supple and moisturized as if I just applied this product. That has never happened with any product! I also put some around my eyes and my forehead and it has definitely reduced the appearance of the lines in those areas. I also felt pleasantly "refreshed" afterwards, for a few hours. Not sure if that is the scent or the cream itself, but it felt really nice.All in all, this seems to be a product that is very specialized and would attract a very high-end customer.  At the current price (5/30/15) of 46 dollars for 1.5 ounces, it probably does! For me, the only detraction is how expensive this is. For nearly half the price, one can purchase many moisturizers and get 4 times the amount in the container.  So for that reason, I deduct one star. Otherwise, highly recommended!

2 years ago, I built a 2-story house with dormers. One of them has a half-circle window transom over the regular window. On the back are two shed dormers which also have windows. Needless to say, even though these are great windows which I can tilt in to clean, there are two which are in the two dormers over a loft area. So, unless I learn to fly (hey, it could happen, right?) the only way to clean these windows (inside or out) is with a pole like this or a very tall ladder or both. I chose both.So far, this thing has performed really well. Combined with the squeegee tool, I can make my windows very clean very easily. I normally wait for a very wet rainy morning or a foggy one and then just go outside, squeegee off the two windows and that's it. I don't even scrub them. The house is in a very rural, isolated area, so there's not a lot of pollution, but I do get a lot of bug dookie on them, so when they're very wet, that's the time to clean them. As long as you keep it up on a bi-weekly basis, you should have fairly clean windows most of the year.  As well, it's handy to get spider webs from the lofted ceiling and I'm planning on using it to re-paint the ceiling as well. It's a great tool, very badly needed at my house. Highly recommend this product, zero problems so far.

I'll admit it, I have a weakness, almost a fetish for planners and calendars. I usually purchase a Sierra Club calendar for a custom leather binder I had made, but since this planner fits in almost the same way, I decided I'd try it.  I like many things about it.The cover and binding are very nice, very retro style, like an old textbook or novel with a cloth cover. The months are tabbed, very easy to find, lots of space to write in on each day and there's a full 2-page mini-month calendar at the beginning of each month to reference if need be. In the back there's 10 pages of "notes," two of which I think could have better served as a larger version of the holidays' dates which are listed on one page only in miniscule type so small I needed a magnifying glass to read it. Time zones/zip codes map as well. Nice if you need it.The page whiteness and opacity is really good, you can't see the next week or what's written on the back of the page at all. And there's a handy cloth ribbon bookmark to help keep your place.  I think it's worth the price listed currently (20.00) and I'd recommend this item to anyone needing a planner.

Having both a Rachel Ray and a Circulon set of cookware, I use a lot of plastic, rubber and other types of non-marring utensils. This is the first time I've been able to experience anything made with silicone and so far, it's a pleasure using the spatula and the pasta fork/grabber.  Just using even a hard plastic spoon on those surfaces makes me a bit nervous because I take a lot of time and trouble making sure the surfaces are never scratched, never washed in a dishwasher, never abused in any way. These tools are perfect.The first thing I noticed when I opened the package was the TOTAL lack of any kind of smell. Seriously, there was absolutely NO odor of any kind. That's a first for me, and I have a very sensitive nose. No plastic-y smell, no factory smell, no odd smells... nothing. Wow.Then handling these felt very comfortable, there is an inner portion that is hard over which the softer red silicone is molded. This gives the tools a firmness but also their non-damaging ways. The handles are nice, pierced so that they can hang and fit the hand well.  I did not have a pasta fork and so it's a welcome addition and makes getting a few noodles for "testing" very easy considering I had to use a standard fork in the past, risking a scratch on my cookware.For me, the color is a little dull, (not nearly as bright as what they show in the photos) and leans toward a burgandy or dark candy apple red, rather than a nice HOT red or vermillion which I would have preferred.All in all, this will easily be the "go to" set in my kitchen for all uses. Great set, good quality and a pretty reasonable price at this writing. Highly Recommended!

I don't use a cellphone for photos, but I do use my tripod quite extensively for lighting, photographs and more. This adapter/clamp is great for holding lights, gobos, reflectors, etc. for photography needs and I love how it's so small that it doesn't get in the way of anything. The little screw clamp is perfect and the clean design keeps it out of the way. It's tiny but powerful and my only worry is that it's so small that I might lose it in my... um...complex studio environment (read: cluttered). Fit perfectly with my adapter to the tripod I own and I imagine with that screw hole size, it's nearly universal. Great product that comes in at a slightly high price, but when you need something like this (and I did) you need it!  Highly recommended to all photo and video types, both pro and amateur.

I cannot commend the makers of this film high enough for bringing to light one of the most odious crimes of the century.When a man makes a trust and a will, he does so thinking that he can go to his grave and have his wishes carried out. These instruments of law, which are normally held inviolate and in perpetuity, are seemingly not worth the paper their written on any longer, thanks to one judge in Pennsylvania. To compound the horror of this act, the knowledge that it was tied to a 100-billion-dollar art collection that was amassed by one man - possibly the best collection of art that the world has ever seen - leaves those of us with much smaller means with a view of life that seems futile at best, given the forces of government, big money and power-hungry social mavens which might work against our own small plans.Dr. Barnes' is hopefully haunting these people's conscious on a nightly basis. May they never rest in peace in this life or the next one.

Reading short stories are one of my favorite pastimes. While I was enjoying reading each of this author's stories, I figured out something. Justin Taylor knows the craft of writing very well. Unfortunately, he does not understand what to write about or that good writing only gets you so far. In order to break into that next level, IMO, there needs to be a great story with a point, a message or something I can take away. A lot of these tales seemed like they were taken from life experiences but lacked any sort of lesson or poignancy. Snapshots of dreary lives, even in the case of an elderly woman (which in my opinion had the best chance to really tug some strings) just seemed like bland diary entries.One or two of these stories almost gets there and just when I thought the author is going to take it up a notch and make some kind of amazing breakthrough or statement...? The story ends. And I felt like there was no point to all that craft in the first place. It's like being told your going to get a cream-filled pastry only to find out that there's not really anything in the center.Cream, Mr. Taylor. I want cream in the middle of my pastry or at least a roach so there's some drama and something I can tell my friends about.Three stars for the good writing, 2 stars taken away for lack of a take-away.

Even though I don't own an RV, I'll have a hundred other uses for this great product. They can prop up my riding mower to clean the underside, level out a ladder while painting stairwells, prop up a car while changing a tire or working on the underside, especially on uneven ground.The design is great, these can make a ramp without shifting and the style of the carrying ability is pretty smart. They are heavy duty! You cannot bend these at all, even with a lot of weight on them. The lattice design means strength without weight. There are a lot of ways to stack them as well to fit just about any requirement where you need stability and strength while holding something up or leveling it for long periods of time. Recommended, four stars.

I can see these drapes working well in a rental suite or perhaps a vacation cottage where a finer set might get damaged. These are 100 percent poly, so they'll take washing fairly well (if they don't, I'll report back later.)  The design is nice, a somewhat "Morrocan" look (which is on-trend currently) that would work well in a lot of settings.  The white "see through" is a nice touch, and I can see these as stand-alone or working as sheers for a heavier set over top.  The only part I'm not pleased with on this set is the side edges which are not hemmed, but instead are using "selvage" from the original bolt as the edging. I may end up putting a rolled hem on the edge myself to help make them seem a bit higher quality.  A nice set of drapes for the guest bedroom, cottage or rental.  Three stars.

...and not as nice as the picture. The bracelet comes on and off easily, but for the money, the weight seems to be a bit light. As well, there is substantial pitting in the metal in places, meaning that either the mold was not very well made or the silver under the rhodium was not cast very well. It's an OK piece of jewelry, but not what I'd call "fine" jewelry by any standard.  The weave design is attractive and I can see this being a good cuff bracelet for a teenager that you wouldn't want to make responsible for a more extravagant piece until they're ready.  Three stars.

Short story volumes are usually a pleasure for me to read. Vasquez' collection was a bit more difficult. There are 6 long stories here (a 7th one is much shorter) and they wind over the course of 240 pages. I would not call these "short stories", they are closer to novelettes, but not quite there."The Return" is the shortest and ironically, easily the best of this collection. I could see this one being fleshed-out further into a novel. I was intrigued by it far more than the others. I'd rate each tale as follows:Hiding Places - 3 starsThe All Saints' Day Lovers - 4 starsThe Lodger - 2 starsThe Return - 5 starsAt the Cafe de la Republique- 2 starsThe Solitude of the Magician - 3 starsLife on Grimsey Island - 3 starsThe tone of this small collection is somewhat dark and brooding. I was not in a bright, cheery mood after reading these. I'm not saying that all things in literature should be bright and cheery, but a ray of sunshine would be nice once in a while during the dark clouds. It's as if the author is saying "Hey, have affairs, get mixed up in some sordid business if you want, but it's not going to be much fun and be prepared to pay the consequences."  There is death, suicide, depression, regret and more.Overall, it's great writing, but the content of the tales is my overall problem. Just not very happy stuff here, folks.  Three stars.

This is possibly the most un-intuitive software I've ever used.  It's appalling.  The remote playback is iffy, works sometimes, doesn't work other times. If you are expecting to watch your secured space remotely, you will have problems.  The camera's "live view" stays live for about 10 seconds. Then camera's go into freeze-frame.  Every. Single. Time.If you want to playback the alarm recorded sequences, you have to wait for 10 minutes for the system to load it's past footage. While it's doing that, prepare for your system to be held hostage, you cannot do ANYTHING else while it's loading.  And if you try to up the speed of playback, be warned that 4x speed is actual human speed (albeit a bit slower). Otherwise, everything is in slo-mo.  And 4x doesn't always work, it mostly just stops all action.  The icons and the way the entire scheme is set up is an obvious techie delight, but an end-user failure.  Even the guys that set our system up had trouble figuring out how to use it. And they handle this stuff every single day!The user manual is a joke, you need to print it out in order to use it.Cameras? Good.  System reliability?  Fine.  Recording all alarms?  Good.Software?  HORRIBLE.

Accented by a shiny, bright red handle, this ingenious umbrella collapses down to about 10 inches tall and closes easily. I was able to get the cover over it fairly quickly as well. Very sturdy build, not a flimsy, typical umbrella. I love the handle and the weight of it, very nicely stores in a car or closet. I think this will probably live in my car as I'm always getting caught in the rain. Just whip the cover off, press the button and "BOING", it opens up.  Plenty of room for two underneath of it and it's reflective to car lights as well for added safety. I truly can't find anything negative to say about this umbrella. It's a tad pricey (and most likely the high-end executive is the best customer), but worth it in my opinion. Five Stars for keeping me dry.

This is a very nice item from the standpoint of workability and installation. Batteries are already in place, just remove the tab, stick it on a metallic surface, the magnets hold it there.  You can have it on all the time or just with motion detection.I put mine under a door eave on the metal door itself on my patio area where it's protected from the rain and sun. It works well, VERY bright and lights up the entire back yard. Between it and the video system I have, the results are great: Any motion and the light goes on and any action is recorded immediately on my camera.The only negative I have about this is the aesthetics are not great. It isn't something that looks really nice once installed, the orange switch, the way the lights are arranged, just not a "good-looking" item in my opinion. I think if it were re-designed into a more attractive fixture, I'd give it four stars. But I imagine for utility areas and other non-living spaces it would do.

Put this seed out a week and a half ago on rocky / clay soil in a very shady area on a gentle slope. Raked the ground first, put in seed, raked gently afterwards and put in more on top of that. Used straw on top and then waited.The area had good rains the entire time after sowing.At this point, about half the seed has germinated and is filling in sparsely. It's not great soil, so I'm not expecting much, but once a couple more weeks pass, I'll fertilize it well and hopefully that will do the trick.I'm as pleased as one can be about the germination rate of this seed, this is not the best soil and it's about what I get any time I use shady seed on rocky soils. It takes fertilizer to make it take hold and get thicker, the years I don't, it usually dies out and I start all over. Looks good in the summer months and then the next spring it's gone. It's a difficult area to keep grass on, but I figured I'd try one more time.

It must be nice to be a publisher while also being a writer. Just think, you can publish ANYTHING you write. And therein lies the problem with "Muse", a protracted, long-winded, slow-moving story of an editor trying to solve an extremely boring mystery that involves a long-dead poet's coded notebooks. And be patient kids, it's laborious getting to the meat of this turkey unless you like eating feathers.It literally takes 80-some pages to wade, slog and drudge your way through backstory after backstory, premise after premise, stage-setting after stage-setting to get to ANY sense of a plot, story or action. You'd think a publisher would know better! While this masturbatory mess of mean-spirited missives-in-disguise might be fun to write and think about for Mr. Galassi, it's torturous for any reader other than himself.When you do finally get to the kernel of what passes for a story, it's weak at best. The writing? Passable. The editing? Abysmal.If it were up to me (and sadly, for the general public, it's not) I'd chop the first 78 pages off the book and start it there, on page 79. Then, I'd figure out a way to weave in the over-indulgence of backgrounds and the endless list of characters into the story, bit by bit, so the reader is not overwhelmed up front by all of these unnecessary people, histories and settings which have almost NOTHING to do with the actual story per se.If you are impatient by nature, skip this one. If you like a story to move at a pace slightly faster than glacial, skip this one. If you like a plot to have a bare minimum of interest or start, say, in the first 30 pages or so, skip this one. Oh, who am I trying to kid? Just skip this one at all costs.

Keeping all the benefits in mind that this paste supposedly affords the daily user, the one thing that stays with you more than any other effect is the taste. To be utterly frank, it tastes like minty industrial chemicals. Think Sani-Flush. All of the research and consumer testing that one would assume goes into a product such as this and yet... bad taste? It doesn't make sense. I'll continue to use it, perhaps mixed with a much better-tasting paste. However, I'm still somewhat perplexed as to why Colgate, a "multinational consumer products company focused on the production, distribution and provision of household, health care and personal products" (from Wikipedia) which has sold toothpaste since 1873 and was the first to sell it in a collapsible tube (!) would not take the time to perfect the taste, since one cannot possibly use the product without putting it in ones own mouth. And there, once in the mouth, the product treats you to a taste that is both minty and unpleasant, creating an oral paradox, nay, a mouthy mass of malfeasance.Three stars for unsubstantiated health benefits (seriously, how would I truly be able to tell?) and two taken away for taste. And if an oral product should do ANYTHING, it should taste good.

When you open a bottle of wine for yourself and friends (or just yourself, you selfish elf), invariably there is some slop going to happen. Especially if it's the 2nd or 3rd bottle. Ahem. Seasoned wine-drinkers will know what I'm talking about here: You open the bottle, you pour a glass and immediately one or two escapee drops of wine travel down the neck of the bottle to eventually rest on the bottom, leaving a ring of red (or white, if you're that sort) on the table or counter. And it happens with each pour. At the end of the evening, you're left with a series of rings, especially if you've given up on keeping neat. Leave it for the maid. After all, what are you paying her for?Metrokane has solved this pesky problem with their Wine Pourer/Stopper. The set of two is in a brushed silver and feature a lovely little clasping trigger that snaps closed if you want to - gods forbid - leave some in the bottle. Once they're closed, the bottle does not leak. Almost. I found that a few drops do escape until some sort of equilibrium is reached and then no more. It's curious but not a huge dilemma as there never seems to be a good reason to close the valve in my household. The stopper inserts nicely into the bottle, no leaks. And the best part of all: ZERO drippage after pouring.Not. One. Drop!A great little product, nicely priced, easy to use (with one caveat in the sealed wine department). Four stars, recommended by this tippler. And now I'm thinking of sacking the help.
Not the best, tends to float in leveler, make sure you anchor it down with some kind of adheasive, especially if you are using self-leveling pour.
A nice light, not too bluish or greenish, very neutral.
Light is rather cold, not as warm as I had hoped. Price is a bit high in my book.

A quirky, compelling tale about a boy who is raised as a bird in India and transitions into normalcy by being adopted and living in NY.  The story skips around a bit, we're not privy to his transition as much as the results of his getting his own apartment and meeting new people. A fairly well-written piece but somewhat dark. Some readers might be disturbed by the sex and violence, but they are not a large part of the story. One character, Silber, is a magician and while the tale does not center on him per se, I felt it detracted from the story in many places. The author weaves the 9/11 tragedy into the end of the story in a plausible way. It's a good read, but not a great one. I found myself skimming through the last three chapters. Three stars.

I don't know what Scott's is up to. Either they are shipping very old product and it's no longer viable or this seed simply doesn't germinate. Either way, I'm not getting ANY results at all.Prepped several areas in the yard where moles have been or I've pulled patches of weeds. I sprinkled this product in all the areas. Watered. Waited. And waited.Results?  Nothing.  Big waste of my time.One can see seeds out there, but they are not doing anything. My opinion is this is old seed that no longer is viable and is being shipped out to get rid of it.So, I'm off to the garden store to get good, old fashioned "pasture grass" seed that comes up every time I spread it. Scotts has lost this customer for life.1 star, zero stars if I could.

I had taken out some nursery trees in my yard to move them to a new location. This left a 10 x 20 foot area in my yard which I tilled, added some good top soil and then raked out even. Then I put a double coating of Scotts Turf Builder Grass Seed - Centipede Grass Seed and Mulch over the entire area, first coat I gently raked under about a quarter inch and then re-seeded again leaving the next coating on the top, using up the entire container to ensure a good, thick lawn area. I watered it well and waited for my nice new patch of grass to come up.It's been over a week now, we've had warm temperatures during the day and 3 - 4 good soaking rains.There is zero germination. Not one little green spike. Zilch. Nada. Nothing.I've been seeding lawns for many years, I know what I'm doing and usually you get something within 5 days or so. I have never had this happen before, where NOTHING comes up.One star, not recommended.

If you own a large dining table and like table linens, you know how difficult it is to find something that wears well, doesn't stain easily, won't shrink and - importantly - looks good.  This cloth is sewn well, all of the corners look neatly stitched and finished. The 100 percent polyester means it will not shrink or stain, great feature, but it doesn't feel like poly, has a very nice hand.The decorative weave between the white and the bisque border is a very nice touch, adds a little elegance to the look.The fabric is a bit thin for my tastes, so I would not call it "heavy construction" as the manufacturer does, but if you put another cloth under it, you will have a much better appearance for the white areas. On my table, (which is blond) the wood shows through a bit, so I'd imagine that on darker woods it might show even more.Other than that, for the price, it's a very nice table cloth that goes well with my dining room interiors of cream, white, silver, almond and bisque. They have a gray version as well which is a more modern twist to this cloth that I'm sure many would appreciate (myself included!).  Four stars.

A nice thin-weight denim jean with gold / brass thread stitching and a relaxed fit. Perfect for summer evenings. Even after washing, the fit remained correct. The rise is a bit high but not so much to be uncomfortable. The seat area fit me very well and actually helped my shape look better than it does in reality. I'm always pleased with any Dickies product. They are ahead of the pack in my book. Four gold stars.

Having seen a few of these stories profiled on "American Greed" and other shows, I was anxious to read the true tales of crime in detail.  Amore delivers everything I wanted. The book follows the story of several art forgeries and frauds, including not only the background of the forgers themselves, but also the investigators to some extent. This is a fascinating and compelling book, hard to put down and moves very quickly. It explains the terminology very clearly and even a novice would enjoy reading about this particular subject.  Amore covers the crimes from the 50s and onward, up to the internet age and it's own brand of particularly cunning and devious shysters that prey on innocent (and sometimes greedy) art lovers.His denouncement of some of the institutions own greed (which create an almost "blind" eye toward the obvious) is spot-on. These galleries and dealers have a gut feeling that what they're handling is not real, but the siren song of big bucks is simply too hard to ignore and they move ahead into becoming not-so-unwitting accomplices.As an artist, I found it particularly curious that most of these forgers were brilliantly talented artists themselves, yet willing to lend their skills regardless. It's a sad commentary on just how much greed has taken over the minds of even the creative sort, those that used to be satisfied with one meal and a palette of paint. No more. A quick buck mentality rules.I highly recommend this book to all art lovers, real crime enthusiasts and anyone who loves to see justice prevail. Five stars.

The Linksys N600 worked right out of the box. While I couldn't connect directly, I was able to connect through their site for my Windows laptop. I wasn't too keen on giving them my network password, but I guess they're not in my neighborhood (to freeload on the WiFi), so it doesn't really matter that much. Was able to walk around my entire house and get WiFi, but once I got past the garage outdoors, it didn't seem to have as strong a signal. It's winter here and although logic tells me otherwise, it may have something to do with the signal being weak outdoors. For most small houses and apartment dwellers, this would be sufficient. The speaker connection port seems a little odd to me, considering that most newer speaker systems are wireless. If the system would provide a signal to the speakers without wires, it might make more sense, but I can't see someone plugging this into the wall and then plugging speakers into it since most wall outlets are not located in great places for a speaker system.A nice little device, not much trouble to install or get going, so three stars for the good, two taken away for having to give up my network information and the spotty signal within 100 feet of the device.

The author, Huan Hsu has a problem.  He's an American-Chinese man who has become interested in his family's history, specifically the fabled porcelain that his great-great grandfather may (or may not have ) buried in his mainland China backyard before the revolution. But hardly anyone knows much about it and those who do seem to want to keep him from knowing more.Thus starts his long, winding tale of travel, employment, language barriers, history-delving and relative-meeting in both mainland China and Taiwan. Hsu's saga not only encompasses his family's past, but also it's present and the diaspora of various members - present and missing. And it also covers China's past in great detail: the history of porcelain, architecture, government and more. While the tale does get off the path now and again, it does so with rewards. We're treated to a compressed history of China and the spasmodic idiocy of the revolution and all of it's crazy outcomes in various eras. To say his family was affected deeply is putting it lightly. But then, who's family in China was not? We're also given a fairly good history of China's ceramic industry throughout time and up to the present. China knows they are the cradle of all things ceramic and they are just now getting that cache back, although in pieces and at high prices.Hsu goes through a plethora of locations, relatives, language situations and shards. Many, many shards. However, the problem I had with this saga is how long it took to get to the shards and the winding, twisting road was not something I found particularly enjoyable and the writer veers off-course into other territories quite often. Many of the first chapters should be chopped down, in my opinion and have far too many examples of minutiae for my taste. Things start to get interesting around page 130, when Hsu starts to actually experience interesting things and places.The writing style is good, if not a bit long-winded. I think the book could easily be pared down to about 250 pages instead of the 360 it now sits at. There is far too much unnecessary information about things not necessarily related to his family or porcelain per se.  While I didn't mind reading about the other subjects, they're not what interested me specifically and the book never actually lives up to it's title other than a few shards of what could have been his families original wares making their way into the author's possession before he leaves. As to how that happened, I won't ruin the story. But be forewarned, it will take nearly as long for the reader to make the discovery as it did for Hsu to actually live it.A good read, but slow going. I recommend the book to those interested in Chinese porcelian, history and culture.  Four Stars.

It's great to find a product on the market that offers non-meat protein and all the vitamins that this product has, especially without dairy.The Chai Vanilla is an interesting flavor, with hints of cinnamon and nutmeg. (If you don't like eggnog or cinnamon flavers, you may not like this.) I did not find the taste displeasing at all, and that's a first for me on any protein drink. I tried dissolving a spoonful without using a blender, it's probably best to use the blender if you don't want lumps hanging around the bottom. My next try was more successful and it blended smoothly.  The green color may be offputting for some, but I've had many seaweed mixes and am used to that, as well as yerbe mate, which turns green as it cools.A note to anyone out there who has a sensitive intestinal tract: You may need to start with just a teaspoon of this mix and work your way up to the full amount they suggest as this is pretty "hot" stuff and it took me 2 days to get used to the effects. I would not drink this by itself, but instead perhaps have it with your lunch and make sure and take a probiotic with the drink to help ease any problems. I have yet to do a full recipe because just two tablespoons gave me a bit of problems but not that severe.The French Vanilla is pretty good, not as rich-tasting as the Chai, but a fairly good imitation of what true French Vanilla tastes like. I found that it dissolved a bit easier than the Chai for some reason or perhaps I could not see it as easily in the mixture. Either way, I'd recommend that a blender or shake-maker be used instead of simple stirring.

Whether it's from switching shampoos or the ingredients in this shampoo, my hair has been behaving very well, feels better and doesn't seem to get dirty as fast. This is a thick shampoo which lathers up very nicely, it doesn't take much. The scent is citrus-y, but more in the light orange range than lemon in my opinion, like the artificial orange flavor that hard orange candies had when I was a kid.  It's not bad, I don't mind it much, but don't expect an actual lemon basil scent. Other than patchouli, I have yet to experience a shampoo scent that matches up to what the bottle says, so this isn't a surprise.  Otherwise, a very good shampoo for decent price.  Four stars.

At first, the unit seems small, like it's not going to really do much. And being used to seeing massage chairs which are covered in moving parts, I was pretty skeptical.  I plugged it in anyway and fired it up.Full disclosure: I suffer from a right shoulder injury that happened in a car accident when I was 18. I have severe nerve damage in that shoulder and pain/tightness 24/7/365. For 3.5 decades. I've been to dozens of chiro / message experts, nothing has really helped that much. Either too light a touch or too hard which just aggravated the injury. So naturally, that was the first place I wanted to test the unit out. And let me tell you... heat, vibration, movement... my shoulder immediately started making little popping sounds, all of the tendons loosened up and after about 10 minutes, I can honestly say I have no more tightness or pain in that area. I shifted my body around to get all the areas in the shoulder taken care of.The darn thing is a wonder!OK, well, so far so good, let's move to other areas and see what it does. I basically put it on a high-back upholstered chair and let it fall about an inch at a time, every 10 minutes, starting right below my skull and all the way down to my tailbone until it couldn't go any further.WOW!  I am totally relaxed now, my back feels great. My shoulder still does not have pain, a full 30 minutes later. After reading another review about it being good for feet, I figured "why not?".  Oh man, it's fantastic, my feet are still tingling and feel amazing. I'm going to take a hot shower and use this thing again tonight. I just hope I don't wear it out! The only negative I can see here is that it does not come with any kind of travel/carrying case. But that's a very slight negative considering what it's done for my shoulder.Excellent product! Five tingly, warm and relaxed stars!(PS: It's now been over an hour, shoulder still feels great!)

A relatively good wiper that is marred by it's lack of simple, complete instructions for installation.  Not wanting my car to look unbalanced, I bought the other side's wiper and began using them right away. Installing them was not easy nor were the instructions large enough or easy enough to understand. They are innovative in that there is a carapace which covers the blade mechanism (presumably to keep ice and snow out) and they are segmented while a single strip of hard plastic runs beneath which can slide during operation. The blade itself rides on this strip. Definitely a new kind of blade, but time will tell how well the rubber wears under a typical mid-western winter's snow, ice and salt onslaught. If they do well, I will return to update this review, but so far, mine meet the windshield nicely (Kia Sorento) and swipe the glass totally clean.

NOTE: THIS REVIEW IS FOR ONE, FLOOR-STANDING SPEAKER IN MONO MODE.The Pioneer Elite SP-EFS73 Dolby Atmos-enabled Andrew Jones Floorstanding Speaker not only presents itself in a beautiful way, it performs beautifully. IMO, this is not something that is for the average consumer, but meant more for a more sophisticated audience who appreciates fine audio equipment for either a home theater system or simply listening to music.The physical appearance and size is really very nice, takes up very little real estate on the floor. The faux wood fooled me for a while, but after getting a good look at it, I realized it was a laminate on HDF.  It's a heavy speaker that comes with optional screw-in spikes for carpeted situations.I wanted to test this out in two modes, one in the area of my house that has a cathedral ceiling and one in a typical "box" room because of the Atmos effect of having the additional speaker (on the top of the tower) aimed at the ceiling. To do so, I actually went and purchased a 4ohm receiver to wire into the top ports of the speaker to get the full effect. In the cathedral situation, it was not nearly as strong, since it's obvious (from what I've read) they're relying on the flat ceiling to bounce the sound down back at the listener. It did much better in the box shaped room and I was fully surrounded by sound while watching a DVD or listening to standard CD and MP3 music. I can only imagine what two of these would sound like in stereo and am half-tempted to bust out the drachmas to get another one.The separation of sound from the various sets of speakers is phenomenal. There is very little bleed over from treble to bass. Very crisp high end for both classical and rock music and truly incredible bass for such small speakers at the bottom of the "tower".  I punched the signal up to 14, which is about as much as I could stand and there was zero distortion. (My system goes to 25, but I don't want to set off an earthquake). To have only one of these deliver all of the sound it was giving me... well, it's pretty great stuff. Once a subwoofer is added, I'm sure it would be mind-blowing.The only negative I can think of is that they come in one color, black. With the various modes of decor happening in modern houses, this is a huge disappointment and there's really not a good reason to limit the colors like this. For that I'm removing a star.Otherwise, this is a very solid piece of equipment that performs very well. Four Stars.

Having just the bare-minimum of knowledge about the world of fashion and it's fickle ways, I had only heard the names of McQueen and Galliano via TV shows like "America's Next Top Model", "Project Runway" and other shows which often run through the slew of big names like tossing unwanted shoes to the side at a store-wide sale. But among the greats in fashion, these men apparently own two names that will stick in fashion history. Both came from London's 70s underground fashion world, went through the fashion schooling at St. Martins and then embarked on whirlwind careers that left audiences stunned and enthralled via mega-fashion houses of the likes of Dior and Givenchy.The author, Dana Thomas, comes to us from The New York Times' Style magazine, so she's no hack when it comes to writing about the colorful world of fashion and has a fairly extensive history of writing about it. Her knowledge shows strongly throughout this work, in the descriptions of the artists as well as their creations. The writing style is solid and other than a few odd repeats, the story moves along nicely and is carefully documented in various quotes and snippets from other sources. Ms. Thomas put together about as complete a picture of the two men as possible, including private life details that many other news outlets will either miss or leave out due to shortage of space. It's as complete a biography for both as you'll likely find.Admittedly, their stories are fascinating and I think this book will appeal to many, even those not addicted to fashion. Their stories are excellent examples of success, excess and the ultimate crush/crash that fame and entitlement can have on an artist. It's a very absorbing book and while a bit long (nearly 400 pages), it reads fairly smoothly and quickly.  Highly recommend, 4 stars.

After watching this movie for the 2nd time, I'm struck by how much potential it had and how it just fell flat in so many places.  You've got two great stars, a great writer, a great script in part by Francis Ford Coppola... lots of great supporting cast and sets, good sets...  wow, so much here to work with.  What happened?Well, firstly lets look at the flavor of the film. It's set in the 1930s depression era. Yet it feels very late 50s from the beginning. The haircuts, the clothing, the music, the language... it's just not 30s flavor at all. Redford's hair looks orange instead of blond. Natalie is a bit overweight and looks older than the part calls for and her hair is totally wrong for 30s. The music is schmaltzy and not at all in keeping for the period. The camera angles and shots at times look very 60s television (which is not surprising since most of what Pollack had done was TV thus far). The director even threw in a hand-held shot at one point, the only one in the film. Can you say inconsistent? Nothing was blending together to put you into that era or that story.Now, how about the acting? Many people say she was aptly named. There are hints of greatness in the job Ms. Wood does here, but for the most part, it's not happening when it really needs to and over-acted when it doesn't need to. Subtlety is not her strong suit. Redford always plays everything so straight (with absolutely ZERO accent) that it can ruin an otherwise good script. Still, he's almost good in this, because he's still a bit raw - later films are not helped by his presence, IMHO. The supporting cast easily outshines the stars and that's the joy I dredged from this one. Kate Reid is great as a frowsy, overly-selfish Momma and Charles Bronson and Robert Blake both put in good performances. Willy is played pretty nicely by Mary Badham, who resurrects her pitch-perfect "Scout" act from To Kill a Mockingbird, however older and wiser.The script is good, but takes a horrible left turn when Alva gets to New Orleans. How is she surviving? Is she working the streets or a waitress or shop girl or what? The bit of money she stole from the husband she left in Mississippi couldn't have been much, he was just laid off. We're supposed to believe that she wanders around for weeks, partially living off of the food she keeps throwing at the pigeons, I guess.  And then, magically, in a city of over 458 thousand people (at the time) they magically find each other. OK, I'll suspend disbelief for a bit. But then Momma, who shows up later to drag Alva away because... well, that's the problem. If Momma has found a new man and is doing OK, why does she need Alva? Why waste time coming to New Orleans? It's a bit much and not very believable.I was hoping to find the same resonance that Splendor in the Grass had or perhaps some trashy, southern drama/fun as in Cat on a Hot Tin Roof, but found neither in this film. Three lazy, melting stars for this syrupy would-be drama that drips slowly into the river.
Yup.  Nice pants, good for working or for playing.  Me likey.

I set off two of these in my log cabin to help rid it of wood roaches, which are a common problem there since it's in the middle of the woods. It's winter and they like to come in from the cold. Well, any of them that come in now will get a surprise. I went back in two days later and there were lots of dead roaches on the floor. I'm going to set off the rest of them in my steel barn to help rid it of bugs as well.Many people here have posted that there are more insects than before, but what they are probably seeing is an increase in activity on the part of the insects that were already there. They tend to move around more when their environment has been disturbed and this insecticide is just such a disturbance. It does not attract more insects, it simply makes the ones that are there move around more. It's also a "contact" type of surfactant, so they actually have to crawl over a surface that has the poison on it in order to die, so it's actually a good thing that they're moving around. Personally, I would not use this in an area that will be lived in within a week or two. While it most likely is considered "safe" by the FDA, I am not into taking chances with chemical insecticides. My cabin will not have any people in it until spring, so I'm not worried about any residual effects at that point. Hopefully, it will keep working until then and kill any bugs that get in.The odor is a lot more pleasant than other "bombs" that I've used, so that's a plus since it's going to be hanging around on surfaces for a bit. Four stars for this product, one taken away due to it not being a general air-killing type of insecticide that creeps into all areas but relies on the surfaces being crawled over instead.

The Tacwise cable tacker is an extremely well-designed tool. Nice coated stainless steel body, heavy-duty construction, fits the hand nicely.  It comes with not only the option of two sizes of staple, but it also has two different strengths to put them in so if you are going into harder wood you can ramp up the shot.  There is a groove in the front and back of the stapler to line up the cable nicely in the tool so that you don't shoot through your cable or wiring.  I can see this being a tool I use not only in wiring the rest of my basement, but also putting up fence as the staples are perfect for heavy wire fencing needing to be fastened to a post.Very easy to load, take apart, etc., had no troubles there at all. There's really nothing I can say that's negative about this staple gun.All in all, this is a great tool to use and well worth the money.  Five Stars for a decent tool.

Fairly nice tablet of paper, the covers are very sturdy (plastic coated?) and the dividers work very well and hold a few papers themselves if need be. These are thick, about an inch of paper in each. I like how the covers are two different colors, which will help differentiate them if I use them for two purposes. I'm going to use one at the construction site to help keep track of various projects there and the other at the home office. I'm very fond of how narrow the lined paper is as well, gives much more room for making notes. Being a lefty, it's nice to have a choice of having the spiral on the other side, so most of the time, I use the back of the sheets.  Good product, four stars!

After receiving it, I tried this unit for three nights in a row. It does smell good but did not make sleep any different for me. The fragrance is very much like the non-natural lavender oil that you can buy which is derived from chemicals rather than actual plant essences. It's close, but not really a lavender smell and I can say this with authority because I grow several kinds of lavender in my garden and have purchased real lavender oil in the past. As far as chamomile, I don't smell any presence of it at all.To be honest, I'm a little leery of plugging something in and leaving it that way when I'm gone, so I tend to use this only when I'm sure I'm going to be present.The pads are easy to install, I'd use one to start and see if that is enough scent after 5 hours instead of installing both. They sent 6 pads with the unit, so enough to last quite a while.I'm using it in my bathroom now to help deodorize since the sleep enhancing simply did not work for me.  Three stars... but not the kind you see in your sleep.

In Kelly Link's collection of short stories, the characters are all a bit damaged or failed in some way. Link is a strong writer and these stories prove it, if not in a skewed and formulaic way. It's not hard to pick out the formula: write a somewhat interesting story then add something other-worldly to spice it up a bit. The format is very reminiscent of Twilight Zone or Outer Limits. Most of the stories hit the target and are oddly entertaining, others simply aren't worthy of the rest of the collection. My favorite was "Summer People" where an unseen family inhabits a cottage in magical ways and give gifts that can either delight or haunt, depending on your past behavior.It's a nice collection overall, but not everyone is going to like Link's style. I did, but not in every case. Three stars.

In general, I purchase soaps for what they smell like. I'm not fussy about any moisturizing qualities or deodorant longevity. Simply put, if I like the way it smells, I buy it.After washing my face with this bar (and yes, it got clean) the odor is so strong that I found myself using alcohol to get it off my face and re-washed with a better bar after that.It does NOT smell like mandarin oranges or tiare flowers. I've smelled both and this is not even close.This particular scent smells like cheap bulk-price room deodorizer oil that you buy with the sticks. In fact, it smells exactly like one that a friend has which makes my sinuses close up and I start sneezing. It's incredibly strongly scented to the point where I'm going to simply use it in my linen closet to keep them smelling fresh.Not recommended unless you like to smell like room deodorizer.

This digital scale is very nice looking, sleek, low to the ground, hardly any markings or patterns which is exactly what I look for to accessorize my modern home.After putting the batteries in, I weighed myself in various locations and on various floor surfaces. This scale gave me a different read-out every time, hovering within about 5 pounds of my actual weight. I have another digital scale (A Thinner by Conair, an early model which has a thick glass platform) which I've used for many years and it's read-out is very consistent. Every time I moved the Taylor scale a few inches on the same surface, I got a new weight reading. My conclusion is that this scale is not very consistent and tends to add a few pounds compared to the readings on my older scale.Three stars for looks, two taken away for inconsistent readings.
Incredible film. I can't say anything here except that you just need to watch it and see the innocence of childhood evaporate when the boy sees what his parents are up to.  Haunting.
Worked exactly as needed, a very tight space to get a grill into and I like how this is simple, white and fit well.

This is a good humidifier, but it's very difficult to fill the containers easily as the tops of them are not flat.  This needs a major overhaul in this design area.Otherwise, it works, but is a little noisy...  but I don't mind the noise, my house is as quiet as a tomb otherwise.  I sort of like the "blurp" of the water as it's taken into the system.  Works very well in my 1900 sq. foot home... brought the humidity from 28 percent up to 48 percent in about 2 hours.  Now I don't feel like I'm going to crack in half and the floors are not nearly as creaky as they were.  My eyes feel better too, not nearly as dried out all the time from the fans and the wood stove.  Nice unit for the money.

I've always liked bats, and even did some research on them many years back for a press release for the North Dakota Extension Service, so was delighted to find this book in the queue. Dr. Merlin Tuttle, the author and long-time bat conservationists, writes in an appealing and very readable style, and casually knocks aside exaggerated horror stories with facts and anecdotes. He fought against ignorance in the 70s and 80s, and states that the world is seeing a resurgence of the horror stories fed by ignorance, to which he states, "[Hundreds] of bat researchers world-wide remain healthy despite lifetimes of close association with bats. In fact, even among the millions of people who eat bats or harvest guano from caves, reports of possible harm are exceedingly rare."Bats provide a service, and a strong economic reason to protect them. A single bat can eat 1000 insects in an hour, so imagine what a colony of hundreds could do! They eat pest insects, some even searching out pests before they have a chance to lay eggs, thereby saving agriculturalists large amounts on pesticides. Nector and fruit-eating bats provide pollination that is much better than birds or bees. Bats are also shown to be highly intelligent and sophisticated, even altruistic, like the vampire bat, which will share food with other bats and adopt orphaned pups. They have proven long-term memory, with bats who have been tamed returning occasionally to the person with whom they have bonded, and remembering how to do various things that had been taught years before.Obviously I could go on for some time, but will end it here. I strongly recommend this book to anyone to learn more about this fascinating and often beautlful animals. My only gripe is that the ARC doesn't have the pictures that will be in the final release copy, which will be available Oct. 20, 2015. Highly recommended!

I love this scent, it's gorgeous, and the product does as advertised, keeping the bathroom smelling nice. However, there is a problem with the bottle. It leaks around the nozzle and around the place where the top and bottom connect. This makes it very difficult to maintain a steady and consistent volume of use, and also makes the bottle just icky to use because the liquid is all over the user's hand. The company needs to do better with the bottles. Otherwise a product I would recommend.

This is a wonderfully plush and absorbent toilet tissue. It feels nice and does the job with less. However, it isn't particularly compressed. Compared to our normal tissue, which comes in a double roll, these are actually larger. Still, nice product. If you want a toilet tissue that is soft, plush, and absorbent, then this is your choice.

After only a few days of using this product, I am noticing a definite improvement in the area around my eyes; the dark circles are reduced and my crow's feet seem less obvious. The product dispenses easily through a pump, allowing the user to use as much or as little as needed. The texture is lovely, and it smooths on and soaks in quickly, leaving the skin soft but not greasy. I'm impressed! If you want a good product for your eyes, definitely check this one out.

So yes it is possible to have a YA story without a a love triangle, or love inteest at all. This is awesome, and lack of long spells of brooding over which hunky guy (often one good and one evil) the pase of the story moves along at a strong clip. In fact, about guys:Michael Hannigan was important to the football team. If he could pass with a C average, he'd become important to some university's sports program somewhere, and maybe, ev.entually he'd make it to the NFL and earn a few million dollars a year for throwing a ball around and sustaining head injuries.That's what happened to tall dumb guys.As far as coming up with the name:"We could call her... Princess X.""Why X?" Libby asked."Because X is the most mysterious letter," May told her.
