And things with X's (sic) in them are usually pretty cool.Thus begins the odyssey of Princess X -- created by two lonely girls based on chalk art on the sidewalk, with suggestions from a crowd of youngsters who pause to watch the ideas emerge. The plot is well summarized on the book page, so I won't go into it again.I was disappointed that the webcomics had not been added to the ARC to allow a proper evaluation, though the basics of each missing panel are described. It's just not the same. This why I dropped a stat.However, if you are looking for a YA book that is not the ordinary brood-fest over boys, you should quite like this one. You will hopefully also appeciate that the girls are strong and rise up to the challenge of adversity. This book was released in May, so definitely grab a copy if you can!

This is a pretty piece of jewelry. I have rated it as 4 stars because the diamonds have very little sparkle, and the chain seems delicate. I shall need to take care not to break it. However, the pendant is nice and strong feeling, a good, solid feel to it, and thicker than I had expected. The box it comes in is very nice for storing a piece of fine jewelry, even to including a pouch on the back of the card in which to store the chain. It would make a fine present for any woman in your life, or as a nice gift for yourself if you care.

A nice, sturdy stapler in a bright color, great to add a pop to your desk. The Vine description indicated there were to be test staples included, but they were not, thus the deduction in rating. Things need to be as described. Still, if you're looking for a stapler and want some color, check this brand out.

Original 4 star review below.  Reducing to 2 stars, because after just a few weeks,  the flip-out stand broke completely off. It wasn't even knocked around, it was just tipped over by one of my cats. Travel clocks need to be able to stand up to a bit of punishment, so I'm reducing the rating and recommend it only for those who will treat it very gingerly.this is a nice little clock. It can be run on 2 AAA batteries, or by plugging into a USB outlet. If you use the batteries only, then the back light and projection only work when you want it to. Plugged into USB, the projection and back light are always on. The only problem I had was with setting it. It took several tries before the mode button actually kicked in, and I can't figure out how to change the day of the week or the year; when I set this up yesterday, with date of 9/1, it gave the day as Monday rather than Tuesday. As nearly as I can tell this cannot be fixed, so a minor issue there. Otherwise it's great for what I'll need it to do, and I think would serve well as a travel clock.

Overall I did quite enjoy this story. The various levels and layers, past and future, the Victorian novel (is it true or fiction?), the mysterious contents of the envelope. Sweeping ideas, but the whole thing didn't quite pull together for me. The ending was confusing, because I don't know if this ARC actually showed the materials in the envelope included with the final copy of the book, so it's possible that I'm simply missing that last bit. I did very much like Zeke's little comments he was always writing in the dust or on smudged glass or whereever he could, such as, "The truth of nothingness, that is despair." There ae a lot of these sprinkled through the text.One interesting thing that is covered as a sort of "moral" in the story is the notion of history repeating if people don't learn. It's eloquently said here:"We must know where we have been. If we cannot see our own patterns, then we are nothing but a mindless flock of birds flapping blindly in the night, scraping and pecking in the dust."If you enjoyed J.J. Abrams' "S", or "House of Leaves" then this book might be for you. It is engrossing through most of the book. Check it out.

The screen protector from MoKo for my Galaxy Tab is a decent product and has been working well so far. The main problem is when putting it on, it didn't fully adhere to the corner of the screen. However, it's not a corner i use often, so it's no big deal. If looking for a screen protector film for your Galaxy Tab S 10 then this would be a good one to choose.

I have a Kindle PaperWhite so can read in the dark and avoid the problem of having to walk across the room to turn off the lights when I am ready to sleep. My husband does not have this and occasionally friction has arisen when he wants to read and I want to sleep, as I am closest to the switch to turn the lights off. Needless to say, he has been in need of a lamp so he can read in bed without disturbing me. I hoped this would serve the purpose.First, the brightness: we turned it on and said, "whoa!" It really is very bright. The flexibility lets him direct the light right at his Kindle without the light disturbing me. Very happy with the ability to make the appropriate adjustment. This is an attractive piece and designed to take up as little space as possible. All in all, a most satisfactory result. Recommended for anyone who wants a good lamp.
The cats love it, so I love it. It has great natural ingredients, smells good enough I want to eat it, and makes my cats happy. Fellow cat slaves, check this stuff out;.

I've been reading (and loving) Nina Post's books from the beginning. Aside from a couple places where the timeline was turned around a bit, I can't find anything to fault in this latest novel. Shawn and Sarah continue to have very random discussions, Shawn still feuds with his family and treat his cat in a way of which I approve. He has moved to a new department in his hometown where he has to train a whole new group to let him do things his way.I don't want to end up with spoilers and typing in reviews on my Kindle is slow, so I will wrap up with a hearty recommendation of this book, as well as any other by Nina Post.This ebook was purchased by me (cough... yesterday) and this review is completely unsolicited.

I finished this book and turned right around and read it again. That is how  EPIC I found it. Wise words, if occasionally profane, and well worth reading for any who often find themselves thinking, "What will (X) think if I do (Y)." Stop worrying what other people think and live your own life your own way.

I doenjoy these sorts of stories, so don't misunderstand me. If you can lose yourself in the story and ignore details that don't fit, you'll likely enjoy this book. Here was my main problem.When Hank calls in the elders only to have one of the guests die, the Elders hold him as a suspect. They also disbelieve him about the evidence in the briefcase when it disappears. However, it is later stated that the Elders are able to see right through a person and all but know what he or she is thinking. It is also revealed that they are always able to tell whether someone is lying or telling the truth. So why the suspicion and mistrust? Other, of course, than that would be the end of the book. Still, once I noticed that I couldn't unnotice it and it grated on me through the rest of the book. If you think you can ignore that, and if you like urban fantasies, fairy tales and detective stories, check it out. It's free, so you won't be out anything but time.

I hope to write a more thorough review at a later time, as writing them from my PaperWhite is slow. But I wanted to gush at how much I loved this new book in a new series. An urban fantasy thriller, this book will not disappoint those who enjoy either genre.The characters are great and develop realistically. The two mains - Eleri Eames and Donovan Heath - are excellent. They both have their problems, faults and strengths and develop within the course of the book. Those who know me know how I feel about romance gumming up the works, so won't be surprised to hear I'm particularly happy to report this book as romance free!I noted a number of technical problems with editing, including the consistent misuse of discrete and into when discreet and in to should have been used. There were also numerous run-on sentences that would have benefited from semi-colons. The author also created the word "sensical" when sensible would have done fine.However, as I said, these were very nitpicky things that I doubt the average reader would have noticed and they certainly didn't detract from my enjoyment. I am excited for the next book in this series and will be watching for it.Those who have followed my reviews over the past few years may remember that all previous reviews of A.J. Scudiere's books were done off review copies. This one may have been offered too. I don't know since I've been out of pocket since my cancer diagnosis. The point is that I purchased this book myself. I am a huge fan of Ms. Scudiere and remain eagerly watching for new stories from her fertile mind. This book, like any by her, is highly recommended by me.

I had to strictly restrain myself while reading this on my Kindle to avoid sharing quotes that would spoil the story but there were just so many places that made me laugh or think that it was difficult. What amused me the most was the combination of the mundane and the horrific, such as when Cuthbert is talking to Ashton about cooking pasta but he had to go down to the temple afterward to sacrifice some virgins to Cthulhu. Highly recommended for people who enjoy Cthulhu mythos and don't mind a touch of silliness.

Although I think some of the stories were enhanced a bit, this was still a interesting look into crime and detection in the late 19th century. Recommended or those interested in true crime. It's not too long and makes a quick read.

I really enjoyed this book, starting a new series in the Honorverse. I will mention that this book is highly character driven and slower moving than those in other series, so if you require fast action and lots of 'splodies you might be disappointed. Stick with it. I suspect things will be heating up in future books.

The ideal reader of this monster mashup anthology would be someone who really loves bad B movies. The worse the better. If you go in with low expectations you'll be good. Most of the stories have bad editing. Wrong word entirely or wrong homonym. Screwed up punctuation. That sort of thing. A few of the stories are just bad. The majority run between mediocre and okay. Two blew my socks off (in a good way). "Frightening Cliches" by Bennie Newsome is cleverly written bad, the sort of bad that can only come from a brilliant writer. I plan to find the rest of his work, as well as that of DK Mok, whose "Keeping it Together" offers a fresh (and often laugh-out-loud funny) take on zombies, as well as a clever expectation-twisting surprise at the end. Just brilliant! Too bad it was only those two stories that brought my rating up to three stars.

A super cute set of stories mostly about the challenges and joys of the ber small portable pooches. Like the adorable "Animal Whisperer...er...rrrrr," this one is no longer available, nor has a promised second volume appeared. I have no idea why these were taken down but am hoping and wishing for them to be republished.

This is just a cute and fun story, perfect for animal lovers. Sadly it seems to no longer be available and that's just a pity. So to the authors I say: BRING IT BACK! Don't deny the pleasure of this story to future readers.

I am not certakn how I acquired this book. I know I won at least one of his books on LibraryThing in exchange for a review, but think I just picked this one up on Amazon because it soumded fun. And it really was! Mike Murphy lives in an urban fantasy world and is a PI. The stories from his files are hilarious. Additionally the author has twisted and misused several fairy tales to good advantage in his other stories. Don't miss this one.

This anthology of short-shorts (16 stories in 69 pages) contains a variety of ideas and story types, all of a dark nature but written in a haunting and engaging style that will keep the reader hooked. I have a few more books by this promising author that I look forward to reading. Check it out: this anthology has something for everyone.

While most of the stories were entertaining, the editing left much to be desired. There are errors of punctuation and verb tense, run-on or clipped sentences and everywhere the wrong homonym being used. Compliment and complement are both ussd and both used incorrectly. A small sampling of others:taught - tautlead - ledAlso there were instances when a simple spellcheck would have caught things like wale and dumfounded. If you can read and enjoy the stories (and they are horror) and ignore the rampant errors then great! But if, like me, you can't turn off your inner editor it might be better to try something else.

As Buffy said : Note to self. Religion. Freaky. When a would be Messiah/prophet leads his people into the desert, lack of knowledge about the area almost leads to their starving. Naturally upon finding a fertile valley he believes he has found Eden. When representatives of a Native tribe try to stop them he refuses to stop. There are houses, food, and an orchard of enormous trees bursting with fruit. But where did the previous settlers go? And why are there no apples preserved? I finished this novella and said "wowza" to myself.  Short but sweet, chilling hardcore horror. Highly recommended.

I absolutely loved the first three books in this series and have been anxiously awaiting each as they are translated into English and released here. This one, however, was a disappointment. The previous books were funny, witty, and provided a good mystery to solve. In this one, the idea fell flat. It's a good idea - Pascha deals with several children - but it just wasn't as funny or witty as the previous books. The mystery was still good, and kept me guessing, which is why I've rated it at three stars, but overall, if you plan to skip one in the series, this is the one to skip.

Book Info: Genre: Weird WesternReading Level: AdultDiversity: GLBTQ characters, various religions, interracial relationshipsTense, Person, POV: Past tense, third person, limited POVRecommended for: Fans of Weird Westerns, Lovecraftian books, steampunkTrigger Warnings: murder, mutilation, torture, mention of necrophilia, cannibalismAnimals: at least one horse killedMy Thoughts: These are listed as steampunk, but thus far there is limited steampunkery. To me, this is mostly a Weird Western with strong Lovecraftian influences. There are also very many stretches of interesting philosophical discussion between the various characters that I quite enjoyed. For instance:God simply is, Bick said. Humanity embraced It. They gave It color and gender, shape and form. They put words in Its mouth. They always have, and they still do, perhaps they always will. I always experience God as a 'He,' but God is too vast to be held prisoner by language or biology....What things do you think the Almighty was whispering in my ear all those countless eons? Words of endearment? Of joy and peace and love? No. He dipped his tongue in the blackest blood and he whispered to me of slaughter, of death, of torture and atrocity. That is your creator, Biqa. He built this entire lovely, lovely playground so that he could tear it apart, abuse and neglect his toys and listen to the terrified screams of the monkeys as they tried to understand.Where did payback end exactly? Charlie Upton had murdered Jim's Pa. Jim killed Charlie. One day Jim might get shot or hanged for what he did to Charlie and sometone like Mutt or Jon Highfather might seek revenge in his name. How far back did the blood flow? When was it enough? Could anything ever get square?I'm enjoying the character development in these books. Mutt, for example, has really loosened up, and he's quite funny in this book. Jon is off a lot, leaving Mutt and Jim to take care of business in the town. Doc Tumblety is such a creeper, and of course incompetent to boot. As Jon Highfather states: And that's our first-rate medical care here in sunny Golgotha. He may seem pretty horrible at first, but after awhile you come to realize that deep down inside, he's much worse than that. He's very misogynistic, saying at one point to Kate, Hush now... Men are talking. As for Kate, she makes a great addition to the cast and to the town; I hope we'll see her again! I enjoyed the bits and pieces of Chinese history and legends that Ch'eng Huang provides to Jim as he is instructing him on how to use the jade eye. I was more than a bit troubled by the inclusion of the Thuggee, as their worship of Kali Ma is a perversion. It is true Kali Ma is the Mother-Destroyer, the one who must destroy the world so it can be remade anew, but that doesn't mean that people should be going around randomly murdering in her name.Also, it is mentioned off-hand that Baba Yaga came to Golgotha, albeit briefly. She is not mentioned by name, but a house on chicken legs is a dead giveaway. I do hope that this story will be told in full; maybe the author has a number of these little anecdotes that he could use to put together an anthology of short stories set in Golgotha?Toward the end, Clay and a Professor Zenith have a science showdown that is wonderfully fun as they shout at one another, using very civilized language and high-toned insults. It struck my funny bone and hopefully I won't be the only one amused by it. At the end, Clay says, I swear... anyone with a little copper tubing and a dynamo thinks they're a scientist these days.This is an excellent follow-up and I'm grateful to the author for sending me this ARC so I didn't have to wait until October to read it! I haven't commented on editing because this is an uncorrected proof, so any errors I spotted will likely be cleaned up by the final draft. Definitely check this out if it sounds like the sort of book you'd like!Series Information: The Golgotha seriesBook 1: The Six-Gun TarotBook 2: The Shotgun ArcanaDisclosure: I received an ARC from the author in exchange for an honest review. All opinions are my own.Synopsis: 1870. A haven for the blessed and the d***ed, including a fallen angel, a mad scientist, a pirate queen, and a deputy who is kin to coyotes, Golgotha has come through many nightmarish trials, but now an army of thirty-two outlaws, lunatics, serial killers, and cannibals are converging on the town, drawn by a grisly relic that dates back to the Donner Party and the dawn of humanity.Sheriff Jon Highfather and his deputies already have their hands full dealing with train robbers, a mysterious series of brutal murders, and the usual outbreaks of weirdness.  But with thirty-two of the most vicious killers on Earth riding into Golgotha in just a few days time, the town and its people will be tested as never beforeand some of them will never be the same.

This is a short placeholder review until such a time as I can write a longer, more detailed one.This is the second book in The Chaos Born series, after "Children of Fire."  While re-reading that one before this book, I noticed that the author has a real hate-on for  horses.  A lot of horses are killed in the first book, but you can't keep track because in two different occasions it was "all the horses" in an area.  So I decided to keep track in this one. There were only 5 horses killed in this one, but there were a bunch of dogs killed.There is a lot of character development in this one, although I must say I was most disappointed in how weak-minded Rianna (Vaalar's mother) turned out to be.  Scythe is a mystery still in a lot of ways - she would be her normal self at one moment and the next she'd switch to nurturing for no apparent reason. The group travels to the Frozen North in this book, where we meet Norr's clan and finally learn why he left his people.This is an Advance Uncorrected Proof, so I won't comment on editing. I will, however, mention that this book was pretty messed up physically. It was missing two pages altogether, and on two separate locations there is a page moved past where it should be (example, the first section was page 202, 207, 208, 205, 206. 209). There were also many, many places where the print was faint in patches, and one page where there were actual blank spots on the page. I checked the other Vine reviewers and as far as I can tell I was the only one to receive a proof like this. Doesn't really affect my opinion of the book, but I thought I'd point it out.If you liked the first book, you should like this one. If you like epic fantasy, especially high fantasy, then you should like this. I liked it well enough that I will probably pick up the final book when it comes out next month.

This is a short placeholder review until such as time as I can write a more detailed one.This is a fast and furious book, following on from the first book in the series.  We meet some pretty amazing people, and learn more about what happened to a few of the more mysterious characters.  I can't go into details so as to avoid spoilers.  However if you liked the first book, if you like books dealing with alternate ideas of history and religion, check this series out.

Actual rating: 3.5Book Info: Genre: Dark epic fantasyReading Level: Young Adult to AdultRecommended for:Trigger Warnings: murder, killing, assassination, violence, rape (M/M and M/F), torture, mutilation, stealing, slavery, infidelity, sexual assault, cannibalism, danger to child/kidnappingMy Thoughts: This is a general review of the overall series. To read the reviews of the books in the trilogy, go to the individual reviews on each book's page.This is a dark, gritty epic fantasy. The first book of the series feels oriented toward young adult readers, having the typical fantasy coming-of-age tropes. However, by book two the writing is more oriented to adults and the sorts of problems inherent in ruling and judging and generally being adult and taking responsibility for your own actions. While many of the themes remain dark, by the end of the third book in the trilogy there is a strong feeling of hope and redemption.The first book in the trilogy is rife with editing errors, and the third book also has a number of them. Only the second book in the series shows decent editing. I'm not sure why this is. The first book also relied strongly on tropes, but as the trilogy continues you can see the author's vision of the story opening up and also see the author's craft improving. All in all, a satisfying and interesting trilogy, and one I'd recommend to fans of dark epic fantasy.Series Information: The Night Angel TrilogyBook 1: The Way of Shadows, review linked hereBook 2: Shadow's Edge, review linked hereBook 3: Beyond the Shadows, review linked hereDisclosure: I purchased the omnibus edition of the trilogy for myself. All opinions are my own.Synopsis: 3 volumes in one giant omnibus edition."Way of Shadows", "Shadow's Edge", "Beyond the Shadows": all in one beautiful hardcover edition

Book Info: Genre: Dark epic fantasyReading Level: AdultRecommended for: fans of dark epic fantasyTrigger Warnings: murder, killing, assassination, violence, rape (mentioned but not seen), torture, mutilation, stealing, slaveryMy Thoughts: After the first book in this series, it turns more into adult fare. I neglected to mention this in the review for book 2. Also, although not as bad as the first book, this one again has a number of editing errors, including misused words and many missing words. I just can't fathom how this happened; aren't publishing houses supposed to have superior editing staff?However, all in all, this is a satisfying conclusion to the trilogy. The ending is a bit abrupt after all the build-up, incorporating a certain element of deus ex machina, but at the same time it makes sense based on the hints that are dropped over the course of books 2 and 3. The author has said he plans to write further books in this universe, set at a point some years in the future, and I will definitely be watching for those. Many of my problems with the first book, such as overuse of tropes, is cleaned up by the end of the series; you can see how the author has grown in writing. I will, in fact, be seeking out more works by this talented author. If you enjoy dark, gritty fantasy that has elements of redemption and hope, then definitely check this trilogy out.Series Information: The Night Angel TrilogyBook 1: The Way of Shadows, review linked hereBook 2: Shadow's Edge, review linked hereBook 3: Beyond the ShadowsDisclosure: I purchased the omnibus edition of the trilogy for myself. All opinions are my own.Synopsis: Logan Gyre is king of Cenaria, a country under siege, with a threadbare army and little hope. He has one chancea desperate gamble, but one that could destroy his kingdom.In the north, the new Godking has a plan. If it comes to fruition, no one will have the power to stop him.Kylar Stern has no choice. To save his friendsand perhaps his enemieshe must accomplish the impossible: assassinate a goddess.

I first read this book in the ORIGINAL version in 2011.Book info Genre: Paranormal YAReading Level: Young AdultDisclosure: I was given a free e-copy of this book by the author in exchange for an honest review. That was the original version. I then edited it, and it was released in a second edition. I do not receive any remuneration based upon sales. All opinions are my own and based upon the original version of the full novel.My Synopsis: Alex Drummond has enough to deal with, really. His father was killed by a drunk driver a few years ago; his mother got remarried and moved them in with her new husband, who is a vicious alcoholic and beats Alex frequently to within an inch of his life; Alex's step-brother, Frank, is a layabout who also beats on him, and his two step-sisters are an annoyance to him; and he's an outsider at school, small and picked on by the larger kids. Now he's developed an alarming tendency - when he touches things that were somehow touching a person when they were murdered, he falls into a vision and relives their death. And the people whose deaths he is reliving expect him to do something about it.My Thoughts: Partly a paranormal suspense book, partly a coming-of-age story, and even including a little bit of romance, "A Life of Death" is a completely amazing story! I won't lie to you, it is often very intense - the tension evinced by this book is amazingly well-done and I often felt my heart racing from the extremity of emotions that it raised. It is tightly plotted and suspenseful; the characters are well-developed and realistic - the whole thing just came to life in my mind while I was reading it, and the sudden silence whenever I would look up showed me just how much it filled my mind while I was reading it.The story is bracketed interestingly - the very beginning and very end are Alex as an older man, a police detective, helping his son with a project for school. The story itself is the tale he tells the boy. I thought this was a neat way to open and close the story and it left me with hopes that we might expect a series of Alex Drummond mystery novels in the future. I would certainly buy them!My Recommendation: Fans of paranormal mystery and suspense stories should enjoy this book. Definitely give it a read as soon as you can!

Book Info: Genre: Dark epic fantasyReading Level: Young AdultRecommended for: fans of dark epic fantasyTrigger Warnings: murder, killing, assassination, violence, rape, torture, mutilation, stealing, slavery, cannibalism, danger to child/kidnapping, sexual assaultMy Thoughts: This second book in the Night Angel trilogy is much better edited than the first book, which is very strange; I guess maybe there was a different editor? Why they wouldn't have had an editor go through the omnibus edition to check for consistency I don't know but there it is.Things move along very quickly in this book. Kylar learns more about his abilities and Talent, as well as the extras that the ka'kari provides him. I was very happy about some of the people who are disposed of in this book, and also intrigued by some of the new characters that show up. One this this author is very good at is creating characters that will cause a reaction in the reader, be it good or bad. There is a great deal of gray in the series, where the bad guys aren't really evil so much as twisted, and the heroes are often damaged in ways that make them less than perfect. I like this sort of thing.If you like dark epic fantasy, with an antihero and lots of violence, check out this trilogy. Don't let the problems with the first book put you off; this one is better.Series Information: The Night Angel TrilogyBook 1: The Way of Shadows, review linked hereBook 2: Shadow's EdgeBook 3: Beyond the ShadowsDisclosure: I purchased the omnibus edition of the trilogy for myself. All opinions are my own.Synopsis: Kylar Stern has rejected the assassin's life. The Godking's successful coup has left Kylar's master, Durzo, and his best friend, Logan, dead. He is starting over: new city, new friends, and new profession.But when he learns that Logan might actually be alive and in hiding, Kylar is faced with an agonizing choice: will he give up the way of shadows forever and live in peace with his new family, or will he risk everything by taking on the ultimate hit?

Book Info: Genre: Dark epic fantasyReading Level: Young AdultRecommended for: older YA, fans of dark epic fantasy who don't mind typical tropesTrigger Warnings: murder, killing, assassination, violence, rape (mostly M/M), torture, mutilation, stealing, slavery, cannibalism, infidelityMy Thoughts: The beginning of this book is pretty typical epic fantasy fare, other than the fact that our hero is an antihero. But Azoth is an orphan, he's taken in against the odds by a powerful man who learns that Azoth is more than he appears, rising up from his poverty-stricken roots, etc. And, of course, the love interest that is forbidden. Still, once Kylar is on the scene, things heat up and I found myself tearing through the pages to find out what happened next. So don't let the typical trope throw you off from reading this book if it sounds like something in which you are interested.However, I was astounded by the sloppy editing on this book. It was released through one of Hatchett's publishing groups, and editing errors were heavily scattered through the book. There is a part where Azoth calls another character by his first name in a familiar manner, even though he has not yet met that character and really doesn't know much about him. And there are a lot of missing words from sentences. I'm amazed that a professional editor working for a major publisher would be so sloppy. If that will bother you, keep it in mind.Still I did enjoy the book, despite how dark it often is. If you like dark epic fantasy, antiheroes, and don't mind the typical tropes and editing problems, then check this one out.Series Information: The Night Angel TrilogyBook 1: The Way of ShadowsBook 2: Shadow's EdgeBook 3: Beyond the ShadowsDisclosure: I purchased the omnibus edition of the trilogy for myself. All opinions are my own.Synopsis: For Durzo Blint, assassination is an art-and he is the city's most accomplished artist.For Azoth, survival is precarious. Something you never take for granted. As a guild rat, he's grown up in the slums, and learned to judge people quicklyand to take risks. Risks like apprenticing himself to Durzo Blint.But to be accepted, Azoth must turn his back on his old life and embrace a new identity and name. As Kylar Stern, he must learn to navigate the assassins' world of dangerous politics and strange magicsand cultivate a flair for death.

Book Info: Genre: Satire/speculative shortsReading Level: AdultRecommended for: Those who enjoy speculative fiction and clever storytellingMy Thoughts: I learned about cabinets of curiosities from reading the Pendergast novels by Douglas Preston and Lincoln Child. One of the novels is actually titled The Cabinet of Curiosities and it explains what these are. Basically, a cabinet of curiosities is a private collection of interesting and odd things, which were quite popular in the 19th century. Whatever the person putting it together is interested in would be collected. In this collection of short, speculative, essay-type stories, the various writers describe the stories behind the items in Thackery T. Lambshead's cabinet of curiosities.This book is not as funny as the book of fake diseases I just read, but it is still wonderfully well done. The various authors have written of their assigned objects so convincingly that I often found myself thinking that I should look up more information on one thing or another, but of course the chances are that they were just making things up. However, there were some fairly funny stories, such as the story Diminutions by Michael Moorcock, in which some men decide to bring the Gospel to germs, and to receive some extra funding:Bannister... persuaded the governors that, if a will to do evil motivated these microns, then the influence of the Christian religion was bound to have an influence for good. This meant, logically, that fewer boys would be in the infirmary and that, ultimately, shamed by the consequences of their actions, the germs causing, say, tuberculosis would cease to spread. [p. 169]I enjoyed the stories by Charles Yu and Garth Nix so much that I plan to look through their available works to find new books for my wishlist. So, yeah, I really enjoyed this one, too.If you are interested in this book, or if you read and enjoyed it, then you should check out the earlier anthology, The Thackery T. Lambshead Pocket Guide to Eccentric and Discredited Diseases (review linked here). And if you haven't read this one yet, definitely check it out; it's really fascinating and the stories are very well done.Disclosure: I bought this book for myself. All opinions are my own.Synopsis: The death of Dr. Thackery T. Lambshead in 2003 at his house in Wimpering-on-the-Brook, England, revealed an astonishing discovery: the remains of a remarkable cabinet of curiosities.A carefully selected group of popular artists and acclaimed, bestselling fantasy authors has been assembled to bring Dr. Lambsheads cabinet of curiosities to life. Including contributions from Alan Moore, Lev Grossman, Mike Mignola, China Miville, Cherie Priest, Carrie Vaughn, Greg Broadmore, Naomi Novik, Garth Nix, Michael Moorcock, Holly Black, Jeffrey Ford, Ted Chiang, and many more.

Book Info: Genre: Medical Guide Satire/Speculative fiction shortsReading Level: AdultRecommended for: Anyone who likes a laughMy Thoughts: If you want to know what sort of lunacy to expect from this book, here is just a tiny taste.Discussing Ballistic Organ Syndrome: In rare cases, the Ballistitis virus infects the patient's entire body. Eventually, some event causes one or more cells to rupture, after which the patient's body is disrupted in an explosive ejection of all bodily organs. This manifestation of the syndrome frequently occasions the death of the patient; at best, the loss of all bodily organs will cause considerable inconvenience and distress (as set out in Doctor Buckhead Mudthumper's Encyclopedia of Forgotten Oriental Diseases). [pg. 4]Letter to Dr. Wexler, of whom the writers are not fond: Dear Sir: Kindly send your anthrax-soaked missives elsewhere. And if you want to get serious about contagious letters, then invest in some smallpox like a normal person. [pg. 286]There are also a couple cookbooks mentioned that sound interesting: French Cuisine with Codeine and Mousses with Morphine.I will point out that I would not say this book is lavishly illustrated. Each entry generally has only a single illustration; sometimes there is a second at the end of the section. Now, The Thackery T. Lambshead Cabinet of Curiosities, which I'll be reading and reviewing next, does have a lot of pictures. But this one, not so much.Still, if you like a laugh, you'll enjoy the clever way each author creates a character for themselves, and the creative uses of real information mixed with their own creations that fill this satirical book. I enjoyed it a lot.Disclosure: I bought this book for myself. All opinions are my own.Synopsis: Imagine if Monty Python wrote the Mayo Clinic Family Health Book, and you sort of get the idea. Afraid youre afflicted with an unknown malady? Finally you have a place to turn! Book SenseYou hold in your hands the most complete and official guide to imaginary ailments ever assembledeach disease carefully documented by the most stellar collection of speculative fiction writers ever to play doctor. Detailed within for your reading and diagnostic pleasure are the frightening, ridiculous, and downright absurdly hilarious symptoms, histories, and possible cures to all the ills human flesh isnt heir to, including Ballistic Organ Disease, Delusions of Universal Grandeur, and Reverse Pinocchio Syndrome.Lavishly illustrated with cunning examples of everything that cant go wrong with you, the Lambshead Guide provides a healthy dose of good humor and relief for hypochondriacs, pessimists, and lovers of imaginative fiction everywhere. Even if you dont have Pentzlers Lubriciousness or Tian Shan-Gobi Assimilation, the cure for whatever seriousness may ail you is in this remarkable collection.

Wow, this smells amazing! I would love to have a full set of personal care products - shampoo, body wash, lotion, scent - in this scent. It's gorgeous. I like the pump action, which delivers the perfect amount of foam with a single pump. It feels light and airy on my skin, but when I've rinsed my face, my face feels clean and fresh without the dry feeling some facial cleaners have. This is a wonderful face cleanser. If you like something that will leave your face feeling fresh and clean and at the same time provides a treat for your nose, this is the product.

Book Info: Genre: Non-fiction, historical anecdotesReading Level: Any who can read it can learn some fun facts about RomeRecommended for: Anyone interested in learning fun and interesting facts about the RomansMy Thoughts: There are a number of quotes from the book in the synopsis, but I just have to add a few of my own that I found funny, such as:Romans on Dealing with Children:Pliny states, in Natural History, Putting goat dung in their diapers soothes hyperactive children, especially girls. [pg. 5]Romans on Solving Marital Discord:Livy reports that about 170 women from leading families were convicted in 331 B.C. of poisoning their husbands. Other sources give even larger numbers. [pg. 8]Romans' Preferred Animal to keep Watch:Marcus Manlius Capitolinus saved the Capitol from the Gauls in the early 4th century B.C. when he was alerted to their approach by the cackling of Juno's sacred geese. [pg. 19]Romans Naming Themselves:Caracalla [ruled A.D. 211217] called himself Germanicus after victories over the Germans, and it was said that he was mad enough and stupid enough to say that, had he conquered Lucania [a region in southern Italy], he would have claimed the title Lucanicus [which means not only Lucanian but also sausage]. (Historia Augusta Life of Caracalla 5). [pg. 21]Romans on Successful Grape Cultivation:Vines should be freed for a few days from the trees to which they were attached, and allowed to wander and spread themselves, and lie on the ground they have gazed at for the whole year. Just as cattle released from the yoke and the dogs after a hunt enjoy rolling about, so vines also like to stretch their lumbar regions. (Pliny Natural History 17.209) [p. 60]Romans on Useful Medical Treatments:Touching the nostrils of a she-mule with one's lips is said to stop sneezing and hiccups (Pliny Natural History 28.57).Sexual intercourse is good for lower back pain, for weakness of the eyes, for derangement, and for depression (Pliny Natural History 28.58). [p. 73]Romans on Proper Disposition of Criminals:A justification for vivisection: It is not cruel, as most people maintain, that remedies for innocent people's ailments in all future ages should be sought through the sufferings of just a few criminals (Celsus On Medicine Proem 26). [p. 77]Romans on Making Friends Through Diplomacy:Cats were regarded as sacred in Egypt. In the mid-1st century B.C., the historian Diodorus Siculus was an eyewitness when an Egyptian mob lynched a member of a Roman embassy who had accidentally killed a cat (The Library 1.83). [p. 121]Romans on Treating Alcoholism:People who drink wine in which eels have been drowned lose their appetite for drinking wine (St. Isidore Etymologies 12.6.41). [p. 151]Roman Graffiti:Apollinaris medicus Titi Imp. hic cacavit bene (Apollinaris, physician to the emperor Titus, had a fine s*** here) (Corpus of Latin Inscriptions 4.10619, a graffito in the Casa della Gemma in Herculaneum). [pg 186]Romans on being Scrooge McDuck:By the end, Caligula had developed a passion for handling money; he would often walk barefoot over huge heaps of gold coin poured out in a large open space, and sometimes he even lay down and wallowed in them (Suetonius, Life of Caligula 42). [pg. 217]If that isn't enough to pique your interest in this very entertaining book, then just consider the sorts of interesting things you might learn! Because this book is filled with stuff like I've given above, and the author has provided below. I highly recommend this book, and plan to seek out his other book about the Greeks.Disclosure: This book was a gift from a friend. All opinions are my own.Synopsis: Here is a whimsical and captivating collection of odd facts, strange beliefs, outlandish opinions, and other highly amusing trivia of the ancient Romans. We tend to think of the Romans as a pragmatic people with a ruthlessly efficient army, an exemplary legal system, and a precise and elegant language. A Cabinet of Roman Curiosities shows that the Romans were equally capable of bizarre superstitions, logic-defying customs, and often hilariously derisive views of their fellow Romans and non-Romans.Classicist J. C. McKeown has organized the entries in this entertaining volume around major themesThe Army, Women, Religion and Superstition, Family Life, Medicine, Slaves, Spectaclesallowing for quick browsing or more deliberate consumption. Among the book's many gems are:Romans on urban living:The satirist Juvenal lists "fires, falling buildings, and poets reciting in August as hazards to life in Rome."On enhanced interrogation:"If we are obliged to take evidence from an arena-fighter or some other such person, his testimony is not to be believed unless given under torture." (Justinian)On dreams:Dreaming of eating books "foretells advantage to teachers, lecturers, and anyone who earns his livelihood from books, but for everyone else it means sudden death"On food:"When people unwittingly eat human flesh, served by unscrupulous restaurant owners and other such people, the similarity to pork is often noted." (Galen)On marriage:In ancient Rome a marriage could be arranged even when the parties were absent, so long as they knew of the arrangement, "or agreed to it subsequently."On health care:Pliny caustically described medical bills as a "down payment on death," and Martial quipped that "Diaulus used to be a doctor, now he's a mortician. He does as a mortician what he did as a doctor."For anyone seeking an inglorious glimpse at the underside of the greatest empire in history, A Cabinet of Roman Curiosities offers endless delights.

Book Info: Genre: Literary fictionReading Level: AdultRecommended for: those who liked the movie, those who like very violent stories that are twistyTrigger Warnings: violence, those with arachnophobia beware, making soap out of human collagen, murder, suicidal ideationMy Thoughts: One of the keywords used to describe this book is nihilism. I think this is particularly appropriate. Over and over the narrator repeats things like, Maybe self-improvement isn't the answer... Maybe self-destruction is the answer. Or, At the time, my life just seemed too complete, and maybe we have to break everything to make something better out of ourselves. Or, It's only after you've lost everything... that you're free to do anything. It reminds me of a line in a GWAR song: Sometimes you have to burn everything down so you can have nothing at all.I felt I could finally get my hands on everything in the world that didn't work... Nothing was solved when the fighting was over, but nothing mattered.Me, with my punched-out eyes and dried blood in big black crusty stains on my pants, I'm saying HELLO to everybody at work. HELLO! Look at me. HELLO! I am so ZEN. This is BLOOD. This is NOTHING. Hello. Everything is nothing and it's so cool to be ENLIGHTENED. Like me.So, as you can see it is not a subtle message, but indeed one that is pounded into the reader over and over, like punches in the face. It's actually rather brilliant, but ultimately depressing if you take it too much to heart. There is much discourse over the ultimate meaning of this book. To put it out there, I think this book is about modern man's search for his place in the world. Men evolved to hunt and fight, and nowadays are more likely to be hunting for a paperclip and fighting for a good parking spot. It has left them at loose ends (thus the wars), and this book is about men seeking a way to turn the tide back to the times when they were providing more meaningful services to humanity.I've read a few books by Chuck Palahniuk and enjoyed them all, but this one is the best. Which is ironic, since it's also the first book he had published. I've talked to a lot of people who say his earlier work, such as this book, is brilliant, but that it loses a lot of that brilliance in later books. After having read this one, and considering the other books I've read by him, I can see where that comes from. I should re-read those books and see what I think now, if I can find my copies! Anyway, if you saw and liked the movie, or if you like books that will seriously twist your brain, then check this book out. It's a mind-warper.Disclosure: This book was a gift from a friend. All opinions are my own.Synopsis: The first rule about fight club is you don't talk about fight club.In his debut novel, Chuck Palahniuk showed himself to be his generation's most visionary satirist. Fight Club's estranged narrator leaves his lackluster job when he comes under the thrall of Tyler Durden, an enigmatic young man who holds secret boxing matches in the basement of bars. There two men fight "as long as they have to." A gloriously original work that exposes what is at the core of our modern world.
Madeline Ash writes sweet, human, likable characters. I've enjoyed everything I've read by her.If you haven't done so already, but " Uncovered by Live" - I REALLY, REALLY liked that one.

I found the book tedious. I felt it could have had at least 100 pages trimmed. Plot elements eliminated. Etc. it seemed forced, contrived and boring. And I'm NOT referring to the information about flowers. I enjoyed that. The rest - meh. An angsty teen story pretending to be literature.

I was hoping for a funny, light read. I didn't find that in this title. I found the characters unlikeable. The three stars is for an interesting plot. I learned a lot about social class in Regency London - people with money, people with titles but penniless, the race class, and servants.Interesting. I wish the main players had better personalities.I will probably read book two. Maybe. Maybe not. Would I recommend this title to another reader? No, probably not.

I was worried I'd look a little like Barney in this dress. I wear a size ten and am short, 5'1". I ordered an XL and it fits well.The top two snaps are designed to be left undone. If you close them, the fabric puckers.It's a casual dress. Nice for work. You may want to add a colorful scarf to break up all the purple.

Red Heart Shimmer Ivory - I originally purchased this yarn to make a baptism sweater for a vintage baby dress. The color says "vintage." I changed my mind and decided to make a wedding shawl. Please note that your skein may look different than mine based on when and where it was purchased. I bought mine March 2015 in Minnesota.This is worsted weight 4 - approximately 280 yards per skein.The strand of shimmer is a thread, not glitter. So you won't have to worry about it falling off or getting all over your outfit.The shimmer thread in the ivory skein is subtle and will probably not show up well in photos. In person, it's so nice.The thread is also opal-like. Subtle lime green, pink and gold. Think of an opal stone.I will try this again in white and black. So beautiful.

My husband picked these up for our teenage son. He lost a bit of weight after a case if the flu. We've tried other ensure drinks when he was younger and he didn't like them. I thought a punch variety would be good. I was disappointed to see this beverage contains artificial sweetener. And sugar is one of the first ingredients. Puzzling.A cup of milk has 8 grams of protein. My son can drink milk so we will stay with that for less money.Why not make a variety out of 100 % real juice. No sugar? No artficial sweetener? Add a bit more protein?My son also said this drink has a horrible aftertaste.A miss for us. We won't be buying these again.

Funny, cute but the characters were overdone. The stereotypes became old after all while. I'm giving it four stars because it held my curiosity. I wanted to keep reading to see what kind of trouble Sophy would stir up next.

This is the fourth book in a series. There is no need to read the first three. I haven't - but I want to after finishing this one.Thank you NetGalley and the Publisher for the review copy of this book.What a unique, fun and charming group of people. I felt as if I knew them all personally by the end of the story.I will admit, the mystery took a backseat some of the time. There was also A LOT going on in this story. Many, many characters - it wasn't confusing. It felt slightly cluttered.** But I probably felt that way because I wanted to spend more time with each of them. Such fun writing and detail.If you enjoy a good clean story, a whodunit, along with some laughs and romance - pick this one up. I recommend it.

0:49 MinsIf you need a gift for a little girl, consider this cat watch. It's funny and cute. Keep in mind, it's LARGE. The face is bigger than a quarter. It will be quite big on the wrist of a little girl - very big - but I think she'll still love it.

0:49 MinsIf you need a gift for a little girl, consider this cat watch. It's funny and cute. Keep in mind, it's LARGE. The face is bigger than a quarter. It will be quite big on the wrist of a little girl - very big - but I think she'll still love it.
I have an Etsy shop and love this app. You are able to see stats easily. A fast way to look around the website.Great - and free!

What a fun, quick read. Madeline Ash has the knack of writing very likable characters - even the side characters. All fun and sweet.Thanks to NetGalley and the publisher for a complimentary ARC of this title.This short book is a perfect choice for a vacation. Sexy, but not overdone at all. If you love tension and flirting, this is the story for you.

Sarah and Nina Grimke - truly inspiring women. In a time when society ladies went to school to learn to be a good and respectable wife, they stood up for their religious beliefs and moral convictions. On top of this, they were female. Time after time they were told they couldn't, shouldn't, would never make a difference - or even have an opportunity to try!! Yet they carried on.Handful and Charlotte - more amazing, strong clear voices. Unwavering in what was truly inside their soles.Brave, inspiring women. Thank you Sue Monk Kidd for bringing their story to life.
Very interesting. A look back into early forensic science and murder investigations. Parts are dramatized, but not overdone or cheesy. I loved it.

Descriptive, eerie, spooky read. I liked this very much. It was similar - kind of - to The Willows also by Blackwood. Either one would make a fun 'read-out-loud' story around a campfire. It may take you a few nights, but well worth it!! I wish there had been more time with or detail of the creature though. One small drawback.

A yummy morning treat. It's good on its own with just milk. You can also add lots of ice. Either way - awesome.The powder takes a while to dissolve and you'll need to stir again when half done to get the bits that have settled on the bottom.Love it. I will buy more.

This is my second Barrymore Tebbs book. After finishing this one, I know I will be back for more.The story reminded me of the original Twillight Zone TV series. Haunting, original, a slow build of fear and freaky goodness. A puzzle that gives you chills. Quite good.I took off a star because I was distracted by the vagueness of the time period. 60s, 70s ? I believe at the end we learn it's 1975.

0:48 MinsBernat Softee Baby yarn is just that - super soft and perfect for babies. I've purchased Prince Pebbles yarn on two occasions from a local craft store. I have to admit, the second time purchasing, the teal and gray were much more subtle. So be prepared for the color to vary. Buy more than enough skeins for your project. I loved it both times, I was just surprised at the lighter skein the second time.The skein I bought recently states:120 grams, 4.25 ouncesWeight = 3, lightMachine wash and dry.100% acrylicApproximately 283 m or 310 yards.This looks very nice on its own or worked with two strands of yarn at once - Prince Pebbles and white or Prince Pebbles and a soft gray. Lovely colors blended together.The video is just the Bernat Prince Pebbles - not blended with another color. The top portion of the sweater is DC and the bottom is alternating DC, SC across. The next row down, I put a SC stitch on top of a DC - DC on a SC. It gives it a tighter weave and looks interesting.As you can see, I have a lot of yarn left after making this 3 to 6 month baby sweater. The skein sitting there is what I have left over. I might get a newborn size sweater out of what is remaining - especially if I make the sweater in all DC rows. The DC/SC rows use more yarn due to the tighter weave.Since the yarn is so soft, you may encounter splitting - not a lot, just every once in a while. I was not bothered by it.Buy it. Buy extra. Prince Pebbles makes eye catching baby items. I've received many compliments on my baby sweaters.

0:45 MinsI  purchased this Bernat Coordinates Posy Patch yarn from a local craft store. It is amazingly soft and bright. It reminds me of confetti or an angel food cake. Baby clown colors! So festive.The video shows the labelWeight = 3, lightYards = 392Material = Acrylic, Rayon, and NylonThe baby sweater is two strands of yarn at once: Posy Patch and an off white, I believe I used Caron Simply Soft. The smaller piece shows what Posy Patch looks like on its own. The bottom section is DC rows and the top is SC.As you can see, I have plenty left over for a second baby sweater.I will buy this again and hope Bernat brings it out in more colors.

Two thumbs up!! (Because I think it would be a fun movie) This story starts out quick. There is instant fear due to a missing person. The feeling grabs on and doesn't let go for the entire ebook.How can you describe darkness? Curran succeeds in beautiful descriptions of the atmosphere using all the other senses. Sound, and even smells. "perfectly black". Ooooh - loved it.Thank you DarkFuse and NetGalley for the ARC of this ebook.The building of fear is accompanied by a slow destruction of everything around Jon. I enjoyed the additional characters - his neighbors' personalities and reactions. Iris, the crazy political guy, Billy, and Bonnie. It all made for a rich, tight, wonderfully scary novella! Bravo!!

I bought this Sugar and Cream cotton yarn at a local craft store because I loved the colors. Once I got it home I caught a whiff of it. Eeew. I had no idea this was a scented product.Why ruin a beautiful yarn with this nasty scent? It smells like 20 year old cheap perfume. It literally makes my eyes itch.LOVE the colors. It looks great with bright white. I used it as a trim on baby washcloths.Lovely colors - horrible, pungent scent.

This review refers to the product and not the price or seller. I was quite disappointed with this red velvet cake. They have a slightly bitter, chemical flavor. Not good. I will not be buying these again.

This anthology was published in 1921 by Mary Cholmondeley. She is better known for her novel "Red Pottage."  There are eight unrelated shorts in this book. I'll admit I didn't care for most of them. The best part is actually the forward. Cholmondeley tells us of the cottage she lives in and a memorable experience she had during a war. Quite beautifully done. I wish an entire novel had been written on those subjects. It reminded me of Elizabeth Von Armin's "Elizabeth and Her German Garden." But unfortunately the short stories were not anywhere near as good as the opening pages. If anything, download this title and just read those. Three stars for the intro - two stars for the shorts.

Another great romance from Madeline Ash! If you like stories with heart, emotion, and intense longing... Pick this one up. The setting, characters, and back story are all top notch. So well done.I received an ARC of this title in exchange for an honest review.Once you've read this one be sure to look up "Uncovered by Love"Madeline Ash is on my watch list! Write more please!

Three stars does not mean this story was bad... I liked what was there. Menace was the second title by Gary Fry that I've read. I enjoyed them both. Lurker was my first - a good read. Go look that one up.Menace has an interesting overall concept - one that was revealed a smidge too far into the book for my taste. I wanted to have more time with creepy kids, plotting family members, spooky old mansions, etc. I enjoy novellas - this one needed more scare and action, less build-up.I enjoy Fry's writing style and hope to read more of his work. He'd be great at mysteries. I hope he tries that soon.I received this title from Dark Fuse via NetGalley. Thank you!

... But I started to skim at 60%... then stopped reading altogether around 65%. It became too weird, fast, a tumble of actions, story ideas, backstory, etc. The writing seemed very, very rushed.  I'll give it three stars because I liked the first 45%.

Doom Castle... Copyright 1900 by Doubleday, Page & Co.Topic - Spies, Scottish Highlands.Free Project Gutenberg title.Nope - couldn't make it beyond 12%. Too many references to people, places, and things I didn't know a thing about. Too many foreign phrases that weren't translated. Too many obscure words. Sorry - I gave up on this one. I'm giving it two stars because there were nice sprinklings of humor here and there.

This review refers to the free kindle ebook.Let's discuss - at great boring length - all the philosophical, religious, moral, social, magical, hypnotic, blah blah blah aspects of life and death. Were all these higher levels of discussions used... I have no idea! I was so bored I skimmed.There is an interesting ghost story buried in all the mumbo jumbo. Feel free to dig for it if you like. But don't say I didn't warn you to skip this one.

I was quite intrigued to see how the author would reshape an old classic. Turn it from ghostly characters to one using immortal vampires. I was not disappointed. Ms Eden can write paranormal stories with great action and drama. I've read other titles by her and they are all consistently good.Thank you NetGalley and Cynthia Eden for the review copy of this ebook.The storyline flows well. It fit nicely into a novella length, but at the same time didn't leave me questioning areas or feeling rushed.If you like snarky, sexy bad boys, a steamy scene or two, great action, and just the right amount of suspense, then give this story a try. Actually, pick up any of Cynthia Eden's work.

I received a complimentary copy of this book via Goodreads giveaways.Such a unique and quirky story. Each character was vivid and special in their own way - some I liked, some not so much... But that was the beauty of the writing.I found myself laughing at things I shouldn't. Wishing for encounters and breakthroughs. I wanted everyone to have a happy ending right from the start.And Johnny Depp.... Louise needs to be played by Johnny Depp if a movie is ever filmed.I plan to suggest this title to my book club. I'm sure it will bring LOTS of discussion.

This short novella follows Daniel, his friends, and family. The tension was present from the beginning and had me turning pages.Thank you NetGalley and Dark Fuse Press for the review copy of this ebook.I enjoy stories that are haunting and creepy. This one fit the bill. No gore. The story would have been even better if I knew more about the characters. It's easier to worry about people you "know."There was a nice blending of past and present. Well done. I'm not sure I understood the ending - but I'm ok with that. Left me wondering and guessing after the story was over. Nice.

Wow  I was in the mood for a good historical romance and I found a GREAT one in The Illicit Love of a Courtesan.So many positive aspects to this book  a new (to me) historical arena  courtesans. I knew nothing of this world or of their place in history. I was pleased to learn about it from an inside and emotional point of view.The setting  Jane Lark can paint a scene! We are shown many, many settings and all of them were vivid without being wordy. That is my favorite part of period novels. This book was a wonderful trip into other worlds.The characters - I found myself instantly reacting to all the people in the story: the trapped heroine, the sweet little boy, the bad guys you want to boo and hiss at (or punch). So well done.There is a lot of tension in this story. You will find yourself turning pages just to see what happens next. The storyline is varied and changes  in a good way. I enjoyed it so much! Im also glad their is a book two waiting  The Passionate Love of a Rake.

If you are in the mood for a lighthearted story, then I suggest Be Careful, Its My Heart.This was a fun, quick read  but not so quick that it felt rushed. The characters were charming and the plot fun. Kait Nolan has a wonderful skill of writing tension. This kept me turning pages.The town of Wishful, Mississippi is a great setting. I certainly hope Ms Nolan continues this series. My only critique is, I hoped for more atmosphere and mood from the small town setting  more physical description. I think I want this because I know I will love the scene Kait will paint.If youve read any of the short novels from the Harlequin Kiss line of books, you will LOVE this title.Im eager to read more.

On Goodreads and Amazon, at the time of this review, this title is labelled as a cozy mystery. I feel it is not that at all. There is a mystery in the plot, but the story leans more toward literary fiction or women's fiction.I found the setting and characters vivid and charming. The backstory of Beth and Kenny, deep and somewhat sad. I was pulling for them... pulling for Katherine, Mr. Thompson and the others. So many people in this story needed a happy ending.Was it a tear-jerker? No. It is a complex, heartfelt saga involving many families. Many generations. I enjoyed this very much.

This is a nice, quick novella. You will find a pleasant setting, likable characters, and sexy scenes.Thank you NetGalley and Entangled Press for the review copy of this title.Even though I found this ebook an enjoyable read, it was somewhat plain. It was nice, fine, OK. Nothing very memorable. It didn't need to be longer, it just needed more spark.I think this author has talent. She just needs to push things further, deeper

Meg and Harry have moved to a quiet coastal town. It is lonely, cold, and sad... just like their marriage. Meg has quit her job and spends long days by herself.Thank you NetGalley and Dark Fuse Press for this title.What I liked most about this novella was the steady build of fear, paranoia, and panic. The atmosphere surrounds meg and closes in on her. So creepy and well done.At times it was a little slow, but the details were all a part of the story. Is it truly happening? Is it Meg's imagination? What the heck is outside her window!?A great short piece. I will definitely look for more by this author. His writing gave me the creeps!

This is a calm, easy going story about people daring to go after what they want. I say "calm" because it is a gentle and sometimes slow story. Sprinkled throughout are touches of Stella Gibbons' great humor. I didn't want to miss those - but at times the action was so slow I was tempted to skim.We are presented with various groups of people: 1) The ones who always do what they should, follow standard, act appropriately. 2) People who dare to cross the lines of society and challenge norms, people who do what they want regardless of the consequences. 3) the peripheral characters who are caught in the crossfireThis is an easy going story with touches of Gibbons' dry wit. If you'd like to read a title with that humor in the forefront, read Cold Comfort Farm. Both books are good, it just depends what you're looking for.

0:40 MinsThis yarn is fine, bright and very pretty. I like it so much.The small work is four rows of SC and three rows of DC using a G sized hook. My sisters say I crochet loosely. The "L" work is two outer rows of the Miami yarn in SC. The inner yarn is SC and puff stitch using Caron soft white.While creating these pieces I did not encounter any splitting.I like the slight shine to the Miami yarn. It's perfect for hats, sweaters and mittens.Lovely.

I love it when an author can take a simple idea or an everyday setting and make it frightening. Two men are canoeing and stop on a small island to rest for the night...no problem, right?The author brings to life the surroundings, elements, and nature in a beautifully scary way. So well done.

I enjoy this cinnamon flavored tea. It is sweet without adding sugar.This is very good hot or served cold over ice. Even when diluted, the spicy flavor comes through.One problem - the bags can unfold slightly causing the leaves to escape. You need to be gentle with the bag. Perhaps I received a defective batch.I will continue to buy. Great tea.

This short story was nicely done. I was definitely creeped-out in a few spots.The concept was one I had never heard before - Necroforms. EeeewI felt it could have been better if I felt a connection to James and Liz first - before all the creepy occurrences. I was told about them, not shown. Plus James was kind of a jerk.Scary, tense scenes. I liked it.
This product is disappointing. The scent is so slight, I can barely smell it. I have to lean in.  I wouldn't even call it subtle...I will try another brand.

Three words - beardy, hot, stud. Yep. Yummy.Penny Watson paints one sexy dude. The bedroom "action scenes" are sure to get you hot and bothered.Another plus - if you like reading stories with: adorable youngsters, slobbery dogs, and quirky townsfolk, then "Lumberjack in Love" is a perfect pick.I will read more by Penny Watson.  Thank you for the awesome read!

What a lovely and heartfelt story.I really enjoyed Abby, Brant and their unusual family. The characters are all sweet and likable.There are a few sex scenes - so keep that in mind. It was all well done. I found myself teary-eyed more than once.I'm looking forward to more from this author.

I enjoyed this author's writing style. The ebook description now states it is a prequel to a full novel... It ends at 68%. I wonder if the full length story takes things slower. Paige and Mateo pounce on each other a little too quickly for my liking.

If you are looking for a nice, easy romance, then this is your book. I found it sweet and fun - predictable, but a good quick read. It is also a clean romance with very little swearing and no sex.A perfect fast read in between longer, heavier titles.

0:48 MinsI was looking for another everyday bracelet and came across this one. I wasn't buying it particularly for the magnetic qualities - I just liked the look of it.It is solid-feeling and has a nice weight to it. It doesn't feel plastic or cheap. The stones are bright and pretty.The clasp is a bit tough to open, but I assume it will loosen up with use.I also was surprised by the prominent cooper color. I did order this style but it appears much more cooper compared to the image. It is all over copper in color, not just hints of it. But... still a nice bracelet. Instead of wearing it with black tops, I will pair it with browns and reds.

I thoroughly enjoyed this short ebook. I giggled and chuckled all the way through - I even cringed in a few spots.Jonathan is lovable and the story such fun. A few parts were over the top, but that was part of the charm.I may have gotten a little misty-eyed at the end.This story would make a great TV movie.

0:48 MinsI was looking for another everyday bracelet and came across this one. I wasn't buying it particularly for the magnetic qualities - I just liked the look of it.It is solid-feeling and has a nice weight to it. It doesn't feel plastic or cheap. The stones are bright and pretty.The clasp is a bit tough to open, but I assume it will loosen up with use.I also was surprised by the prominent cooper color. I did order this style but it appears much more cooper compared to the image. It is all over copper in color, not just hints of it. But... still a nice bracelet. Instead of wearing it with black tops, I will pair it with browns and reds.

I enjoyed this story immensely. What could be better than a story about a boy (teen, actually) and a dog? Thank you NetGalley and Scholastic for the review copy of Rotten.Teen males looking for a book - here you go.Jimmer is a likable character and Johnny Rotten is a fantastic dog - misunderstood, but a character readers will want to cheer for.One aspect I loved about this title, once finished I didn't feel emotionally drained or beat up. The scenes, families, and school segments are all believable and in no way over the top.Students will turn pages quickly in order to find out how the story ends. I feel there are many themes that would work well for book reports. None of it was dull though - a great story. I've already recommended it to a few teen readers.Web resources put this title at a Lexile Measurement of 670L.

I am told that LED lights use on 10% of the energy of an iridescent bulb so this light was a no brainier.  I installed it into my daisy chain of 12v lighting.  50w equivalent in LED is very bright.  Looks great and this light doesn't have the glass lense that is needed to protect a iridescent bulb.  Burns much cooler, too!

This stuff seems to dry faster than the JB Stick - which is both good and bad.  Once you have mixed it in your hands, you have about5 minutes or so to shape it before it starts to hardens so I try and use 1/2 - 1 inch "slices" of the roll - unless I obviously need a bigger piece for one project.  Better to go with smaller pieces for multiple locations so that you don't end up wasting it if it hardens too soon.  I use it for all kinds of stuff.  Adheres to just about anything including metal, plastic, wood, etc.

These work gloves are tough and are designed, like all of Dickies stuff, for good old-fashion physical labor.  They should keep your hands reasonably warm in the winter months are well as they are a thick thermal design.

These are amazing little bulbs that are much brighter than I expected. See how well the light up a stone staircase on the side of our house. Since I have only had them a short time, I cannot comment on their longevity. But, they produce little heat and I assume that they take only a fraction of the energy of a traditional bulb. You can also get by on a smaller transformer.

Awesome.  Replaced all of my old landscape half-moon lighting sockets with these bases and used these LED bulbs: Mudder 6pcs Set G4 48-LED Warm White Light Crystal Bulb Lamps 3 Watt AC DC 12V Non-dimmable Equivalent to 20W Incandescent Bulb Replacement LED Bulbs

These earbuds sound pretty darn good for the price.  See the photo as I modified them to actually fit in my ear canal with this product Slic Sound - Transform the Performance of In-ear Headphones and secured (glued) the Slics with this product http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B003S2E4UE
Nice sharp blade.  Cuts through pizza crust easily with little effort and efficiently.  Simple rock the blade back and forth a couple times and the pieces separate without tearing.
Great, high quality gasket.  I replaced the thin, flimsy ones that came with my outdoor lights.  These are much thicker and will repel water/rain.

These screws are pretty good.  There are a couple of disadvantages of nylon screws: 1) The Phillips slots are soft and prone to disfigure if you over tighten.  2) The stems snap off the head pretty easily if you over-tighten.
Great for Dog's breath.  I have stayed away from adding it to water though because other have said that their dogs have drank Let.

The case is slightly soft and a little bit rubbery.  This helps prevent scratches - especially on a clear case.  The mint green bumper looks very classy on it.  I did have a problem with some of my earphone jacks not being able to plug in fully.  To counter this, I bought Josi Minea x 3 Pcs 3.5mm Audio Jack Extender Headphone Adapter with Gold Plated 4-Pole 3.5mm Connectors (3 Ring Jack) for Apple iPhone 6 / 6 Plus / 5S / 5C / 5 4S, iPad Air / Mini, Samsung Galaxy S6 / S5 / S4 / S3, Note 4 / 3 Nexus 4, HTC One, Nokia Lumia & most other Smartphones & Tablets [ 3 Pack ]  So the only thing I can suggest on an improvement is to allow more room around the earphone and charging jack.  So minus 1 star for that.

These loops are great for staying in your ear.  However, the  speaker ends are round and to big to fit into your ear canal.  They just kinda fit over the ear canal.  To counter this, I ended up fitting them with Slic Sound - Transform the Performance of In-ear Headphones.  For music, they are not bad - but definitely not audiophile quality.  They are great for spoken word like YouTube videos, audio books, etc.

These are nice storage containers for a variety of different objects - screws, sugar, cookies, etc.  The lids will come off without pressing the button if the contents are heavy enough and you are gripping the container only by the lid.  They do not appear to be an air-tight fit.

Great for a listening party or for simply sharing audio on a plane with your companion.  My wife and I do this listen to movies on my iPad while on a flight.  The adapter is solidly made, looks cool, and can handle FIVE inputs simultaneously.  The only drawback is that the device controls the audio volume for all plugged in earbuds.  But, for this economical price, one wouldn't expect individual volume adjustments.

I like it a lot.  The only question is will your case allow it to sit on the protruding lightning prong.  My wife's Otterbox case would not.  But it works great with my iPod Touch that I do not have in a case.

I spent a half hour messing with the configuration on this and I could never get it to revert to my regular SSID names.  This isn't that useful as auto-configured because it puts and _EXT on the end of the regular SSID name and you cannot seamlessly.  In terms of the extra range it provides it is great.  But in terms of its ease of modifying the SSID name, it is much more difficult than the Netgear AC1200 Wi-Fi Range Extender Dual Band Gigabit (EX6150-100NAS)

I have been a huge fan of Burberry London in the past.  But, Burberry Brit surpasses this with its crisp, "clean", spring scent.  the 3.3 ounce bottle is huge and will last a few years with daily use.  The spray top is a must as you don't waste any or get it all over your hands.  The smoke tinted translucent bottle is classy and blends into your bathroom counter.

Nice Product, with great accessory package.  Vacuum is nicely weighted and has powerful pick-up, on carpet as well as bare floors.  Double filtration system is easy to access and keeps dirt and particles inside the canister.  Canister snaps on and off for easy emptying.  Hose bypass is equally as powerful and there is an appropriate accessory for most clean-up jobs.  The vacuum head does swivel which is helpful working around certain areas, but can cause awkward maneuvering when just wanting to make long clean passes over a large area.  Only improvement would be the addition of a locking feature which would facilitate use in larger unobstructed areas, otherwise we are completely pleased with this product.

Stryper has created 12 new songs that sound remarkably different than NMHTP from 2 years ago.  "Yaweh" is simply Epic and a no-brainer for an opening track.  In general, the quality of their last four offerings: Second Coming, The Covering, NMHTP, and now, Fallen are amazing. While many other bands show their age (after 30 years), Stryper has plenty of gas left in the tank.  Special Thanks! to Frontier Records for signing them and giving them enough of a budget to deliver a wonderful product - including the artwork.

While this stool (more so than a ladder) is good.  Rubbermaid has a similar product that is about the same price and is even better.  Rubbermaid RM-SLA3-T 3-Step Ultra Light Aluminum Step Stool with Project Tray, 225-Pound Capacity, Grey Finish is about the same height and also has a nice shelf for holding things like paint cans & tools.  The tradeoff is it isn't as light.  But the shelf ladder, is not all that heavy.  Decide what is best for you.

I buy this monthly planner annually for my elderly mom that likes to write her appointments down rather than put them on a computer or phone.  The bungee cord has a good amount of tension that keeps the planner closed.  The boxes for each of the 30/31 days are approximately 2x2 inches - which is a nice size for writing while giving the user the whole month to view on a centerfold (two pages).  All in all, very pleased with this planner.
Good looking inexpensive,casual shirt.  Looks just like the photo and fits as expected.  Can't go wrong for under $20.
Good looking inexpensive,casual shirt.  Looks just like the photo and fits as expected.  Can't go wrong for under $20.

The locks are a great improvement over the original S-Biners as I had my cellphone case, keys, etc. unlatch from the older version hooks (without the locks).  The new version's locks slide easy enough with just the right amount of tension.  I have used it for a week without an hassles.  I feel a lot safer now.  The slides will probably wear down after a while with use, but they are not expensive to replace.

Solid Quality Boost Seat that is easy to install and remove and should last for many years.  It is great that seat can accompany such a wide range of weight.  This means that it won't become too small in a year or two.

This is a really great holster for the price.  It fits my Note 5 perfectly that has a Verus case on it.  I added a S-Biner (Climbers Hook with Lock) Nite Ize LSB4-01-R3 S-Biner Slide Lock, Black and now I can carry it on my belt loop.  See the accompanying photo.

I love these snack assortments but I, have to subtract 1 star for the price as it is hard to believe that chocolates and nuts, in a canister smaller than a basketball, costs $40.  Enough said on that.  The Hershey's are the typical taste and quality of the regular candy bars.  The nuts are salted and the little packages are about 280 calories.  So, be careful!  lol  We intend to use them as a premium treat for Halloween Trick-or-Treaters.
