They are perfect for providing a unique treat that will make you stand out as the go-to house in the neighborhood.

I set the app up on my iPad and it is very easy to use.  You do not even need to "open" the app.  As long as I have my Bluetooth connection established, I simply get on the scale each morning and the weight automatically gets sent to my iPad.  I have another scale that I placed side-by-side with this one for a "second opinion."  And the results match down to the tenth of a pound so I would say that this scale is very accurate, too.

Quality product that appears fresh.  I digested it easily without any unpleasant burping taste later.  I did not see any significant weight loss supplementation as some have claimed to experience.  Nevertheless, this is a good product to be taking as an Omega 6 source.

I originally ordered this case as a bridge for my brand-new Note 5 until the Verus case was in stock because it was economically.  To my surprise it is actually a good-looking, protective case.  The clear is practically invisible from any distance and really shows off the Note 5 itself.  The material has a rubbery feel and is slightly soft - which is to its advantage as it will not be as scratch-prone as a harder, plastic surface.  You cannot go wrong with this case at a very economical price.

This is a great, sturdy roller comparable to the EPE Black High Density Foam Roller - 6" x 18", Round, 1.9 lbs per cubic foot  Being an AmazonBasic, I expected there to be a cost savings over the competition, but only slightly so.  Perhaps the Amazon version is keeping the competitions' prices down, too. Great for ab workouts and provides leverage and comfort for a variety of on-your-back exercises.

While the ceramic blade will last a lot longer, it is not as sharp as a blade and the tip is rounded (which is a plus for safety, but a minus if you need a sharp point).  The 3 positions are very limiting compared to a blade.  The longest position only protrudes 1/2 inch at best.Update 9/29/2015: After using this cutter for a while, I have added a star.  I have found that the fact that it isn't as sharp as a razor blade comes in handy much more often than I first thought it would.  It is more like a retractable letter opener with a sharper edge.  Great for cutting tape, etc.  I keep it with a can of pens on my desk and I am surprised at how many times I have gone back to it.

Does the job.  Incredibly over-priced.  It is just a piece of foam. Looks incredibly cheap while covering up the gorgeous screen on my Blue mic.  Here is another item that is highly rated at a fraction of the price.On Stage Foam Ball-Type Mic Windscreen, Black

I just got this book and the break-down of "Eruption" by itself is worth the price of admission.  The book comes with a code where you can go online and download the accompanying audio files.  The songs are broken up into 4 or 5 pieces on the audio files to aid with learning particular sections.  The pieces are played at both normal speed and at 1/2 to1/4 speed so that an intermediate can keep up.  These transcriptions are the real deal and even "Eruption" is manageable at the slow-demo speed for most intermediate players.  The only downside to this product is that whole songs with backing tracks are not offered like with other Hal Leonard PLay-Along series publications like Van Halen 1978-1984: Guitar Play-Along Volume 50 (Hal Leonard Guitar Play-Along)  I originally subtracted 1 star for not have the full length backing tracks, but decided not to as the author of this product probably had no control over this aspect.You may wish to invest in a piece of music tempo software so that you can gradually increase the rpms of the tracks.  I use Song Surgeon 4 (just google it) and I love it.  There are also some cheaper alternatives that aren't quite as snazzy like Amazing Slowdowner.

I didn't order these for the "coach" function rather for a non-corded way to listen to tunes while working out at the gym.  The buds stay in the ears and are comfortable.  There are many size accessories included to fit different sized ears.  The sound is very good, but the low end bass is wanting.  Also, the volume isn't particularly loud - especially if you are in a noisy place like a gym or airplane.

do not like beets and I do not like the taste of this stuff either. But, I WANT the benefits. So, I invested $25 in a capsule making machine that I bought on Amazon. It is definitely cost beneficial to make your own capsules as opposed to buying them. And, I don't have to taste any beets to boot! The nitric oxide that comes from beets will dilate your blood vessels - and studies show that it can even repair arteries containing plaque. The NO2 peaks about 2 hours after ingesting the capsules for me. Now about this product, I think it works great and I like the idea of buying a brand name and not some generic stuff in a baggy. Beet Juice does stain, so watch out if you are making capsules. Cranberry juice will also mask the taste somewhat.
High Quality light that should last many growing seasons.  Fits perfectly in any standard lamp socket.

Purchased these bags for my wife prior who is an avid quilter with 3 sewing machines.  She loves these bags, the large bag comfortable fits either of her Pfaff 6250 or Pfaff 7560 with the machine covers on and leaves space on either side of the machine for addition project items and smaller cutting mats/rulers and supplies in either the front or rear of the main compartments and pockets.  The Large bag will also accommodate her Singer Featherweight in it's original carrying case with plenty of room for other project items and tools.  The medium bag fits her Singer Featherweight in it's original carry case as well and is easy to carry.She took her Featherweight in the large rolling tote stuffed with a slew of projects when we traveled via airline this summer.  She found it easy to maneuver through airport and it fit, though very snug, in the overhead compartment of the plane.  On the way home, the airline attendant offered to stow it in the attendants luggage closet which was nice.  The medium bag fits in the overhead compartment with no problem as well as under the seat.  Handles are sturdy for carrying and all the interior and exterior pockets make it a perfect set-up for any type of travel whether for vacation, retreats or just taking to a guild sew-in day.  Bags all fit inside each other for easy storage once home or just leave packed and ready to go for the next trip.  This was exactly what my wife was looking for, a great value for a very functional well-made sturdy product.  Highly recommend, a must have item for the serious sewing machine traveler.

This bag is lightweight and easy to manage, but forget trying to roll-it, you'll need to purchase yourself a stuff bag - only drawback is that it doesn't come with a stuff bag to attach to your pack.  Easy to carry & lightweight, seems lighter than the 3lb posted on the carry weight specifications. The dual zip and inverted hood make it flexible for easy entry/exit without getting tangled if extra clothing is needed for warmth.  Definitely a spacious bag.  With that said, depending on the person, probably not a true 40 degree bag without extra clothing layers especially for smaller females, yet for a mummy bag spacious and warm enough for a larger man to be comfortable and move or turn.  I usually sleep in a hanging ENO hammock and this fits perfectly head-to-toe in my hammock.  Washes/Dries quickly without distortion.  Overall a good bag for the price.
The six feet long cable works with both my iPhone 5S and iPad Air.  It appears to be of good quality and equivalent to an Apple brand cable.

I really like this tool and I do not know how I lived without one of these.  It does a great job raking hot wood to maximize the smoke while grilling.  Perfect size and the spring like device on the end prevents the heat (associated with diffusion on the metal) from reaching your hand.

Awesome harness that looks just like the picture. My dog is 7lbs and the "small" fits him well but that is because he is a powder-puff with lots of hair. If your dog is borderline on the size chart, then go with the smaller size unless your dog has lots of hair. The leash hooks stay erect and it is always very easy to attach the leash. There is a Velcro fastener that is expandable should your dog gain some weight. I have a male dog, so I like the fact that the harness doesn't come down close to his waist where he may pee on it when lifting his leg.

Nice Shirt.  Fits as expected.  Look better in person than in the photo.  If you are borderline on the size chart, then get the next size up.

These work perfectly.  I can now control four outlets in our bedroom and sitting room.  Have two remote is great.  We put one on the wall and the other we attached to our headboard.  So, we can turn the lights on and off without having to get up.  Very convenient.
I replace my old Liftmaster eyes with these and they worked just like the originals.  Be careful, there is a right and left - so make sure you know which one goes on which side.

These are a lot more narrow than an American sized shoe.  I wear a 10.5 U.S. normally, but I bought an 11 in this shoe.  The size (in terms of the length) was right on.  They were actually a little to long - which I would expect with an 11.  However, the width was so narrow that I could not put the shoe on.  So, if you have a wide to extra wide width foot, then this is not the right shoe for you.

The new George Foreman grill is the best one that I have owned.  I really like the new ceramic plates.  They are super slick and are supposed to be much more durable than Teflon.  They are so slick that bacon strips actually slide down the slope towards the bottom of the grill.  The temperature settings is great.  You can set it lower so that you do not burn things - especially if you need to step away from a few. I can fit 8 pieces of foot-long bacon strings onto the grill at once.  Nice!  The only thing that I could say to improve it is the electric cord is really short.  So much so, that you  might need to put a quality extension onto the end.  Other than that.  Great Job!!

Mr. Negus is now on his 9th Edition of this gem of a book that is about 850 pages long.  This is a great book for beginners as well as the Linux learned that want to learn more.  The book is divided up into 6 (VI) parts: Getting Started (rudimentary topics), Becoming a Power User, a Sys Admin, a Server Admin, Security, and Cloud services.  The chapters are short and concise.  This may frustrate more experienced users who want to dive deeper.  But to me, this book is about Linux.  So, for example, it doesn't go into Bash or Korn Shell, however, it does give one the basics on Linux shell scripting.  Overall, this is a wonderful place to start for most readers that wish to grasp Linux from a single book.

Compact and light.  Fully inflates in just a few breaths.  Can be used in a hammock or on the ground underneath your sleeping bag.  Definitely makes sleeping on the ground a much more favorable experience.
Works perfectly. I use it to charge an iPhone 5S and an iPad Air 1G.  The short cable is ideal for plugging into a portable battery charger where a longer cable is a hindrance.

These handle glass wipes are superb on glass.  Low odor.  I tried it on my iPhone and iPad that both have a plastic screen protector.  The wipes worked great as long as I dried with a towel.  Otherwise, the wipes left streaks.

This is an amazing card.  From 3 feet (from the router), the throughput is about 80% of the speed that I get comparing it to being hot-wired with an Ethernet cable.  Overall, the average throughput is about 50% greater than my N WIFI Card in my Dell Laptop.

I was delighted to find out that I could still have a waffle while on the Atkins Diet if I use Carbquik. The net carbs for my waffle in the picture (including berries and cream) is only 15 Net Carbs. Here is the breakdown 3/4 cup of Carbquik (5 net carbs), 1/2 cup of Kirkland frozen three berries (7 net carbs), 4 tablespoons of whipped heavy cream (2 Net Carbs), 1/4 cup of cream (poured into mix) (1 Net Carb), 1 egg (0 Carbs), 1/8 cup of canola oil (0 carbs), 1 teaspoon of vanilla extract (0 carbs), 1/3 cup of Stevia (poured into mix), 1/8 cup Stevia sprinkled over berries (0 carbs). Enjoy!!

I was delighted to find out that I could still have a waffle while on the Atkins Diet if I use Carbquik. The net carbs for my waffle in the picture (including berries and cream) is only 15 Net Carbs. Enjoy!!
This unit is ideal for a beginner - especially a pre-teen.  OR a great one to travel with.  The stiches are basic, but it does do very well for what it does.

I like it a lot as others mentioned, but I thought that this camera would be easy to use as a webcam, too.  This isn't true, at least for me, as it does not come with any software and the audio is tuned specifically for spoken voice.  The audio failed pretty bad when I tried to use it as a webcam to record me playing guitar.

The Pro Body groomer works great if you go slowly and carefully along the contours of your skin.  It is very easy to use and operate.  I cannot speak about the longevity of this product personally, but I do have one of the original Mangroomers and it functions as well as the day I received it four years ago.  I found the plastic guards to be practically worthless, though.

I love these flatbread cracker.  I am on the Atkins diet and I like these because one stick only has 6 Net Carbs.  I eat them with cheese and occasionally by themselves.  In some ways they are more flavorful than an everything bagel because you get the same amount of seeds with only a portion of the bread.

Our whole family LOVES this large hammock chair. We bought it to replace one that had stretched out, but this one is bigger, more than we expected. I'm 5'6" and can lounge in it with my legs stretched out straight, with a "canopy" over my head from the netting! So it will easily accommodate someone over 6' tall.The weave of this hammock chair makes it particularly comfortable. We had tried another one where the cords were too rounded and thick and it dug into our backs. The cords in this chair lie flat, so you can contort or stretch yourself however you want.We bought it in black. It's well worth the money and we'd buy it again!

This is a nice solid state drive that is very fast - as fast as other SSDs on the market (especially at this price point), and certainly faster than the standard spinning hard drives. Since this comes with cloning software and an external enclosure for copying & cloning (or for just using as an external SSD), the price is actually really good.Assuming that you know the difference between an SSD and a "standard" drive, you'll know that the first benefit of the Kingston Savage HyperX is the dramatic increase in read/write speeds. This means that games and programs stored on this drive will start up a lot faster. However, once programs start up, they will only run faster when an SSD is in place if there are a lot of read/write disk operations required for the program - in other words, if your program requires more memory (RAM) than your computer has available, then the program will read & write information to your hard drive, which slows down programs unless they have a fast hard drive.The disk space for this laptop-sized drive is fairly good, but it will work in any machine. I really liked the external drive enclosure that allows the drive to be powered just through the USB connection - I used this for a while before I installed the drive internally, and the external access speed was great. Overall, this is a very nice drive that I'm happy to recommend.

This Pioneer receiver produces incredible sound quality, has an easy set-up, has 7 HDMI inputs for crazy surround sound, Bluetooth, etc. Too many features to list here; just scroll up to the product info. (No point in wasting your time with a full list when it's already here.) We set it up with four speakers and tested it with some of my favorite, crunchy metal, like Dokken's "Mr. Scary" and Accept's "Balls to the Wall." It rivaled my Bose speaker for the crisp, clean sound, and it was easy to adjust bass and treble using my husband's cell phone. It instantly responded when I selected another song from his playlist. There are numerous ways to calibrate (i.e. tweak) the sound for your personal tastes. The sound was equally impressive when we watched a movie; it was like being in a theater.The only disappointment was the spotty Bluetooth connection. It cut out on us a few times, with the receiver and the Bluetooth device only a few feet apart. We haven't dug deep into troubleshooting this problem, and it hasn't done it every time we've used it, but it would certainly be a major bummer if it did so regularly (if it does, I will update my review). It would kill a major feature of this receiver.Given the $600 price tag, and the complex fine-tuning features offered by this Pioneer receiver, I'd say it isn't for everyone. The casual viewer or listener who wants surround sound can find it much cheaper without all the bells and whistles. But if you're REALLY into sound quality, and are a gear head when it comes to this kind of equipment, it's a worthwhile investment.
It doesn't stay on! It falls off when you handle the camera and even when using it. Waste of money.

I already owned two Travelon purses before ordering this backpack for a recent trip to Europe, so I knew about the high quality and how secure Travelon's bags are. My husband was always carrying a messenger bag and would load it up with too much stuff as we explored, so I wanted to get a lightweight, secure bag. The Travelon backpack fit the bill perfectly! It is lightweight, well padded, has plenty of organizational pockets and sleeves, and it holds a lot for a small bag. We easily fit our sun hats, a cardigan, my camera and souvenirs in the main pocket, with water bottles and an umbrella in the outside pockets, and my husband's wallet, snacks, chargers, sunblock, etc. in the front pocket. When we bought several bags of gummy bears in Europe, it easily handled the heavy weight of them for the flight home. The backpack fits perfectly under a plane seat with extra room for a purse or your feet, and of course in the overhead.My favorite feature, as with my other Travelon bags, is the locking zippers. If we had anything of value in the main compartment, like my camera, we locked the zipper. It takes two hands to lock and unlock it and isn't easy -- which is exactly what you want, to thwart thieves. The fact that the straps are cut-proof makes it a truly secure bag. When we sat at outdoor cafes, we simply put a strap under a chair or table leg so no one could grab it and run.Travelon's bags are machine washable but also clean up quite easily with wipes or dishwash detergent, as we discovered when forgotten bananas in the top compartment got smushed! This bag will be coming with me on all my trips from now on, as my Travelon purses already do. I've already recommended this bag to my friends and heartily recommend it to anyone who needs a secure way to stash their gear when hiking, exploring, traveling, etc.

After 2.5 years of antibiotics for chronic Lyme disease, my gut got screwed up (despite probiotics) and I became gluten intolerant. Having to suddenly switch to a GF diet almost two years ago was a daunting, expensive proposition, and I am always on the hunt for good-tasting GF food (a lot of it is just not palatable). One of the hardest things to give up was pasta, including mac n cheese. Most gluten-free pastas have texture issues and some can downright inedible (Ancient Harvest quinoa mac n cheese pasta, I'm looking at you). But I have found rice-based GF pastas to be the best tasting, so I thought I'd give this a try.I was pleasantly surprised by this pasta, although it has a very mild cheese flavor. It's a bit salty, but not overbearingly so. I made it with unsalted butter and plain almond milk, and cooked the pasta for 10 minutes (GF pasta always seems to take the longest cooking time suggested). The pasta held its shape, unlike quinoa elbow noodles that fall apart or really poof up. I like that it's organic, and it has a higher end taste than other GF mac n cheese pastas I've tried. I didn't like Amy's mac n cheese, but the Walmart Great Value one and Trader Joe's are pretty good and the most cost-effective. But I have to add a slice of American cheese or shredded cheddar to boost the flavor to those, and I'd probably add some shredded white cheddar or even shredded parmesan to this Horizon one to boost its flavor a bit. When I reheated the leftovers, they definitely didn't have as much flavor, or saltiness, as when I first cooked them.These are definitely worth a try and I'm glad I did try them. I'll get them again for sure. The sauce is pretty thick, so if you add more milk or butter to thin it out, you'll definitely want to add extra cheese.

I was disappointed when I got these shorts and discovered that they are NOT cargo shorts as advertised. The "pockets" on the legs are decorative only -- there is no actual pocket. The description should reflect that. As I needed actual pockets, I am returning these shorts.I contemplated keeping them because they were comfortable at first and they look nice on. Overall, they fit well, but when I was testing them out and sat down, they were uncomfortable in the groin area. The seam wasn't noticeable when I was standing, but it was painful when I sat down for several minutes. Even repositioning the shorts didn't get the seam away from where it shouldn't be pressing! I am somewhat high-waisted so that could be a factor. If you're not, it may not be a problem for you. Since they offer free returns, they're worth a try if you don't care that they're not cargo shorts. The fit was as expected.

We have window films on many of our windows, to reduce glare on computers and TVs, and to cut down on the hot sun baking certain rooms. I chose this 3M film kit in the light color because the current ones in our office make it too dark. Well, it might be called "light" but it is just as dark as the one I had up there. It blocks a fair amount of light (it says 35% of the sun's rays, which is pretty dark) and I'd consider it medium, not light. When I get around to trying again, I'll aim for something that blocks 20% or less.As others have noted, it's a pain to put up the window film, as it is with every window film. 3M includes a squeegee and a blade for trimming the film, so you don't have to buy them separately. It is really a 2-person job to install this film. My husband has done this many times but he was holding it up to the window to see how much trimming would be needed, before I came in to help, and it got crimped. Once you get a crimp in these films, you'll always see them. So I'd suggest cutting a piece that's a little bigger than you'll need, rather than cutting from the whole roll when holding it up against the window. Trimming once it's up is fairly simple, but go slowly...it's easy to tear it or cut incorrectly when sliding the blade on window films.The quality is higher than many other window films we've used, but I'm still going to be looking for something lighter. I'd only recommend this "light" shade if you have a really bright room and need to cut down the light quite a bit. Our office faces north, so it doesn't get blasted with direct sun.

The WeMo tunable white bulb starter set is a non-starter...literally. I have an Android 5.0.1 phone, installed the WeMo app, and...nothing. It will not recognize the WeMo device, despite my trying multiple outlets and restarting the app several times. I followed the extremely limited instructions to get this set up and running, but it simply doesn't work. My phone found the WeMo WiFi network, which tells you you won't have an Internet connection with it connected, but it won't find the device. I didnt get a chance to test out if it really would displace my Internet connection, because it only connected twice and never again. That would be another major issue if you cant get online if connected to the WeMo network.When I started the app again, trying to find the device, it logged me into the network, then asked me for my home network password and logged me into that. I tried to find the device again, and the app wouldnt find it. So I unplugged the device again.After unplugging the device again and leaving it that way, I looked at my phone and it no longer showed the WeMo Link network in my WiFi connections list. I plugged it back in, waited, connected when it reappeared...and then my phone screen flashed and it instead connected to my home network and took the WeMo connection out of my list of connections. Sigh.So I plugged it back in  again  and waited for my phone to find the network. It didn't. The WeMo device was flashing green, then flashed yellow, and then the light became a solid green. My phone still wouldn't see the network. Then the light went off altogether. I know for a fact the outlet its plugged into works perfectly, because its where I normally have my Flex 2 phone charger plugged in.If you read reviews of WeMos app on the Google Play store, you will see it has a 2.8 rating and numerous complaints about unreliability, particularly with Android 5.0. For many users who already had it working, it stopped working with 5.0. Im sure if I wait long enough, theyll fix the bugs, but Im ready to throw this whole kit out the window.Additionally, the app requires you give it an alarming number of permissions. I almost didn't install it because of that...I never install apps that require so many permissions. It's invasive and makes me feel like the app is a massive security risk, especially since the WeMo network doesn't display as secure on my phone. Ive already uninstalled it. Nothing about this experience has given me any confidence in the app or the company, nor has it given me any desire to try again if they work out the bugsbecause:Theres also a problem with the light bulbs. We decided to test it first in our office. My husband put the bulb into our wall lamp and turned it on. It flashed three times before remaining illuminated. It does this every time we turn it on. VERY annoying and rather strange. The light is also dimmer than the equivalent bulb we had in there before. If It actually dimmed more than this, it would be too dim to be useful for anything other than lets-get-it-on lighting. I dont know if it would be brighter if adjusted with the app, since the app wont work. But its too dim to use as is and the flashing is annoying enough that I will smack my husband if he puts this damn bulb into any other lighting fixture in our house.If it were possible to return a Vine product (we get them free in exchange for doing honest reviews), I would box this non-starter set up and ship it back. It would be a great gift for someone you hate, or someone who youre hoping will hate you and end all association with you.P.S. And no, in case youre wondering, I am NOT a newb when it comes to stuff like this. Im very tech-savvy. Its the product that aint.

This cat door would be a 5-star product if 1) it was insulated and 2) if the door was slightly higher.Our cat LOVES to be out on our screened porch, even on cold days and especially on hot and humid days. Having to open the door several times a day was a pain, and we couldn't leave her out there when we left the house. When we traveled, unless we had a cat sitter who stayed in the house, she only got to go on the porch twice a day for short periods. So this was a no-brainer for us, despite the price.Even though she uses a cat door to go into the basement for her litter box, it took a few days of training (and a lot of treats) to get our somewhat dimwitted kitty to figure out how to use it. Once she used it on her own, she was constantly outside. I'm glad it locks, because when it hit 95 degrees here the other day, I brought her in and locked it. (I also put something in front of it so she would understand she wasn't going out, rather than being confused as to why it wouldn't open!) But she absolutely loves the freedom it gives her! She has been sleeping out there at night too and is so happy to have this door.When we installed it last fall, we made an H-shaped wood bracket to put above the window so that no one could jack open the window from outside and break in. We painted it white and no one has noticed it unless we've pointed it out (we have off-white faux wood blinds so it blends right in). But as soon as it got really cold out, our kitchen was freezing. The metal retains the cold and so does the glass on the sides. So we put together a ridiculous plywood board/memory foam sandwich. We had to duct tape the cut-out near her window to keep her from getting bits of foam in her fur (we went with patriotic duct tape, which amuses visitors to our house!). It did the trick, but really, they need to better insulate this thing. It would be perfect if it they did that and raised the door so the cat isn't scrunching herself down so much to go in and out.You will need to have some kind of table or ledge on BOTH side of the window, unless it is just a few inches off the floor, for your pet to go in and out safely. We had built our spoiled kitty a lounging perch for the porch, and that's on the outside. Inside, we used a triangular cat post (it has a scratching post and self-brushing station!) we already had as well. Our cat weighs about 9 pounds and fits through the door comfortably. A pet larger than 15 pounds would not likely fit; I'd probably say up to 12 pounds would be just fine.Overall, definitely recommend if you have a screened porch or can otherwise keep other animals from coming inside.

We bought our first fire pit a few years ago, a portable one that has a carrying case. It's gotten a lot of use but after being left out in the rain, both the spark guard and the bowl itself got fairly rusty. It's still usable, but isn't overly attractive. Suffice it to say it'll be used to roast marshmallows, since those make a horrible mess when they get into the fire pit! But I don't expect it to last much longer.When the CobraCo copper fire put became available at Amazon, I grabbed it. It's an impressive size, about 28" wide, but not too big. It was easy to put together; my 13-year-old was dying to have a fire and dragged the box into the backyard, in the dark, and began to assemble it! The addition of his father and a flashlight made quick work of the assembly and before long, we had a roaring fire. I mean, roaring. We used dried branches from a pine tree in our backyard along with some store-bought firewood logs, but I think the copper helped it retain the heat. The bowl also has small holes (maybe 1/4" round) in the bottom, which helps airflow.If you buy this, be sure to watch it as the first fire glows. It's cool to see the patina of the copper change with the heat. It will change dramatically, even with just one fire. I am a little concerned that the bottom of the bowl didn't just change color, but texture as well, right through to the other side of the bowl. It's now rough rather than smooth. I read in another person's review that you're not supposed to put water in it to cool the ashes because that would corrode the metal; my husband assures me no one did this, so I do hope it's not corrosion I'm seeing. It cooled off fairly quickly.As most other reviewers have reported, our spark guard is dented, and we've only used the fire pit once. We currently have it stored in the garage (base, bowl and lid separately; it takes up a lot of space if stored as it's used), so it could have gotten dented when it was put away, or while the fire was going. I'm not really worried about that. I love that this fire pit includes a poker that can also lift the lid off the pit while the fire is going. It's long enough to keep you at a safe distance from the fire.We haven't used the included cover, but if you are going to keep this outside, I would strongly suggest using it to prevent rust. Since we use ours in the grass, we have to put it away each time.All in all, I would recommend this fire pit if you don't mind the extreme discoloration that results even from just one use, and if you'd use it often enough to justify the price. It's attractive, sturdy and well-made, and it delivers a sizable fire. I personally don't want to roast marshmallows over it because they really do gum up a fire pit, but it's great for lighting sparklers and warming up your outside space.

Annie's snickerdoodle bunnies are the first gluten-free cookies I've had that taste like regular cookies! Most GF cookies are too dry. These are perfect! They're dangerous, though, because the bunnies are little and it's easy to just keep shoveling them in. Even my husband loves them, and he has no need to be gluten-free!

I ordered these in two sizes, as I am a size 8 but sometimes fit an 8.5 better. Neither fit comfortably. Even with the smaller size, my toes slid to the front edge of the slipper after just a few steps. That would be fine if they didn't have a ridge around the edge that's firmer than the slipper bed. I sent both pairs back.It's a shame, because the slipper bed is very comfy. As others have said, if you have wide or thicker feet, they would likely stay in place and you'd be cradled in comfort. I have small bones and even with size 8 feet, they're slender.

My 17-year-old picked out this cool watch. We couldn't believe the price. Well, it is too good to be true! It's unfortunately a piece of junk.The first one we received didn't work correctly. The second, smaller (round) dial wouldn't keep time if he was moving. I am not making that up. If he sat still, it kept time. But if he was just walking between classes at school or around the house, it would stop working. I called Amazon because the seller didn't allow exchanges, only refunds (even though Amazon fulfills it), and Amazon immediately sent us a replacement. They even overnighted it, as it was a birthday gift. He loved the style and how large the case is (it truly fills up the entire wrist), so he definitely wanted the same one again. Now that the replacement is broken, we're not going to see if three times' the charm.We received the replacement watch about a month ago. A week ago, he was at school and the watch literally just fell apart. The leather strap just fell off the watch case. It was frayed and had torn. Luckily, he was sitting down and the watch slipped off into his lap. When he got home, he sewed it back on (he's handy that way). Yesterday, while in a car riding home from a friend's house, he noticed the face of the watch was cracked, over the main timepiece. He hadn't smacked it against anything and it had been fine when he'd last looked at the watch just a little while earlier. He's never dropped it.So as the old adage goes, you get what you pay for. In this case, even less. It is a very handsome and cool watch, so he is quite disappointed. But it isn't ready for primetime, if you'll forgive the pun! Time to search for yet another one...

My 17-year-old has decided to eat as many of his meals as possible with chopsticks, so we decided to get him a permanent pair. He picked these out himself and he loves them. He says they're a little slippery, but if you're used to using chopsticks, it won't be a problem for you (he is quite adept with these). The squared edges make them easier to hold than, although not as comfortable as, rounded chopsticks. They also wash up very easily. He's used them for several weeks now and they still look brand new. They're simple and elegant. Definitely a good buy!

These Blue Point towels are nice and plush. The sage color is very trendy right now and is a great match to my existing bathroom dcor. It is a slightly yellower sage than I typically see, so keep that in mind if you're trying to color match. The color on Amazon, at least on my screen, is pretty accurate.It is frustrating to have to wash them 3-4 times to get rid of all of the extra fuzzies, but hey, that's the price you pay for luxurious towels! (I have another set of towels, a department store brand, that I've had to wash more than 6-7 times to get the fuzzies out.) There is a nice extra bit of detailing before the hem in addition to the border detail. And the size of the towels is just right -- not too big, not too small. Perfect for the average size person. And of course, it's an added bonus that the towels are eco-friendly. I would definitely recommend these!

My middle schooler carries way too much stuff in his binder every year, and used to go through a binder each semester. They'd just fall apart. We started buying the Mead 5-star binders and they definitely last a lot longer. So when this one became available through Vine, I grabbed it for next year. His current Mead binder has lasted through the entire school year (we have 4 weeks left) and I am expecting this one to be just as durable.This 2" binder has a nice feature in its 6-pocket expanding file, which can be accessed from both inside and outside the binder. This is great for when the teacher hands out papers at the end of class and for papers the students need to remember to show mom and dad at home. They can put their papers into the divided files without having to open the entire notebook. From the inside, this section is accessible behind a velcro tab.On the inside cover is a large zippered pocket, which I didn't notice the first time I opened it because it blends into the background. But it is a mesh, see-through pocket that will hold plenty of school supplies. There's also a velcro-tabbed pocket that would hold a smart phone or calculator.The 2" rings are round and have a capacity of 880 sheets. The only thing missing is a folder pocket for loose sheets in the back of the notebook, but with the front expanding files, you can slip any loose pages in there.For the money, it's a great value. It would be nice if it had a zippered pocket on the outside for quick access to a needed pen, pencil or eraser, and that's really its only flaw. Otherwise, it's stylish, will hold everything your student needs, and it should last a full school year, if not more.

My disabled uncle has a really hard time getting in and out of cars, to the point that I literally had him try out dozens of old cars, SUVS and minivans before we found something he could get out of without too much effort (he is on a strict budget, so we were looking at older model vehicles). But as he has severe arthritis in his knees, he still struggles to get up from chairs and from the car. So when I saw the Able Life Auto Assist Grab Bar, I immediately ordered it.On his first try, he couldn't get up because it was in his way. He is 6'4" and nearly 300 pounds. We had to reposition his car so he could open the driver-side door all the way to give him more room. On the second try, he was able to get up more quickly than usual, and he said it was definitely easier than trying to get up without it. But he had to slide his body around it a bit. It was also higher than the seat he is normally pushing off from, but its firmness (the handle is hard plastic) did give him enough leverage to mostly counteract that. He was happy with it and excited to receive it!I agree with other reviewers who said if someone has a left-side disability affecting the shoulder, elbow, wrist or hand, they wouldn't be able to use this. I have chronic tendinitis in my left wrist, and pushing up on this would flare it up (on a bad day, I have trouble getting out of cars as well due to hip bursitis). I also don't see how it would be useful as an ice scraper because it's so small. You wouldn't be able to reach much. The key holder is a small, narrow channel, so it would definitely only fit a house key or a car key that's not on a key fob.I can also see this scratching the paint in his doorframe. Because the part that goes into the door latch is metal and you have to push it downward (and it's narrower than the opening so it slides around), it will likely scratch the surface. His car is really old, so it doesn't matter. But if you have a newer or expensive car, you may want to put something like a removable electrical tape or a padded adhesive to make sure it doesn't scratch or dent it.I didn't see a flashlight in it either as other reviewers said (5/13 update: the mfr has removed that from the produce description), but that isn't why I ordered it. I am just glad there's something like this out there that can help disabled people get out of their cars more easily. We more able-bodied folks aren't always there to help!

I literally am still using a decades-old and smaller, gray metal version of the Swingline Classic stapler that I stole from my dad so often, he finally gave it to me. When MY kids need a stapler, they always come grab mine. The small plastic ones that fit in their backpacks always break or just don't staple enough sheets together. So now they have this larger black one in their school supply drawer, although I may be stealing it from them on occasion! With its sleek design and smooth lines, it feels better in the hand than my old one.As you'd expect from Swingline, it's heavy duty, both in the weight and feel of it, and in its ability to cleanly staple several sheets together (I have not tried to do 20 at once, but I don't doubt it will). If I am sitting down, I tend to prefer holding the stapler in the air when using it, and some staplers aren't strong enough to work properly like that, because they rely on downward force. The Swingline works just fine whether you're squeezing it together or pushing down on it on a hard surface. Because it's all metal, it would be a bit heavy for a backpack. It's best kept where you'll use it most (and if your child's teacher doesn't have one this nice, it's cheap enough for you to buy it for him or her as a gift for the classroom!).Really, there's no reason to buy any other brand. I expect this Swingline to last as long as my 40-year-old one (and I am glad I won't have to refill it as often...it holds a lot more staples!). There's a reason it's a classic!

I have been casually reading Buddhist books the past few years and have found the Buddhist philosophy to really fit well with many ideas I already had about how I wanted to live my life. My perspective on many things has changed for the positive, thanks to Buddhism, and I want to study and embrace it more actively.When this Beginner's Guide to Meditation became available, I jumped at the chance to explore it. I've never really tried to meditate before; I am one of those people who is an active thinker and easily distracted multi-tasker. I've always thought it impossible to clear my head and have kind of always liked that I am a deep thinker. But I figured it couldn't hurt to give it a try, and I began reading this book.Immediately, I could see that it ISN'T a practical guide for absolute beginners. It is instead an anthology of philosophies on meditation by leading Buddhist monks and scholars. Each one offers his or her own perspective, and rather than feeling guided along, I felt like I didn't know at all where to start. Which approach should I try first? What's the easiest way for a newbie to get started? And I haven't been studying Buddhism long enough to know many of the terms and had to keep flipping to the back to review the glossary.I think this book would be a useful guide for someone who's already started to meditate and wants guidance on how to get the most out of it. It's very interesting, but a bit overwhelming for this newbie. Perhaps it seems incongruous with the entire meditation thing, but I wanted something more concrete, more step-by-step, to help me get started. I feel like I would be better served by going to a local Buddhist center to explore meditation with someone who can guide me, and then using this book to explore different avenues for finding what works for me.I did appreciate an early essay which warned us not to become "professionals" at meditation but to make it a hobby. We shouldn't take it so seriously that we miss the point. I will keep sage advice like this in mind when I do try meditating, but at the moment, I feel less excited to try it than before I picked up this book.

Ok, let's face facts: a gluten-free diet is killer on the wallet. At about $6 for 9 ounces, Jovial's GF brown rice tagliatelle is one of the most expensive GF pastas out there. But I have to say, it is one of the best tasting!I recently got a copy of America's Test Kitchen's new GF cookbook, and they reviewed several brands of GF pasta. Their favorite, at least for lasagna, was Jovial's brown rice pasta. I agreed with their assessments of other GF pastas (Ancient Harvest' corn/quinoa blends are too grainy and taste terrible with any kind of sauce), so I decided to try one of the Jovial pastas. I ordered this tagliatelle because it's the closest to fettucine, and I love making fettucine alfredo from scratch.I did a taste test earlier today and cooked up just a little bit. At 10 minutes and about 20 extra seconds (I wasn't in the kitchen when the timer went off!), it was just becoming mushy. But it tasted great! So tonight, I made the rest and mixed it with my alfredo sauce, and it was delicious! I cooked it for only 9 minutes and 30 seconds and it came out just right. My husband tasted it and said it tasted like an Asian fettucine. LOL. (He is most likely to have brown rice if we're having Chinese food!) But he liked it quite a bit.My only concern was that, as I prepared to pour the rest of the bag into the pot, I spotted a few pieces that had black specks all over them! I removed those and cooked up the rest, since my earlier sample had tasted fine and I didn't get sick. I will be contacting the company and will update my review when I hear what they have to say. GF products tend to get moldy very quickly (I literally bought this a week ago), so I hope it wasn't sitting around and that it wasn't indeed mold.

My husband had already tried the CLEAR Citrus Fresh scent version of this shampoo, and we liked it better than Head & Shoulders, so he decided to try this scent as well. He uses dandruff shampoo with conditioner to control flakes that occur because of a dry scalp, and H&S shampoo with conditioner has served well to control his dandruff ever since he started using it.The Clear shampoo compares favorably to H&S: it's thicker and lathers more than H&S, and it seems to control his dandruff just as well. His hair feels clean and soft, though I don't think that's any different than before.The Ocean Mineral scent is nice but not as pleasant as the Citrus Fresh scent. Neither is overpowering like the perfumes in some shampoos, so if you like this scent or one of the others that are offered, you won't have to worry about the scent of your hair announcing your entrance to a room or triggering an asthma attack for your sensitive spouse (aka me)! It smells much better, and more natural, than Head & Shoulders. My husband's hair smells good all day long, which it didn't with H&S. I am fussier about the smell of his shampoos and deodorants than he is, so he has me pick them out for him! This one gets a thumbs up from both of us.We recommend this shampoo and he will likely stick with it over H&S, even though it's slightly more expensive. The only problem is that it's been hard to find them locally so far, so we will end up ordering them here on Amazon.

This is a cute dress, although quite bright. You definitely won't go unnoticed in it! I ordered it in a medium and found it to be too snug around the chest and ribs, and too tight just under the arms. I wear a medium or a small depending on the brand, so a medium in this should have fit better. If you're a small-chested medium (A or A-B cup), it might fit ok. Otherwise, I'd suggest ordering up a size.The material was nice and bouncy, and the pattern would help hide any extra curves you might have.

A couple of months ago, I bought my husband a new camera that is considerably bigger than what he's had in the past. He used to have point & shoot cameras, as he is not particularly savvy when it comes to the advanced features that the bigger, more capable cameras seem to have (I shoot with a Canon 60D and studied photography). With the new camera came a need for a larger bag for his Nikon Coolpix 820 and a few accessories.This CaseLogic camera bag seems to fit just right for his needs. He needs enough room for the camera, extra batteries, and the connection cables for hooking the camera up to either a PC or a TV. As with many camera bags, the main compartment is divided by semi-rigid pads with velcro on the sides. These dividers can be removed altogether, or just shifted to accommodate different-sized cameras or other devices. One of the dividers comes with a flexible cover that he configured to flip over the central compartment. The Coolpix fits perfectly in that central compartment, and the insulation should keep it safe even if he drops the bag several feet onto concrete (not that he usually does this!). The compartments on either side are large enough to hold the rest of his accessories, with enough room to hold an additional lens or other accessories.There are mesh pockets on either side of this bag that have come in handy to carry a small water bottle on one side and a small travel umbrella on the other.  Larger bottles, umbrellas or other gear would not fit well, but that doesn't bother him because he didn't get this to compete with a full-size messenger bag (I had one for my Canon gear and it killed my shoulders). You can wear this bag like a messenger bag, however, as the shoulder strap is plenty long enough to go over your opposite shoulder.One feature that he doesn't like is that there is no zipper to completely seal the inner compartment. However, the lid flap can be pulled down rather snugly, and it stays closed with a decent amount of velcro. It's fairly easy to pull open the lid from the velcro and take out the camera. When you don't need to be prepared to take a picture, you can decrease the chance of an accident by connecting the two snapon clips that make the lid fairly secure.A last feature of this bag is a rain cover with which you can wrap the entire bag. It took him a couple of minutes to put on the cover, but it seems functional in that you can open the bag and reclose it quickly without taking off the cover (though you'll need to make sure you get it out of the rain before opening it at the start).Overall, this bag is the right size for his camera, it's well-padded and easy to use. We are both satisfied with it and would recommend this bag to anyone with similar needs.

For the money, I don't think the X-Mini portable bluetooth speaker is worth it. At full volume, there is considerable distortion and static. I synced it with my iPhone 5 and played some crunchy metal with strong bass and searing guitars (Accept, Dream Theater, Scorpions) to test out how it handled both bass and treble. It only sounded ok at about 60% volume. At full volume, the distortion would only go unnoticed if you were having a loud party and people weren't there to listen to the music. There is no volume control on the speaker; you control the volume from your MP3 player/phone/tablet/whatever.It was easy to sync with my iPhone. You just turn the speaker on and put it near the phone. Open your Bluetooth settings, and once it finds it, tap the name of the device on your screen to connect. It is indeed portable and will fit into a purse, coat pocket, etc. You can use the strap to loop it through your belt loop. I walked around our first floor with it, while leaving my phone in the den, and it didn't cut out until I was on the other side of the stairs and a pantry some 30 feet away, so the reception is good. You could definitely walk around a party with your phone in your pocket and the speaker in a central location and not lose the signal.By comparison, X-Mini's MAX wired capsule speakers offer MUCH better sound quality, and they have a bass boost (I am enjoying a little Rush with them right now!). They're also quite a bit louder. They're not that much bigger than this wireless one so they'd go along with you easily as well. The only difference is they're not Bluetooth, so you need to keep the speaker next to the device.If you must have a Bluetooth speaker, I'd suggest looking at other options. This one just isn't worth $40. I'm giving it to my 12-year-old!

My husband has used the Clear Men's Scalp & Hair shampoo & conditioner for a few weeks to see how it compares to Head & Shoulders (which is the brand he's used for the last few years).  He uses dandruff shampoo with conditioner to control flakes that occur because of dry scalp, and H&S shampoo with conditioner has served well to control his dandruff ever since he started using it.The Clear shampoo compares favorably to H&S: it's thicker and lathers more than H&S, and it seems to control his dandruff just as well. His hair feels clean and soft, though I don't think that's any different than before.The Citrus Fresh scent is nice and, most importantly, it's not overpowering like the perfumes in some shampoos, so if you like this scent or one of the others that are offered, you won't have to worry about the scent of your hair announcing your entrance to a room! Major bonus is that I like it much better than any of the H&S scents he's used, even their citrus one. His hair smells good all day long (without triggering an asthma attack for me), which it didn't with H&S. I am fussier about the smell of his shampoos and deodorants than he is, so he has me pick them out for him! This one gets a thumbs up from both of us.We recommend this shampoo and he will likely stick with it over H&S, even though it's slightly more expensive.

I went gluten-free several months ago, and it was a challenge to say the least. I wish this book had been out then, but I'm still very glad it's out now! I had already picked up a few GF cookbooks but when this one became available through Vine, I grabbed it. I didn't realize it was from America's Test Kitchen until I got it. My confidence in the book shot straight through the roof; I know how serious they are about testing their recipes, as a former neighbor was one of their at-home test chefs.I was not disappointed. The book begins with a very well-written explanation of what gluten is and how it works, and why most gluten-free products are dry, grainy and just plain unpalatable. They tested numerous existing recipes with various GF flours already on the market, and although they liked King Arthur's all-purpose GF flour and Bob's Red Mill, neither were perfect for every type of recipe. So they created their own blend and tested each recipe with all three flours, tweaking repeatedly as they went.They also tasted and tested several GF pastas and breads. I have tried a few of the ones they tested and completely agreed with their assessments. I hadn't found a brown rice pasta I liked and have been using the new Mueller's and Barilla brands (which are not discussed in the book, since they just came out and the book was likely already at press), but they use white rice flour. I'm hypoglycemic and would prefer brown rice. Now I have a new brand to try. They also discuss in detail various product substitutes and how different ingredients impact a recipe. With this information, I feel well-prepared to try to tweak some of my favorite recipes to make them gluten-free.Here's what's really amazing: for EACH recipe, they describe it in detail, explain why it works, talk about substitutions, and give you step-by-step instructions. Some recipes take up four pages, but you'll never have to guess what you're doing. You will have complete confidence that the recipe will work out, because they were so thoroughly tested and because they walk you through it (I had mostly stopped buying cookbooks because I preferred to read reviews for recipes online, but with ATK, you know they've already gone through numerous modifications to make them just right). They didn't include too many main dishes, particularly meat or chicken dishes, because many of them are GF to begin with, and if you need to swap regular flour for GF flour in your own recipes, they have tips for that. So they focused on baked goods, side dishes, breakfast, and other items that those of us who avoid gluten normally can't eat (or have suffered through icky GF versions of).I can't recommend this book highly enough. It is THE gluten-free cookbook to buy, period. If you're just starting out, getting a guide to help you navigate the GF diet would be wise (I borrowed the Complete Idiots guide from a neighbor and found it so useful, I'll be buying the new edition). But once you're ready to start cooking GF from scratch, this is the book you want. I've been glad to find ready-made GF packaged goods for easy risottos and flavored quinoa blends, but this book is the first one that makes me excited to truly cook gluten-free.My only complaint? No French bread/baguette recipe. Perhaps that's asking too much, for there to be a quality GF baguette recipe, but I figure if anyone could do it, America's Test Kitchen could. So I'm bummed not to have one, as I love baking baguettes from scratch. Something to keep in mind for the Web site, ATK folks??? Please?! Don't make me cheat!!

Elisa Lorello has an unusual gift in her ability to make her characters and their situations real, sometimes painfully so. She introduced us to Andi Cutrone, and eventually, her husband Sam Vanzant, in her novel "Faking It." We met Sam toward the end, when Andi was finally ready to have a real relationship after recovering from the shock of her cheating fianc dumping her for the other woman, and discovering herself as a sexy, self-confident woman, thanks to the "lessons" she received from the gorgeous escort Devin.Whereas "Faking It" was about Andi becoming the person she was meant to be, "Ordinary World" is about her inability to rediscover that woman following the sudden death of her husband on their 5th anniversary. He'd run out at the last minute to get something for their special dinner and was killed by a drunk driver. The novel begins with the funeral. I learned the hard way not to start reading a book like this while my own husband was out of town for work! I ended up putting it down after an hour and waiting until he got home before picking it up again. It's brutally sad for quite some time.And from what I can see from other reviews, that's what a lot of people didn't like about it. Yes, it's a downer for much of the book. And just when you think Andi's finally getting it together, after rediscovering Devin and a bit of herself while on a trip, she keeps taking one step forward, three steps back in her recovery. It's easy to get impatient with her: Why is she holding on so tightly to Sam, especially when there's someone else who adores her too? Why can't she let go of guilt for even trying to move on? Why isn't her therapy really working?But unless you've been through something as devastating as the loss of your husband, especially one who finally made you feel complete and as loved as you'd always craved, you really can't say you wouldn't react the same way. I am very fortunate not to have gone through such a thing, but even as I got frustrated with her lack of progress, I couldn't help but wonder if I'd deal with it any better if my own husband died, and so suddenly. It strikes me that, just like with everything else Lorello writes, Andi's inability to deal with this loss is very much authentic and is probably based on experiences someone she is close to has had, because of how in-depth the insights are into Andi's psyche. It's very real, and that's probably what upset many readers: "Is this how I would feel? I don't want to think about it."This is not one of those books you'll put down after finishing it and say, "Phew! I feel great!" It does rip a hole in you, and even though it ends on a positive note with Andi finally going in the right direction (I won't say if it's with Devin/David or not), you're still going to be aware of what it took to get there and you'll still feel a bit raw for several days after you put it down. It will affect you all the more if you went through personal struggles with happiness, self-image or self-confidence before finding true happiness with your own spouse, without a doubt. And if you've gone through something like this already, reading this could either help you resolve some of your own feelings, or it could rip your heart out and bring up those feelings again, especially if you haven't moved on sufficiently.I would still recommend it, especially if you enjoy solid character development, emotional growth, and Lorello's writing in general. I have now read all three books in the Andi Cutrone series (the newest one is called "She Has Your Eyes") and remain a huge fan of Lorello's gift for creating authentic, relatable characters and situations. I follow her on Facebook and look forward to reading many more of her novels. (But please, can we have some less brutal story lines in the future, Ms. Lorello?!).Have lots of tissues ready, and read it when you have a private moment or place to do so, and then hug your spouse!!!

I only drink decaf, but many decaf coffees still have enough caffeine to make my heart race. So when we got a Keurig for Christmas, the first thing I did was come to Amazon to find a decaf variety pack so I could try different brands. I'd much rather try one cup without buying a whole box of them, or what I used to do, buy a whole pound of coffee at the store and then discover I couldn't drink it.More than half of the coffees are medium roast, extra bold, which I thought would be problematic but only one of them made me jittery (the Van Houtte house blend). My favorite is the first one I tried, the Donut Shop Medium Roast, Extra Bold. I now buy the 18-pack of just that one. The Caribou Blend Medium Roast was almost as good; same for Wolfgang Puck's Chef Reserve and Green Mountain's Vermont Country Blend. I was afraid Emeril's Jazzed Up one would make me jittery, but it was very good and I had no trouble. Newman's Own Special tasted a bit light to me, and the Green Mountain Hazelnut was good, but a little weak. I haven't tried most of the light roast coffees since I found myself preferring the stronger ones, so I will be saving those for guests.All in all, this is a great sampler pack and I would highly recommend it! There are a few flavored ones, and a Celestial tea, so there's some good variety. Great for varying tastes and for finding the ones you'll buy regularly.

I first became a fan of Elisa Lorello's when reading the first novel in the Andi series, "Faking It." Lorello has a spectacular gift for getting inside her characters' heads, hearts and souls, and creating very real, identifiable and relatable characters. The reader may not always agree with or like what her characters do, but it's easy to see what motivates them. It's easy to learn from them, and their inner dialogue and experiences can help you figure out similar issues in your own life. You'd think she was a psychologist in a past life. Her characters and their life situations have such authenticity, and it really does make you wonder, "What would I do in this same situation?" I always feel like I've grown a little bit along with her characters by the time I finish the book.In this third book in the series, Andi and David have finally settled in to a more relaxed lifestyle together, although some of her emotional scars remain from the death of her beloved husband a few years earlier. In the second novel, "Ordinary World," Andi grieved her husband's death so deeply it prevented her from getting a grip on her life for nearly two years (very difficult but cathartic novel to read). I didn't actually realize there was a second novel in the series until discovering this new one through the Vine program, so I picked up that one too and read it first. Unlike many series, though, if you haven't read the first two novels, you won't be completely lost with this one, because Lorello sufficiently references past issues that affected the characters so that you understand what motivates their behavior and shapes their experiences today. I'd still recommend reading them first for the full picture, but you'd still enjoy this novel just the same.But it wouldn't be a Lorello novel if she didn't rip the rug out from under her characters, and in the second chapter, she gets right to it: a 15-year-old girl literally shows up at David and Andi's doorstep with the claim that she might be David's daughter. Andi sees it in Wylie's eyes immediately, hence the oft-repeated title of the book, "She Has Your Eyes." Just as Andi's finally ready to commit to marriage with David, he now has a potential daughter and they have to figure out if or how she'll fit into their lives. To further add to their challenges, Andi gets devastating news about a family member that will further test and change everyone's relationships. And if that wasn't enough, Andi's cheating ex-fianc resurfaces and wants to be friends.I can't say any more about the plot without giving things away, but Lorello deftly weaves these story lines together and fully explores the impact of these events on Andi, David and their relationship. The reader will wonder along with Andi if they'll be able to survive these challenges intact, and whether they should. There are times the reader might even get mad at the characters (Andi and David, like most people, have their moments where they're selfish or insensitive), but that's part of what makes it so real. Andi had put her husband Sam on a pedestal and never saw any of his flaws (he never seemed to see hers either, which made him even more fantastic), so when she's faced with how most people respond to challenges, she's often at a loss about how to deal with those problems constructively. We see her, David and the other key characters make mistakes and grow throughout the story, and figure out how they need to manage and improve their relationships, so in the end, it's quite satisfying.I love novels where the characters truly do grow as people and their lives change for the better, without the syrupy crap you find in typical romance novels. That's why Lorello's aren't classified as romance novels, and why you may enjoy her books as much as I do (just be sure to have a hanky ready...she does like to make you cry!).

Easy Reading.  A tongue-in-cheek pre-WWII story of "what if...?": a mixture of fiction and historical facts about Jack Kennedy as a young man and F.D.R.Jack's admiration of Winston Churchill is in total conflict of Joe Kennedy, Sr.'s loyalty to Chamberlain and his passiveness to Germany (Joe Kennedy, Sr. was the American Ambassador to England at the time).  Being the son of American Ambassador, F.D.R. could use him secretly to be his unofficial eyes and ears on events taking place overseas.  Who would suspect this young man as he traveled Europe on the pretext of gathering information for his college thesis?To sum it up, there are nail-biting moments.  There is romance. There is conflict.  Everything comes together to make this enjoyable reading.  A good WWII novel before the United States finally became involved.

Warner Archive presents "ROBERT MONTGOMERY COLLECTION" (4 Discs) (1931-1940) (767 min/B&W) -- Starring: Robert Montgomery, Ernest Torrence, Dorothy Jordan, Charlotte Greenwood, Irene Purcell, Tallulah Bankhead, Hugh Herbert, Madge Evans, Roland Young, Nora Gregor, Heather Thatcher, Sally Eilers, Rosalind Russell, Robert Benchley, Edward Arnold, Reginald Owen and Edmund Gwenn .... some of the cast from all eight films.Directed by Harry A. Pollard, Sam Wood, Harry Beaumont, Robert Z. Leonard, Jack Conway, George Fitzmaurice, Richard Thorpe1.) - Shipmates (1931) (72 min/B&W) - Starring Robert Montgomery, Ernest Torrence, Dorothy Jordan(Directed by Harry A. Pollard) .... BearManor Media presents "CHARLIE OF NOB HILL" (Paperback) -- by Gene Arceri.It is not only about Charlie's heroism, but the fact that he and Miss Nova were inseparable from the very first time they met. Coming from Mrs. Binder of Pets Unlimited, this was several years earlier on one cold December day. Bringing Charlie in a basket, his curiosity could not take it any longer, he peered out to see a woman with soft Grey hair and twinkling blues eyes - it was love at first sight. Miss Nova gazed at Charlie's handsome black and white markings, the black scalloping on his back and ears, and the perfect black mustache. "He looks just like Charlie Chaplin!" she exclaimed. "He's just beautiful".Christening him on the spot, now you belong to me. Charlie thought and he supposed he could get use to being called Charlie, but what's a CHARLIE CHAPLIN?My favorite part of the book is on page eleven ... Charlie watched from the doorway as Miss Nova instructed a visiting friend to hang up some of her pictures. They were signed photographs of the men associated with on her publicity work in Hollywood -- One was HUMPHREY BOGART, the inscription read: "To Nova-You ain't so tough". The other picture was of a smiling CARY GRANT and he had written, "Nova, what makes you so small?" (Miss Nova was under five feet tall.) -- Between them now hung a picture of CHARLIE. "Well, she said, "now we have three tigers on the wall - BOGIE, CHARLIE and CARY".Very reasonable and a good value for the price --- For product description and editorial review check this out on the Amazon site above my review.Big thank you to Ben Ohmart and his staff, BearManor Media, a small press that publishes BIG books. They pride themselves on publishing quality entertainment biographies, so they often put out the first book on unique subjects -- plus specializing in books with nostalgic themes and keeping classic Hollywood alive not only thru his publishing house, but thru his own books, there is something for everyone.Highly recommend! -- Author Gene Arceri brings a tear to your eye - very touching, for the CAT LOVERS in all of us!Check out his other books -- Brooklyn's Scarlett Susan Hayward: Fire in the WindTotal Page: 42 Pages ~ BearManor Media #ISBN-13: 978-1593933685 ~ (November 26, 2011)

Black Dog Books presents "DEAD MAN'S BRAND" (Paperback) ~ by Norbert Davis (Author), Bill Pronzini (Introduction), Ed Hulse (Appendix), Tom Roberts (Cover Design)I've collected pulps for many years - and as one reviewer states, we are living in the Golden Age of Pulp Reprints, and I also take my hat off to Black Dog Books and editor/publisher Tom Roberts, we now have these collections at our fingertips.All eight are fast action packed stories, but the first story in this collection A GUNSMOKE CASE FOR MAJOR CAIN, has to be my favorite.  It was adapted into a B-Western, HANDS ACROSS THE ROCKIES (1941), starring one of my favorite Western stars Bill Elliott (Wild Bill Hickok) and Dub Taylor (Cannonball Taylor), mixed with plenty of gun play and humor.  Of course many of the names are changed to fit our stars handle in their films, but remained faithful to Davis' plot, still basically on the same plain.  Reprinted here for the first time since its original magazine appearance, as with the other stories herein.Collection of eight Western tales, from Action Stories, Dime Western Magazine, Star Western and Western Aces (1935-1942) -- pure entertainment.With a an introduction by Spur Award winner Bill Pronzini -- Must agree with Pronzini, all eight stories collected here are all first-rate entertainment by a born storyteller.  Kudos to Tom Roberts and Black Dog Books for rescuing them from Western pulp obscurity.Appendix, HANDS ACROSS THE ROCKIES: The Lone Film Credit of Norbert Davis by Ed Hulse, writer, pulp and film historian, and editor of the BLOOD 'N' THUNDER magazine.Cover art by Tom Roberts, when justice comes to a cow town, hell follows with it.Very reasonable and a good value for the price --- For product description and editorial review check this out on the Amazon site above my review.TABLE OF CONTENTS: (Chapter, Title and Page Numbers)INTRODUCTION by Bill Pronzini --- 71. A Gunsmoke Case for Major Cain (Oct. 1940) --- 112. Their Guardian From Hell (March 1937) --- 343. Leetown's One-Man Army (Oct. 1941) --- 614. Dead Man's Brand (Nov. 1942) --- 985. Boot-Hill Bait (Nov. 1935) --- 205APPENDIX by Ed Hulse --- 227(Hands Across the Rockies:The Lone Film Credit of Norbert Davis)Great job from publisher Tom Roberts and his staff at Black Dog Books, at in bringing forgotten series of characters and hard-to-find works from rare magazines - Black Dog Books have for over ten years, been publishing collections of rare and obscure fiction from the golden age of the pulp magazines (roughly 1920-1945) -- They have found their niche, whether it's Westerns, Detective Stories, Adventure Fiction, Crime Fiction or Science Fiction -- something for everyone!In closing, "A Gunsmoke Case for Major Cain"  October 1940. BearManor Media presents "IDA LUPINO:BEYOND THE CAMERA" (Paperback) -- by Ida Lupino (Author), Mary Ann Anderson (Author)I love the comments in the afterword, where Lupino states - "I was now able to tell WARNER BROS, to go to hell!  None of us were happy there.  I used to go up on the hill beyond the studio and throw rocks at it.  I was always going on suspension or doing roles that I absolutely hated.  I refused to do roles turned down by other actresses, like Better Davis."Lupino never said she was the poor man's Bette Davis, WARNER BROS. came up with that bad line, not me.  I respected Davis, Now Ida could do heavy, light - She had a great sense of scene construction.  If she could have only gotten another picture like THEY DRIVE BY NIGHT or THE HARD WAY, she could have stayed on top.  Lupino's states, acting is a born talent within people, it can be polished and made better but you definitely cannot teach someone to act, you need to leave that up to the audience -- Orson Welles puts it best, actor's acting, I am Bored.In the director's chair, after films NOT WANTED (1949) and OUTRAGE (1949), Ida had offers by all the studios as a director, but she remained independent.  When filmakers was dissolved, Ida turned her full attention to television directing, first directorial assignment was HAVE GUN WILL TRAVEL, Richard Boone was a wonderful man, but he was not out to baby any director, believe me, but after the first episode he said, "I like you, I want you on the rest of them.  I stayed on and directed four episodes.  Boone liked his direction hard-boiled."Very reasonable and a good value for the price --- For product description and editorial review check this out on the Amazon site above my review.TABLE OF CONTENTS: (Chapter, Title and Page Numbers)Foreword --- xi1. Black Dog Books presents "NOMAD'S TRAIL" (Paperback) ~ by E. Hoffmann Price (Author), Tom Roberts (Book Layout & Design), James Reasoner (Introduction), Allen Anderson (Cover Art)As James Reasoner states in the introduction - For the most part, the Simon Bolivar Grimes stories have been out of print since their first appearances in SPICY WESTERN more than 70 years ago. BearManor Media presents "THE FILMS OF THE FRENCH FOREIGN LEGION" (Paperback) -- by Philip Leibfried (Author)Have many films on the 'French Foreign Legion', but was not aware of the ones I've missed.  As the author points out in his introduction -- Created by an order of King Louis Philippe of France in 1831, the LEGION ETRANGERS originally served as a means of ridding France of thousands of political refugees who had sought asylum there after revolutions in their own countries in Southern and Eastern Europe.One of the most famous and a great story BEAU GESTE, by Percival Christopher Wren, published in 1924, of an unshakable bond among three brothers, which featured action, adventure, mystery, and a character by the name of Sgt. Lejaune, who became a symbol of cruelty as great as Simon Legree.  Something I didn't know was, BEAU GESTE was remade three times as a theatrical feature, but its leading characters, including an ogre of a sergeant, have influenced generations of filmmakers and film goers.  Beau Geste (1926) (Silent) with Ronald Colman, Neil Hamilton, Ralph Forbes & Noah Beery ... also, Beau Geste (1939) with Gary Cooper, Ray Milland, Robert Preston, Brian Donlevy & Susan Hayward (This is one of my favorite films, great acting and direction by William A. Wellman) ... also Beau Geste (1966) with Guy Stockwell, Doug McClure, Leslie Nielsen & Telly Savalas.In both silent and sound eras, many leading actors appeared in FOREIGN LEGION FILMS, but these motion pictures have been given short shrift in biographies and autobiographies of those performers, as it turns out films about the FOREIGN LEGION are not as highly regarded as the outfit itself.Very reasonable and a good value for the price --- For product description and editorial review check this out on the Amazon site above my review.TABLE OF CONTENTS: (Chapter, Title and Page Numbers)Acknowledgements --- viiIntroduction --- ixCHAPTER ONE: --- 1Seminal Sands: Under Two FlagsCHAPTER TWO: --- 17Celebrated Sands: The Novels of P.C. WrenCHAPTER THREE: --- 37Silent Sands: Cinema de Legion 1914-1928CHAPTER FOUR: --- 49Sound Sands: Cinema de Legion 1929-2000CHAPTER FIVE: --- 67Singing Sands: Legion MusicalsCHAPTER SIX --- 75Shifting Sands: Films of the Post-World War II LegionCHAPTER SEVEN: --- 85Subtitled Sands: Foreign Foreign Legion FilmsCHAPTER EIGHT: --- 113Satiric Sands: Comedies and CartoonsCHAPTER NINE: --- 131Sundry Sands: The Legion on the Stage, Radio & TelevisionCHAPTER TEN: --- 149Superfluous Sands: Marginal French Foreign Legion Filmsand Spanish Foreign Legion FilmsBibliography --- 159Index --- 163In closing, author Philip Leibfried has given us much in depth, a complete listing of such depictions as possible through 2007.Thank our lucky stars for Ben Ohmart and his staff, BearManor Media, a small press that publishes BIG books. They pride themselves on publishing quality entertainment biographies, so they often put out the first book on unique subjects -- plus specializing in books with nostalgic themes and keeping classic Hollywood alive not only thru his publishing house, but thru his own books.An interesting must read ~ Highly recommend!Total Page: 180 Pages ~ BearManor Media #ISBN-13: 978-1593936730 ~ (November 10, 2011)
