Now at times I felt Julia was a strong lead, but then there were times I wanted to smack her and tell her to grow up.  I would've liked to see that strong female lead all the way through the book.What I truly enjoy about LL Collins's books, is that she creates real stories and real characters.  Her stories are stories that could  happen in real life and we get the feelings and reactions of characters as they would handle things in reality.  She is able to tell the story so that the reader is able to connect with the characters and feel what they are feeling.I will warn you though that this story is kind of the insta-love/lust type story.  Right from the get go, Julia and Carter are attracted to each other, but their feelings grew for each other fairly quickly.  So if you aren't a big fan of that type storyline, then this might not be the book for you.  For me I really liked it and felt it worked well for these characters.  This story really shows you how even the best laid plans can be changed when you meet the right person!!!

What I absolutely love about Lauren Blakely's books is that she knows how to create a story that is the perfect combination of heart, humor and melt your kindle steam ;)I have read MANY books by Lauren and I have never been disappointed.  Her books have always captivated me, made me swoon, made me blush and yes I have even gotten angry at her characters, but that is what truly makes a 5 star book in my opinion.Consumed by You was no different.  This story was sweet, heartfelt, fun, and sexy all rolled into one.  She has created characters that you can't help but suck them into your heart and feel like you are a part of their lives.  I thought the pace and flow of the story was spot on.  This book isn't extremely long, but it never felt rushed or that it was missing something.  Consumed by You is the third book in Lauren's Firefighter series, but can be read as a stand-alone.  I personally haven't read either of the first two books and it didn't take away anything from this story.  You do have reoccurring characters from the previous books, so it kind of ruins the endings of those books, but after reading this one, I want to go back and read the first two to see how each of those couples stories played out.In this book we follow the story of Cara and Travis.  This book is pretty much a second chance romance because Cara and Travis have a past history together.  Cara and Travis dated back in high school but separated when they left for college.  Travis has a HUGE phobia of relationships because of what happened to his mom after his dad is tragically killed when he was 10.  He felt that if he avoided connections to other people (women) then his heart is safe.  Cara on the other hand wants what every girl wants.  The marriage, kids and a loving home to come home to.  Just like her sisters.  But Cara and Travis can't forget what the two of them have in the chemistry department.  So they come up with a plan.a 2 week fling!!!  That will solve all their problemsRight???  Well you are going to have to read the book to see how everything works out for this couple.If you have read the first two books in this series then you are going to enjoy seeing the previous couples in this book.  You get to see where they have gone since their books.  Being that I hadn't read them it was still nice having them in the story because it showed the close bond these friends all have.  It really made you want to be a part of this circle of friends.I would 100% recommend this book.  I have LOVED every Lauren Blakely book and I don't think you'll be sorry if you pick up this or any other of her books.  They are downright sinful.in the best way ;)

Sky High was my first book by C.J. Lake.  I really enjoyed this story.  It was a fun, flirty and sexy read.  It is also a book that can be read in less than a day.I thought the storyline and flow of the story was really good.  I also enjoyed the characters and how well she developed them.  My only real complaint about this book was the ending.  I felt it was kind of abrupt.  I would've loved to have an epilogue or even just another chapter or two completing their story better.  Now don't get me wrong this is NOT a cliffhanger ending or one that leads you to believe there is more to their story, it just felt to quick.  It's hard to explain except to say I wanted a little more.Sky High is the third book in C.J. Lake's Attraction series, but can be read as a stand-alone.  You will see the characters and couples from the previous books, but it doesn't take away from this story at all and you won't fell lost if you haven't read the other books.One thing I really liked about this story was the author had the characters become friends first and really took their relationship at a believable pace.  It was nice to see a couple start out as friends and not just jumping into bed the first time they meet.  Although with that said I did have one frustration during their friendship..I didn't like that Sky continued to "date" other guys while befriending Jamie.  You could feel their attraction right away, so to me she shouldn't have continued on with the blind dates.  Even if it was to help out her BFF's sister.  I will say that except for a short term separation, this couple really didn't have any drama, yes the author tried to spice up the drama a little by having Jamie become jealous of Remy, but even that was short lived.  I will say the chemistry that this couple had was off the charts.  I thought the author did a really great job at conveying their feelings and creating  tasteful and steamy sex scenes.  Those scenes were truly some of my favorite parts of the book and not because of the sex, but because of the connection I could feel between Sky and Jamie.I would recommend this book to any fan of the New Adult Genre.  I thought this book was truly refreshing in the sense that it wasn't totally cliche and the Hero was actually a really sweet, funny and lovable guy.  Yes I love my cocky jerks and alpha males, but it is nice to see a "nice" guy win in the end sometimes too.  I know that I will for sure be reading the other books in this series, to see how the other couples come about.

What can I say.I LOVE Michelle Leighton's writing/books.  She always gives us a story that is both entertaining and intriguing.  I love that she can create a suspenseful story but add in the right amount of romance to it too.  Oh and the sexy times in this book were STEAMY ;)Strong Enough grabbed me right from the prologue.  My heart broke after reading it.  I felt that this book was truly a story about redemption and learning to love oneself and others and also learning to be loved by someone.  Can a person who truly believes they are a monster be redeemed and loved?  Are they able to grow and learn to love another?  Well those answers is what you find out while reading this book.I felt this book was written perfectly.  I felt the pace and character development was spot on.  I also thought the storyline was captivating and unique.  It had the right amount of suspense to keep me turning the pages.  The secrets and betrayals that are revealed in this story are ones I wouldn't have expected.  I loved that Michelle was able to keep me guessing throughout the whole book.Strong Enough is told in Dual POV.  We meet Muse and Jasper in this story.  Muse is a girl who has been raised by her military father and has left her hometown because she felt it was in her dad's best interest in keeping him safe.  When her father fails to be there at the determined time for their weekly call, Muse panics and hires a bounty hunter to find him.  In comes Jasper.  Jasper is a man who grew up in a horrible situation, you'll understand after reading the prologue.  He has shut down all feelings and emotions and has become what he thinks is a monster.  Now Muse hiring Jasper isn't as cut and dry as you might think.  Secrets and Lies are revealed, but I am not going to tell you what they are, you NEED to read this book.  Ah..Jasper King.what can I say about him except, he is one hero you won't want to miss meeting.  I don't know what it was about him, but something sucked me in and didn't let go.  I loved his character and I truly felt connected to him.Another thing I loved about this book, was that even though this is the first book in Michelle's newest series, it can totally be read as a standalone.  This book does have a Happy ending and a complete story.  The next book in this series will be about another character that you meet in this book.  (One of Jasper's friends)  After reading this book, I am totally looking forward to Rogan's book.If you are a Michelle Leighton fan, like I am, then you don't want to miss this book.  It was a story that had suspense, lies, betrayal, redemption and love!!!  This was definitely a GREAT start to her new series :)

"Welcome to INDULGE, where your fantasies meet reality."INDULGE is a totally Indulgent read!!!  This book was so good it totally deserved more than 5 stars!!!!This has to be the BEST Georgia Cates book I've read to date, and that is saying something since I Loved all her other books.  She knows how to create a story that has it all.  This book has got to be the steamiest of Georgia's books.  You will definitely want a fan and cold drink with you when you read this book.  This book totally sucked me in.  I loved the storyline and the characters she has created in this book.  The pace was fantastic and the writing flawless.  I read this book in less than a day, because it was so good I couldn't put it down.  Georgia had me laughing, swooning, crying and even rolling my eyes at times.  I love when an author can do that to meit shows true talent!!!In INDULGE we meet Anna James (AJ) and Beau.  AJ just came out of a crappy marriage and her best friends give her an all paid trip to Jamaica with them to the resort Indulge.  She hesitantly goes along, because her friends are swingers and live a different lifestyle than she does.  Indulge is an all inclusive resort that tends to lean towards Hedonism and Polyamorous couples.  Even knowing this AJ can't pass up a trip like this.  On her first night she is alone and hungry so she goes to a restaurant on the grounds, finding out the wait is too long but she is able to be seated with another single diner, so she takes a chance and does that.  This is where she meets Beau.  What happens from here is a fun filled adventure into learning to broaden your horizons and try new things ( not all sexual ).  I loved Beau right from the start!!!  He completely stole my heart.  He was a man with a very naughty mouth, but a heart of gold and he loved his family immensely!!!  I loved watching both him and AJ grow into stronger people as their time together continued on.  I don't want to say anything more because this is a book that everyone should experience on their own ;)INDULGE is a standalone novel with a Happy Ending.  It is told kind of in Dual POV.  The first 12 chapters are told from AJ's POV and then there is a time jump and we get 6 chapters in Beau's POV, then for the last two chapters it is back in AJ's POV.  The epilogue is in Beau's and I absolutely LOVED the epilogue.  She finished their story amazingly well, so that the reader is not left wondering what happened to this couple.  She did put a little something in the epilogue about Beau's brother Judd and I am hoping that is leading to a book about Judd.  I would love a story about him :)If you are a Georgia Cates fan then you DON'T want to miss this book!!!  This is the best book by her to date.  If you have never read a book by Georgia then what are you waiting for.Start with this one, you won't be sorry!!!!

I really don't know how to write this review to make sure it does this fabulous book justice.  I was absolutely blown away from this book.  The storyline was filled with heart and emotion and I honestly thought it gave an accurate portrayal of what a person struggles with in life when it comes to abuse, bullying and alcoholism.This is the first book I have read by Tiffany Aleman, and I will say it won't be my last.  The amount of emotions that Tiffany makes a reader feel while reading this story was fantastic!!!  My heart broke for these characters, but it also smiled and laughed with them.  It also learned to love these characters as their flaws were revealed.  I know that this is only the beginning of Brayden and Karmen's journey and I am truly hoping that they do get their HEA.  I feel it is going to be a tough and long road for them to get there.Now I do feel it is necessary to warn readers that this book does end on a cliffhanger and touches on some subjects that could be triggers for some people.  As for the cliffhanger, it isn't a nail biter or a pull your hair out, it is the perfect ending to the start of Brayden and Karmen's journey.  As a couple they aren't in a great place at the end of the story, but they are in a healing place.  I feel that this book ended right where it should have.  As for the tough subject she covers, it is the topic of Bullying, abuse and alcoholism.  I want to say the Bullying is the prime focus of the story, because it was the focus of Brayden and Karmen's past history,  but the abuse and alcoholism do play a big part in Brayden's backstory and why he is the way he is.  I thought Tiffany did a wonderful job in showing the daily struggles both Karmen and Brayden had to go through.I thought Karmen and Brayden were both great characters.  Full of emotion and heart.  I truly just wanted to jump into the book and give both of them hugs.  I do hope that in the second book we get to see Brayden open up more to Karmen.  It will be nice to see him let her in.  I am interested to see how Karmen weathers in the next book.  To see how she overcomes this set back from book 1.As for the secondary characters, I thought they were all wonderful and just as important to this story as the main characters.  Drew, Chelsea and Tammy were all amazing supports for both Karmen and Brayden.  I was extremely happy to see Drew transform into a better person compared to his High School days and to ask for forgiveness from Karmen for all the wrong he did back then.  It made it more believable that him and Karmen could end up being friends now later in life.I would 100% recommend the heartfelt and emotional journey to everyone.  If you aren't a fan of cliffhangers I don't think this is one you have to wait for book two before starting this one, just be aware that at the end there is more to come!!!!

Caught in Us was just what I was looking for.  This book was AMAZING.  It had everything I look for in a 5 star read.  It had a wonderful love story, sexy times, a little suspense, some family drama, and the best ending I could've hoped for.I have read and LOVED every book Layla Hagen has written and Caught in Us was no different.  her writing style sucks me in every time.  I love her story lines, and the characters she creates.  She has the great ability to create characters who you just grow to love and can't help but feel a part of their lives.  Being that this is the third book in her Lost Series, I am sad to see this series end.  These characters will live on in me for a long time to come.  This story is told in some Dual POV.  We get mostly Dani's POV but she does throw Damon's POV in quite a few chapters.  This is a fun, sweet and sexy read that was a fairly quick read.  Like I stated earlier there is a little drama, but nothing over the top and she added an element of suspense to keep you turning the pages.I loved how she created Dani and Damon's story and how it all unfolded.  This story is told over the course of a couple years.  It starts out when Dani and Damon are in high school and Damon is a transfer student at Dani's school.  Damon was a bad boy to the core and to say they have a rocky start is an understatement.although I did love their banter.it had me laughing a few times.  Their friendship/relationship slowly grows over the first half of the book and then the family drama kicks in and forces Dani and Damon to separate.  A year passes and they are reunited.  This being their freshman year in college.  They both attend Stanford.  From here we get their sweet love story and the suspense of the storyline.  I absolutely loved both Dani and Damon.  They were as opposite as two people could be, but truly brought out the best in each other.  They knew how to showcase each others strengths.Another thing I loved about this book, was how Layla incorporated the other characters from the other two books into this story.  We kind of got the back story because this book starts before James has met Serena and Parker had met Jessica.  But then how she tells the story we also got to see where these two couples end up and what they have been up to since their books.  It was just a really interesting way of telling this story and I loved it!!!!Caught in Us is a third book to a series, but can be read as a stand alone.  Being the way the author wrote this book, you really don't even need to read the first two books before reading this one.  I would suggest it, but it is not necessary.  This book does have a HEA and it wrapped up this series very nicely!!!I would 100% recommend this book/series and author to anyone who hasn't read any of Layla Hagen's books.  Her stories will suck you in and leave you smiling in the end.  Pick up one of her books today.you won't be sorry!!!!

What happens when, what starts out as a simple agreement, turns into something more and feelings are brought into the picture ???  You get an interesting journey to a HEA!!!This book was exactly what I was looking for at this point.  I was looking for an Erotic love story that wasn't just about sex, but had an interesting storyline as well.  Well 30 Days was both of those.  This is the first book by Christine d'Abo that I have read and I am really glad I took a chance on a new author.  This book was a fun and very sexy read (but by no means overdone or raunchy) but also had some great feelings built in.30 Days is a Second Chance at Love type story.  We meet Alyssa and Harrison in this book.  Alyssa is a 30 something woman who tragically lost her husband from cancer.  After mourning her husband for 2 years she is finally ready to move on and find someone new.  I thought the author did a great job at portraying the feelings a widow goes through when trying to move on with their lives.  We saw her go through fear, guilt, anger and loneliness.  I liked watching Alyssa open herself up to new experiences and the possibility of new love.  Before her husband died he gave her an envelope with a letter and some cards in it.  The note is he way of telling her to move on and be happy.  The cards are 30 days worth of sexual experiences.  When Alyssa sees the cards she in mortified and can't even think of doing the stuff on them, until she meets Harrison!!!!  He opens her eyes to what possibilities there could be ;)  Harrison is a temporary neighbor who is living in Alyssa's complex for 3 months.  He is just coming off a bad relationship and is in no way looking for a new one.  That is until he meets Alyssa and hears her proposal.  To say these two have amazing chemistry is an understatement.I thought my kindle was going to melt at many different times.  But under all the sexual experimentation.there really was a sweet love story built in.  There wasn't a whole lot of drama in this story, what was created was created solely by Alyssa and Harrison.  They were each others road blocks.We don't meet many secondary characters, the one that really sticks out is Nikki, Alyssa's sister.  I liked the support system Nikki lends to Alyssa, even if jealousy can come into play.  I would love to read a book about Nikki so that we could see her get her HEA finally.So if you are looking for a fun, and extremely sexy read, but has feelings also, then 30 Days is the book to pick up.  This book is told solely in Alyssa's POV and has a Happy Ending.  I would've liked to see some of Harrison's POV but it didn't take away my enjoyment of the story.

I was very excited to get my hands on a canister vacuum, as I haven't used one since I was a kid. Specifically, I was looking forward to using a vacuum with a much smaller footprint (at least the business end of it) than uprights tend to have. But I guess there's a reason we haven't used a canister in the last thirty years: much of our house is carpeted, and a canister isn't really cut out for using on carpets. But more on this in a bit.There's a lot to like about this Bissell. It's attractive and easy to assemble. The wand extends very smoothly to accommodate use by taller people. The canister snaps on and off easily for quick cleanup. There's a cord rewind button. The tools (but not the alternate head) fit on board so they're in easy reach while you're using it.The vacuum comes with two heads. The first is the so-called Turbine Foot Attachment, which is for use on hard floors. The other is the Multi-Surface Professional, which can be used on both hard floors and carpets. The vacuum touts itself as a "hard floor expert," and it works great on hardwood or kitchen floors. It's nice that a head for carpets is also included with the machine, and this would probably be adequate for people who have hard floors and a small rug or two to clean. But if you have a lot of carpeting in your house, I wouldn't recommending going with the Bissell--or, I'm thinking, with any canister vacuum. With a canister, after all, the user is pushing the vacuum head along the surface of the floor, and that's hard to do on a carpet when what you're pushing isn't on wheels. Vacuuming the rug in just our small TV room was a tiring task and not one I'd like to repeat very often.There are a few other minor negatives as well, which I've summarized below along with the machine's pros:PROS-- Attractive-- Easy to assemble.-- Wand extends smoothly-- Canister snaps on and off easily-- Cord rewind button.-- Tools (but not the alternate head) fit on board so they're in easy reach while you're using it.CONS-- Not great for cleaning carpets-- Takes up a lot of space when stored, unlike a canister vacuum-- The position of the cord rewind and power buttons are the reverse of what I'd like. Since I'm right handed, the machine is usually to the right of me, and I expect the power button to be on the left of the machine for easy reach. I keep pressing the cord rewind button by mistake.-- When it's stored, the wand slips into a small plastic bracket on the machine that seems fragile to me. I won't be surprised if it eventually breaks.In sum, although the Bissell comes with a head for cleaning carpets, don't count on using it if you have more than a small amount of carpeting to clean. It's too hard to push, and the multi-surface head doesn't have a beater brush to help get stuff up out of the rug. But if you're just looking to clean hard floors, you won't go wrong with this one.

I have not had any issues with my Nest Cam after using it for several weeks. The camera was a breeze to set up, and the app has consistently worked well. The image quality I've been getting is quite crisp, perfectly acceptable for my needs. The camera is also very nice looking, and I like that its base has some heft to it so it feels like it's not going to tip over when standing upright. What I most appreciate, however, is that I receive notifications on my iPod Touch within seconds of the camera detecting motion in the room it's in. I like the iOS notifications much better than email notifications, which I've received from other cameras in the past.The camera came with a trial subscription, which means that before the trial expired I was able to enjoy the convenience of seeing my video history. It's great, but for me it's not worth the subscription fee. There are currently two subscription options. You can see the last 30 days of your video history for $30 a month or $300 a year, and the last 10 days for $10 a month or $100 a year. I'd really like a third option: a two- or three-hour video history for $2 a month or $20 a year. *That* I would pay for, and I bet a lot of other people would too. $2 a month from a lot of people is better than not having them subscribed at all, Nest people. Please consider it.I see that there are a lot of negative reviews here on Amazon from people who've had bad experiences with their cameras, but my own experience has been thoroughly positive. Good luck with your buying decision.

Now that I've played with the Scotch Advanced Thermal Laminator for a while, I kind of want everyone who needs things laminated to come to my house and let me do it for them. It's fast. It's fun. It's easy. It does a good job. The sleeve you put your stuff in adheres not only at the edges but all over the item, so that you can cut off all edging and have, say, a perfectly laminated bookmark with no overhang. So, five stars, Scotch, on this great product.That said, make sure you use it as directed. A morality tale:My daughter came home from college (yes, throwing her under the bus here), eyed our new lamination station, and got busy. First it was regular stuff. A test paper, a bookmark. Then it got more intense. She broke out her box of dried flowers and quickly put together a collage, cranked the thickness of the laminator up to 5mm, and ran it through. The result: not bad. And then I left the room.In my absence she decided to experiment by putting a couple small dabs of paint in a sleeve and running it through. The result was a laminated sleeve with long streaks of paint running the length of it. And--you may have guessed it by now--paint got inside the machine.She figured, reasonably enough, that she could get rid of the paint by feeding sleeveless paper through the machine. Perhaps after doing that a number of times, the paint would be pretty much gone and regular lamination could continue, but things went from bad to worse: the paper checked in, but it didn't check out. It was stuck inside, crammed into a very small space on the exit side of the rollers. We tried using various tools to get it out, but it soon became clear that we'd have to expose the innards of the machine if there was any hope of clearing the paper jam.With some misgivings, we took off the cover and spent a fair amount of time trying to get the paper out. Knives were introduced, tweezers, paper clips. Nothing worked. And after quite a long time we decided that taking off the cover wasn't enough. At this point, I had pretty much given up on the idea that we'd ever get the laminator working again. Taking things apart is easy, but there's a lot that can go wrong when it comes to putting them back together. Nonetheless, I further disassembled the laminator. There was a lot of dried paint in it, more than we'd expected. We chipped it off where we could. But even at this point, it wasn't an easy thing to get to that jammed paper. I wound up having to pry a piece of metal back and then finally, finally, I was able to pull out the paper, which the machine had folded into a very tight fan, each of its accordion fins only a few millimeters wide.I reassembled the laminator. To my astonishment, and with the sweet stench of burning acrylic heralding its success, it spat out a laminated test sheet--perfect but for needing to be wiped free of melted paint. Ladies and gentlemen, we have a working laminator.The moral of this story is, be careful what you stick in the machine. Probably you won't try running paint through it, so you're in the clear there. But this woeful tale does point to what is arguably a flaw. Should someone accidentally insert a sleeveless piece of paper into the laminator--and I can see this happening--there is very little chance that that paper is going to come out again. There is no easy way of clearing a paper jam. Perhaps there should be. (And that's why I've deducted a star from my review.)

In Alexander McCall Smith's latest No. 1 Ladies Detective Agency novel, Mma Ramotswe is talked into taking a vacation, and leaving the agency in the hands of her sometimes difficult colleague, Mma Makutsi. But it's difficult to let go, and Mma Ramotswe finds herself almost as busy on vacation as she is at work. There's a case to solve, a young man to save, and a curiously-named new business in town that needs to be investigated. Mma Ramotswe approaches everything with her trademark grace and wisdom. Readers of McCall Smith's Botswana novels will enjoy this installment in the series as much as his previous books.The leisurely pace of McCall Smith's stories can make one feel as if nothing much is happening in the books. However busy Mma Ramotswe may be, she still has time to contemplate the broad Botswana sky, to enjoy conversations over cake and tea, and and to mull over the remembered wisdom of her beloved late father, Obed Ramotswe. As slow as the books may seem, however, we have watched the series' main characters grow and change quite a lot over the course of 16 books, perhaps none so much as Mma Makutsi, whose circumstances have changed dramatically since she first came to work in the agency. In this latest novel, we see something new emerge in Mma Makutsi, and so does her boss. It's a pleasure to witness.

Olaf is very cute and nicely constructed. I like that his sno-cone-making innards are concealed inside his tummy, and also that you can use that space for storing your paper sno cone cups (or enormous wads of cash, for that matter). It's also a nice touch that the sno cone holder--the arm that holds the cup in place as you're working the machine--is removable. That allows you to use a bowl to catch your shaved ice, which is probably what we'll be doing once the batch of cups that came with the machine is finished.The machine is very easy to use, and very fast. The shaved ice that comes out is very fine. Arguably you could use the machine for putting shaved ice in a drink, although it's probably too much bother to do that on a regular basis. On the other hand, a few days ago when my daughter wasn't feeling well--a bit overheated--I was able to quickly prepare a bowl of plain shaved ice for her, and it was exactly what she needed.The machine comes with two plastic molds for freezing ice. We left one empty in the freezer, somehow, and it cracked and is now unusable, so I'd advise against doing that yourself. You can use regular ice cubes with Olaf, however, so even if you do wind up destroying both molds, you're not out of luck.So, I pretty much like everything about Olaf...except his size. He's about 15 inches tall. For a kitchen appliance that you're probably not going to be using all the time, he is HUGE. He takes up a substantial amount of counter space, and he simply will not fit inside our cabinets, though your mileage may vary. When the initial thrill of using Olaf has worn off, he'll probably wind up in a box somewhere, unfortunately, and less easy to access, because keeping him out on the counter is probably not going to work for us in the long run. Size may seem a minor thing, but it causes logistical problems, and if it's not convenient to keep him out on the counter, or even inside a cabinet, that detracts from his usefulness. Anyway, just be aware that Olaf, for all his good points, has this considerable down side.

Philips' Bluetooth Clock Radio is a solid offering. It offers everything you might expect in a clock radio: AM/FM radio; dual alarms that can wake you with either a buzzer or the radio, both of which get louder the longer they're left unanswered; snooze; up to twenty preset radio stations; auto-scan tuning; brightness adjustment; and timed sleep-to-music function. The device goes a little above and beyond by providing a USB port in the back and allowing Bluetooth pairing, so that you can listen to music from your iPhone, etc, through the clock radio's speakers. These don't matter very much to me, but for some people they can be handy.What matters most to me in choosing a clock radio--and I've had many over the years--is  how intuitive it is, and to a lesser but still substantial extent, its footprint. On the latter score the Philips shines: it's a tidy cube less than 5" (if you don't count the protruding tuning button) on each side. And it does fairly well on the intuitive scale too: it's not the best I've seen--that prize still goes to my old Sony Dream Machine, which lamentably is now discontinued. But it's also not the worst. (There's a prize for that, too, and it goes to the Sylvania SCR1997 USB Bluetooth Alarm Clock Radio. I spent quite a while trying, and I NEVER figured out how to set the time on that thing.) For the most part I was able to figure out how to work all the functions on the Philips without appealing to the directions. (I had to look, however, to see what buttons had to be pushed in what sequence to program the preset radio stations.) The buttons are all arranged in a square on the top of the device, recessed so they're flat. What I particularly like is that the two alarm buttons, which are at the rear right and left of the square, have raised dots on them so that when you're feeling around in the dark you can identify them. And an even nicer touch: there's one dot for the first alarm, and two dots for the second.So all in all, this is a decent machine. I don't think you'll be wowed by it, but you're unlikely to swear at it either.

0:02 Mins More than 20 years ago I did some soul searching and realized I needed to find myself a better toilet paper. After some field tests I settled on a brand called White Cloud, which was produced by Proctor & Gamble. A very short time later, perhaps just a few months, P&G killed off its White Cloud brand, and the toilet paper I'd come to believe was the best available became Charmin Ultra. I watched over the course of maybe a year as the packaging on the White Cloud tissue morphed, its White Cloud branding becoming less noticeable as the Charmin Ultra name became more prominent. Finally the references to White Cloud just disappeared, the old name swallowed up like a ham sandwich within reach of a Charmin bear. This was back in 1993 or 1994.P&G, so I read, allowed its White Cloud trademark to lapse, and starting in 1999, Wal-mart began marketing a White Cloud toilet paper, manufactured by Scott Paper (not to be confused with the short-lived Michael Scott Paper Company). I've never tried this new White Cloud, which has only its name in common with the old White Cloud. Reviews suggest it's worth a go, however.But my point is that I've been a devotee of Charmin Ultra since I made that switch back in 1993. I don't recall purchasing another brand since. I buy the big packs of double rolls as cheap as I can find them at the grocery store. Double rolls, I say. I have NEVER had the nerve to buy the mega rolls because I was worried they wouldn't fit into my fixtures, and I'd have to buy one of those toilet paper extenders one hears about (Charmin Extender Adaptador (For Mega Rolls)). Frankly it all just seemed too complicated.Until now. I've made the plunge, people, and come out the other side, and I've learned a lot.There are three sizes of Charmin toilet paper rolls: double (with 164 sheets per roll), mega (308 sheets), and mega plus (369). There is apparently no such thing as a single roll, although the existence of a double roll would suggest that there should be. I can't speak about the mega plus--I'm not sure I've ever SEEN a mega plus in real life--but I can tell you that the circumference of a mega roll is 2.5 inches more than the circumference of a double roll (16.25 vs. 13.75 inches). (Note that the double rolls are wound more loosely than the mega rolls.) So, the big question is, would a roll of toilet paper 2.5 inches larger than anything I've ever used fit in my bathroom fixtures?I'm happy to say that the answer is YES. It is admittedly a tighter fit than before, but not so tight as to be a problem. Anything larger, however, would not fit: that means you, Charmin Ultra Mega Plus.So does this mean that I'll now be switching to mega rolls? It looks like the answer is no. I've done some price comparisons and from what I've seen (though your results may vary), a 12-pack of mega rolls tends to sell for the same price as a 24-pack of double rolls. You might be fooled into thinking that this is a wash, but consider that there are 3936 sheets of toilet paper in 24 double rolls vs. 3696 sheets in 12 mega rolls: if you buy the mega roll, you're paying the same price for 240 fewer sheets.(The sheets are the same size in both.)  [EDIT! I'm seeing some packages of Charmin Ultra Soft mega rolls online with 308 sheets, and some with 328! Very confusing. If you find packages with 328 sheets per roll, then that's exactly twice the number of sheets as are in a double roll, and 12 mega rolls would indeed equal 24 double rolls.]In coming to a decision about roll sizes yourself you'll want to consider the following factors:Price: Which size costs less per sheet or square foot in your area?Storage Space: Do the rolls fit wherever you usually store them?Bathroom Fixtures: Do the mega or mega plus rolls fit in your bathroom fixtures? If not, you may have to purchase the Charmin Extender. My research suggests that, at nearly $10 a pop, you're never going to save enough buying mega rolls to earn back that outlay.Convenience: How irritated are you about the frequency with which you need to change your toilet paper rolls? Would ridding yourself of that irritation be worth the price of one or more toilet paper extenders?All important questions.While I can't tell you what size toilet paper you should purchase, I can wholeheartedly recommend Charmin Ultra. You work hard. You play hard. You deserve it.Good luck with your decision, one and all, and Godspeed!

The Oceanique popcorn rug is attractive, but I certainly wouldn't call it plush. I don't mind its feel on my feet, but other family members find stepping on the "kernels" of the rug unpleasant. The 17" x 24" rug, which is what I received, is on the small side, but it's ideal for certain bathroom setups. Buyers should just be careful when they order that they know which of the two available sizes they're getting.There are two problems with the rug that keep me from recommending it with any gusto. First, the backing isn't rubberized, so it slips around in a way that you really don't want in a frequently used bathroom. For this reason I've moved it from our main bathroom to a half bath that doesn't have a shower/tub. Second, the instructions call for you to wash it in cold water--fine--and lay it flat to dry. This is just so not going to happen. At least not often. Where on earth am I supposed to lay it flat to dry? And how long is the rug going to be out of operation when I do? Yet another reason to move it to a bathroom where it's less likely to need frequent cleaning.

Retired OSI agent Maxine Decker continues to grow on me. In her third outingafter The Blade and The Shieldshe finds out about a long submerged, corroded Nazi device that's recently surfaced in Mexico. Whatever the thing is, and despite its condition, it's worth killing for. And as you might guess, Maxine and her former husband, OSI Special Agent Kenny Gates, are on the short list of potential victims.The book follows Maxine and Kenny as they try to figure out what's going on: it turns out that the Nazi relic is tied to a very real threat in the present day, and thousands of American lives are at stake. The main story is interrupted periodically by excerpts from an old diary. A woman named Magda Scarlet provides a riveting account of a personal tragedy. Her story seems at first to be completely unrelated to the modern-day drama that's keeping Maxine busy, but of course it's not. Eventually the two storylines merge, and it's a bit of a surprise when they do. (My one complaint about the book is that Magda Scarlet's transformation is so dramatic that it perhaps strains credibility.)The Tomb is a quick read with short chapters that keep you turning the pages. An entertaining plot, but I'm increasingly in it for the characters. I really like the relationship between Maxine and Kenny: it's a sweet romance that somehow keeps you hooked despite their history. Their happily ever after didn't take the first time, but we're hoping they'll give it a second shot.[Disclaimer: I received a review copy of this book from the authors.]

Buying a 10-port USB hub was one of the best decisions I've ever made...and I made it three years ago. I bought Plugable's  10-Port High Speed Hub, and it's worked perfectly for me ever since. I mention this because as far as I can see, the TRENDnet 10-port USB Hub is identical to the Plugable hub in all respects except for the logo and writing on top of the device.The design of both units is exquisite. They have a small footprint and come with long cords so they can easily be positioned at a convenient spot on your desk. Of course each device will increase by nine the number of available USB slots you'll have, and they'll make those slots MUCH more accessible. Both units have two flip-up ports in the rear, which makes them even more convenient. Both are plug and play, and take about three seconds to install and start using.I love my Plugable. And if the TRENDnet holds up as well as the Plugable has, I'll love it just as much.

I'm no expert on batteries. I don't understand anything about the specifics of how power is consumed and so on. So my approach to this product is as a fairly ignorant but perhaps average consumer. I now own three different battery chargers. One of them has the same capacity as this one (5,600 mAh), and the other has about a third that capacity. So the 5,600 mAh chargers are able to put out about three times as much power as the other one, and they will take a correspondingly longer time to charge. That's about it for my appreciation of how they work.The chargers do all differ in their appearance/shape, in the extras they come with, and in how they are recharged. So, for example, I have a Tylt ENERGI2 1800 mAh charger that is a square shape, rather thick, that has built-in prongs that can pop out and plug into a wall. That's an extremely convenient feature. Another charger, the Gembonics 5600mAh, comes with a squid-like cord that has a bunch of different cords all attached together--lightning, mini-USB, USB and the old Apple connector. Also convenient, although sometimes I think it doesn't make a very good connection with my iPod.At any rate, the Amazon Basics charger doesn't have a squid cord or prongs. It comes with a simple, very short USB to mini USB cord for charging. You have to supply your own cord for charging your devices (at least, those that don't take mini USB). I don't mind this, as it's usually pretty easy to have the right cord at hand. What I like most about this one is its size and shape. It's about the same width as my iPod Touch 5, a little thicker and a little shorter. It's a great size for slipping in a shirt or pants pocket. As for aesthetics, I really like the matte black finish. The charger also comes with a little drawstring bag, which I suppose is a nice touch, but I can't imagine ever bothering to store it in there. Perhaps if I were traveling with it....In short, I really like the look and size of this charger. It could be improved by coming with a squid cord such as I describe above, but this is hardly a deal breaker. Recharging it isn't as convenient as recharging my Tylt, but then the convenient size of this device precludes its having built-in prongs.

So this is what a quality pan feels like....I've been using this set of pans for several weeks now, and they've been great. The anti-stick coating is very effective. (As the pan ages, of course, it may work less well. Time will tell.) Eggs, for example, when using a little bit of spray oil, will slide right out of the pan. It's a heavy pan. Initially I thought it might be cumbersome for that reason, but what I like about it is that it sits very firmly on the stove burner. I have some other pans that are light enough that the handle weighs down one side of the pan, and that turns out to be surprisingly annoying.The heaviness/thickness of the pan probably is also responsible for its handling high eats particularly well. Where my other, lighter pans would be smoking and would burn food in high heat, these hold up very well and heat evenly.The stainless steel handle is riveted onto the pan and it feels very solid and well constructed. I was a little worried that the handle would heat up enough while cooking that I would have to use a pot holder to touch it, but that hasn't happened. I've had the pan over heat long enough, for example, to carmelize a bunch of onions and then cook hamburgers, and the handle has never become anything more than pleasantly warm.The only criticism I can think of regarding these pans is not really a fair one to make: I'd prefer it if they were a little deeper. Very often, when cooking for three or four in the larger pan and flipping stuff with a spatula, the food is in danger of falling over the sides if I'm not careful. But as I say, it's not fair to fault this pan for not being a different size.

We've been very pleased with this towel set. The bath towel is nice and large, and the towels are fluffy but not too fluffy. (This is a matter of taste. I'm used to towels that are a step above sandpaper, so I'm accustomed to a certain roughness in towel use. Indeed, I actually want a bit of that road feel, if you will, when drying off.) There haven't been any problems with the towels. The first couple of washes produced a fair amount of lint, but I think that stage is now over with. I liked these towels enough, in fact, that I wound up ordering six additional Pinzon 550-gram bath towels, in different colors. (Those purchased towels are slightly different, as they come with a wider stripe than these for some reason. I prefer the narrower stripe.) The Pinzon label is Amazon's house brand. As I learned in a helpful towel review by Margaret Picky, the name is fitting: Vicente Pinzn was a Spanish explorer who sailed with Columbus in 1492 and discovered the Amazon River.

This twine dispenser is so well designed it'll make you wish you had more uses for string. I swear to you that after putting this thing together and using it a few times, I Googled "clever uses for string." There's really nothing to fault here: the product fits together easily; it works perfectly; it looks great; and as I say, the design is flawless. Would that every product were as well thought out as this dispenser.

2:01 MinsThere are two things to consider in reviewing the Angel Soft Soft Packs: the tissues themselves, and their newfangled soft delivery system. As for the tissues, they're just okay in my book. Serviceable, but not as soft as our go-to tissues, the Cadillac of tissues, Kleenexes. And the delivery system? Well, I find it kind of exciting. My daughter and I have created a video that illustrates how tissues are likely to be used in the average family. It also demonstrates the ease/lack of ease with which the tissues can be removed from the pack. As the video shows, the first few tissues are a little hard to get out. It helps if you adopt a sort of swish and flick, bend and snap approach: lift up to one corner of the opening and down to the other. Once you get past the first few, they come out fast and easy. You won't encounter difficulties again until you get to the last few tissues, when the pack is light enough that you'll want to hold it down with one hand while removing the tissue with the other.I quite like the soft pack because of its advantages over cardboard: you can grab a pack for your car, say, and it won't get crushed and broken, like cardboard boxes do. You don't have to dig your fingers into a cardboard box to take out the last tissues when they're no longer popping up as they should. So I'm sold on the soft pack idea, and the tissues themselves are good enough.

I haven't yet read the last couple of books in this series: while I was off doing other things Mma Makutsi changed her title and had a baby--pretty big doings. Still, time moves slowly in McCall Smith's Botswana, and one is able to jump into his books out of order without missing too much. This time out, Mma Ramotswe is asked to discover the identity of a woman with amnesia. She also concerns herself with the future of Charlie, her husband's girl-chasing apprentice mechanic. Meanwhile, Mma Makutsi is wading more fully into entrepreneurship by opening the caf of the book's title: things don't quite go as planned. As always, it's a delight to spend some time in the company of Mma Ramotswe and her people. McCall Smith's writing is a simple joy, in the way that watching dust motes waft lazily in a shaft of summer sunlight is a joy. Life should have more such moments. And more such books. Fortunately, Mr. McCall Smith is a most prolific author.

There's nothing to complain about here. I filled the dispenser with regular hand soap (Care One brand), and it has performed flawlessly. The dispenser has a large mouth, making it easy to fill. It's easy to use, because the entire head of the dispenser gets pushed down to pump the soap. It dispenses the soap without any problem, and without dripping onto the counter afterwards. Plus, it looks good. (By the way, the lid of the dispenser I received is not white, as pictured. The circular top--not the sides or the spigot--is a silver metal. I think I would have preferred an all white top.)

Joel Dicker's much ballyhooed The Truth about the Harry Quebert Affair is a very long book. Reading it, one has a lot of time to think about whether jumping into a 650-odd page tome was a good idea. I'm still not sure. There was a lot I didn't like about it. A litany of complaints: I'm pretty sure a lot of the book could have been lopped off to good effect. I found much of the story implausible. The too-precious chapter openings--in which Harry gives Marcus advice about writing--are often nauseating. Marcus' mother--a minor character, thank you, Jesus--is a ludicrous caricature of a Jewish mother. Everyone was supposed to love the fifteen-year-old Nola--whose disappearance in 1975 is the book's great mystery--but the persona she presented to people, as described in the book, was not particularly likable in my opinion. And the book within a book, Harry Quebert's alleged masterpiece, well, it reads like schlock in the snippets that punctuate this book. Towards the end, my interest in the story increased as we finally found out whodunit. And there is indeed a decent mystery buried in these pages. But there are so many twists and turns in the last couple chapters that I wound up not really caring by the end of it what had really happened to Nola.

Taboo is a simple but very fun party or family game in which teams of players compete to guess words given a set of clues. The person given the clues tries to get his or her teammates to say a specified word while not saying any of the taboo words. One real example from Taboo Buzzd: the target word is VELCRO, but the clue giver can't say FASHION, FABRIC, STICK, or ZIP. The standard Taboo game comes with boxes of cards, a buzzer (for use when the clue giver says a taboo word), and a small hourglass for timing rounds.Taboo Buzzd offers pretty much the same game play but in a more portable package. Like the traditional game, it comes loaded with about 1000 words to be guessed, and of course the timer is built into the game. It works fine, and it's more convenient than playing the card game. But there are two negatives which may turn you off:1. While you're playing the game, there is an electronic timer ticking down the seconds, gradually becoming more insistent until there's a sort of explosion when your time is up. This is convenient, obviously, because it notifies you when the round is up: with the traditional game, it's very easy to get caught up in game play and not notice that the sand in the hourglass has run out. Unfortunately, the ticking sound in the Buzzd game is extremely loud and annoying, and there is no volume button. I've covered the speaker on my machine with packing tape. This helps a little bit, but it's still irritatingly loud.2. Taboo Buzzd is very low tech. It has a small screen with a pixelated font and four buttons. It looks like something that could have been on the market in 1990. It gets the job done, so I suppose it doesn't have to be any more complicated than it is, but I'd expect more of a game selling for this much. Buzzd looks like something you should be picking up in a discount store for about a quarter the price.

Turns out, even at six inches, this locker organizer is too wide for my daughter's (very narrow) middle school locker, so it will have to await actual locker use until high school. We can't test it, then, to see how well it holds up to locker slamming. My guess is that the magnet on the back is substantial enough to take the slams, but I wouldn't be surprised if the dry erase marker can sometimes be jostled out of its cup.The organizer is pretty simple: it comes with a decent mirror and a marker, and the glossy surface of the entire organizer can be written on with the marker. I'm not sure how practical it is, really. There's not that much space to write on, and any notes necessarily can't be taken home with you. So I guess you'd be writing notes to remind yourself only of things that are happening at school. ("Band practice at 3:00!" That sort of thing.) I suppose it's principal function really is as a mirror. But even if it's not particularly practical, your kids may find it fun to have a small place to express themselves on the inside of their locker.

I read Eric Jager's The Last Duel some eight years ago, and it still stands out for me as one of the best books I've read since I began blogging books. I was delighted, then, when the author sent me a copy of his new book, Blood Royal: A True Tale of Crime and Detection in Medieval Paris. As the subtitle promises, Blood Royal tells the story of a crime, the murder of Louis of Orleans, who was struck down one night in 1407 by a gang of assassins. This was no ordinary murder, because Louis was the brother of the King of France, Charles VI (a.k.a. Charles the Mad). Charles' intermittent bouts of insanity led to disputes between Louis and a cousin, John of Burgundy, over the regency and guardianship of Charles' young heir. Louis, then, was more involved in the government of France (and, incidentally, with Charles' wife Isabeau) than he would have been were his brother not crazy.Roughly the first half of Jager's book tells the story of the build-up to the assassination and the investigation of the crime by the Provost of Paris, Guillaume de Tignonville. Jager also provides us with backstory about Tignonville and the prisons and executions he oversaw--very interesting, gory stuff. Tignonville's original police report is extant, happily, preserved on a parchment scroll, and it allows Jager to paint a detailed account of what happened in the days leading up to and immediately following Louis' murder. Ordinary Parisians, by virtue of living near the scene of the crime, were suddenly part of a nationally important investigation, and their everyday movements, documented by interrogators, became part of the historical record. As Jager writes in his epilogue, "The events of November 1407 lit up their lives like a flash of lightning, and the Provost's scribes briefly captured their excited and worried voices, which then fell into silence and near oblivion." I can't emphasize enough how interesting I find this sort of history, getting a glimpse of the lives of ordinary people from a lost world going about their ordinary business: a purveyor of wicker baskets, a nosy neighbor woman who slept in the nude, watercarriers who made their living delivering buckets of river water to private residences.The second half of the book deals with larger issues, the national and international ramifications of Louis' murder: civil war in France, renewed hostilities with England, the unthinkable savagery of the Hundred Years' War. Tignonville is mostly missing from this part of the book, and ordinary folk are looked at only in the aggregate. This larger story is of course the big picture stuff that changes history, but for me Jager's story--and nonfiction generally--is most successful when it focuses on and fully unpacks small events. And Jager is expert at doing so.

The Quartet Magnetic Combination board is a decent white board for the price. The plastic frame is cheap, but it comes in attractive colors, and the strip of cork board down the side somehow makes it look nicer. The board comes with two striped magnets for affixing items to the white board part.I was worried that the cork board would not be deep enough to take a regular thumbtack. If you look at the board closely, it looks like the white board fills up the whole frame and an almost paper-thin swath of cork board is laid over that. I'm not sure how it's constructed, but in fact the cork board works fine: I had no trouble inserting standard sized pushpins.The one negative I see is that the mounting magnets that are included in the package are not strong enough to hold the weight of the board: put it on your refrigerator, and it will slowly slide down to the floor. Otherwise, the board does the job it has to do, and it looks pretty good doing it.

This is a decent white board for the price. The frame is plastic, which betrays its cheapness, but it comes in attractive colors--mine is green--which is nice. The board comes with two magnets which can be used to affix items to the white board. Some of these Quartet magnets come with magnets that have a striped design. My board came with clear magnets, which are considerably less attractive than the striped magnets. Having this be a magnetic bulletin board is a nice touch, though I'm not sure yet if that will prove to be an important factor after continued use.The frame also comes with double sided tape and mounting magnets so that you can either affix the board to a wall or to a metal surface. To do the latter, you first position the tape on the back, then affix the magnets to the tape: the magnets themselves aren't sticky, in other words. I did not try hanging the board up on a wall, so I'm not sure whether that would hold well. But I did put the self-adhesive tape and magnets on the back and tried putting it up on my refrigerator. Unfortunately, the magnets weren't strong enough to hold the weight of the board, which slowly slid down the refrigerator door. It held a little more firmly--though not firmly enough--to the door of our dishwasher (the difference being, perhaps, that the refrigerator door is textured and the dishwasher door is smooth).So the two downsides of the board are the ugly magnets and the fact that the mounting magnets it comes with can't do the job of holding it up. The latter is the more important concern, but it's not a deal-breaker. In short, a good enough white board.

My first, many attempts at using this product one-handed didn't go well. The tape worked as advertised only maybe one out of five times. It eventually dawned on me, however, that I was holding the dispenser wrong. You have to hold it in such a way that the movement of the roll of tape is in no way impeded by your hand. In other words, you have to hold it in a rather unnatural way, very consciously only touching the dispenser with your fingers (your palm can't come into play) in order for it to work. Once you do that, it works fine. And the tape seems sturdy and sticky enough to do its job. So, in the end, I'm a little disappointed with the dispenser (and in myself, for not recognizing what I was doing wrong sooner), but if used properly it does do a decent job.

The Swingline Fashion Stapler looks cheap. It's all straight lines and bargain bin-looking plastic, and the rubber feet on the bottom are narrow little strips that just look ineffectual. Aesthetically speaking, it's not much, except for its color--though this shade of green just seems wrong to me as a stapler color.That said, I've now tested the Swingline against my trusty Red Stapler, and its performance has surprised me. My Red Stapler has formerly contended with and handily beaten the PaperPro StandOut Standup Stapler (see my review: http://www.amazon.com/review/RU4RHFHA1DBRD/). But I'm afraid that it's now met its match (with an important caveat--see below). The Swingline has a solid feel to it, and it's easy to use one-handed. It turns out that it can also handle a lot of paper at one time. I tested both staplers by having them staple multiple sheets of paper together. At 27 sheets the Swingline is still going strong, and I can still use it easily with one hand. But my Red Stapler falters at this stage: it can still staple effectively if I use two hands, or if I use it against a desk, but one handed stapling simply doesn't work. The Swingline definitely wins the day here.The important caveat alluded to above may turn out to be a big problem.The hinge of the stapler, where it opens and closes, has a metal rod going through it. It's a plus that it's not plastic: the hinges of some mini staplers are made of plastic, and they inevitably break there. But the problem is that while the rod has a head on one end that keeps it in place, there is nothing keeping the rod in place on the other end. (By contrast, my Red Stapler is constructed in such a way that the rod in its hinge could not come loose.) Twice already the rod has started to work its way loose. It's something that I'll have to keep an eye on for the life of this stapler. Yet another sign of cheap construction, but in this case one that has more than aesthetic ramifications.So, the Swingline gets 5 stars on performance, and perhaps 3 on appearance. Marks off also for the metal rod problem. I'm still giving it 4 stars, however, since performance, I think, trumps the other two considerations.

The Eureka AirSpeed does a good job as a quick touch-up vacuum. It offers a number of advantages, chief among them that it's extremely light. It's also corded and so is pretty powerful, and it's easy to assemble and use. All very good. Against this are a few disadvantages. At 16 feet, the cord is rather short. Looking at other stick vacuums on Amazon, this doesn't seem to be an unusual length for this type of product, but it is inconvenient. Plug the vacuum in a few feet from the base of your stairs, and you may have trouble doing the entire stairway without moving the cord to a different outlet. The vacuum comes with a crevice tool. The tool has a ring that attaches to the stick of the vacuum, but the connection is not very strong and the thing falls off constantly. Finally, the handle does not feel very strong where it attaches to the vacuum unit. I feel like it would snap if too much pressure were put on it. None of these complaints are a big deal, but they do detract a bit from the user experience. To sum up, here are my pros and cons:PROS-- VERY light weight-- Easy to assemble-- Easy to use (emptying, for example, and putting back together again)-- Corded/powerfulCONS-- 16-foot cord is too short for some tasks-- Crevice tool falls off routinely when in storage position-- Handle doesn't feel solid

This is a pretty basic device, so there's not much to be said about it. The ring of the Brewing Buddy sits atop a cup. You put coffee grounds in the mesh sac, and add hot water. The results doubtless wouldn't please a coffee aficionado, but the device does the job. It's easy to wash. The ring is sturdy and stays where it's supposed to. Nothing to complain about, really.

This is a handy first aid kit to have around the house. It comes stocked with a lot of everyday first aid supplies: band aids, thermometers, gauze pads, aspirins, a cold pack, and so on. It seems like an okay value for the price at which it's currently selling on Amazon (around thirty dollars), although the grayed-out list price Amazon shows (over a hundred dollars) is crazy. The case itself is quite nice: lots of little compartments to fit things in so they don't all get mixed up together. I've moved our old first aid supplies into this case because it's better than the unsegmented box we were using.The case comes with screws for hanging it on a wall. In theory, I suppose that would be a good idea. You could create an immobile first-aid station whose whereabouts everyone would know. But in fact, if you kept this case on the wall and tried to open it when vertical, everything would fall out once you open the door. You could store the case is vertically, but I would recommend opening it only when it's horizontal.-- Debra Hamel

The FK100 is a really handy utility knife, and easy to operate once you figure out how it works. There's not much to it, but the instructions were so cryptic that I had to play with it for a while just to figure out how to load the blade and how to fold the knife up when finished. (To insert the blade, push the button near the front of the device *when it's half folded up.* To close the knife, you have to push aside a piece of metal in the handle.) I like that the blade can only come out when the knife is not fully extended--it's safer to use that way. And I like very much the solid feel and grippiness of the device in your hand. It's an elegant tool, much better than those one-piece utility knives I've used in the past which leave the blade exposed when not in use (and which you have to unscrew to insert a blade).

To an extent, one's opinion of the Contigo Jackson water bottle will be a matter of taste. Do you like drinking from the bottle's wide mouth or not? I find that I don't. I prefer narrow tops the size of, say, Poland Spring water bottles. Others may like water bottles that come with built-in straws. I imagine it's just a question of what you're used to.Beyond the question of taste, there are more objective considerations. On the plus side, the Contigo bottle is slender enough to fit easily into the mesh pockets on the side of knapsacks. And that wide mouth makes filling the bottle, or putting ice in it, quite easy. It's also easy to open the lid to take a drink from it. Push a button on the side of the cap and the lid snaps open. But that easiness is to my mind also a serious drawback: the lid is *too* easy to open. I would strongly advise against putting it inside a knapsack, for example, since the lid could easily snap open accidentally and soak your belongings. (My daughter dropped the bottle on the floor once and it opened accidentally.)My only other negative is minor. There's a colored loop on the top of the lid that swings open. You can use it to carry the water bottle. But this seems more aesthetic than practical: it doesn't seem like it would be comfortable to carry the bottle by its loop for a long time. And the plastic loop could be cracked with one good drop, rendering it useless.-- Debra Hamel

On the one hand, I can't fault the construction of this hamper. It fits together easily. The handles are comfortable. The material is sturdy but lightweight. The cover is cleverly designed so that the flaps are flexible but remain in position when not in use. It looks decent. My problem is that, at least for me, the Good Grips Double Flip hamper actually makes the job of doing laundry more difficult.A standard, plastic laundry basket is a pretty flexible tool. (1) You can collect dirty clothes in it, including sorting clothes into different baskets if you're so inclined. (2) You can carry the dirty clothes to your laundry room. (3) You can easily move the clothes from the basket into the washing machine, either by (a) dumping them in (because the size of the laundry basket allow this to be done easily) or by (b) extracting clothes from the basket selectively by hand. (4) When the laundry is done, you can fold the now clean clothes back into the laundry basket and carry them back to where they need to be.The Good Grips hamper does a good job at number (1) above, collection. It's okay at number (2), though the hamper is a bit more awkward to carry around than your average laundry basket. But it fails at numbers (3) and (4). The hamper is too awkward and too big to lift up so as to dump clothes into a washing machine--and the double basket would make dumping problematic anyway. It's also too deep to comfortably extract clothes from. (And where to put it while you're picking clothes out? On a floor and you have to bend down too much. On a table of regular height and it's too tall to reach into. Perhaps it would work if you put it on a chair--if you happen to have room in your laundry room for one.) The hamper is likewise too deep to make it useful for folding clothes back into when they're clean.In short, the hamper is a nicely constructed item that does not serve its principal purpose well. I've decided to put mine to use instead to store balls in--basketballs, soccer balls, etc. It works well for that, but then again, the Good Grips hamper comes with a pretty hefty price tag. You may not consider it a good value for storing sporting equipment.-- Debra Hamel

The X-ACTO SharpX Electric Pencil Sharpener is a powerful sharpener intended to handle a lot of work--more an office or school machine than a home machine. It sharpens pencils very quickly and in my experience so far evenly. It has a big drawer for shavings with an LED light that signals when the drawer is full, which is a nice feature. The best feature is that it stops sharpening when it senses the pencil is sharpened: the motor keeps going, but the teeth aren't engaged, so what tells you that the pencil is ready is a slight change in the sound. (Actually, if you're adding LED lights, one that lights up when the pencil is sharpened would be nice.)For the most part, this sharpener is a winner:-- It's powerful.-- It stops sharpening when the pencil is sharp.-- It has a large drawer for shavings that's fairly easily removed.-- The dial for pencil size is easy to adjust.There are negatives, however, which may influence your buying decision:-- When you pull out the drawer you'll inevitably find more shavings under it, perhaps knocked loose from the mechanism as you're pulling out the drawer.-- The  unit has suction cups on the bottom that hold it in place when it's sitting on a kitchen counter (for example), but these won't hold it in place when it's on a wooden surface. You'll then have to hold the unit steady in one hand while you sharpen, which is a bit less convenient.-- The sharpener is *big* and takes up a lot of real estate.-- De gustibus, of course, but in my opinion the sharpener is seriously ugly. I realize, however, that worrying about the attractiveness or not of one's pencil sharpener is probably the epitome of First World problems.In all the most meaningful respects, then, this sharpener does a good job, and it comes recommended.-- Debra Hamel

The Ambient Weather WR-111B emergency crank radio is similar in my ways to the Etn American Red Cross ARCFR160R Microlink Self-Powered AM/FM/NOAA Weather Radio with Flashlight, Solar Power and Cell Phone Charger (Red), which we purchased, by luck, just a couple of weeks before Hurricane Irene hit in 2011. Both radios include an AM/FM/weather radio, flashlight and cell phone charger, but there are some differences between the two. I like both, for different reasons. Here are the points in the Ambient's favor:1. Both radios can be charged by solar power and hand crank, but the Ambient Weather radio can also be charged by USB device--you can plug it into your computer (cord included) or, if you have the proper converters, into an outlet or your car. (These alternate means of powering the device would mostly be important if you plan on using the radio other than during emergencies, perhaps if you can foresee being without power and you want to charge it up ahead of time.)2. In addition to providing weather radio, the Ambient has a weather alert mode: it will go into standby until there's a weather alert. I have tried out the mode but have not yet been notified of an alert.3. The phone charger on the Ambient is more convenient than the one on the Etn. With the Ambient, you plug your phone into the charged radio, and it charges your phone. It's easy, and my phone hooked up easily and started charging with no problem at all. But with the Etn you need to plug in the phone and crank. I'm not even sure that I've managed to get it to charge at all by this method, as there was no indication on my phone screen that it was charging.Of the above points, I personally only care about the third. If the Etn had the same cell phone charging system as the Ambient, I'd be happy. Here's what I like about the Etn:1. This may be superficial, but the Etn is just a much nicer looking device, and it's smaller, so it fits in your hand better. By contrast, the Ambient is bulky and kind of ugly.2. The directions that come with the Etn are short and sweet, whereas the pamphlet that comes with the Ambient is intimidating.3. It's nice that the Ambient comes with cords and connectors (two cords with three connectors, to be precise), and yet, this also makes it a bit more unwieldy. You have to carry them with you, keep them with the radio, worry about losing them. That suggests maybe you should keep the box the radio came in to store them in, and it just takes away some of the attraction of the radio.4. [EDITED! See below.] The biggest point that the Etn has in its favor over the Ambient, however, is the radio tuning. The Etn has old-fashioned dials for station and volume. They may not be sexy, but they work, and they work fast. The Ambient has a digital tuner, and you advance through it one click at a time: 99.1, 99.2, 99.3, 99.4...you get the picture. There's no way to make this go faster: if you hold down the button, it doesn't start speeding through the numbers. If you have children at home during a blackout, for example, with only an emergency radio for entertainment--children who are accustomed to pecking through preset radio stations like crazed pigeons (or something)--then tempers will run high.EDIT: It turns out that the Ambient *does* have radio scanning! You just have to push in the tun+ or tun- far longer than I expected. So, forget the whole crazed pigeon scenario. And yes the auto scanning was mentioned in the directions, but I guess I didn't read the fine print carefully enough.In short, I prefer the Etn for its form factor, but if cell phone charging is a big concern, the Ambient's probably a better bet.-- Debra Hamel

Since the new normal here in the northeast seems to be lengthy power outages following annual hurricanes and winter storms, it's a good idea to have flashlights or lanterns at the ready. The Energizer LED lantern is a very thoughtfully-designed emergency light. There are a number of details that I quite like:-- It folds up into a very compact unit, easily held in one hand.-- The strap, when closed, can be put around the unit to keep it from popping open accidentally (in a knapsack, for example, if you were using it for camping).-- The light can be dimmed by pressing the on/off button for an extended period of time.-- The battery pack is accessed at the bottom of the unit. There's a screw at the bottom, but what's nice is that the groove is so big it can be unscrewed using a coin: no need to search for a screwdriver in the dark.When on at full strength, the light is quite bright, and able to light up an entirely dark room pretty well.There are two potential negatives in the design that I can see. The first has to do with the handle. It's permanently attached to the device on one side. On the other side the handle has a clip. If you want to use the handle as an actual handle when the lantern is open, you'll wind up having to manipulate it rather a lot: you have to unclip it and reattach it so the handle will go up, then unclip and reattach so that it wraps around the base of the lantern. My concern is that the plastic clip at the end of the handle won't be able to handle the strain. (That said, you can put less strain on the clip if you attach it before wrapping the handle around the bottom. It's easier to push the handle into position when clipped than to clip it when the handle is already in position.)Second, I said above that the handle protects the lantern from opening accidentally when packed in a knapsack, but there's nothing to prevent it from being turned on accidentally: the big red on button could easily be pushed in under such conditions, wasting batteries and, perhaps, leading to the lantern not being available for use when you really need it. Of course, if you're not packing this up for use on the go, then this wouldn't be an issue.A final note: The unit turns on and off with single clicks. But if your click is a little slow when you try to turn it off, you'll find that it doesn't turn off. You might think there's something wrong with the on/of switch, but it's fine: it's just that if you linger when clicking then the light will start dimming instead of turning off. Click quickly.-- Debra Hamel

The Good Thief's Guide to Amsterdam is the first book in Chris Ewan's series about Charles Howard, the author of a bestselling series of books about a thief who just happens to be a thief himself: I can't tell you how much I love this idea. Needless to say, the book is set in Amsterdam, where Charles runs into problems with both of his careers, though the focus is naturally on the illegal side of his life. The only other character who's likely to show up in subsequent books is his editor, a woman he's never met but whom he tells all to on the phone. Charles also runs into a con man who makes a good character and who I can see possibly showing up again if he doesn't mind traveling: the next book in the series is set in Paris. I was prepared to love the book because of its setup and instead just liked it a lot: enough that I'll be reading more in the series. I'm also eager to read the author's stand-alone thriller Safe House.-- Debra Hamel

Pretty much every man, woman, and child in beautiful Pagford and its ugly, socioeconomically depressed appendage known as "The Fields" lives a miserable existence. Children hate parents, spouses hate spousees, everyone is mean or depressed or abusive or abused. J.K. Rowling's first post-Potter book The Casual Vacancy shows us that muggles can be every bit as unpleasant as Death Eaters. I did eventually become somewhat interested in Rowling's characters, and ultimately the story was moving, but it took much longer than I wish it had for me to become invested, and all the while there really wasn't anyone I wanted to root for. (Okay, there were a couple of teens who were more abused than abusive, but I still wouldn't want my daughters hanging around with either of them.)-- Debra Hamel

Every Day is an Atheist Holiday brings more stories from Penn Jillette, who is an interesting guy. He's smart and opinionated and foul-mouthed and godless (thank god) and also very well-meaning and sentimental. He's been naked in public more than you might expect and is more forthcoming about his sex life than you might wish. Reading his stuff is the literary equivalent of listening to his Penn's Sunday School podcasts, which are recommended.-- Debra Hamel

Luther: The Calling is a prequel to the BBC television series Luther, and it tells the story of what happened immediately before the first episode.
