If you saw the series, you'll know that it begins with Luther in a bit of a crisis. This book fills in the gaps in our knowledge, and it fits seamlessly into the story as we know it. The author, Neil Cross, also writes the series, and he captures the characters on paper very well. Very exciting, fast-paced read. I hope Cross writes more of these.-- Debra Hamel

Red Eye's Greg Gutfeld is very smart and very funny, and what he has to say in The Joy of Hate about the abuses of the modern culture of tolerance will make most readers angry--or should. I don't think his humor comes across as well in print as it does on TV. If you're a regular watcher you won't have problems reading the book in his voice, but people new to him may find references to transgendered unicorns and the like rather strange.-- Debra Hamel

Shipwrecked is a very well-written adventure story about a yacht trip that ended badly in 2001. Actually, stepping back from it, the adventure wasn't all that exciting (well, I'm sure it was for the participants, but it's not necessarily exciting enough to warrant a book). But Shubaly's writing makes it worth the read. My only problem was that the whole arc of the story was undone in the very last section of the book--Shubaly, having gone through this ordeal, learned nothing from it, and immediately fell back into his previous, self-destructive ways. I get that that's the truth, but maybe omitting those few sentences from the Single would have made it a stronger piece.-- Debra Hamel

The brown Belkin Leather Cover Folio for the iPad Mini has a lot going for it:-- The case has a nice magnetic clasp that can be put out of the way by bending it back all the way.-- The iPad wakes up and goes to sleep when the cover is opened or closed.-- The cover folds open easily to become a stand so that you can watch movies, etc., in landscape view. It will stay open in two different positions.-- There's a hole in the back cover so that the iPad's camera is not covered.-- Most importantly, the iPad snaps into the stand easily and very securely.As far as negatives, there's not much to say, but:-- The case will not allow you to prop up the iPod vertically, so if you're using it as an e-reader, that may be a disadvantage.-- The volume buttons on the right are a little hard to get to. I suppose it would be hard to make a cover in which this wasn't the case, however, since the edge of the iPod slants inward.-- As far as looks go, the cover is a bit bland, not ugly, but not eye-catching either. It almost has a plastic feel to it, too, despite being leather.Aesthetics aside, however, and despite my other minor quibbles, this is a solid case, and I feel comfortable knowing that my device is securely protected in it.UPDATE 4/15/2013Well, less than a month in and the case broke. It was dropped from a height of about four feet onto a wooden floor and must have hit the floor just right: the upper plastic corner completely snapped off so that it no longer holds the iPad in place at all. I don't know if this is a fault of the case, really: it just happened to hit the floor at a vulnerable spot and broke. But it's a shame that the usefulness of such a nice case depends entirely on fairly breakable plastic.

The cork remover works as advertised. It saves so little effort, however, that it s more a novelty than a useful tool. I actually found the small foil removal tool supplied with the cork remover to be more of a time saver.

These Moshi Moonrock ear buds are marketed--at least on Amazon--as being made for the Kindle Fire. I'm not sure why. They're standard size ear buds and thus can work in probably any media player--certainly they work on both my iPod Touch and my 1st generation Kindle Fire.The ear buds come with three sizes of ear plugs--small, medium, and large--and they fit very comfortably. They also sound great, with minimal noise from the cord. To my mind they're comparable in sound quality to my JBuds J2 Premium Hi-FI Noise Isolating Earbuds Style Headphones, which I also think sound great. Unlike the JBuds, the Moonrocks have a pause switch on the wire: someone's talking to you, and click the button rather than fiddling with your music player. That's very convenient, and it worked fine with my iPod. It did not work, however, with my Kindle Fire. I tried it both while using Amazon's Cloud Player to listen to music and while watching an Amazon Instant Video. Perhaps it would work on the Fire in other apps.Another nice feature of the Moonrocks is that the ear plugs come with two different accent colors--red and white. You could use the same color for both ears if you want, but if you don't, you can color-code it so that you can easily tell which is for which ear: red for right, for example.The Moonrocks come with a cord storage unit. You plug the ear buds into the holes of the unit and then wrap the cord around it. It's made of flexible plastic and there's an opening around the edges. It's a nice idea to include something like this for travel purposes, and its looks cool in the pictures, but I found too awkward to use, and I've stored it away with the product's packaging.All in all, very nice headphones. The case is a disappointment, however, so if that's a big selling point for you, you might want to rethink.-- Debra Hamel

I've installed a toilet seat or two in my day and installing this Mayfair (replacing, I note, a Mayfair that came with our house when we bought it twenty years ago) was definitely an unusual experience. Most toilet seats attach with a plastic nut and bolt. You screw the bolt down through the toilet from the top, and it's covered over when you're done with a plastic housing. To remove the seat, you would snap that housing up and unscrew the bolt, which--were you to do this too much--would easily become stripped. This Mayfair is quite different. What you wind up doing is installing a sort of snap closure onto your toilet. The seat then snaps onto that, and is tightened by shifting what would be the plastic housing on a regular toilet seat. That probably makes it sound very complicated, but it's not difficult to install at all. I just wanted to get across that this is a revolution in toilet seat attachment. With this new mode of attachment it's a very simple thing to take the toilet seat on and off, should you want to. No unscrewing bolts or anything. You just push that housing to the side and lift.Why the change? The manufacturer touts the idea that you can lift the toilet seat off for cleaning purposes. It's really not necessary to remove a toilet seat to clean it, of course, but perhaps some people out there actually do that. More importantly, the new attachment type must be the reason that this toilet seat will--the manufacturer promises us--never loosen. And that is an idea I can get behind. There is surely something uniquely worrying about sitting on a toilet seat that is not firmly attached to its base. And tightening that seat--finding a screw driver, flipping open that by now repulsive housing--is not a task one looks forward to. If this Mayfair can deliver me from that particular hell, I'll be very happy indeed. Time, of course, will tell. Time on the order of years.I said above that installing the seat is easy, and it is. The only problem I had was due to the very confined space between my toilet and the wall, and the accompanying limited visibility. I actually wound up disobeying the instructions, which call for you to attach the snap connector thing to the toilet while it's attached to the seat. Because I couldn't see anything, I finally took the seat off, and tightened what needed tightening as much as I could by hand, then reattached the seat and used a ratchet to finish the job, as directed. If you're likewise struggling blind in a cramped space, you might want to try this as well.A final word. If, like me, you don't read the final sentence or two of the directions fully--satisfied that it must say something like, "tighten completely"--you will likely let loose with an expletive when, upon tightening the bolt, it breaks off. Horrible images went through my mind of having to reinstall the old seat, but it turns out that that the thing is supposed to break. Crazy, eh? So all is well. The toilet seat looks nice and fits perfectly, and I'm looking forward to years of non-slip usage of the thing.

0:23 MinsI've had a Dropcam HD Wi-Fi Wireless Video Monitoring Camera since May 2012 and I've been mostly happy with it, but with two reservations. Most importantly, the picture is dull, with most of the color bleached out, which means that it's not only less pleasant to look at, but less useful than it could be. I've had it pointed at my front porch and, for example, cannot tell whether the red flag on the mailbox is up or not because the red blends in with the green bushes behind it. (Notice that in the attached video you can see the red flag just fine!) Second, the email alerts are not that helpful, for two reasons. First, they're so sensitive that I receive notices when cars go by, which I don't really care about. Second, last I checked with Dropcam, the alerts only go out once every half hour. So if someone comes to your door between one alert and the next, you're not notified by email.With that background, I got my hands on a Belkin NetCam. I was delighted by it immediately. Here's what I like about it:1. The setup was absolutely simple. No problems whatever. I had it running in minutes.2. The picture is BRIGHT. Far brighter than what I get with the Dropcam. I've added two images to this item to show the differences between the two.3. You can take pictures or video of what the camera is seeing on the fly. The video attached to this review was taken that way with the microphone off at 640 x 480, with a frame rate of 15 (out of a possible 30) and a quality of 5 (out f 5).4. You can choose to receive email alerts when the device detects motion. Unlike the Dropcam, there is no thirty-minute delay, so when the camera detects motion, you get an email. This is a good thing. The other thing I like about the email alerts is that they include two pictures rather than one. Very often with the Dropcam, which sends one picture, you get a photo when something has just entered the area being monitored, and you can barely tell what it is. With two pictures, you get that first image and the a second one, when whatever has entered the area farther into the frame. The result is a much more informative alert.What could be improved:1. As for negatives, the only real downside of the device for me also has to do with the email alerts. You can adjust the sensitivity of the motion detection with settings from 1-5. What I'd like is to receive alerts whenever someone comes to my door or is in the front yard, say, some 15 feet from the camera. But none of the settings give me that. A setting of 1 seems to result in no alerts coming in at all. But settings from 2-5 result in my getting alerts for cars driving by. Admittedly, sometimes I seem to get fewer alerts about passing cars than other times, and I'm not sure yet what the pattern is. Certainly all settings from 2-5 have alerted me about traffic in front of the house at one time or another. Hopefully the gradations of motion sensitivity for the alerts can be improved in software updates--I'm not sure if that's possible, however.2. There is no Kindle Fire app (yet?).3. The NetCam does not allow you to talk through the device as the Dropcam does. (That is, using the Dropcam you can talk to people in the room from some external site). But this isn't a feature I care about, but some may.On the whole, highly recommended!-- Debra Hamel

Mr. Monk Gets Even is the 15th book in the Monk series and the last one that Lee Goldberg will be writing. (I see from Amazon that Hy Conrad will be continuing the series.) So, a bittersweet read, as I've enjoyed the series for many years now. This one wasn't quite as funny or even quite as moving as some have been in the past, but it did wrap things up well--wrapped up, at least, as the end of an era rather than of the whole series. I won't give anything away, but Mr. Monk does get even, at least for now: given a universe as unbalanced as ours, things are likely to become odd for him again very soon. And the characters around Monk find themselves in the right places at book's end too. Thanks to Lee Goldberg for many years of good reading.-- Debra Hamel

You can choose to receive email alerts when the device detects motion. Unlike the Dropcam, there is no thirty-minute delay, so when the camera detects motion, you get an email. This is a good thing. The other thing I like about the email alerts is that they include two pictures rather than one. Very often with the Dropcam, which sends one picture, you get a photo when something has just entered the area being monitored, and you can barely tell what it is. With two pictures, you get that first image and the a second one, when whatever has entered the area farther into the frame. The result is a much more informative alert.What could be improved:1. As for negatives, the only real downside of the device for me also has to do with the email alerts. You can adjust the sensitivity of the motion detection with settings from 1-5. What I'd like is to receive alerts whenever someone comes to my door or is in the front yard, say, some 15 feet from the camera. But none of the settings give me that. A setting of 1 seems to result in no alerts coming in at all. But settings from 2-5 result in my getting alerts for cars driving by. Admittedly, sometimes I seem to get fewer alerts about passing cars than other times, and I'm not sure yet what the pattern is. Certainly all settings from 2-5 have alerted me about traffic in front of the house at one time or another. Hopefully the gradations of motion sensitivity for the alerts can be improved in software updates--I'm not sure if that's possible, however.2. There is no Kindle Fire app (yet?).3. The NetCam does not allow you to talk through the device as the Dropcam does. (That is, using the Dropcam you can talk to people in the room from some external site). But this isn't a feature I care about, but some may.On the whole, highly recommended!-- Debra Hamel

I was worried that the handle of the OXO Good Grips dust pan would be too short and I'd have to stoop a bit to use it, but not so: I'm 5'9" and it's not too short at all. The broom is not a full-sized broom. It would take forever to sweep a room with it, for example, but there's no reason to try. Just use a regular broom, then finish up the job with this set. If you think of the broom as a whisk broom, which it is, then you won't be disappointed.The design incorporates teeth for cleaning out the broom, which is clever. One negative is that it's a little clumsy to empty the catch into the garbage. You kind of have to hold it up awkwardly by the handle at a 90 degree angle. I'm not sure how or if that could be improved.I don't know how excited I can get about a whisk broom set, but this does the job pretty well. I certainly prefer it to squatting down with a regular whisk broom to pick stuff up.UPDATEI've just increased my rating to five stars because, in fact, I have become pretty excited about this broom. It turns out that it's so convenient to use that I wind up spot sweeping all the time, which means that my kitchen stays cleaner. I'm quite happy with it.-- Debra Hamel

The Withings WS-30 Wireless Scale (it's apparently pronounced with a long I as in Wi-Fi, i., Wi-Things) is an elegant piece of equipment. It's shiny and modern and good-looking, and it feels sturdy on the floor. (I mention that because my previous scale, the Taylor 7506 Glass and Chrome Digital Scale, is--by design I think--a little unsteady, and I find that annoying.) Setting up the scale was surprisingly easy, for the most part. Everything that might have been hard was easy. It connected immediately to my wifi and I was able to connect it with both my Fitbit account and with a fantastic IOS app I've been using for years, Weightbot. The Withings' weigh-ins synch flawlessly with both. One can view one's information both on the web and via iPhone/iPad apps. I probably won't use the web interface very much but will stick with the IOS app or view my results on Fitbit or Weightbot. (The web interface is much less elegant than the IOS apps.) The device recognized both of my daughters immediately, but it took a couple of weigh-ins, for some reason, for it to recognize my husband and me. But that solved itself very quickly and wasn't an issue.I did have a couple of problems, however, that are both related to a lack of easily found documentation for the product. After the amazing ease of setting up the scale and connecting it, a question of mere minutes, it took me literally about a half hour to figure out how to change the display units on the device from kilograms to pounds. (I finally discovered the information online on Withing's Zendesk account. You have to push that button on the bottom of the device that looks like a computer monitor, then look at the display. To select from the possible units press that same button again.) It also took me a long time to figure out how to make the separate profiles I'd created for the scale private. (For that you have to go into your Withings account, click "info" for the profile in question, and then click the "make independent" link in the bottom right. That will send an email to the other person and they can set up a password at that point.) Neither of these things is difficult to do once you know how. But the information should be easier to find--perhaps included as instructions that come with the device, as they're pretty basic things that most users will probably want to do.All that said, I'm really pleased with the Withings scale!-- Debra Hamel

Overall I'm very pleased with this straightener. Here are my thoughts after using it for a couple of weeks:-- The straightener works better on dry hair than wet hair. To straighten wet hair requires repeated strokes.-- The straightener is supposed to leave hair softer because of its soy-infused plates. I'm not sure whether my hair is softer or not, but it's true that the straightener doesn't dry out my hair.-- The straightener is intuitive to use.-- The product smells like burning plastic when it's heating up. It's possible that this will go away with time, however.-- The straightener heats up quickly, but not as quickly as its advertising suggests. (The time may depend on what setting it's set for.)-- The steam vents are supposed to direct the steam away from your head. These work most of the time but sometimes I find that it doesn't channel away from my head properly.

This device is a neat option for those of us who don't have up-to-date car stereo systems that connect via Bluetooth or audio jack to their phone or other music player. Just tune your car's FM radio to an empty, static-only frequency on the dial, tune the Tonor device to the same frequency, plug the Tonor into your phone (or iPod or whatever), and you're all set. The output from the phone will be played through your car radio. I found the audio to be clear and free of static.A couple of points to note:I found that it's important to turn the volume on your phone up all the way. This makes the transmission clear, and you can then control the volume through your car radio.The orientation of the Tonor device assumes that the audio jack of your phone is at the bottom left corner. If that's not the case for your phone, you'll have to hold your phone upside-down and/or backwards to read the Tonor's display, but that's no great hardship.If you're traveling a significant distance, you may find that as different radio stations come into range, you'll have to occasionally change the frequency the Tonor uses, since an empty frequency in one area may not stay empty as you drive.Full disclosure: I received a sample of this item in return for a review.

I find it kind of weird that, for decades, outlet testers have not taken the obvious step toward simplicity and clarity that this one takes. For all those years, outlet testers (such as this one, also from Sperry Instruments) have used a cryptic system of indicator lights -- a system that has to be translated. Off, off, red means "bad ground"; yellow, green, off means "open neutral," and so on. Granted the translation chart is printed right on the indicator (for all such indicators that I've seen), and doing the translation isn't exactly rocket science, but still, this cryptic system is an open invitation to make errors that are time-wasting at best and deadly dangerous at worst.Finally, with this outlet tester, the cryptic "secret decoder ring" is supplanted. A lit indicator light next to "bad ground" means "bad ground"; "open neutral" means "open neutral," and so on. No translation needed.Professional electricians may object to the added bulk of this device versus the older style of outlet tester, but this is great for homeowners to check whether their existing outlets have been wired correctly, and for do-it-yourself-ers to make sure they've done their work right.

These are a good fire starter. When lighting wood fires, they allow you to do without kindling, as they burn long and hot enough to light small split logs (up to around 4" x 3"). If you light a lot of fires and getting kindling isn't a problem, you may want to use a cheaper fire starter, such as Lightning Nuggets, which cost less than 1/4 as much. I haven't tried these with charcoal, but they ought to work fine for that as well.

When I received this rug I liked the rustic look of it and the soft feel underfoot. I was a little worried that it didn't have a non-slip coating on the underside, but that didn't give me any problems.As happens, eventually the rug needed washing. The care instructions said to dry the rug by laying it flat, but I saw in other reviews that this simply doesn't work, unless you've got a week or two to wait for your rug to dry. So I put it into the dryer. There were a few loose threads in the nap of the rug after washing and drying, but basically it seemed fine. Then a while later the rug needed washing again. (The rug is near our cats' litter box -- 'nuff said.) This time it came out of the washing machine with about 1/3 of the hem on one end unstitched, so the whole rug was starting to unravel.So it's two washes and then into the trash for this rug. Not exactly good value for the price.

I first set this camera up for use on my iPad. The setup procedure is long and complicated. Among other difficulties, it involves a couple of screens that are completely non-intuitive: one where there's no prompt telling you you have to tap a magnifying-glass icon before anything will happen, and another where there's nothing telling you that you have to click a Save icon to continue after you've entered some user data (a keyboard <return> does nothing). On my first attempt at installation, something or other went wrong after I'd gone through the whole process, and I had to stick a paperclip wire into the device's Reset hole to start over from scratch. (Note: If you open a technical support ticket on the TrendNet website, they don't email you when there's a response to your question; you're supposed to just log in periodically and check the ticket status.) My second attempt worked okay, and the device now works in conjunction with the TrendNet app on my iPad.I also tried installing the app on my old iPhone 4, which only supports iOS 7.x, and this was a bust. The app launches and starts to show the video, but then crashes after about 5 seconds.This installation and initial test were done with my iPad in Wi-Fi. To access the camera via 3G or 4G, the manual unhelpfully tells you to refer to instructions on the included CD-ROM. (Remember those?) These instructions are in the form of several videos, which for some reason kept dropping the audio on my fairly-up-to-date Mac. I switched to an online instruction video (requires a QR reader for your computer or typing in a very long URL), and the part of the instructions I needed was buried at 6:45 into the video. A plain old text file or PDF would have been a lot easier.So all in all, setting up this device was about as easy and user-friendly as hacking into an Iranian nuclear weapons lab. If and when you make it through the process, the camera seems to work fine, but the difficulty of getting there compels me to give the product a 2-star rating.

The compound leverage of these cutters provides a really impressive ratio of handle-motion to jaw-motion. To open the jaws to their maximum (about 1/2 inch), you have to spread the handles to almost 180 degrees. But although the jaws open to  about 1/2 inch, don't expect to cut anything tougher than copper or aluminum of that diameter. I managed to cut through a 1/4 inch diameter steel chain link, and that was definitely pushing the upper limits of what the tool (and my muscles) were capable of. I had to brace one handle of these cutters on my bench and lean my weight on the other handle.So the 18" model of these cutters won't be much use for cutting medium to heavy chain, or anything but really lightweight padlocks. They're a good size for easy cutting of chain link fencing and slightly larger jobs.

I thoroughly enjoyed this book. In it, Peter Biskind  examines a host of films from the fifties (and a few from surrounding years), putting them onto the sociological equivalent of an analyst's couch, so to speak. Through the aperture of these movies, all the conflicting social forces that were vying with one another in the U.S. during 1950s can be seen at work: Liberalism versus conservatism, individualism and personal freedom versus community and conformism, expanding opportunities for women versus reactionary antifeminist backlash, and lots more.For the most part Biskind presents a convincing case that  the movies he looks at stake out this or that position on this or that spectrum of conflicting social opinions and trends, but I'm certainly not saying that I agreed with all of his points. A thinking, critical reader is always unlikely to agree with everything they find in an opinion-packed, interpretation-packed book like this one. In particular, I was profoundly unconvinced by Biskind's argument that the 1954 giant-ant movie Them! carried an anti-feminist subtext. But disagreements like this were the exception rather than the rule for me, and in any case I always found his discussions and analyses to be interesting, engaging, and entertaining.As an example, here's a passage I particularly enjoyed from a section on the James Dean vehicle Rebel Without a Cause (1955): "With its trilogy of sick families, Rebel touches all the bases. Parents are criticized for being too strong and too weak, too authoritarian and too permissive, for being absent when the kids need them and smothering them with affection when they dont. If its bad to treat teen-agers like children, its also bad to treat them like adults. In Rebel, parents cant do anything right."Quite a bit of the book is devoted to examining gender roles --  how views about these roles were changing during the 50s, and how a range of movies portrayed and commented, either positively or negatively, on this change. The book's evisceration of the savagely anti-feminist Mildred Pierce (1945) was a particular delight for me in the text.So again, this is a deeply interesting, engaging, and entertaining book!

This toothbrush is a replacement for a previous, similar model from Sonicare that I purchased on advice from my dental hygienist about 8 years ago.  I loved my old Sonicare and my hygienist raves about how healthy my teeth and gums are at every yearly cleaning.  Of course, I dont know how much my great teeth and gums is the result of the Sonicare and how much is something else, but Im nevertheless devoted to my Sonicare.  The new Sonicare doesnt really add any features that my old one didnt have but after 8 years, although the old one was running fine, I felt it was time for a replacement.  So far this one seems to be just as good as my old one so Im very happy with it.  The true test will be at my next cleaning but Id be very surprised if this toothbrush doesnt perform just as well as the older model.

For starters, I'm more than a little dubious about the elaborate cleaning system that comes with this shaver. Why should a shaver need to be cleaned (with a dedicated device and a proprietary detergent solution, no less) every day? I submit that it doesn't, and therefor if you purchase this shaver a goodly portion of your money is paying for something that's of no value at all. Thankfully, instructions are included on how to clean the saver without the cleaning apparatus (soap & water, run the shaver, rinse).Moving on to the shaver itself, it seems pretty good. I'm used to using rotary-head shavers, and I'm not willing to say that this reciprocating-blade system is better or worse in terms of closeness or comfort; as near as I can tell it's the same. There is definitely a lot more vibration to the shaver than with a rotary-head device, and people coming from a rotary shaver may find that this takes some getting use to. Regarding comfort, the instructions include the notice that's common with all electric shavers, telling you that "your skin and beard need about 30 days to adjust to any new shaving method." I don't understand how this works, but it seems to be true, so don't leap to judgement if this razor causes you a little skin irritation over the first few weeks.One interesting feature is that the sideburn trimmer can be used together with a detachable, adjustable-height comb that can be used to trim a beard or mustache to a given length. Not having a beard or mustache, I couldn't try this out. For giving a nice straight edge to sideburns, the trimmer works very well; it's wide and cuts close to the skin.The shaver has a low-charge indicator warning you when it's time to recharge. I've seen other shavers that display a digital readout supposedly showing how many minutes of use are left before a recharge will be needed, but I know from experience that this display becomes meaningless as the battery ages. So I don't count the absence of this "feature" as a minus.

I did a head-to-head comparison of this product with Trader Joe's Virgin Organic Coconut Oil, which actually costs considerably more than this Island Fresh brand, and I thought the Island Fresh coconut oil came out ahead. The flavor and aroma seems more coconut-y, and the texture smoother, as the Trader Joe's was a little lumpy. The sweet, pleasant coconut aroma and smoother texture will be especially important for those who like to use coconut oil for massage and aromatherapy, and I found this oil excellent for cooking too.Full disclosure: I received a sample of this item in return for a review.

If there's a pattern to be found in the late period Roth Zuckerman novels, it's that they follow a general (and probably an intentional, since Roth is far from stupid) template.  Nathan Zuckerman stumbles upon a person who has been subjected to a something rather shocking (the act of homegrown terrorism in "American Pastoral", the outing of being a Communist in "I Married a Communist") and is generally dead by the time he starts to find out the real truth, forcing him to cobble together a biography of that person either through talking to siblings or his own memories or simply pure imagination.  Typically there's a woman involved and a great deal of unfairness being visited on someone and all of that is wrapped in an analysis of what the American Dream might mean at different parts of the twentieth century.  Generally misery seems to be the key takeaway, although small wonders sometimes abound.I wound up reading the trilogy slightly out of order but it worked out because in the order I read it comes across as Roth tweaking and perfecting that aforementioned template.  "I Married a Communist" was too busy taking potshots at people that he knew, or lecturing us about politics, to really bite down into its characters.  "American Pastoral" was heading in the right direction, adding a necessary dose of compassion and despite more talk about glove making than you'll ever probably experience outside borrowing a book from the library on how to make gloves it treated most of its characters less as plot points or metaphorical stand-ins and as people caught up in their lives and unable to get out of their own way or at the mercy of forces beyond their control, whether those forces were politics or the bonds that attach one family member to another.For the most part, this one gets pretty much everything right.Like most Roth novels, the beginning doesn't so much ease you in as challenge you to keep reading, as Zuckerman goes on about the Bill Clinton scandal that is happening around the time the novel is set (it comes up several times so Roth either means it as a contrast to what's going on (the likely answer) or it was really on his mind for some reason).  The general setup doesn't engender a whole lot of promise either, as esteemed senior citizen professor Coleman Silk, a fiery tell-it-like-it-is fellow like many Roth protagonists winds up getting himself forcibly retired when a comment he makes about two missing students is twisted beyond all intent into a racist invective and blows up out of his control.  His refusal to meekly step down and apologize for something he didn't makes him both outcast and pariah.  His wife eventually dies due to causes related to the stress and when Zuckerman finds him he's ranting like a crazy man, as unyielding as a brick wall and about as easy to have a conversation with.  He wants Zuckerman to write a book about the experience, and while for a moment it seems like the book is going to turn into a treatise on the evils of political correctness, it turns out that isn't the most interesting story here.Given the levels of irony hinted at, it shouldn't take you too long to figure out what the interesting twist to Silk's life here is, and despite the potential for that twist to be used as a cheap and tawdry base for a more exploitative type of novel, it really starts to take off once Roth starts to weave in the issue of race and the history of how this country handles race (spoiler alert, in case you don't follow the news: poorly) Silk starts to become less a man ranting at us about how all his colleagues killed his wife by being spineless and how students these days are all entitled dummies afraid of being offended than the story of how one man decided to tackle the issue of race by playing the only game there was to play, and that was being someone else.  For once we've given a realistic look at the stakes at play and everyone comes across as both disappointed and disappointing, no one is able to get entirely what they want so the best they can do is come close.  But everyone has different reasons why those choices are bad ideas, some are practical, some are principle and sometimes the cost from a certain perspective is just too high.  Roth doesn't shy away from that, painting Silk as the kind of person who is forced to make the decisions he wants partially because of how he expects to be treated but partially because of what he wants for himself, his insistence to not be part of any group that would have him as a member, even if it means alienating his family, even if it means lying for the rest of his life.To that end Roth surrounds him, not just with an unusually eloquent Zuckerman (he seems affected quite deeply by his meeting with Silk and the events of the novel in general, sticking around not just for curiosity but a genuine desire to see the story through) but a round of characters that actually feel like people, starting with the women.  For once, Faunia Farley doesn't generate complete eye rolling beyond her initial appearance, when Silk takes up with the rather uneducated apparently illiterate campus worker, but Roth's portrayal of her is actually rather sensitive as the novel takes pains to point out that uneducated doesn't always mean stupid,  The relationship between her and Silk never falls completely into the vein of "let's make a didactic point kids!" and instead operates more like two adults who are enjoying having a sexual relationship.  Even Silk's nemesis Delphine Roux, the feminist professor he helps hire but now sees him as dead wood, could have been little more than a dress or pair of ladies' slacks covering a skeleton made entirely up on screeds (or worse, Roth's way at getting back at someone he knows) but in a few of her more involved scenes comes across as a person trying to do what she thinks is right because it's right even as she can't separate the personal history at play.  As others have mentioned, the only weak spot is Farley's Vietnam Vet husband, all PTSD and jealousy issues, existing mostly to ensure the plot does certain things that Roth needs it to do (even so, his last scene seems to convey the pain and loneliness of being trapped inside your own head with a war that hasn't quite ended yet).It all adds up to a more intense experience than you normally get from a Roth novel, which generally suffer from a bit of clinical detachment, and there's a fair number of scenes that showcase both Roth's eye for memorable interactions and his ability to make it count from an emotional standpoint (a slow dance between Silk and Zuckerman early on is probably the most notable).  Via Zuckerman, who for once isn't making it about him, it comes across as angry and despairing, infused with an grasping sense of loss and the people who are left behind to deal with it.  For once, instead of smacking us with an arch sense of a need to tell us about stuff that we'd never known was important to us, it feels weary and lived in, people fully wrestling with the weight of decisions made not just a long time ago but constantly and ongoing, decisions that can't be easily divided into good and bad but defined by the question: what will it take to stay alive?  In a century where people were hemmed into alleys that could only lead to one place at the end of which was a grinder stained with the hopes and dreams of everyone who came before you.  In the wake of it, all you can do is decide how to stick around for the next day, whatever it takes, and if some good comes out of that by some miracle, you can always claim later it was all meant to be part of the plan.

This one often gets the "Roth's best novel" tag (he has a few that vie for the honor, though I don't think anyone has ever come near anything resembling a consensus) since it's about America, especially 1960s and beyond America (when it all got real), and it won the Pulitzer Prize, among other prizes, which generally means that a lot of people who read important books thought it was pretty good as well.  Out of all his Zuckerman novels, it's one of the few I can read without cringing at some point over some ridiculous plot point or characterization, and it's definitely one of the few I can read without being aware of the scaffolding involved in making it as meta-construction of a story (despite it actually being so).  It's shocking in a way that seems realistic and when people react to events they tend to react like real people and not people acting out complicated literary metaphors meant as a commentary on society today (even if they really are).  In a lot of ways the elements here are all elements that we're seen in his other novels, maybe put together a little differently or given a new spin with age and experience, but he's not really going over fresh ground here except maybe from an altered angle.What seems to make this one different for me is the sense of compassion.Most Roth novels that I've read so far seem to have a kind of contempt for the main character in some respect, not only acknowledging that he's not perfect but seeming to take delight in his flaws and how he hangs himself with his own rope regardless of how right or wrong he might be.  It can make for a blistering reading experience because when the author doesn't feel any kind of sympathy for his character he can take the character that might not be as possible if he felt even just a little bit bad at making what could be an otherwise normal person appear as a raging genius idiot.  It's a sense that comes through often in his narratives, especially in the later period novels when events may or may not have been drawn more from personal experience.Yet, here the feel is different, though not at first.  We get Nathan Zuckerman again running into a story that could be told only to him while attending his high school reunion and reminiscing about an old classmate who was beloved and seemed like the most perfect person in the world: Swede Levov, an amazing athlete who eventually took over his father's world famous glove manufacturing operation.  The memory of an encounter several years before with Swede leads to questions at the reunion, most of which are answered by the Swede's brother.  The answers to those questions involve learning what terrible things happened to the Swede, mostly caused by his daughter doing something rather unfortunate, and Zuckerman decides to do his best to figure out where it all went wrong.A lot of this has the skeleton of books like "I Married a Communist" where an absent protagonist only appears in flashbacks and is described at great length by his brother as a real standup guy who is unfortunately unable to deal with the cruelties of life and thus ill-prepared is beaten down by them.  But Roth takes a slightly different tactic here, instead letting Zuckerman's imaginings of what happened exactly to the Swede serve as the real narrative, making us wonder how much of this is based in fictional fact and how much of this is Zuckerman interpreting this through his own filter.What it leads to is perhaps the best evocation of the fifties sliding into the mess that was the sixties as witnessed by someone doing their best to stay the heck out of the sixties.  People looking at it as a critique on the counterculture and the anti-war movement are probably barking up the wrong tree.  As brutal (and brutally funny sometimes) as the conversations between the Swede and his very trying daughter Merry are, Merry is ultimately a very one-note character, existing purely to move the plot along with some shock value or subject us to a barrage of anti-war protests taken to a ridiculous extreme.  Where the book succeeds best is spelled out in the beginning scenes with Zuckerman remembering his old high school and the times that he grew up in, where the book attempts a hard look at nostalgia, not just in general but a very specific kind and for a very specific era of the country.  It harkens back to a time that felt different from everything that came after it, and the grasping need to recreate that time in both form and memory, and in some respect delineate the surprise that occurs when people look around thirty years later and realize things have changed, only to wonder "how did this all happen."  And it's a form of nostalgia, not just for a childhood, but for the feel of a time and place that can never return, when the decades of American history felt like actual decades that could be separated out in look and feel.  Nowadays it becomes more difficult to tell the decades apart, especially as we move further into the twenty-first century, and most of our nostalgia centers around technology ("Look how big phones were!" despite cell phones today being bigger than my cell phone was in the nineties) or television shows/movies (which is fine, too, because everyone keeps remaking them for us).  Here there's a longing for an attitude and a texture that no longer exists, and maybe never did, but once departed can never quite be returned.We get that in the Swede, in his grasping for what he calls the "american pastoral", the steady successful job, the nice house, being surrounded by family.  And Roth seems to criticize it in suggesting that the only way the Swede can achieve all of it is by letting himself passively fall through the decades (which is how he ultimately loses control) but at the same time evoking a sense of sympathy for him.  The Swede isn't a bad person in what he wants, what makes him ultimately a failure is a failure to understand what's happening around him and how to react to it.  Instead of moving with the times and adjusting himself to it, he tries to plant his foot firmly in place, to let his vision narrow until the only thing he can see are the gloves that he has his workers so painstakingly make day in and day out, not even noticing the events flaring up all around until he has no choice.  He desperately attempts to cling to what he finds important and even while other characters might find him pathetic, there's a certain nobility to it as well, which is a rare feeling in a Roth novel, a nobility in the attempt and a nobility in how he fails to recognize how doomed to failure he is.  But he always comes across as honest in his intentions, and there's a touching persistence in how he tries to hold it all together, not because he wants to maintain some kind of delusion, but because he honestly things that what he holds dear is the pinnacle of life, even if he can't go far enough to restore what he loses.In that sense, it's telling that as the novel proceeds the relationship between the Swede and his daughter becomes less important as the gradual stripping away of all the things he used to find important, leaving him with the realization that perhaps he doesn't understand people at all, and that holding things close only leaves you clinging to the tatters as the years make short work of it all.  Some people don't seem thrilled that the novel doesn't really have a resolution of sorts, but it only ends because it has to end somewhere (and since we've already had a death, it's technically ending even before it starts).  We don't go back to Zuckerman, and for once Roth doesn't let his favorite narrator get the last word, except maybe in an oblique sense.  Instead we get the adage of "life isn't fair", both as question and statement, asking us perhaps if as shallow and terrible people we deserve what we get, and then saying that even if we weren't awful people this would happen to us anyway because life doesn't care.  The bleakness of that optimism strikes me as typical Roth, both begging and railing, but gives this one a different feel is that instead of coldly looking downward on his characters and their sufferings (much of which are due to their own actions), just for once there's a sliver of a sense that despite the downfall of the Swede, Roth doesn't quite believe he deserved it a hundred percent.  And it's that tiny fraction of light that's the difference between remembering how the days used to be, with warmth and acknowledgment of that impassable distance between, and standing in a museum of days gone by, convinced that you never left because you're unable to tell the difference.

There's a song from the Beautiful South called "Song for Whoever" where the singer discusses how the women he dates wind up giving him material for his hit songs (prefiguring a certain country-pop crossover superstar, I suppose), eventually reporting with no small amount of glee that "the number one I hope to reap depends upon the tears you weep so cry, lover, cry . . ."  It's an interesting, if humorous, dissection of how we mine our lives for tragedy and use those moments to craft other moments that people can relate to.  And if in that process we move lots of units, then hey, it'd sure be a shame to let that money go to waste.If Philip Roth wasn't such a extraordinarily good writer of prose, I'd be more suspicious of the games he seems to like to play with the reader, dangling bits of what could be elements taken from his personal life, often given a salacious spin, and seeming to suggest with a wink that he could be discussing himself in a thinly veiled fashion but maybe it's all made up or maybe it's satire or maybe you're just reading too much into it you gossip seeking reprobate.  He seems to like dancing on that very treacherous intersection between reality and fictional and analyzing not only the places where they overlap but our reactions to the overlap and how it colors our perception of the work (and by extension, the author).This one is a bit stickier to dissect.  Most of the time I try to stay away from the broader context of novels until after I read them, that way details which may not be completely relevant to reading the novel get mixed in with my first impressions.  But it's hard to avoid the wider context in this case.  Some time before this novel was published Roth's ex-wife Claire Bloom published a memoir which detailed, among other things, what it was like to live with one of the most famous writers in America at the time.  And the answer, alas, was "not much fun" as she apparently laid bare a whole host of pettiness and foibles that seemed to eventually wreck their marriage and depict Roth as less than a stellar human being.  One can't imagine any person, even one with a thick skin and used to personal attacks, justified or otherwise, taking such an act very well.  Thus, depending on how you want to read the novel, this may be a somewhat veiled rebuttal, part "You didn't get the whole story" and part Marvin Gaye's "Here, My Dear" as the character Eve Frame shares more than a few similarities with his ex-wife, especially in Roth's interpretation of her relationship with her adult daughter from a previous relationship.  They don't jump at your in an obvious fashion except that the narrator's criticisms of them are so specific and unrelenting and sometimes mean-spirited that you start to get an uneasy feeling, like a joke that's gone further than it intended and is trending toward the offensive.To his credit, though, Roth doesn't craft an entire novel around a polemic about his ex-wife, choosing to set the novel as a weird sort of nested series of flashback.  Roth standby Nathan Zuckerman runs into his extremely old former teacher Murray Ringold and as the two of them start reminiscing, Murray recounts the story of his brother Ira, who was a famous performer before the Communist hunts took over America and ruined his life, especially after his wife published a book about he was nothing but a redder than red Commie.  Thus the book consists of Murray's detailed narrations, interspersed with Zuckerman's own recollections of when he met Ira as a youngster, so that the plot basically boils down to two people telling parallel stories to fill in their own blanks.  It's interesting but the constant reminder that everything is a flashback makes the whole affair feel rather flat at times.  Because it's all happened already there's really nothing at stake and so you're reading basically to find out all the dirty details which will mostly be revealed in time.In this case it has to come down to the characters and their ideas.  And in this instance Roth sort of falls short.  He depicts the time quite nicely, evoking a sense of what America was like in the 1950s when people started to see Communists under nearly every rock, and what it was like to be a Communist in those days (apparently it was like being married to Roth, not a whole lot of fun).  We watch the rise and fall of Ira as he's shaped by the twin collections of his brother and Zuckerman and while the narrative doesn't shy away from his imperfections, there's also a bit of a saintly demeanor to him, a noble soul that is suffering unnecessarily and while I don't to draw parallels between Roth's desire to perhaps reclaim his dignity and this novel, it does feel a little self-serving in parts.  Even worse is the depiction of Eve Frame and her daughter, neither of whom come across as nice people (except for one scene when Zuckerman interacts with her daughter) instead seeming petty, vain and needy, especially when compared to the long-suffering Ira, who only wants to help the workers of the world.All of this would be okay if the book didn't subject you to the characters giving long political rants detailing their beliefs, especially the Ringold brothers, both of whom are ardent socialists and spend pages and pages at a stretch going over the same points again and again, ranting about America and Eisenhower and Nixon and the unions and the working class.  Perhaps it's meant to be a satire of how the extreme left-wing took themselves just a bit too seriously (there's several scenes of people being visibly annoyed as Ira goes off on yet another speech about the working class to anyone who will listen, willingly or otherwise) but it means you have giant blocks of text engaged in one sided political discourse and while I'm not completely unsympathetic, I've already read Ayn Rand novels so I think I've more than served my fair share of time weathering dialogue being used as a blunt hammer.It all makes for an interesting experience but not an especially memorable one except maybe in how weirdly personal it all seems.  The lack of any kind of narrative tension deflates any momentum and while I like seeing hypocrites being punctured as much as the next person, the people involved are such caricatures that you only get the kind of satisfaction that you probably would feel if you had written the whole thing yourself.  As an evocation of the times it's probably a better candidate than "Happy Days" was but unlike the show the book never learned the lesson that people are more inclined to listen to you if you loosen up and have a sense of humor once in a while.  The one moment the personal and the political come together is, sadly, the end sequence, where Roth's prose takes on an effortless grace that is sublime to watch (and most writers would kill for) and only makes you wish the rest of the book had that kind of elegiac delicacy.  I give Roth credit for allegedly managing to blow off some steam and get paid for it in the process but he would have been better off if he had just separated the plot of Ira Ringold into a separate novel and written an essay called "Everything My Ex-Wife Says is Wrong".

Ooh, this one is . . . uncomfortable.  Roth has teasingly drawn from his life before, and or at least seems to be in a constant game with the reader daring them to figure out how much of what he is writing is autobiographical and how much is simply an informed and exaggerated variation (a game that can admittedly get tiring after a while for people who want to read a story and not pay the author to subject us to a detailed psychological examination of his flaws, or lack thereof) but this one gets fairly intense when you realize that several of the events in the book mirror things that happened to him during his first marriage.  I'm not sure if that classifies the novel as a exorcism of sorts, or a bizarre form of revenge therapy or just a cold-hearted "boy this will sure move numbers" attitude but it does, like it or not, cast a different shade on the work, which has a different feel than most of his other novels in that vein.  Not personal but more . . . to the bone?  Like when you're kidding around with friends and then somehow crosses a line that nobody really knew existed and then suddenly the joking around gets deadly serious.  It feels like that.But not at first.  At first it feels like one of Roth's innumerable games where Nathan Zuckerman stands in for whatever aspect of his life he's cleverly attempting to convince us he's fictionalizing.  Only he takes it one step further this time, giving us two stories about Zuckerman but written by another author, Peter Tarnopol.  The two Zuckerman stories are variations on a theme, where poor Zuckerman gets trapped into two different relationships, the second of which seems to be at the hands of an honestly crazy person.  That's the first section "Useful Fictions" and when that gives way, we move into "My True Story" which is supposed to be Tarnopol telling us the story of his disastrous marriage and even more disastrous separation (and failure to divorce) his wife Maureen.Tarnopol is basically another version of Roth's first person narrators, in the vein of Alexander Portnoy (or Zuckerman himself), erudite, a sometimes adversarial relationship with his family, and very complicated relationships with women, most of whom seem like absolutely nutty people in the eyes of said narrator.  Jumping back and forth in time, Tarnopol relays to us both how he meets Maureen and gets tricked into marrying her (apparently similar to how Roth married his first wife) and the women he meets subsequent to leaving her even as she refuses to divorce him, much of which causes Tarnopol no end of stress.  A lot of the novel, much like "Portnoy's Complaint" is given to us from the psychiatrist's couch, although unlike that novel the doctor is allowed to get a word in edgewise.  It covers much of the same ground, infidelity, relationships, the intertwining of the artist and his life, and a lot of it comes across as so ridiculous at times that it could almost be funny.Except . . . it's not.  Maybe Roth has dug so far down here that the only thing coming up is the thickest of black crude but as a whole the novel feels far more savage than his other works.  Most of this comes from the utterly toxic relationship between Peter and Maureen, who have passed from nitro and glycerin to something new and far more dangerous.  Maureen seems to be actively psychotic (an early scene where she tearfully lambastes Tarnopol for answering a question about how his editor is with the editor at his publisher instead of her tells you a lot of what you're in for), spending most of the time saying crazy things or lying or manipulating, acting like a time bomb that keeps resetting itself every time it goes off.  It's harrowing watching the two of them go at it, even more so as the marriage winds towards its inevitable end and matters get ramped up to a degree that is actively unsettling.  It's riveting but with both characters fairly unpleasant it's probably a fair question to ask why we need to subject ourselves to it.And it is a valid question.  Stripped of the voyeuristic aspect of wondering just how much of this was reflected in Roth's own life, you're left with a narrator who is a hysterical coward, getting pushed into situations that no rational person would see themselves getting into and then twisting himself into psychological knots attempting to justify both his reasons for staying and going.  To Roth's credit, all of the other characters seem more than capable of calling Tarnopol out on his crap, but it's cringeworthy watching him make one bad decision after another even as people warn him of the consequences of his bad decisions.  The fact that Maureen is an unrelenting lunatic gives you an upclose look at what it's like to live with an actual madwoman but it also slants the book so much that it's hard to feel any sympathy for Tarnopol to any degree beyond basic human decency about not wanting to see a guy get screwed constantly.  She's so terrifying that you want to feel bad but when he ignores good advice to stay with her anyway after a while you stop being sorry for him and wonder who's going to bleed first (it's sort of a tie).Saying the book is narratively biased is probably putting it mildly.  To that end that book feels less like a story than a nightmare Roth is trying to wake himself up from.  With most of the women stripped of their nuances (lover Susan is inactive to the point of being a paperweight, passive beyond sanity and another damaged case, although one can suppose she's in good company) and Tarnopol surrounded by people smarter than he is despite his inability to recognize that, you wind up marveling more at the car wreck aspects of it than any kind of emotional investment in the story itself.  It's brutal and uncomfortable to read, though probably not half as much as it was to experience it in real life, but the more you find out how much of it was based in reality (I didn't know until after I read the book), the more you start to wonder if this is another example of Roth playing a clever game to blur the line between life and art and fiction, or just a way for him to present the evidence and say, "Look, see, none of this was my fault . . . what else could I do, she was crazy!"  Drawing from all aspects of the real world is an admirable trait of any writer but here at points it feels more like Roth had decided what he wanted to do, and then wrote a book to try and justify it.

I'm a fan of baseball basically due to marriage, as my spouse is a near lifelong fan of the local pinstriped team and as such my shelf of "stories about baseball" consists of Michael Bishop's "Brittle Innings" and, er, this one (I do have the "The Natural" around somewhere and that odd Robert Coover novel, which I'm not sure is really "about" baseball, per se).  I find all the various number crunching aspects of the game fascinating in an academic sort of way and while I haven't been able to sit through an entire nine innings yet, if they somehow compressed the game to a nicely succinct five innings or so, it would be just about perfect (though thanks to the magic of extra innings, it's theoretically possible to play a game that just never ends, which can be a version of heaven or hell depending on your perspective).With that said, Philip Roth would be among the last people I would expect to write an entire satirical novel about the sport of baseball, and make it actually entertaining.  Out of all his books I've read so far, this one feels by far the most relaxed, the one where he really lets his hair down and just has fun with the concept to see how goofy and ridiculous he can make it.  While he's written novels that are funny, most of the fun and games seem to exist in service to a larger point he's trying to make, or wrapped in so many layers of symbolic irony that you don't even lose sight of the fact that Important Things Are Being Said.  Here, he writes scenes where midgets try to kill each other on a baseball diamond and you can almost hear him giggling to himself as the scene plays out.The novel is structured as the story of the third American baseball league, the Patriot League, which according to the narrator was wiped from existence and history by the US after it was revealed that Communists were behind the whole thing.  The narrator is sportswriter Word "Smitty" Smith and if you can power past the first fifty pages or so of the novel where Smitty basically engages in a degree of alliteration that would characterize a very specific form of Tourettes the rest is fairly smooth sailing.  And by "smooth sailing" I mean absolutely absurd.  What Roth does here is take pretty much every cliche that had been seen to date in baseball stories and films and blow them up to the point where they seem like living cartoons.  He gives us players that go beyond athletic into god-like, and a rivalry between a pitcher and an umpire that runs the risks of turning into a hysterically brutal "Tom and Jerry" short.  He takes every situation and puffs it up to the breaking point of insane, and then plays it all perfectly straight so that even the people on the outside are staring at the mess going, "What the heck?"Breaking the novel up into digestible sections, with each one telling its own story even as it incrementally furthers the main plot in some fashion, gives the book the feeling of linked short stories and probably works better than if he had tried to tell the whole thing straight through (the sections are generally just long enough not to overstay their welcome).  The plot, such as it is, takes off when he focuses on the Ruppert Mundys, the only team that has permanent away team status due to their field being commandeered by the US military during World War Two.  He gives us a band of motley players that consists of teenagers and drunkards and dwarves and the handicapped, all of which seem to be drawn from real life (better baseball historian than I can probably have a grand time playing "spot the reference") and exaggerated so that it all fits in with the weirdly circus like atmosphere.  Bizarre event stacks up on bizarre event and if you're the kind of person who would marvel at the number of strange configurations between these people that Roth pulls out of his rear over and over again, this book will seem like one of those neverending games played on a summer night just as the sun goes down, oddly magical and charming.  However, it's also quite possible that none of this will seem realistic at all and you'll heave the book away in frustration, wanting an actual human character to at some point appear.Still, he gives his characters some semblance of dignity.  The quiet calm of midget Bob Yamm (hired as a pinch hitter because being so small, his strike zone is almost impossible to hit and thus he's almost automatically walked every time) contrasted with the sheer anger of his other midget rival feels like an island of realism in the midst of all the insanity, much like the frustration of Roland Agni, the best player on the worst team trying to get traded to a team that might actually win a game and being told repeatedly that he has to stay put for the good of the nation.  The sense of real people trapped in a warped funhouse and forced to play with people who are revel in the craziness works better than it has any right to and its almost a shame that Roth has to nod toward an actual plot eventually, bringing in the aforementioned Communists (and Jews, just for good measure) and a vast conspiracy to undermine the American Way via our most patriotic of sports.If he can't quite bring it home, I don't think he ever really seriously intended to.  While the satire looms large (calling a novel about baseball "The Great American Novel" is sarcastic in itself) in both our mythologizing of the sport and its players, as well as the inflated concerns of the American people that circa the 40s and 50s that there were Communists lurking under every rock and tree (here turning out to be hilariously true), it feels like Roth includes those concerns because he has to and his real reason for writing this was just to have an excuse to screw around with a sport he has some fondness for and see how wacky he can be (the answer: pretty darn wacky).  As such there's really no other Roth novel like it (it seems to be sort of a hidden gem in his catalog, not really discussed with high praise or low scorn) and a nice look at what happens when a Famous and Important Author decides to cut loose.

If you ever wanted to imagine "50 Shades of Grey" but from a Jewish perspective, this may be the closest you'll ever come.  Like that hit that has redefined the taste of the masses as "much worse than we originally suspected", it features a sexually explicit storyline featuring a person with substantial control freak tendencies, mundane taste in women and a really exotic taste for meat in ways that the butcher never anticipated.  Unlike that future classic, however, it's funny where it's actually meant to be.  It's the novel where Philip Roth basically makes his transformation into PHILIP ROTH, literary superstar, the fellow we know and love and are sometimes frustrated by, and the sheer notoriety of the novel would follow him for years until even he had to make fun of it via sort of stand-in Nathan Zuckerman and his delightful literary book about doing it, "Carnovsky".  Questions of "how much of this did he make up" would dog him for years, as if people couldn't comprehend that a guy whose job it is to make up things for a living wouldn't be able to figure out that certain things are universally funny, and are even funnier when you add a slab of liver to it.This is the kind of novel you're either going to be thoroughly engrossed and amused by, or are going to find it meanderingly obsessive and with so many personal details that even a reality TV star would be like "Whoa, pal, TMI."  It basically concerns one thing, and one thing only, and that is Alexander Portnoy, and his constant quest for sexual gratification, one that seems to touch every single aspect of his life, from his relationship with his family to women to Israel and the Jewish experience in America, one that seeks to touch it all over the place, touch it gently and touch it hard, sometimes even touching itself in the process.  It's told as one long stream of consciousness rant, ostensibly Portnoy telling all his worries to an extremely patient psychiatrist, who probably never thought that a simple question of "Tell me what's troubling you" would lead to a breaking dam of woes, spilling out one after the other and hardly in a linear fashion.  Portnoy details his life, growing up with his pleasant but overbearing parents, discovering that his sexual flowering is more like an algae bloom, sudden, rapid and before you know it, all over the place.  He tells us about the various girls he meets in the process as he wanders about searching for love and satisfaction, not necessarily in that order.Most of the subject matter here will seem familiar to anyone who has read even a little bit of Roth in his prime, especially if you're like me and bouncing around his career at random.  For the most part a lot of the things that become tropes in later novels start out there, so the shock of the new that greeted readers on its publications may not quite be there.  Still, there's a hilarious focus to this that the other novels seem to lack and the very thing that may turn off some readers (namely, Portnoy's constant complaining) is what gives the novel the edge.  Stripped of the winking smirks toward portions of his life and the almost reflexive need to go meta exactly when the book doesn't need it, this book comes across as exactly what it should be, one guy adrift in a sea of troubles of his own creation and not completely understanding how that happened, even as the recollections of bizarre events pile on top of each other like madly breeding pancakes.  Even with the familiarity of some of its concept, a lot of it comes off as new and fresh because of the sheer singlemindedness of the affair.And it helps that it's funny.  Roth would rarely be this funny again and a large part of that is how well he captures Portnoy's speaking voice as he monologues seemingly in one long sentence, this great rush of words that only gets more and more hilarious as you imagine him getting increasingly hysterical as recounting his life story only winds him up further, until you can almost hear the veins popping out of his neck as he strains to convey the sheer tortures that follow him around every day.  He pleads, he cajoles, he rails and rants and pities himself to such an absurd degree that it goes past narcissism into something far greater, like he becomes nothing but pure ego.  And when sex really enters the picture the book takes off completely into another stratosphere, featuring prose explicit enough to make a dominatrix blush, especially when his sexuality blossoms and he discovers the manly joys of self-gratification, proceeding to reenact the song "Orgasm Addict" to an insane degree, his narrative voice nearly rising to a screech as he attempts to express just how far he's willing to go, even to the realm that is nowadays probably relegated to weird fetish sites in dark corners of the Internet.The prose (and by definition, Portnoy's voice) is more than strong enough to carry it and it helps that Roth hardly pauses for breath when he gets going, allowing our narrator room to argue with himself, adore himself, berate himself, all the while presumably while his poor psychologist sits there and wonders if he should be doing something professional to stop this.  But he's as amused as the rest of us are.  Portnoy seems to possess some self-awareness of how obsessed he is but is unable to stop himself to any sane degree and given a captive audience, he spills everything in the same way he spills his seed, holding nothing back and not really caring what it stains in the process.  A novel for both the literary sophisticated thirty-five year old in me and the thirteen year old in me, he proves that James Joyce didn't steal all the good dirty jokes.  A lot of what transpires here will crop up again (and again and again) in other Roth novels in various configurations but this is where it all starts and probably the only time you'll ever see all the components assembled at once in an unstoppable force.  It's a kind of synergy that's hard to replicate, the kind that comes with a "here goes nothing" attitude and while he would go on to write novels that were considered better or more important, he never would write anything quite like that this.  But the genius of it, of course, is that you only need to do it once.

Having depicted your characters attempting to live day by day during the most involved conflict that the world thus far had ever known, where do you go from there?  Well, if you're Anthony Powell, apparently you veer headfirst into domestic drama against the setting of a post-war backdrop.  People get married who shouldn't get married, people cheat on their spouses, explore their sexual identities, hang out in fancy places.  And talk about books a lot, pretentiously if at all.  It feels like I'm among friends.To that end the last three novels in the, ah, twelvetet (?) are sometimes considered a bit of a letdown when compared to the first nine that comprise the beginning sequences.  The characters have become older and a bit more set in their ways and to some extent it feels like Powell is struggling to find interesting things for them to do that are within the realm of possibility (it's not like Widmerpool can become prime minister, as amazing as that would be).  The newer characters that are introduced are generally interesting but he doesn't seem to have as much of a handle on them as he did the original set and even that precise control slackens by the very end, where the plot dictates as much how people should act instead of letting their personalities guide us to the end.Part of the problem is that coming off the peak of World War Two, pretty much almost anything can feel like an encore, or at least an epilogue (mirroring no doubt how some soldiers felt returning home, after being a part of saving civilization as we know it, sitting at the table to the same pot roast every night for the rest of your life probably felt initially like an anticlimax of sorts . . . although not getting shot at constantly may be a fair trade-off) and coming back to your old life can feel a bit boring in comparison.  Having taken us through the boom years before the war and the war itself, he's got us in the much more austere 1950s, where conformity still has a stranglehold on culture and all the attempts to let loose and be free come across as very odd to all the old guys.  This is still rich fodder for a single novel, unfortunately trying to stretch that theme across three separate novels winds up pushing it and they suffer from a combination of spinning their wheels and a gradual sense of "who cares?"Powell's prose and eye for characters hasn't quite lost a step, it's just that the subject matter doesn't quite live up to what's gone before.  In all honesty, the tone isn't that far off from the pre-war novels but there we had the shock of the new, getting to know these people, while here it's more a settling of accounts as people inevitably drop off for the great multi-part series in the sky, in a much more sedate setting.  When things get wild here, it feels more artificial, like he's trying to insert drama where it doesn't quite belong.As I said, the settings don't inspire much optimism.  The main plot of "Books Do Furnish a Room" centers around the attempts at publishing a literary magazine called "Fission", which Jenkins gets involved in with some other characters.  The hijinks as all the personalities collide isn't quite as exciting as all the dinner party escapades from earlier novels, and by the fortieth time Jenkins mentions Robert Burton you want to reach into the book and slap him.  He manages to get one decent character out of oddball writer Trapnel, who should come across as a collection of tics masquerading as a human being but manages to turn into an actual conflicted artist.  The main problem here is the focus on Pamela Widmerpool as someone we should care about.  She gets way too much time in this book, not only hamstringing the latent awesomeness that is Widmerpool (who becomes a member of Parliament here, of course) but dragging the book into soap opera territory by becoming a character straight out of "Dynasty".  Granted, she's supposed to be hot but she's so unrelentingly mean to every single person in striking distance not only does her marriage make little sense but you wonder why anyone even bothers with her.  She's just angry for no reason all the time and while she's certainly distinctive, it becomes rather tedious after a while watching people attempting to be polite to her before she snarls in their direction.  It does become hilarious how none of this fazes Jenkins, however.The drama ramps up toward the end, with Widmerpool and Trapnel and Pamela all circling each other, leading to some interesting setpieces but everything prior to that is drenched in Powell's silky smooth prose, it goes down nice and easy but leaves very little aftertaste to remember.By the time you get to "Temporary Kings" you can almost hear the steam coming out of Powell's ears as he endeavors to make any of this simmer above even a low boil.  Moving the action to Proust's narrator's favorite place, Venice, isn't exactly the "what do ordinary blokes do in that time period" feel we're hoping for, as Jenkins attends a literary convention that somehow manages to encompass almost every single person he's ever met that's still alive by this point.  More soap opera elements are introduced (spying! murder! infidelity! sometimes all at the same time!) but there are times when it feels like he's throwing things against the wall to see what sticks.  Very little does.  Again, some of the new characters find room to distinguish themselves from all the other genteel men we've encountered before but even when events start to pick up here comes Pamela Widmerpool again to do something cray-cray even as another male foolishly throws himself at her despite the fact that even if she were twice as nice as the book portrays her she'd still be an utterly miserable person.  Her caustic presence basically neuters whatever benefit you might get from Widmerpool and whatever plot seems to be involving him doesn't seem to go much of anywhere at all.  Once again, things pick up toward the end, especially with a surprise appearance by local weird witch psychic person Mrs Erdleigh, who I always imagine as one of those strange ladies from "A Wrinkle in Time", but it's kind of too little too late and most of the juicy stuff is recounted to Jenkins by other people after the fact.  It does get bonus points for being set in a foreign city I've actually visited, however.By the time we reach the supposed finale of the last volume, "Hearing Secret Harmonies", it's more of a grand finally.  While the subtraction of Pamela Widmerpool should only improve matters, Powell decides to go completely off the rails here and have a countercultural cult figure heavily into the plot.
